PUB-DATE: November 1, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 4699 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Art Fairs

"AFFORDABLE ART FAIR NEW YORK," Pier 92, 12th Avenue, at 50th Street, through Sunday. While granting that one person's affordable art is another's waste of money, this fledgling London art fair, which is making its first New York appearance, could be fun, especially for the young, novice collector of contemporary art. Nothing in its costs more than $5,000. Scheduled events include lectures about buying, maintaining and even making art -- and there is not a blue chip gallery in sight. But there are 20 serious New York galleries among the 80 participants from North America and Britain. The remaining names will be less familiar to denizens of New York art galleries, which means that this particular fair will be even more of a collision of different art worlds than usual. Hours: Today and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 65+; children under 6, free. Information: 1-800-594-8499 or www.affordableartfair.com (Roberta Smith).

Museums

"AN AMERICAN LEGACY, A GIFT TO NEW YORK," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Jan. 26). The Whitney trustees pooled their pennies, acquired $200 million worth of postwar American art and gave it all to the museum as a gift. The 87 works, dating from the 1940's through the 1990's, enhance and subtly reshape the museum's account of American modernism. And they are all temporarily on view in this showcase, which ranges from classic Abstract Expressionist painting (Kline, Pollock, Still) to early Pop (pre-silkscreen Warhol), with lots and lots of Jasper Johns. Most of of the choices are predictably canonical; the show perks up with odd-duck contributions by Jay DeFeo and Lucas Samaras. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

* "RICHARD AVEDON: PORTRAITS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 5). Just eight years after the last Richard Avedon show, here's a survey of portraits. The fashion analogy is obvious: the repackaged product, a clever campaign to market the same old goods. But the show is gorgeous: a pitch-perfect mix of modest-size, big and unbelievably big prints, each an exquisitely made object. Whatever else the works might be, they are unforgettable. Celebrity only partly accounts for their status. Mr. Avedon brings other factors to bear: a sense of spectacle, clinical precision, energy, movement even in static head shots (the figures often seem so tense they look ready to jump out of the pictures) and an irrepressible attraction to power. His career dovetails with the era of the paparazzi, the tell-all media and the obligatory scandals and secret sufferings of the rich and fashionable. You might say he raised this cultural fixation to a neurotic art. The trade-off with him is always between style and substance. It's the conflict of our culture. No wonder his pictures are so embedded in our imagination. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* JUDY CHICAGO: "THE DINNER PARTY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 9). This exhibition welcomes back Ms. Chicago's extravagant installation banquet of ceramic plates and handmade table runners dedicated to 39 women. A feminist landmark, it is joining the permanent collection 22 years after its first appearance at the museum. It is amazing to see. Made with the help of hundreds of volunteers from 1975 to 1979, "The Dinner Party" sums up the first stage of feminist art, reflects the late 70's rematerialization of the art object and is startlingly prescient of the art of the late 80's and 90's in its ambition to be both aggressively visual and politically charged. Despite being almost as much a part of American culture as Norman Rockwell, Walt Disney, W.P.A. murals and the AIDS quilt, it retains much of its original revolutionary fervor. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Smith).

* "DRAWING NOW: EIGHT PROPOSITIONS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 6). This generous sampling of work by 26 young artists provides a sweeping, even opulent view of drawing at the threshold of the 21st century. The variety of techniques and materials, the mix of large-scale feats of draftsmanship with clusters of framed works, the broad spate of sources (from American quilt patterns to Japanese anime to 19th-century illustration) and the range of narrative ambition create an exhilarating sense of possibility. The division of the work into eight different approaches, or propositions, balances coherence with diversity. Some of the artists illustrate rather than fully embody the curators' categories, and there is an excess of fashionable, even overexposed artists from a handful of hot galleries. Nonetheless, "Drawing Now" is required viewing for anyone remotely interested in today's art. It sets a standard for future shows of its kind. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; until 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Smith).

* "FACING THE MASK" AND "RECENT ACQUISITIONS: SELECTIONS FROM THE PERMANENT COLLECTION," Museum for African Art, third floor, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through March 2). The Museum for African Art, formerly of SoHo, makes the leap to a new home in Long Island City with a very beautiful if surveyish show, "Facing the Mask," which happens to be all about moving. Some of the moving is physical, some psychological and spiritual, and it is embodied in more than 70 stunning masks, no two alike, from across sub-Saharan Africa. Some were used for popular entertainment; others were moral forces incarnate. Their purpose was transport, and they are supplemented by films of masquerades in action. Also on view is a selection of work from the museum's still small but growing permanent collection. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

"ADOLPH GOTTLIEB: A SURVEY EXHIBITION," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3271 (through March 2). Gottlieb's painting has not aged as well as that of his colleagues Pollock, Rothko and Newman. His journey leads from 1930's representational pictures that resemble those by his friend Milton Avery to the gridded pictographic works of the 40's to the iconic circle-and-burst paintings of the late 50's, which have been his most memorable works. In the 1960's his canvases expand and brighten under the influence of Color Field painting. This 31-painting exhibition casts an illuminating light on a period of tremendous creative ferment in Western art. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Mondays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and 65+ (Ken Johnson).

"MOVING PICTURES," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). This survey of photography with a small selection of video, film and installation art appended may be the largest exhibition of its kind in a major New York museum. Drawn almost entirely from the Guggenheim's permanent collection, it has a snappy yet unobtrusive design by Hani Rashid and ably surveys the expansion of contemporary art by camera-dependent media from the late 1960's to now. It begins with works by Nam June Paik, Bruce Nauman and Robert Smithson, then moves up the museum's ramp through photographs by Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and Andreas Gursky, concluding with video and film by artists like Stan Douglas, Shirin Neshat and Pierre Huyghe. An added attraction is the foam-lined, cavelike video galleries perched at the top of the spiral, which give the show a giddy, Hall of the Mountain King finale that seems to say, "Onward and upward with video." Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (Smith)

* "THE NATIVE BORN: CONTEMPORARY ABORIGINAL ART FROM RAMINGINING, AUSTRALIA," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Jan. 5). Like other Aboriginals, the Yolngu people of Arnhem Land in northern Australia make images on rock and bark, and also make sculptures and weaving. Their cross-hatched paintings are less familiar yet every bit as lively and aesthetically inventive as the "dot and circle" work by the people of the central Australian desert, who are more widely associated with the term Aboriginal. Taking inspiration from ancestral myth and legend, as well as from the waterholes, beaches, forests, swamps, jungles and plains that surround them, the Yolngu produce stylized versions of saltwater crocodiles, lizards, birds, fish and vines. The more than 200 examples here -- including a ritual sand sculpture saluting the creation story about the two sisters who brought water to the land at its birth -- make a visual feast of remarkable freshness. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "POUSSIN, CLAUDE AND THEIR WORLD: 17TH-CENTURY FRENCH DRAWINGS FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS, PARIS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Dec. 1). The Ecole des Beaux-Arts, the world's oldest surviving art school (founded in 1648), assembled an enormous collection of works to instruct its students in the discipline of drawing. Those from the 17th century, the great age of Nicolas Poussin and Claude Lorrain, are especially outstanding. The 71 here survey French drawing from 1620 to 1680, when classicism came to French art, aiming to restore High Renaissance ideals of clarity, order and balance, with the Italian painter Raphael as a revered model. The emphasis is on the works of Poussin (1594-1665) and Claude (1604-1682), a history painter and a landscapist. But lesser-known masters like Simon Vouet, Eustache Le Sueur and Charles Le Brun are also included. Wicked doings in the Bible, sex in mythology, the ordered schematics of French architecture and the pomp and circumstance of the French court are some of the subjects covered in the drawings, which should send any aficionado to the Frick on the run. Hours and admissions: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Glueck).

"QUEENS INTERNATIONAL," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Dec. 1). This selection of work by 40 artists, from 12 countries but all now living in Queens, includes paintings, videos, performance art, installations and other contemporary forms. The art reflects the globalization of postmodernist pluralism as much as -- if not more than -- cultural diversity. Highlights include intricately patterned, mandala-form collages by Marietta J. Ganapin; John L. Moore's dreamy, supplely painted abstractions; Larry Litt's politically provocative video "The Blame Show"; and James Johnson's full-scale copper-clad fantasy airplane, more offbeat labor of love than professional sculpture. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 55+ (Johnson).

LORNA SIMPSON, "31" and "Cameos and Appearances," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Jan. 26). The intricacies of being black and female in a Caucasian world are Ms. Simpson's continuing film subject. In "31," her latest, she records a month in the life of an anonymous black woman, presented in no particular sequence on a fast-moving grid of 31 small screens. Her mundane daily routine in an urban setting expresses the anomie and aloneness of one whose presence is not registered. The film lacks the depth charge of earlier Simpson films, like "Call Waiting," whose characters have more dimension. "Cameos and Appearances" carries on previous Simpson work, combining images with enigmatic texts that have an evocative relationship to the subject. The photographs are all inexpressive heads of anonymous blacks, mostly women but a few men, laid out in gridlike clusters. In characteristic Simpson fashion, they are turned away in silhouetted semi-profile, resolute in their ethnicity but refusing identification or empathy. Neither show represents Ms. Simpson's work at its best. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "THE THAW COLLECTION: MASTER DRAWINGS AND OIL SKETCHES, ACQUISITIONS SINCE 1994," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 (through Jan. 19). This selection of more than 100 European drawings and oil sketches is the latest update on a personal collection that Eugene V. Thaw and his wife, Clare, have been depositing at the Morgan in increments since 1975. The last such show, in 1994, left everyone a bit lightheaded it was so good. This one has a lot going for it, too, including work by Rembrandt, Ruisdael, Degas and the incomparable Samuel Palmer. A cluster of 19th-century German and Scandinavian works give the proceedings a piney, Romantic air. Nearly half the show is plein-air oil sketches, which the Thaws have recently been acquiring in depth. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "BILL VIOLA: GOING FORTH BY DAY," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). An ambitious meditation on the epic themes of human existence, this frescolike video installation consists of five panels, shot using the latest technology and projected simultaneously on the walls of one huge gallery. Each deals with a specific theme: rebirth, journey through life, disaster, death and resurrection. Inspired by the works of Renaissance painters like Giotto and Luca Signorelli, the show relates as much to still painting as it does to the moving images of cinema and television. Except for a few scenes, the action is almost in slow motion, suggesting the stasis of looking at paintings and allowing the viewer to shift attention from panel to panel without losing focus. The liveliest scene is "The Deluge," in which a series of ordinary street events occurs before the facade of a Classical-looking house. They are interrupted by a tumultuous flood pouring out of the building's apertures that sends people running for their lives. The work was mostly shot before the Sept. 11 disaster but is amazingly prophetic of it. If some of the imagery is corny, it is still a deeply felt and provocative piece of work. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "WINOGRAND 1964," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Dec. 1). In 1964 the photographer Garry Winogrand crisscrossed the United States in a slow, black 1957 two-door Ford Fairlaine, taking nearly 20,000 photographs along the way. Here are around 150 of them, most never shown before. Some are not terrific. Winogrand was a hit-and-miss artist, and the show could have been edited. But others are great, and together the images add up to a fresh, divinely eccentric portrait of America after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The resonance with 9/11, though obvious, goes unstated. A poor skeptic, Winogrand clearly saw the fragility and the preciousness of what binds people together. Many of the pictures seem fragile, too: they're fleeting stories sometimes so provisional as to be barely coherent, irreducible, like life, to a simple message. Winogrand captured how America once again transformed catastrophe into commerce, an inevitable but also strangely redemptive process. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $9; $6, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

MARKUS LUPERTZ, "Semiramis," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Nov. 16). Titled after the Babylonian Queen Semiramis, creator of the legendary Hanging Gardens, Mr. Lupertz's paintings, in which rectangles of florid, clotted Abstract Expressionist painting are set off within internal borders, might be a meditation on beauty and decadence. Superficially, these medium-size canvases by the head of the Dusseldorf Academy of Art resemble the paintings of Howard Hodgkin, but they are animated more by oblique irony than by lyrical hedonism (Johnson).

DENNIS MASBACK, Berry-Hill, 11 East 70th Street, (212) 744-2300 (through Wednesday). Layering squares, rectangles and lines in slightly irregular grids, Mr. Masback creates catchy plaid paintings. The artist draws his inspiration from jazz, and that is evident in the syncopated rhythms of his pictures. They also have seductively smooth, slightly brushy surfaces and a softly glowing translucence (Johnson).

GYORGY ROMAN, "A Survey," Janos Gat, 1100 Madison Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 327-0441 (through Nov. 9). This Hungarian painter (1903-1981) had an incredibly adventurous life. Rendered deaf and mute by a childhood bout with meningitis, he went on to become a professional boxer, a candy-maker's apprentice, a world traveler and a novelist. An unpredictable mix of Expressionism, Primitivism, Symbolism and political allegory, his earthy paintings have one eye on war, pestilence and nostalgic memories, the other on the formal and material possibilities of painting itself (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

PHIL BINACO, "Maenads Paintings," Linda Durham, 210 11th Avenue, (212) 337-0025 (through Nov. 28). A friend and admirer of Agnes Martin, this Santa Fe resident creates off-white abstractions out of wax and resin. He meticulously inscribes the thick, smooth surfaces with fine parallel lines to create flickering textures and simple rectilinear compositions. These handsome material objects are animated by a hint of spiritual luminosity (Johnson).

LARRY BROWN, Sears-Peyton, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 966-7469 (through Nov. 16). Spheres, globes and molecular models drift and tumble through space in Mr. Brown's semi-abstract paintings. The artist, an erstwhile pure abstractionist, grounds his cosmic vision in glazed, sensuously painterly surfaces and contains it within compressive compositions (Johnson).

DAVID X. LEVINE, "Teenage Symphonies to God," Cynthia Broan, 423 West 14th Street, (212) 633-6525 (through Nov. 16). If a Tantric master were reborn as an American student of rock 'n' roll, he might make works like Mr. Levine's paintings on paper. The best are pulsating concentric rings of colored circles, like strings of beads, with hand-written words referring to the Velvet Underground, the Beach Boys and other classic groups. Slightly dirtied and roughed up, they look antique, as though they have been exhumed from some forgotten monastery (Johnson).

EDDA RENOUF, "Time Lines," Joseph Helman, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 929-1545 (through Nov. 16). Ms. Renouf, who started exhibiting her work in Europe in the early 70's, makes Minimalistic multipanel abstract paintings, in which rubbed-in shades of red, orange or blue create textures like worn denim. These fields are subtly activated by geometric designs made by selective removal of threads from the canvas. Ms. Renouf means her work to be about time, but its effect is more of elegant, dry formality (Johnson).

WILLIAM STEIGER, "Signal," Margaret Thatcher Projects, 511 West 25th Street, (212) 675-0222 (through Nov. 16). Updating the Precisionism of Modernists like Charles Sheeler and Charles Demuth, Mr. Steiger creates flattened, hard-edged, high-contrast paintings of grain elevators, railroad signals and amusement park rides. They have a fresh material immediacy and a cool nostalgia. The complex linear webs in shades of green or orange describing Ferris wheel-type structures are especially engaging (Johnson).

JUDITH WESTPHALEN, Jan Van der Donk, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 691-5973 (through Nov. 21). This Peruvian painter (1922-1976) was a participant in Latin American artistic and intellectual circles. A four-decade survey of works on paper reveals a sensibility of urbane delicacy. Throughout, the artist engages in a dialogue with Cubism and Constructivism, producing compact compositions of layered, translucent planes in muted hues, shot through with cool, spacey light (Johnson).

SCOTT WIXON; LILIAN VOORHEES, Andre Zarre, 515 West 20th Street, (212) 255-0202 (through Nov. 9) All kinds of abstract elements crowd Mr. Wixon's modestly sized canvases. Puzzling together biomorphic, expressionistic, geological, spacey and funky forms in confectionery colors, he creates dense, jazzy improvisations of infectiously playful freedom. On larger canvases and in muted colors, Ms. Voorhees works variations on a vocabulary of semi-sculptural botanical forms (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "THE AGES OF MANKIND: TIME TO HOPE," Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 932-7347 (through Nov. 24; daily, 9:30 a.m. to noon and 1 to 5 p.m.). All but unheralded, this show seems to have dropped into New York like an unbidden gift, and what a gift: 100 superb examples of Spanish religious art, which is some of the most rapturous and wrenching religious art ever made, seen in a perfect setting. The works include Romanesque madonnas, Gothic crucifixions, paintings of saints by El Greco and Goya, and a handwritten letter by St. Teresa of Avila, all from churches, monasteries and museums in the Spanish provinces of Castile and Leon. The images, among them life-size polychrome sculptures, are sexy, gruesome and, above all, theatrical, projecting big, primary emotions. The effect is gloriously intense (Cotter).

* "BETWEEN WORD AND IMAGE: MODERN IRANIAN VISUAL CULTURE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Dec. 7). This no-frills exhibition is about the dynamics of cultural borrowing, the inseparability of art and politics and the interplay of modernism and Islamicism. It begins with painting and sculptures from the 1960's in which Western styles and Iranian themes merge. It continues with riveting photographs documenting the arrival of the Iranian Revolution in 1979. And it concludes with art that the revolution produced: political posters inspired by both the Western counterculture and militant Islamic ideology. Depending on the amount of reflective synthesis you're willing to do, the results can seem richly layered, or disjointed and undercooked. But the materials and the ideas on display are fascinating (Cotter).

ALEX GREY, Tibet House, 22 West 15th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 807-0563 (through Jan. 3). Mr. Grey's painting, with its tantric symbolism, medical-illustration finesse and New Age optimism, might be described as psychedelic realism. In it, the human figure is rendered with X-ray, or CAT scan, transparency, the way Aldous Huxley saw a leaf when he was on mescalin. Mr. Grey's images have been appropriated by a countercultural audience: they have shown up on promotional posters for rave events and on paper used for blotter-style LSD. But they look right at home at Tibet House, where contemporary versions of religious tankas, meant for esoteric instruction and meditation, often hang (Cotter).

Last Chance

GEORGE BASELITZ, "Paintings and Drawings From the 1960's," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through tomorrow). Before this German Neo-Expressionist started turning his canvases upside down, he made earthy, saturnine paintings and drawings right side up. His gnarly, muddy pictures from the 60's of people and animals have an evocative, primordial quality and sometimes, as in a small ink portrait of a bare-chested Antonin Artaud, a strange delicacy (Johnson).

MARIA ELENA GONZALEZ, the Project, 427 West 126th Street, Harlem, 212 662-8610 (through Sunday). In these photographs, drawings and sculptures the content is less overtly autobiographical than in the artist's earlier work, and more dramatic. The central image is an electrical tower, a structure that generates energy but also, potentially, radiation. Ms. Gonzalez makes it look at once fragile and ominous, and the mood of unease gains force in the upstairs gallery, where part of the floor seems to be swelling as if from built-up internal pressure (Cotter).

JITISH KALLAT, Bose Pacia Modern, 508 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-7074 (through tomorrow). This young Indian artist made his New York solo debut three years ago with work that looked so fully resolved it was hard to imagine where he might take it from there. An answer comes in the new paintings here, in which he has expanded his scale, clarified his compositions and varied his palette. As before, he addresses political subjects -- AIDS, poverty and sectarian violence -- that have a very specific meaning in India, but are also of urgent concern elsewhere (Cotter).

* BERTY SKUBER, Emily Harvey, 537 Broadway, at Spring Street, 212 925-7651 (through tomorrow). Although Ms. Skuber has exhibited almost yearly in Europe for three decades, this is her first New York solo show since 1979. The main work is a series of three dozen extraordinary fabric collages, or miniquilts, stitched from clothing labels. Ms. Skuber began by using labels from her own clothes, but most have been contributed by friends and strangers around the world who heard about her project. It is both an international collaboration and a labor-intensive species of concrete poetry, minutely composed but random, personal but unsentimental (Cotter).

"TRUE MEDIUMS," Cavin-Morris, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 226-3768 (through tomorrow). This fine exhibition features works by psychic mediums who used drawings to materialize receptions from the great beyond. It's not otherworldly imagery so much as the drawing itself that fascinates. Included are ghostly faces drawn with extreme delicacy by Fernand Desmoulin; mandalas like stained-glass windows by Norma Oliver; colorful, stratified landscapes by Agatha Wojciechowsky; and calligraphic flowers penciled by Helen Butler Wells (Johnson).

PETER WAITE, Edward Thorp, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 691-6565 (through tomorrow). Mr. Waite's moody photo-derived paintings of modest suburban houses are made with a nice, economical touch that simplifies detail and delicately outlines forms to slightly cartoonish effect. A touching nostalgia calls to mind Edward Hopper. There is an up-to-date conceptual program, too: each home displays an American flag, making the series a meditation on patriotic kitsch (Johnson).

KAY WALKINGSTICK, June Kelly, 591 Broadway, at Houston Street, 212 226-1660 (through tomorrow). Ms. WalkingStick's two-panel paintings of landscapes and figures have always operated on a push-pull between nature and culture, material and spirit. Recently the artist has been spending time in Italy, and the look of the work has changed. The dark colors she once favored have been replaced by lavenders, pinks and luminous browns. A judicious use of gilding links her diptych format up with altarpieces, a connection that was probably always there but has never been obvious until now (Cotter).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Claes Oldenburg's "Typewriter Eraser," in "American Legacy." (Associated Press); Last Chance: A detail from one of Berty Skuber's fabric collages stitched from clothing labels, at the Emily Harvey Gallery through tomorrow. (Emily Harvey Gallery)

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 1, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 42

LENGTH: 4075 words

HEADLINE: SPARE TIMES 

 BODY:
 ATTRACTIONS

Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. "Looking Back at Clear Comfort," photographs that she took of the house (formerly called Clear Comfort) when she lived there. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children under 6, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. "East European Women: The Films of Judit Elek and Nana Djordjadze." Films by Ms. Elek: tomorrow at 1 p.m., "The Lady From Constantinople" (1969); at 4:30 p.m., "Maria's Day" (1983); at 6:30 p.m., "A Free Man: The Life of Erno Fisch" (1998). Films by Ms. Djordjadze: Sunday at 2 p.m., "Robinson Crusoe in Georgia" (1986); at 4 p.m., "A Chef in Love" (1996); at 6:30 p.m., "27 Missing Kisses" (2000). Tomorrow at 3 p.m., panel discussion with the filmmakers and Catherine Portugues, a film professor. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; and by appointment. Film and video screenings are free with admission unless otherwise noted. Museum admission: $8.50; 65+ and students, $5.50; 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and younger, free. Information: www.ammi.org or (718) 784-0077.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. "The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter," an exhibition of hundreds of specimens from Africa, Asia and the Americas; through May. In the Imax Theater, "Bears," "Kilimanjaro: To the Roof of Africa" and "Pulse: A Stomp Odyssey"; call for show times. Imax tickets, including museum admission, are $24; $17.50 for students and 60+; $14 for children under 12. Tickets to one Imax feature, including museum admission, are $17, $12.50 for students and 60+ and $10 for children under 12. Admission to the Butterfly Conservatory, which is by timed entry and includes museum admission, is $17, $12.50 for students and 60+; $10 for children under 12. General museum admission (suggested donation) $12; $9 for students and 60+; 12 and younger, $7; under 2, free. A combination ticket, including museum and Rose Center admission and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $21; students and 60+, $15.50; 12 and younger, $12.50; under 2, free. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., except Fridays, when the Rose Center is open until 8:45 p.m. for "Starry Nights." Information: www.amnh.org, (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center on seven floors encompasses the Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. "The Search for Life: Are We Alone?" raises the question of life beyond Earth. On exhibit: "Full Moon, Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape," rarely seen photographic prints from NASA's Apollo moon missions. Ongoing. The Big Bang Theater features a narrated visual and audio presentation simulating the beginning of the universe. Cullman Hall, a 7,000-square-foot permanent display area on the bottom level, illustrates processes that led to the creation of the universe. "Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere," with cash bar, jazz and tapas; tonight, Bill Saxton and the Harlem Jazz Scene Quintet, 5:45 to 8:15 p.m. Hours: daily, 10 a.m to 5:45 p.m. (The Rose Center is open on Friday nights until 8:45 for "Starry Nights.") Space shows run every half-hour all day. Suggested admission to the museum, which includes the Rose Center: $12; students and 60+, $9; 2 to 12, $7; under 2, free. Combined admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $21; students and 60+, $15.50; 2 to 12, $12.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street, Lower Manhattan. "Drachmas, Doubloons and Dollars: The History of Money," a major exhibition of currency from the society's permanent collection, is the first exhibition in the society's new Lower Manhattan space. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America. Hours: Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 234-3130.

BARTOW-PELL MANSION, 895 Shore Road North, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. The museum, on nine acres, displays fine and decorative arts from the 19th century. Hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Museum admission: $2.50; students and 62+, $1.25; children 12 and under, free; the first Sunday of each month is free for all. Information: (718) 885-1461.

FEDERAL HALL NATIONAL MEMORIAL, 26 Wall Street, Lower Manhattan. Site of George Washington's inauguration and the drafting of the Bill of Rights. The railing from the first Capitol building, constructed on the site and demolished in 1812, is on view. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 825-6888.

FRAUNCES TAVERN MUSEUM, 54 Pearl Street, second floor, Lower Manhattan. The museum, in a former tavern, is dedicated to the study and interpretation of early American history and culture. One of the period-room displays is the Long Room, the site of George Washington's Farewell Address. Other permanent exhibitions are the Clinton Room, named for George Clinton, the first American-born governor of New York; and a re-creation of an early-19th-century private dining room. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Sundays and Mondays. Admission: $3; $2 for those under 18 and 65+; free for children under 6. Information: (212) 425-1778.

HAMILTON GRANGE, 287 Convent Avenue, at 141st Street, Hamilton Heights. Alexander Hamilton's country retreat, the Grange, originally completed in 1802, commemorates Hamilton's service as the first secretary of the Treasury. Visitors may request free tours with park rangers. Hours: Fridays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 283-5154.

HISPANIC SOCIETY OF AMERICA, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. Dedicated to Hispanic culture with fine and decorative arts of the Iberian Peninsula from prehistory to the present. Through Nov. 9: "Manuscripts and Early Printed Works From Spain and France" and "Convergence and Diversity: Art of the Hispanic World," mini-exhibitions highlighting objects from the society's collection, including recent acquisitions. The permanent collection is also on view. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 926-2234.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th century to the 19th, restored and furnished. Current exhibition: "Reflections: Sept. 11 Through Staten Island Eyes," through Nov. 17. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; ages 62+, $4; children 6 to 18 and students, $3.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. The Intrepid is a converted World War II aircraft carrier with two decks of displays, including four theme halls: United States Navy Hall, Pioneer Hall, Technologies Hall and Intrepid Hall. New on the hangar deck is the Virtual Flight Zone, which places participants in the cockpit of an F-18 Hornet and simulates its movements. Admission: $13; 65+, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; 6 to 11, $6; 2 to 5, $2; under 2, active military personnel and museum members, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., with last ticket sold at 4 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience, the museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. Visitors can explore an apartment that was once home to the Confino family and speak with an actor who plays a 13-year-old family member, on Saturdays and Sundays at noon, 1, 2 and 3 p.m. Confino family apartment tour admission: adults, $8; students, 65+ and children over 5, $6; children 4 and under, free. In another apartment visitors can see a sweatshop and experience shiva, the Jewish rite of mourning, with the Rogarshevsky family. This apartment and two others, which housed the Gumpertz and Baldizzi families, both of whom experienced the economic depressions of 1873 and 1929, respectively, can be viewed on guided tours every 40 minutes, Tuesdays through Fridays, from 1:20 to 3:40 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, every 30 minutes from 11 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Prices for these tours: $9; students, 65+ and children over 5, $7; children 4 and under, free. Special prices for two and three tours. Information: (212) 431-0233.

MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. This preserved late-Federal brick house with a Greek Revival interior, once owned by Seabury Tredwell, a wealthy hardware dealer, was built in 1832. The house holds the original furniture, clothing and personal articles of the Tredwells, who lived there for nearly 100 years. Self-guided tours are available on weekdays; guided tours on Saturdays and Sundays. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $3; members and children under 12, free. Information: (212) 777-1089.

MOUNT VERNON HOTEL MUSEUM AND GARDEN, formerly the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. Built in 1799 as the carriage house for Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, it was the Mount Vernon Hotel from 1826 to 1833. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $4; under 12, free. Reservations: (212) 838-6878.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents material related to the city's history. "The Croton Aqueduct: Illustrations by Fayette B. Tower," starting tomorrow and going through April 6. "The Lubavitch of Brooklyn, an Intimate Portrait: Photographs by Steve Hoffman," through Feb. 2. "Raices: The Roots of Latin Music in New York City," a display of photographs, posters, instruments, costumes and other items that document the evolution of Afro-Caribbean music in the city, through Jan. 26. "The Day Our World Changed: Children's Art of 9/11," through Jan. 19. "Richard Rodgers's Broadway," celebrating the centennial of the composer's birth marked with a display of items from the museum's Theater Collection. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; 62+, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Features exhibitions on the Holocaust and Jewish life before and after World War II. On view through Jan. 5, "Yahrzeit: Sept. 11 Observed," with objects that reflect responses by Jews to the attacks. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; students and 55+, $5; children 5 and under, free. To reserve tickets: (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. The Henry Luce III Center for the Study of American Culture is a permanent gallery on the fourth floor. Through Feb., "Degrees of Latitude: Maps of America from the Colonial Williamsburg Collection" and "Reading Uncle Tom's Image: A Reconsideration of Harriet Beecher Stowe's 140-Year-Old Character and His Legacy," with early editions of the novel from around the world, as well as abolitionist pamphlets, theater and film posters and sculpture. Through Jan. 5: "The Games We Played: Victorian Games From the Liman Collection," board games from the early 20th century, and "Portrait of the Art World: A Century of ARTnews Photographs," celebrating the centenary of the oldest and largest American art magazine, with 100 photographic portraits of artists. Through Jan. 20: "Gouveneur Morris Treasures," decorative arts from Morris's estate. Through January: "Life on a Lapel: An Exhibition of Buttons, Badges, Medals and Decorations From the Collection of the N.-Y.H.S." Through Jan. 12: "Seat of Empire: Napoleon's Armchair from Malmaison to Manhattan." Through Jan. 19: "Home of the Free: A Student Photojournalism Project," exhibition of a project in which middle-school students were given cameras to capture the lives of public servants in their communities. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; children and 62+, $4. Information: (212) 873-3400.

NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM, Grand Central Terminal annex (Vanderbilt Avenue side). "Elevated City: A History of the Els in New York," an exhibition with photographs, magazine covers, train models and other artifacts that document the introduction, use and demise of the elevated rail system, through Wednesday. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 878-0106.

Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. Grounds are open Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Conservatory hours, 10 a.m to 4 p.m. when the garden is open. Suggested admission: $3; $1.50 for students and 65+ (free for 65+ on Fridays); free for children 15 and under; free for all on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Bronx River Parkway at Fordham Road, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. The Everett Children's Adventure Garden is open Tuesdays through Fridays, 1 to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Garden grounds admission: $3; $2 for 62+ and students; $1 for children 2 to 12. Garden Passport, which includes all admissions and a tram tour: $10; $7.50 for 62+ and students; $4 for children 2 to 12. Forest tours, Saturdays and Sundays at noon. Tram tours, daily, every 30 minutes. Highlights of the garden Saturdays and Sundays at 1 p.m. Conservatory admission: $5; $4 for students and 62+; $3 for those 2 to 12; under 2, free. Grounds admission free on Wednesdays and 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Parking: $5. Information: (718) 817-8700; www.nybg.org.

QUEENS BOTANICAL GARDEN, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing. In bloom: ornamental grass, flowering cabbage and kale. Autumn talk: "Garden Photography," Sunday at 2 p.m. Fee: $10; $8, members. To register, call number below, ext. 230. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Free. Information: (718) 886-3800.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres. Hours: daily, 8 a.m. to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The Carl Grillo Glass House features a central palm court, tropical and Mediterranean wings, a seasonal display in the entrance hall and an area for plant propagation. Open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Fridays till 8 p.m.) The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden is open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Connie Gretz's Secret Garden, a walled garden with a formal maze, including a castle and a drawbridge, next to the New York Chinese Scholars' Garden, is open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Fridays till 8 p.m.) Admission: $5; $4 for 62+ and children under 12. Admission to the Secret Garden: $2; children, $1; adults with a child, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of this 28-acre garden. Family art project: "Paints From the Earth," tomorrow and Sunday, 1 to 4 p.m. Learn how to grind colors from flowers, insects, clay and other natural materials. Free with admission. Concert: "Manhattan Mix," chamber music. Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets (which include admission): $15; $12 for 62+; $10 for members and students. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students; free for members and children under 6. Free for all on Tuesdays and Saturdays from 9 a.m. to noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.

WALKING TOURS

"R.I.P.: THE WALKING TOUR" visits sites relevant to the Day of the Dead, including the New York City Marble Cemetery, final home of John Lloyd Stephens, the 19th-century Maya archaeologist, and the Middle Church Slocum Memorial Mosaics, which commemorate the deaths in 1904 of 1,100 people who were aboard in the S.S. General Slocum, an excursion boat that caught fire on the East River. Meets at Anthology Film Archives, Second Avenue and Second Street, East Village. Tomorrow, 2 to 4 p.m. Free, donations appreciated. Sponsored by the Lower Eastside Girls Club. Information: (212) 982-1633.

"GHOSTS OF GREENWICH" covers the haunted history of Greenwich Village, with stops at Washington Square Park and the Cherry Lane Theater, meeting Fridays at 7 p.m at the Washington Arch. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Ramosonian Tours. Information: (201) 394-9891.

ADVENTURE ON A SHOESTRING. Tomorrow's tours include "Salute to Abraham Lincoln" at 10 a.m., which meets on the northwest corner of Eighth Street and Broadway and explores such locations as the Great Hall of Cooper Union, the former site of the Academy of Music and McSorley's Old Ale House; "T'was the Night Before Christmas," a walking tour of the Chelsea area, which Clement Clarke Moore developed as a residential district (his authorship of the classic poem after which the tour is named has been challenged), meets on the northwest corner of 23rd Street and Seventh Avenue at 1:30 p.m.; "Money Can't Buy You Happiness," a tour of the Beekman Place-Sutton Place area, with stops at the former residences of Greta Garbo, Marilyn Monroe and Irving Berlin, meeting at 5:15 p.m. on the northeast corner of 57th Street and First Avenue. Fee for each: $5. Information: (212) 265-2663.

"EXPLORING UNION SQUARE." Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the Lincoln statue at the north end of Union Square. Sponsored by the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District and Quality Street Tours. Free. Information: (718) 783-3260.

HARLEM. Visits historic sites in the area, meeting today through Sunday at 2 p.m. in front of the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street. Fee: $25. Sponsored by Metro Tour Service. Information: (718) 789-0430.

BIG ONION WALKING TOURS. "Immigrant New York," a multiethnic tour through the Jewish East Side, Chinatown, Little Italy and what used to be called Little Germany, Little Ireland and Little Africa. Stops include the African Burial Ground and and Mulberry Bend. Meets today at 1 p.m. on the southeast corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. "Halloween Weekend in Green-Wood Cemetery," stops include the graves of Charles Ebbets and Louis Comfort Tiffany. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the cemetery's main entrance, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Fee for each: $12, $10 for students and 63+. Information: (212) 439-1090; www.bigonion.com.

"LOWER EAST SIDE and CHINATOWN." Visits the bakeries, markets and cafes of the Lower East Side and Chinatown, in particular those reflecting Eastern European and Asian-American influences, Sunday at 11 a.m. Meets in First Park, on the northwest corner of East Houston Street and First Avenue. Fee: $15, nonsubscribers; $13, subscribers. Sponsored by Noshwalks. Information: (212) 222-2243.

"GREENWICH VILLAGE LITERARY PUB CRAWL." Combines readings of works by writers with stops at bars that they made famous. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the White Horse Tavern, 567 Hudson Street, West Village. Sponsored by the New Ensemble Theater Company. Fee: $15; students and 55+, $12. Refreshments not included. Reservations: (212) 613-5796.

"DISCOVER PROSPECT PARK." Focuses on this park's water sources and the last forest in Brooklyn. Meets tomorrow and Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Boathouse in the Prospect Park Audubon Center in Brooklyn. Free. Sponsored by the Prospect Park Alliance. Information: (718) 287-3400.

"SOHO: YESTERDAY AND TODAY." A look at the cast-iron buildings, galleries and boutiques of that area. Stops include the Puck Building, Richmond Hill and the old St. Nicholas Hotel. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the southeast corner of Broadway and Houston Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. Information: (732) 270-5277.

"LIGHTS, CAMERA, GREENWICH VILLAGE." A tour of film sites in Greenwich Village. Tomorrow at 1 p.m. Sponsored by the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. Fee: $15; $12 for members. Meets in Washington Square North, near the arch. Information: (212) 475-9585.

"GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY." This exploration of one of the first garden cemeteries in America visits mausoleums with stained-glass windows, as well as sculptures and monuments, set amid rolling hills. See works by designers such as Stanford White, Daniel Chester French and Richard Upjohn, and the final resting places of Louis Comfort Tiffany, Leonard Bernstein and others. Fee: $15. Meets on Sunday at 1 p.m. at the main entrance gate, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Sponsored by Justin Ferrate Tours of the City. Information: (212) 779-0727.

"MORE TEEMING THAN BOMBAY: THE OLD JEWISH LOWER EAST SIDE." Focuses on the food and history of this neighborhood. Fee: $12. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at Essex and Canal Streets, at Straus Square. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours. Information: (212) 242-5762.

RECREATION

"NEW YORK CITY MARATHON," Central Park. About 30,000 runners from around the world participate in this 26.2-mile run through the city's five boroughs all day Sunday, beginning at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in Staten Island, then going through Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and finally Manhattan, ending next to Tavern on the Green in Central Park. Spectators may view the runners all day as the race starts in the late morning and extends into the early evening. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Information: (212) 860-4455; www.nycmarathon.org.

EVENTS

"ALL SAINTS, ALL SOULS, ALL CINEMA," the Lower Eastside Girls Club Film Festival, is showing films that explore life, death and rites of passage. Today, All Saints Day, honors female filmmakers, featuring screenings of "Aamala," "Witches in Exile" and others. From noon to 2 p.m. is the panel "Meet the Makers: Women in Film and TV." Tomorrow features films that pay tribute to the dead, including several shorts honoring those who perished on 9/11. Anthology Film Archives, Second Street and Second Avenue, East Village. Information and a complete list of films: (212) 982-1633 or www.girlsclub.org.

"IS LIFE NOT LIVING UP TO YOUR EXPECTATIONS?" A lecture by Gregg Krech, author of "Naikan: Gratitude, Grace and the Japanese Art of Self-Reflection," is tonight at 6:30. Fee: $8. Tomorrow, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Mr. Krech leads an extended workshop on the same subject. Fee: $60. Zen Center of New York City, 500 State Street, Brooklyn. Information: (718) 875-8229.

"JOY OF CHRISTMAS," a bazaar with hand-made crafts, lunch items, baked goods, clothing, jewelry, linens and handbags. Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55th Street, at Fifth Avenue. All proceeds benefit causes of the Women's Association. Today, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 831-1462.

"WORLD'S LARGEST BLOCK PARTY," arts, crafts, antiques, clothing, and more than 50 cultural and corporate displays, providing samples and free information. Sponsored by the American Diabetes Foundation. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., on Madison Avenue, between 42nd and 57th Streets. Information: (212) 809-4900.

"THE CITY RESILIENT: PHOTOGRAPHS BY JOEL MEYEROWITZ," 195 Broadway, at Fulton Street, Lower Manhattan. A display of photographs taken at ground zero. Today and tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York. Free.

PUB-DATE: November 1, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; Escapes; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1603 words

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Weekender Hudson, N.Y.

BYLINE:  By KATHRYN MATTHEWS 

 BODY:
HUDSON is a diamond in the rough that's midway through polishing. You can find a lovely old house for well under $75,000, but the neighbors will expect you to plunge into a restoration that's likely to cost you more. The major commercial street has some of the best antiques shopping in the Northeast, but you'll have to drive out of town to get to the supermarket, and while some of the neighbors concentrate on new parks and paths, others are supporting an 1,800-acre cement plant proposed for the next town over. 
 Hudson, an old port town on the Hudson River, has fewer than 8,000 people, but it is the only city in Columbia County, as well as the county seat. Two decades ago, with many shipping and industrial jobs lost, its fine old houses in a variety of styles -- Federal, Greek Revival, Victorian, Italianate, Queen Anne -- were in disrepair, and downtown stores were boarded up. But then outsiders discovered Hudson's architecture and low prices and began moving in, setting up artists' studios and starting small businesses, including dozens of antiques shops, and fixing up the houses. 
 "The idea of owning one of these old houses and restoring it to its former glory is tremendously appealing," said Carole Osterink, president of Historic Hudson, a nonprofit preservation group. The renovation goes on: scaffolding, ladders and work crews are as much a part of the local landscape as a Hudson River sunset. 
On weekends antiques hunters converge on Warren Street, which now has more than 70 antiques shops as well as art galleries and restaurants. Celebrities, accompanied by their interior decorators, are sometimes in the crowds: Whoopi Goldberg, Meg Ryan, Richard Gere and Bette Midler have all been spotted, according to Tim Dunleavy, owner of Rural Residence, a home-furnishings store on Warren Street. 
Many longtime residents remain in Hudson, and there is a rich ethnic mix. Most of the newcomers who are transforming the downtown live in Hudson year round, sometimes telecommuting with the help of Mid-Hudson Cable, a high-speed cable service. But the second-home market is growing. 

The Scene
Hudson is bounded on three sides by Greenport and on the fourth by the Hudson River. Entering from the south, Route 9G passes rolling hills, woodlands and marshes, and the Hudson Correctional Facility. On the east side of town is Kaz, a maker of vaporizers and humidifiers and a prominent Hudson employer. Across the city line, in Greenport, is a sprawl of car dealerships, gas stations and fast-food outlets. 
Hudson proper was founded by settlers who arrived from Nantucket in 1784 and laid out the city grid: numbered streets -- First through Seventh -- run north to south and are bisected east to west by Allen, Union, Warren, Columbia and State Streets. In its early days the city was a bawdy whaling town (despite being on the river rather than directly on the ocean). The street signs have tiny whales imprinted on them as a tribute to the past. 
At the riverside, the just-opened Hudson Waterfront Park offers an expansive view, and in warm weather, boats and Jet Skis cruise to and from the busy adjacent marina. Nearby, the restored Victorian railroad station, now used by Amtrak, deposits commuters and visitors on Front Street. Plans include the renovation of Promenade Hill, a public walkway overlooking the Hudson.

Pros
If you want to own a second home in a place where you can make a difference, Hudson may be your town. A strong sense of civic activism runs through its core. People have an opportunity to get involved here, and many do, whether raising money for the public library or joining a committee to restore a historic building. Weekenders are more than welcome to participate. 
Cultural activities are abundant. You can attend plays at the Hudson River Theater; films at Time & Space Limited, a performing arts center; poetry readings at the Hudson Opera House; and classical music performances at the Pleshakov Music Center, a former bank building converted to a concert hall. 
Escaping to the country takes just minutes by car. Skiing is nearby, and Saratoga Springs, Tanglewood and the Berkshire foothills are all an hour or less away. 
The Hudson Power Boat Association, a private club along the river, has 100 members, mostly local motorboat enthusiasts, but weekenders can also join. 
The city has several good restaurants, including the vegetarian-friendly Earth Foods; Red Dot, a funky neighborhood bistro that serves globally accented comfort fare; and Paramount Grill, with a creative menu including cornmeal-crusted pan-fried catfish and Caribbean jerk chicken. 

Cons
Don't consider Hudson if you are not willing to invest time and money in restoration. Virtually all houses require some degree of work, and the cost in some cases runs into six figures. 
Though Hudson borders the river, there is limited access to the water. Most properties do not have a river view. While you can enjoy a close-up river view at the beautifully manicured Waterfront Park, swimming is strictly prohibited there because of its proximity to the train tracks and marina. 
There is a shortage of services like dry cleaners and cash machines, and supermarkets are across the city line in Greenport. 
Differences in social and economic status have resulted in a sometimes uneasy coexistence between longtime residents and recent newcomers. "There are native Hudsonians who feel left out of Hudson's transformation, resulting in a cultural gulf that has yet to be resolved," said Don Christensen, a freelance financial writer, who, with his wife, Jo Bredwell, a senior partner at J. Walter Thompson, bought a weekend house in Hudson in 1985. 
Though crimeslike robbery and assault, are not a major concern, there are some problems with drug dealing. Overall, weekenders and Manhattan transplants say they feel relatively safe. 
"Just realize this is definitely not the Hamptons," said Ulrik Trojaborg, who lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and bought an 18th-century post-and-beam house off Union Street last summer with his partner. 
Adding to this simmering tension is a rift over the proposal by St. Lawrence Cement, a Canadian company, for an 1,800-acre complex in Greenport. Plans include a blasting quarry, 20-story towers, a 400-foot smokestack and a two-mile conveyor belt to the Hudson riverfront.
"Stop the Plant" signs tend to pop up in newcomers' front yards, while "Support the Plant" signs are often seen where longtime residents live.

The Market
In the past year and a half property values in Hudson have increased by at least 30 percent, said Kathleen Thorsey, a mortgage consultant for the Valley Mortgage Company in Hudson. 
Many New Yorkers have been buying property in Hudson this past year, said the Rev. Kim Singletary, the Hudson city assessor. 
Peggy Lampton, who owns Peggy Lampton Real Estate in Claverack, a few miles southeast of Hudson, also finds the Hudson market brisk. "I was amazed to find that 51 Hudson properties on our multiple listing are now under contract to sell," she said. "Buyers haven't entered any bidding wars yet, but the potential is definitely there." 
Second-home seekers will find prices as diverse as Hudson's architecture. Least available are buildings in move-in condition, with prices ranging from $85,000 to $150,000. Buyers can still get houses for $35,000 to $65,000 if they are willing to invest in restoration or consider buying in areas away from the center of the city's transformation, said Judy Meyer, an associate broker at Coldwell Banker Bartolotta Associates in Hudson (518-828-7111).
Coldwell Banker Bartolotta listings this week included a small farmhouse-style dwelling for $39,000 in a transitional neighborhood near the train station and a large fixer-upper Victorian, with high ceilings and the original woodwork, for $127,000. A three-floor post-and-beam house with a stone foundation on the waterfront end of Warren Street recently dropped from $179,900 to $170,000.

LAY OF THE LAND
A Place for Rest And Restoration

POPULATION: 7,524.
SIZE: 2.17 square miles.
NEIGHBORS: John Ashbery, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet; Lynn Davis, the photographer; municipal employees; factory workers; antiques dealers; artists. Mr. Ashbery, whose rough-hewn stone house is downtown near the Columbia County Courthouse, has described Hudson as conforming "to my idea of what a small town should be."
MEDIAN HOUSE PRICE: $75,000.
RECENT SALES: A 1920's three-bedroom, two-story bungalow, about 1,500 square feet, on North Fifth Street, $59,000; an 1840's multifamily Federal town house on Columbia Street, about 2,200 square feet, with Victorian details and four floors, $80,000; an 1836 Greek Revival on Allen Street, four bedrooms, $190,000.
DISTANCE FROM NEW YORK: 129 miles.
TRAVEL TIME: In light traffic, Hudson is a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Manhattan. By rail, the trip is two hours via Amtrak, which stops in Hudson.
GETTING THERE: Take the New York State Thruway to Exit 21 (the Catskill/Cairo exit). Follow Route 23 East, cross the Rip Van Winkle Bridge, and turn left onto Route 23B/9G. Go north about three miles to Hudson.
WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING: Stay at the Hudson City Bed & Breakfast on stately Allen Street. It's in a Second Empire house built in 1865 and has five rooms with private bathrooms. Prices range from $109 to $169 a night on weekends, and a two-night minimum stay is required on weekends from April through December (518-822-8044; www.HudsonCityBnB.com). Or try the St. Charles Hotel at 16-18 Park Street, just off Warren Street. Its 34 rooms range in price from $89 to $119 on weekends (518-822-9900; www.stcharleshotel.com).

GRAPHIC: Photos: DREAM STREET -- Warren Street is Hudson's main thoroughfare, above, home to some 70 antiques shops. One of them, left, along Warren, where neighbors stop to chat. (Photographs by Will Waldron for The New York Times) Map of New York State highlighting Hudson.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Midcentury Italian Art That Still Eggs On the Irreverent

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Given that tall oaks from little acorns grow, it seems obvious that not all influential art is great art. The significance of an artwork can lie less in its objective presence than in its conceptual ripple effect, and what other artists get from it. Which is why we find ourselves still enduring some of the aftershocks of the art of the late 1960's and early 1970's, as silly, desultory, ephemeral and irritating, as it sometimes was. If Conceptual Art is by now a kind of folk art, whose most extreme states include television commercials and the anarchic feats of "Jackass the Movie," younger artists still build quite solidly on its innovations. 
 This is one of the impressions created by "Zero to Infinity: Arte Povera, 1962-72," an edifying if uneven survey at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden here. It was organized by Richard Flood, chief curator at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, and Francis Morris, senior curator at the Tate Modern in London, and coordinated by Phyllis Rosenzweig, the Hirshhorn's curator of works on paper. 
 The exhibition delves into the Conceptually based art of an irreverent band of Italian artists whose efforts are an important point of origin for much late-20th-century and early-21st-century art. Ranging from a curvaceous frost-covered ladder by Pier Paolo Calzolari to a blank piece of cardboard plopped on the floor according to Emilio Prini's instructions, the show exhibits more than 100 works by 14 artists -- with Jannis Kounellis, Aligierhi Boetti, Michelangelo Pistoletto and Gilberto Zorio providing most of the interest. It suffers from a kind of "my sister/my daughter" effect. 
The show sheds new light on the Italian avant-garde of the 1960's, which is not well enough known in the United States. So it provides a crucial backdrop against which to consider American Conceptualism as well as the subversiveness and questioning nature that are so endemic to art today.
Yet much of the work filling the Hirshhorn's second floor is more sophomoric than sublime, more irksome than genuinely radical; and not enough of it dates from before 1966 to quite justify the show's title. As for infinity, only a few of the artists here even reached triple digits. And by the way, none started from zero: their efforts are haunted by precedents.
These include the classical beauty of Renaissance art, the eerie juxtapositions of de Chirico and Magritte, and the reductivist tendencies of European and American artists in the 1950's. The Arte Poverachiks followed a decade in which Yves Klein exhibited an empty gallery as art, Piero Manzoni offered cans of his excrement as sculpture, Lucio Fontana made paintings by slashing or punching holes in the canvas and Robert Rauschenberg sent a telegram to his Paris art dealer, Iris Clert, announcing, "This is art if I say so." 
Building deliberately and sometimes inspiredly on precedents like these, the artists of Arte Povera waged an insinuating, provocative, usually elegant assault on art. They came together in one of the last consciously fomented art movements of the 20th century. The term, which means poor or impoverished art, was coined by the young art critic Germano Celant in 1967 in a catalog essay he wrote to accompany a show of seven young Italian artists that he organized in Genoa. The original seven grew to 14 artists whom Celant wrote about and exhibited under the Arte Povera banner until 1972, when he announced that it was time for the artists to pursue individual endeavors. 
They also participated in historic exhibitions like Harald Szeemann's "When Attitudes Become Form" at the Zurich Kunsthaus in 1969 and, in 1971, Kynaston McShine's "Information" at the Museum of Modern Art and Mr. Celant's "Conceptual Art, Arte Povera, Land Art" in Turin. These brought together international groupings, variously labeled Post-Minimalism (coined by the American critic Robert Pincus-Witten), Process Art, L'Art Informel, Antiform Art and Conceptual Art. Their common ground included a certain disregard for the finished art object; a preference for everyday, sometimes organic materials; the use of performance, language and photography; and an inclination to claim various social events as art.
Traceable, ultimately, to the work of Marcel Duchamp, such tendencies paralleled the social changes brought about by the student movement, feminism and opposition to the Vietnam War. The Arte Provera artists also reacted to the growing materialism of postwar Italy, whose economic recovery, called the Italian Miracle, had been begun by the Marshall Plan and then sustained by the innovations of Italian design, evident in cars, furnishings and fashion.
The stylistic and physical diversity of the work in this exhibition sometimes makes any notion of an art movement seem tenuous. Pistoletto's slick Photo-Realist images on mirrors are a far cry from Mr. Kounellis's loose assemblings of materials and objects. The gallery devoted to his work, which is the show's most impressive, includes burlap sacks filled with rice, beans and other staples and a series of scales piled with ground coffee. Yet both artists shared a desire to startle, involve and impinge on the viewer.
The show opens with a short scratchy video of one of Arte Povera's greatest moments of impingement: the opening of Mr. Kounellis's exhibition at the Galleria L'Attico in Rome in 1969. In a former parking garage with a floor of gleaming ceramic tile, he tethered a dozen horses to the walls. (I'm sure I'm not the only person who remembers poring over the spare, evocative image of this event in Mr. McShine's catalog to his 1971 "Information" show.) 
The Italians, especially, embraced instablity and natural forces as artistic elements. Giovanni Anselmo used lettuce, wire and granite to create a precarious sculptural arrangement that can survive only as long as the vegetable is regularly replaced. Mr. Kounellis grew cactus in long metal troughs, contrasting the bristling forms with smooth metal surfaces. And in an especially fierce piece, Mr. Zorio pounded rope, coiled to spell "odio" (hate), into a piece of lead, leaving enough to hang the work from the ceiling, as if to demonstrate the enduring strength of the emotion.
The exhibition reminds us that Boetti made paintings from camouflage in 1966, more than a decade before Andy Warhol turned to the motif. It includes startling revelations, like an opulent installation piece by Marisa Merz involving huge coils and tendrils of aluminum hanging from the ceiling (think of Nancy Rubins doing clouds instead of crashed planes). There are also little-known early pieces, like a tall cone that Mario Merz, Ms. Merz's husband, had a basketmaker weave, a predecessor to his more ingratiating glass igloos. There are also relative classics: Boetti's embroidered maps of the world; Mr. Pistoletto's big sphere of weathered newspapers, which seems to have rolled out of one of Kurt Schwitters's Merzbau environments or a painting by Miro; Mr. Kounellis's doorway filled with stones. 
I think reactions to this show can only be mixed. At times you may find yourself trying to stifle the impression that many of the artists are firstborn sons whose mothers viewed their every scribble as an act of genius. There is also the issue of an inescapable Italian elegance, the stylishness that infuses even the most modest or quirky materials; it often seems of a piece with, rather than a reaction against, the glamorous designs of the Italian Miracle. In the show's final gallery, Luciano Fabro's enormous birds' feet, made of carved-stone and silk, might almost be by Ettore Sottsass or Gaetano Pesce.
But the charm, ephemeral beauty and lightness of much of this work also reflects a conscious ambivalence about the act of making permanent art objects. And this ambivalence, transmitted to artists as varied as Sarah Lucas, Thomas Hirschhorn, Maurizio Catellan, Rirkrit Tiravanija and Felix Gonzalez-Torres, may be Arte Povera's greatest legacy.

"Zero to Infinity: Arte Povera, 1962-72" is at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Independence Avenue at Seventh Street SW, Washington, (202) 357-2700, through Jan. 20.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Works by Pier Paolo Calzolari, including his curvaceous frost-covered ladder, in "Zero to Infinity: Arte Povera, 1962-72" at the Hirshhorn. (Lee Stalsworth and Chris Smith/Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Gloom Grows for Japan's Exporters 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
As the big Japanese brand-name manufacturers report their half-year earnings, it is becoming clear that they are bracing for a very tough holiday season.
 Sinking American consumer confidence, rumblings of war in the Middle East and the lingering threat of disruptions from a labor dispute in the ports of the American West Coast are worrying even the most robust of the companies, like Sony and Toyota Motor. Some of the manufacturers have already reduced their earnings expectations, while others are holding their breath. 
 Two of the biggest, Fuji Photo Film and Hitachi, said today that they were sharply lowering their forecasts for the full year despite a profitable showing in the six months ended Sept. 30. Like Sony and Matsushita Electric Industrial earlier this week, they also raised concerns about the faltering rate of growth in their most important foreign market, the United States, and about the cloudy prospects for technology spending. 
Their unease underscores the way much of the fate of Japan's economy rests on the shoulders of American shoppers. If Americans shrug off their losses in the stock market and keep buying video game consoles and minivans, Japan's economy will continue to grow, however limply. But if worries about jobs and battered retirement savings make Americans hesitant to splurge, Japanese exports to the United States will erode further, and the economy will contract.
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is already under pressure to break his pledge to cap the growth of the national debt and agree to approve heavy deficit spending to stimulate the economy. A new recession would redouble that pressure. But even if Mr. Koizumi goes along, it may take months to assemble a big new package of spending, time the economy does not have.
Japan's trade surplus, which grew in the first half of 2002, has already reversed course and started to shrink. Exports had been one of the few bright spots in an otherwise dismal Japanese economy, and exports to America have been the main lifeline for manufacturers. But that rope is fraying, executives say.
"We started sensing something this summer," said Sony's chief financial officer, Teruhisa Tokunaka, "and our people in the U.S. felt that consumer demand would decline there." On Monday, Mr. Tokunaka said the company had cut 100 billion yen ($813 million) off its revenue target for the full fiscal year, which ends March 31. "I hope we don't have to downgrade our earnings again," he said. "It all depends on how we perform in the October-December quarter."
Japanese automakers and electronics manufacturers earn as much as four-fifths of their profits in North America. Some, like Honda Motor, have more sales in America than at home, where consumer spending remains weak.
With their lower forecasts today, Hitachi and Fuji Film joined a growing list of exporters that are scaling back expectations. Though Hitachi made money in the half-year ended Sept. 30 -- a big improvement on a disastrous 2001 -- it cut its forecast for net income in the fiscal year by 40 percent and made similar trims in its outlook for sales and operating profits.
Fuji Film said its profits fell 28 percent in the half-year in yen terms, mainly because of the yen's rise against the dollar over the period. Fuji, which makes about one-fifth of its sales in America, also reduced its profit forecast by 26 percent for the full year.
The drumbeat of downgrades is enervating an already shaky stock market. The main index fell 1.3 percent today and is close to a 19-year low.
Investors worried about economic weakness and unimpressed by the government's latest plan to deal with the country's bad bank loans bid up the prices for government bonds, pushing the yield on the benchmark 10-year bond below 1 percent for the first time in four years.
"Unfortunately, the probability is very high that exports will stop supporting the Japanese economy," said Akio Makabe, an economist at Mizuho Research Institute. "It all depends on the American situation. If the U.S. economy deteriorates, it will be a big problem for Japan."
Japanese companies with plants in the United States also face the job of getting their operations back to normal after West Coast ports were shut down in a labor dispute several weeks ago.
Toyota Motor said this week that the lockout at the ports would wind up costing the company about 10 billion yen ($81 million) this year. Mr. Tokunaka, of Sony, said his company had to resort to air shipments for some goods; he declined to give a figure for the added cost.
The recent weakening of the yen against the dollar -- it is down by almost 5 percent since early September -- helps manufacturers here a bit. But the trend may be halted and its effects neutralized by slowing demand in the United States, analysts said.
Manufacturers would prefer stronger demand to a weaker currency. "I am worried about consumer demand in the U.S. between Thanksgiving and Christmas," said Kunio Nakamura, president of Matsushita Electric, best known for its Panasonic brand. Noting that pressure to cut prices was intensifying, he said, "I wonder how this quarter will turn out."
