GEOGRAPHIC: NEW HAVEN, CT, USA (73%) KASHMIR (92%); CONNECTICUT, USA (73%); JAMMU & KASHMIR, INDIA (72%) PAKISTAN (94%); INDIA (93%); AFGHANISTAN (93%); ASIA (92%); SOUTHERN ASIA (89%); SERBIA & MONTENEGRO (79%); UNITED STATES (73%)

LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2002 



51 of 812 DOCUMENTS


Copyright 2002 The New York Times Company 
 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 72

LENGTH: 3825 words

HEADLINE: Killing Your Friends 

BYLINE:  By Mark Levine; Mark Levine last wrote for the magazine about Bryan Buckley, a director of TV commercials.

 BODY:
To get a primer on endings -- happy endings, wistful endings, big-money endings, long-drawn-out-tear-stained endings -- it might be advisable to stroll right on past Central Perk, the most lucrative fantasy coffee bar in the imaginary West Village, where the ratty velour sofa is always weighted with perky idlers and the latte is poured, heedless of charge, in tureen-size Fiestaware. Because it's clear that, while the end is coming to Central Perk, waiting to be served up in some indeterminate blend of whimpering and banging one Thursday night in the not-too-distant future, those whose job it is to close the shutters from the inside are elsewhere. They -- a team of hard-working, well-paid, stressed-out writers -- are sequestered in a Warner Brothers office building in Burbank, Calif., in a bland conference room whose secrets are guarded with the zeal of national security matters. There they grapple with the question of how, after nine years of pratfalls and clever repartee, the quirky, sexually active, emotionally arrested friends of "Friends," NBC's pre-eminent pop-cultural franchise, are to be frozen into eternal postures of camaraderie or enmity. 
 On the specifics of exit strategy, these writers are mum. They have their reasons. Personally and professionally, they are in no great hurry to skip ahead to this particular finish line, beyond which lies the uncertain and ill-protected lot of ex-employees of a hit show. They may not yet have even determined -- let alone committed to paper -- what lies in store for Central Perk's forever-young clientele. Instead, the writers are standing by while the forces of marketing and promotion whip up a state of sweet and highly rated anticipation. Of course, they are shrewd enough to realize that in their realm there are no endings for the victors, but only a splendidly compensated afterlife in the heights of syndication, en route to a flickering and contented Nick at Nite of the soul. 
 Television, after all, is a world of make-believe contingencies, where meaningful outcomes to life's little crises -- the kinds of outcomes that are notably hard to come by off-screen -- are scripted by committee. It may be that in the instantly recognizable homeroom of youthful loitering that is Central Perk, loopy folk singing is encouraged, and the bonds of quasi kinship can withstand prolonged romantic tribulation, and the regulars are charged with no task more arduous than merely hanging out year after year without any thought of moving on. But in a parallel universe not far away, the clock is ticking -- thumping, practically. 
It's there, on the other side of the set, that Kevin Bright, one fabricator of the soon-to-be-dismantled tableau of friendship-at-all-costs, greets you with a quote. "This is the end -- my only friend, the end,"' he says. "Jim Morrison had it down." Bright, one of three top producers of "Friends," is eating slices of raw halibut from a foam container. It's an hour before "Friends" will begin to tape its 198th, or 20th-to-last, episode, which was shown Oct. 17. The episode count is a significant detail. Syndication deals -- which represent, for Bright and his producing colleagues, the gift that keeps giving -- are usually done in packages of 80 to 100 episodes. And because stations that run loops of old installments rarely purchase more than 200 episodes, it becomes far more difficult for the show that makes more than that number to recoup its production costs. This is a problem for "Friends," with its $7-million-per-episode budget -- $6 million for the salaries of the central cast members -- and it is a predominant, though rarely mentioned, reason that the show is planning to close shop. 
Bright, 47, has been with "Friends" from the outset in 1994. He edits the show and helped design its hip, cluttered look, and he oversees its direction. He has also directed some 40 episodes. Next spring, he will direct its one-hour finale, a show that is likely to be the most-hyped and widely viewed nonsports program of the year. "For a variety of reasons," he claims, somewhat halfheartedly, "it's the right time to end this. As a matter of economics, the show has gotten so expensive to produce that it's not feasible for the network or the studio to keep bringing it back. The cast members want to move on and do something different. And somehow, after Sept. 11 last year, it felt as if an era had ended. It was time for the six friends to grow up out of the age of innocence."
At this point in the season, he is trying hard not to dwell on the ending. He likens the feeling now to the beginning of the last year of high school, and he notes, "I'd be lying if I didn't admit to being scared about what comes next," and when he proposes that "we don't want to tie the show's loose ends up into a tidy package, but we want people to think that the characters will be O.K.," it's hard not to get the sense he might be talking about his own future. 
Most television endings, he reflects, are ignominious affairs, typically imposed on shows with cruel suddenness by failing ratings. This is clearly not the case for "Friends," which finished last season as television's top-rated series. The show's popularity, Bright knows, increases the pressure for a standout ending. By contrast, when he worked on "Veronica's Closet," a middling sitcom with Kirstie Alley that was canceled after three seasons, "nobody really cared what the ending was," Bright says. He was fond of "the idea that for the last episode we would put Veronica and the other main characters on an elevator, have the cable break and plunge them down the shaft. The elevator door would open onto a strange empty space where a bunch of actors from old sitcoms -- Gary Coleman, people like that -- are seated around a card table. The old actors would say to our characters: 'This is the place where we go when it's time. Pull up a seat.'
"Naturally," Bright says, "we didn't do that ending." How did "Veronica's Closet" end?
"I don't remember," he admits.
In the beginning there was a pilot, and it featured these six: Ross, a sensitive-guy paleontologist who has been ditched by his pregnant lesbian wife; his sister, Monica, a fastidious chef who, all appearances to the contrary, is said to have suffered an unsvelte adolescence; Monica's rich-girl high-school pal, Rachel, who dashes into Central Perk in a wedding gown, having fled her appointment at the altar with an orthodontist; Monica's neighbor Joey, a vapid, hunky, aspiring actor; Chandler, Joey's smart-aleck roommate, who works as a data-processing drone; and Phoebe, the dippy vegetarian twin of a character on "Mad About You." The friends were plucked from the chipper, optimistic wing of Gen X: they were as loyal and attractive and well heeled as they were aimless, solipsistic and irony-drenched. 
The series was an instant hit. A long line of television-averse stars, from Susan Sarandon to Brad Pitt, put in guest-starring appearances over the years, but "Friends" never strayed far from its half-dozen core slackers, for whom the writers manufactured enough plot convolutions to exhaust a troupe of roving Shakespearean comedians. The show's most enduring feature has been the wrung-out coupling and uncoupling of Ross and Rachel. Last year's season was driven by the discovery that Ross had impregnated Rachel during a night of wine-sotted nostalgia. Ross and Rachel agreed to a platonic co-parenting arrangement, opening the way for Joey to nurture his own furtive passion for his best friend's lover. Hey, it happens. This year's final season, then, is primarily faced with settling the issue of Rachel's ideal suitor. In addition, it promises to address itself to a crisis of fertility -- that most venerable engine of narrative -- since Monica and Chandler have set themselves to the challenge of conceiving a child of their own, a task they first undertook in a hospital broom closet while waiting for Rachel to deliver.
The "Friends" staff of 13 writers -- eight men, five women, most of them a touch younger than the 30-something characters they write lines for -- showed up for work on the show's final season in mid-June. The grand finale was on everyone's mind. Marta Kauffman and David Crane, who created the series and who remain its lead writers, initiated a discussion of "where we'd like the characters to land," as Kauffman puts it. In short order, an amicable dispute over how to drop the curtain divided the room. "Should they stay in the coffeehouse and be friends forever?" muses Shana Goldberg-Meehan, a 29-year-old executive producer who is in her seventh year of writing for the show, recounting the discussion. "If they keep meeting at Central Perk, won't the audience feel that there's more fun to be had, but that they're missing out on it?" Goldberg-Meehan's boyfriend, Scott Silveri, whom she met when the two were students at Harvard and who is 30 and also an executive producer, counters: "If everybody moves away, it'll be too sad. People will think, This thing we love is totally over. Whatever else it does, the ending has to be funny." The twin perils of sentimentality and incomplete resolution were already apparent. "Viewers are emotionally invested in these characters," Goldberg-Meehan says. "The ending has got to be a little sad." She glances at Silveri, who shakes his shoulder-length hair. "If the final episode is a sobfest, with everybody hugging and saying, 'Oh, my God, I'll miss you so much,' it'll be pretty sickening. We've been funny all these years. We can't just toss it away." 
Kauffman is adamant about one thing: "I want the characters to grow up and be happy. I need to know that they're going to be O.K." Although the writers tend to regard the fictional friends as real people, Kauffman says, no consideration would be given to subjecting them to the kinds of endings that real people regularly experience -- changes that would make for an emphatic and attention-getting, if sour, farewell. "There was a rumor circulating last year that we were going to kill Rachel in childbirth," Goldberg-Meehan recalls. "We got letters from viewers pleading that that not happen. But we'd never do such a thing!" 
So there will be no cancers or bouts of mental illness or stumbles onto the subway tracks or heartbreaking O. Henry reversals of fortune. While the writers value the comic and dramatic possibilities of surprise, they feel their compact with the show's 30 million dedicated fans requires their charmed friends to remain immune from peril. "It would be surprising," Silveri agrees, "to have Monica take a pregnancy test, and the toilet explodes, and she dies. But that's not what we're going for." Crane doesn't even like to joke about such things. "I don't think we want to see the coffeehouse burn down," he tells me, pointedly. "I don't even think we want to see everybody move away." Unlike their counterparts in comic books, the friends will be allowed to grow up; unlike their counterparts in reality, the friends will drift into perpetuity in a manner that will soothe the anxieties of engaged viewers. "It would be depressing to think that they're still acting out the same silly dating stories in their 40's," says Andrew Reich, a 34-year-old executive producer. "But it would also be a bummer to think that they're not going to be friends anymore."
The two looming questions -- Ross and Rachel's relationship, Monica and Chandler's efforts at pregnancy -- await a splashy resolution in the finale. Since the writers know there is overwhelming popular interest in resolving those questions affirmatively, the major challenge they face, as Goldberg-Meehan says, "is to give people what they want, but in a way they don't see coming."
After a day or two back on the job, the writers shifted their attention from endings to the nuts-and-bolts work of writing the season-opening episodes. Endings were allowed to remain an abstraction for the moment. Writing good jokes was a more immediate problem. They filled a board with lists of ideas for plots and subplots, sent off six groups of writers to hammer out drafts of the opening episodes and left the big questions for later. "We don't yet know what the precise ending is going to be," Kauffman says. "I'm not trying to be cagey. We're trying to avoid the ending as long as we can. It's too terrifying." Besides, Kauffman maintains, "I'm not sure I believe in closure -- that everything can be neatly rounded off. Life doesn't work like that. Goodbyes aren't always satisfying. Sometimes you just can't accept loss. Sometimes you've got to go out kicking and screaming. Now," she says, as we part ways, "I've got to go home and cry."
Literary endings offer the exhilaration of a fictional world abiding by orderly rules. A good traditional ending offers symmetry and the consoling thought that the meandering journey has, after all, had a destination. Not least, such an ending provides a model for coping with messy real-life endings. Conversely, an ending that frustrates the desire for closure can seem intolerable, and not just in literature: when this year's All-Star baseball game ended in a 7-7 tie, fans were outraged, and the outcome was cited as evidence of the sport's contempt for its followers. Endings invite an almost ritualistic participation in their heightened emotional states. Non-football fans watch the Super Bowl, and spectators who nap through an opera will stick around for curtain calls, and the final episode of "Friends" can be expected to draw most of its audience from those who are not devotees of the show. NBC, at least, will be counting on a huge turnout, which will generate huge advertising revenues. (The season finale will be an hourlong episode; the network has yet to decide what it will show in the preceding hour.) In 1983, the two-and-a-half-hour final episode of "M*A*S*H," ending on a shot of the main character, Hawkeye Pierce, looking down from a helicopter at rocks arrayed on the ground to spell "Goodbye," was the most-watched show in television history and helped to create the television phenomenon of the highly promoted adieu. It's not mere coincidence that endings are called "payoffs." 
Television shows, though, face particular burdens in bringing themselves to an end. Unlike movies or novels, television series begin with no end in sight and are rarely driven toward a culminating moment. Movies and novels compress the passage of time into packages of consumable length; television series tend to deny the passage of time. The viewer of "Friends" may find himself 100 hours of viewing removed from the show's debut and half a generation older than when Central Perk first opened, but the friends themselves are remarkably the same as they have always been. It turns out that television has a good deal in common with ordinary life: a lot happens, but little changes. 
As a result, most shows that are afforded the opportunity to write their own endings do so in ways that are resoundingly artificial. Some enact the farewell between the series and its viewers: the characters on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" inch across the show's newsroom in a group hug before Mary turns off the lights; Ted Danson's character in "Cheers" throws the barroom set into darkness. Other series force their audiences to wake up to the fact that their experience has been a dream. Did "St. Elsewhere" unfold in the mind of the autistic child of one of the characters? Apparently so. The entire final season of "Roseanne" turned out to be a fiction written by the main character; her husband was actually dead the whole time. Bob Newhart's innkeeper was knocked unconscious and came to in the arms of Suzanne Pleshette, who played the wife in his previous series. "Mad About You" and "The Wonder Years" employed a time-honored escape strategy, offering snapshot glimpses of their characters' futures. Of notable television endings, only "Seinfeld" notoriously refused to give its viewers a dose of nostalgia-producing comfort; the 1998 finale put Jerry and his cronies on trial for bad behavior and brought back a parade of former characters to act as witnesses. Jerry, George, Elaine and Kramer were last seen bickering in a jail cell. 
"Seinfeld" is a cautionary example to the writers of "Friends," who are determined to remain squarely within the bounds of feel-good territory. "The ending of 'Seinfeld' was an insult to the audience," Reich says. "It wasn't funny. 'Friends' would never go for such a self-conscious ending." Adds Ted Cohen, 34, another executive producer, "It tried so hard to defy conventions that it didn't feel like the show." Instead, expect "Friends" to give audiences what Marianna Torgovnick, a professor of English at Duke University and author of "Closure in the Novel," says they most yearn for from endings: "Weddings. Births. Big communal ritualized events. Transition from one stage of life to another. These events correspond to what people do in real life -- they come together at a wedding or a funeral, and then they separate." 
And yet, as Reich acknowledges, television endings, for all their hype, are ephemeral even by the standards of the medium. In the endless replay of syndication, where time is cyclic, not linear, sequence no longer matters. Even if final episodes break into the syndication lineup, the next night, in the drowsy hour after your late local news has ended, you will always find your favorite old shows in media res. "When I get too freaked out about the pressure of writing the finale," Reich says, "I take some comfort from the fact that even if it's not the greatest thing in the world, people will forget about the ending soon enough and still remember the show fondly, as I still think of 'Seinfeld' as an amazing, great show."
The writers are huddled en masse at the foot of the set for the taping of the fourth episode of the final season of "Friends," titled "The One With the Shark." They confer after every take. David Crane tells me, "I try not to play the game of, 'Oh, God, this is the last time we'll do a fourth episode,' but all of us are aware of the emotional ramifications of what it will mean to have no more 'Friends' in our lives."
Like most segments of the show, this one follows three interweaving plots, one of which has Monica paying a surprise visit to Tulsa, where Chandler has been reassigned by his employer. She walks in on him while he is watching pornography and masturbating, and he quickly changes the channel to a nature show. Monica sees this as evidence that Chandler is aroused by sharks. As such, Monica has plenty of opportunity to display the upright indignation that Courteney Cox Arquette has honed over the years. "I caught him molesting himself," she shouts at Rachel. "He was getting off to a shark-attack show." Later she asks Joey, "You don't think sharks are sexy, do you?" Joey dismisses the notion, then pauses and asks, "What was the little mermaid?"
The shark routine nods at the source of television's favorite current in-joke, the Web site called Jump the Shark, which is dedicated to chronicling the downward spiral of once-popular shows. (For the origin of the phrase "jump the shark," see On Language, Page 34.) Most series are in creative death throes for so long, according to Jon Hein, the site's creator, that final episodes tend to be merciful and anticlimactic formalities. "Friends' jumped the shark long ago," he says, "when Ross and Rachel broke up for the third time." (Indeed, on Sept. 22, when "Friends" finally won its first Emmy as Outstanding Comedy Series -- after years of being eclipsed by the more adventuresome "Ally McBeal," the racier "Sex and the City" and the golden-child "Frasier" -- the award had about it the air of a valedictory kiss goodbye to a stalwart, offered in gratitude for longevity and for the economic boost it has given the industry.)
To judge by the reaction of the 300-strong studio audience at the taping, though, there's little evidence that "Friends" is in decline. The audience laps up the snappy dialogue, laughing in all the right places, take after take, and expelling an affectionate sigh when Phoebe is kissed by her guy. I find myself joining in their pleasure -- the pleasure not of ending, but of ongoingness. How, I wonder, can a sitcom possibly come up with a satisfying ending when the best shows are built on familiarity and repetition -- elements that want to deny that endings are the horizon of experience? 
It's comforting to see the actors step into their characters' mannerisms -- to see Ross's hangdog expression and to hear his plaintive tones of appeasement; to see Chandler's self-mocking scowl and Phoebe's spaced-out head-wagging and Joey's puffed-up swagger and the rest. Up close, Central Perk looks exactly as it is supposed to, and its denizens act exactly as they always have, and therein lies the regressive pleasure of visiting an intact universe of likable people exempt from the laws of change. NBC, whose president, Jeff Zucker, has hinted at his interest in prolonging the life of "Friends," will rue the passing of the show, but the network knows that Thursday nights are forever, while first-run sitcoms have mortal life spans; the cast, most of whom have said that they find the subject of endings too much of a downer to talk about, have made it clear that they are eager to pursue careers in film, though surely they know that for every John Travolta, rising to stardom from "Welcome Back, Kotter," there are dozens doomed to linger in uneasy obscure fame as Arnold Horshack or Epstein; and while the creators of "Friends" have made it clear that they are spinoff- and reunion-averse for now, they know too that their moment will be hard to let go of. It doesn't matter how good or bad, funny or sad, poignant or absurd the final episode turns out to be. For an hour in May 2003, it will seem as if all of us are watching it, and immediately afterward we will turn our attention elsewhere. "It's just a TV show," says Matt LeBlanc, who plays Joey, as he pauses between scenes. His tone grows philosophical as he adds, "It'll be sad when it's over, but you gotta move on."
So I try not to read too much into the fact that the episode I'm watching suggests that Phoebe is headed toward a companionable future; or that Joey has returned to his Lothario-like self after last season's wooing of Rachel; or that Monica and Chandler may be Oklahoma-bound. All I can make of the Ross-and-Rachel intrigue is that it has, for this episode at least, been tactfully delayed. (Indeed, the first month of the season has teased viewers with the possibility that Ross and Rachel will not ride off together into the cathode-ray-streaked sunset, after all.) Much to the audience's disappointment, in fact, Jennifer Aniston does not even appear on the set. She's off filming a movie with Jim Carrey, and her few lines are read by a stand-in. Friends, it seems, grow up and move away. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Famous last words: In the series finale of "Cheers" (1993), the bar closed; on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" (1977), the characters got fired; and on "M*A*S*H" (1983), the war ended. The creators of "Friends" haven't yet decided what will happen, but "want people to think that the characters will be O.K." (Mark J. Terrill/Associated Press; Everett Collection; 20th Century Fox/Everett Collection) Drawing (Mark Stutzman)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: LOITERING & VAGRANCY (76%); MEDIA SYNDICATION (69%); NATIONAL SECURITY (52%) TELEVISION 

PERSON: LEVINE, MARK 

GEOGRAPHIC: CALIFORNIA, USA (71%) UNITED STATES (71%)

TITLE: FRIENDS (TV PROGRAM) 

LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2002 



52 of 812 DOCUMENTS


Copyright 2002 The New York Times Company 
 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 41

LENGTH: 2918 words

HEADLINE: The Lasting Picture Show 

BYLINE:  By A.O. Scott; A.O. Scott is a film critic for The New York Times and a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
The movie industry, and the movie audience along with it, began this year in a state of post-9/11 jumpiness. Release dates were postponed, shots of the Manhattan skyline were digitally reconfigured and studio executives scrambled to anticipate the entertainment needs of a traumatized public. Would we be drawn to war pictures or to romantic comedies? Would we want movies that confronted the unnerving state of the world or movies that helped us to escape it? As it turns out, the answer is yes, and no, and all of the above: we just want to go to the movies. 
 In the midst of geopolitical instability and general economic trouble, the box office has once again demolished previous records, by wider margins than ever, racking up increases of 10, 15, 30 percent each weekend over the same weekend the year before and shattering records we never knew existed. ("Sweet Home Alabama," a gauzy vehicle for Reese Witherspoon, was the highest September opening ever, taking in more than $37 million its first weekend out.) But as the studios have flourished, their sometimes rivalrous corporate siblings, the record labels and television networks, have been floundering, throwing good money after bad in a battle for audience shares that seem to be inexorably splintering and diminishing. The recording industry's scramble to protect its copyrights from digital piracy (i.e., from music fans) coincides with a period of creative stagnation as well as financial contraction, prompting every desperate trick in the playbook. And the networks have suffered a similar slackness, rallying behind each flimsy trend only to skittishly abandon it moments later, all the while defending their fragile oligopoly against TiVo and the expansion of original programming on cable. 
 The impulse to go to the movies is at once simpler and more complicated than anyone could predict. Going to the movies is an act that takes many forms. We go to the movies in adolescent packs, on timid first dates, with minivan-loads of children or busloads of friends from the senior center and also alone, on foot, in the middle of the day. We talk back to the characters on the screen, or shush the people behind us who are doing it; we walk out in disgust, or come back the next night, or buy each successive DVD release of something we didn't much care for in the first place. We weep, we rage, we snore, we aspirate our popcorn in bursts of helpless laughter. The varieties of cinematic experience -- the means by which we sate our apparently limitless appetite for narrative, sensation, color, feeling, sound -- are in a way more lasting, more definitive and always more unpredictable than anything we see on the screen. Sometimes, after all, the most relentless hype fails to excite the audience and the surest publicity calculations go awry. Sometimes pictures succeed financially without generating enthusiasm, and we line up out of a mixture of weary habit and bored curiosity. Sometimes movies are loved not widely but intensely, so that devotion to them seems like a secret password offering entry into an exalted coterie. Sometimes we can't remember the end of a movie 20 minutes after leaving it; sometimes it troubles our sleep for weeks afterward. Regardless, we keep going. Why?
The simplest answer may be that a movie ticket remains a bargain, at least relative to other entertainment options, so that habitual moviegoing can be sustained by allowances and minimum-wage summer jobs. But the inexpensiveness of the movies is, more deeply, the symbol of their accessibility, of their unique promise to be available to everyone -- to effect the distillation of reality into image and the transubstantiation of fantasy into fact. And this promise, like everything else about the movies, is double-edged -- offering an image of utopian communal pleasure and, at the same time, of atomization and disaffection. The essential paradox of moviegoing is that it is at once collective and radically solitary, an amalgam of the cohesive social ritual of theatergoing and the individualist reverie of novel-reading. The movies offer visions of a better world even as they are symptoms of everything wrong with this one. As such, moviegoing is perhaps still, in spite of the competing claims of newer media, the exemplary modern cultural activity. It splices together individualism and mass culture -- the insistence on the particularity of identity and the standardization of experience, the line at the box office and the solitary dreaming in the dark -- like a serendipitous art-house double feature programmed by a deity with perverse tastes and an odd sense of humor.
The conventional wisdom of the past decade has been that we are becoming a republic of niche markets and specialized tastes. For Webby utopians this cultural fracturing represented a kind of liberation -- the rise of decentralized, willed microcommunities that would bind the like-minded together in defiance of the boundaries of region, class or background. But at the same time, worriers of various ideological colorations have lamented the loss of common cultural reference points and experiences. The movies, it is true, have not entirely escaped this Balkanization, but they supply the most cogent available evidence that it has been overstated and misconstrued. It is not just that more people are going to the movies more frequently and that there are more movies to see (somewhere around 400 will open commercially in New York by the end of this year) -- but also that, much of the time, we are all going to the same movie. With some regularity, viewers emerge from their subcultural niches to converge on a picture that somehow transcends the differences that otherwise preoccupy them. Sometimes this convergence is almost entirely predictable, as in the case of "Spider-Man" or "Austin Powers in Goldmember," and sometimes entirely unexpected, like the runaway success of "My Big Fat Greek Wedding." Sometimes the movies in question are terrible, sometimes they're not bad and occasionally they're even really good. 
The past year has witnessed the emergence of a new critical parlor game, devoted to determining not the best movie of all time, but the best movie year of all time. This is a curious pursuit, since the year of a picture's release usually represents an accident of the calendar rather than the mystical intentions of the zeitgeist. The longtime consensus best year ever, 1939, gave us "The Wizard of Oz," "Ninotchka," "Gone With the Wind." Among the leading revisionist candidates are 1962 ("Lawrence of Arabia," "The Manchurian Candidate," "Knife in the Water") and 1971 ("The Last Picture Show," "Murmur of the Heart," "McCabe and Mrs. Miller"). The purpose of the arguments, in any case, is to diminish the present by comparison with the past and make us feel bad about the sorry state of current movie culture.
Needless to say, there is always plenty to feel bad about. If we like, we can choose to remember this year as the year of "Men in Black II," "Scooby-Doo" and "Attack of the Clones" -- some of the worst movies ever, and symptoms of the hype, cynicism and planned obsolescence that rule American commercial cinema. It will also, however, be the year of "The Fast Runner" ("Atanarjuat"), "About Schmidt," "Talk to Her," "Far From Heaven" and a dozen more -- many of them products of that same infernal studio machinery -- that may well, in the long run, be some of the best. A year, in other words, pretty much like any other, and of course completely without precedent or portent.
Which should come as no surprise. The history of the movies is a saga of wild, headlong innovation and expansion -- from arcade amusement to global empire, from a silent train lurching into a monochromatic station to Dolby-enhanced, computer-generated spaceship battles, all in the space of little more than a century -- and also, simultaneously, a chronicle of dwindling and decline. Among modern art forms, perhaps only the novel has enjoyed so long and fruitful a death as the movies, whose every golden age has been shadowed by catastrophe. To hear some purists tell it, the first disaster was the advent of sound, which forever destroyed the aesthetic purity of the image. Soon thereafter, in 1934, the adoption of the censorious Production Code squelched the emerging daring and vitality of American cinema. The code's repeal, more than three decades later, would in turn strip Hollywood of the decorum and sophistication that had defined its classic era and deliver it up to the corrosive energies of nihilism, vulgarity and literal-mindedness. The studio system sacrificed the vision of directors and the liberty of stars to the vulgar whims of moguls -- until the system's collapse made matters worse. In the meantime, the movies had been beset by plagues and scourges -- by the Justice Department, whose antitrust division helped wreck the studio system with the Paramount consent decree of 1948, by McCarthyism and worst of all, by television. Then, in the 70's and after, came the swallowing up of the old studios into conglomerates, the rise of the blockbuster mentality, the home-video revolution, the Internet. . . . There has scarcely been a moment of film history not tinged by nostalgia and regret, by a sense of lost possibility and squandered magic.
But alongside this dark, Spenglerian narrative is a bright, triumphalist saga, a fitting succession of happy endings and new beginnings. In the depths of the Depression, the medium established itself as the exemplary democratic amusement, and in every succeeding era it has found new ways of living up to its promise and expanding its domain. After heroic service during wartime, both in and out of uniform, Hollywood, bolstered by an infusion of emigre talent, answered the confusing postwar reality with the giddy splash of Technicolor musicals and the anxious shadows of film noir. At around the same time, American audiences became aware of the rejuvenation of European and Asian national cinemas (and of their tantalizing exemption from the prudish code). And television, cinema's vulgar stepchild, proved to be a training ground for new talent, starting the careers of Robert Altman, Clint Eastwood and Sidney Lumet, among others. Critics, first in France and then in the United States, discovered that those taken-for-granted society comedies, horse operas, crime stories and tear-jerkers were works of art after all, and a newly refined (if at times also snooty) film culture took root in American cities and college towns. It would blossom in the New Hollywood of the 70's, an era of visionary artistry and social engagement, as well as of drugs, sexual promiscuity and wild budgetary excess. The lions of that age -- Coppola, Altman, Scorsese, Woody Allen -- inspired the indie boom of the 1990's, when every film-school dropout with a credit card was suddenly an auteur in the making.
Recently, the cycles of this contradictory history have been replicated in microcosm each year. In the late spring and early summer, if you listen carefully, you can hear the critics grumbling that this is the worst year ever, that even last year at this time there was at least "Erin Brockovich" or "Bridget Jones's Diary" to make their (our) dreary lives more bearable. And then, six months later, as the deadlines for 10-best lists and awards ballots draw near and the studios clog the marketplace with their top-shelf Oscar-worthy goods, the same critics marvel at all the quality and variety on display.
Even the more sober assessments of the business pages yield their share of confusion. Not long ago -- last year or thereabouts -- motion pictures seemed to be nearing the brink of terminal irrelevance. Exhibitors toppled into bankruptcy, labor trouble threatened, production and publicity costs spiraled out of control. The impending conversion to digital technology, moreover, was about to relegate cinema -- along with print, comic opera and fresco painting -- to a state of quaint obsolescence, a hobby for antiquarians. At about the same time, of course, an epidemic of mergers heralded a glittering new age of synergy, in which the studios would serve as the principal content factories in vast and vari-egated networks of distribution, and movies would remain standard-bearers in the global media empire. Every year, meanwhile, the box-office take grows fatter. To paraphrase something Ronald Colman might have said back in 1935 (unless it was Dirk Bogarde in the 1958 remake): it's always the best of times and the worst of times.
The only way to understand the present moment would be to catapult ourselves, with the help of Michael J. Fox's DeLorean (or Haley Joel Osment's robot submarine) into the future we are now blindly constructing. The portents are not easy to read, partly because movies, driven like the rest of the capitalist economy by the twin imperatives of relentless technological innovation and market expansion, are constantly changing, with the goal of producing more of the same. The pictures get bigger and bigger, but also smaller and smaller. The more expensive their production and marketing become, the more safe and trivial they seem to be. It seems inarguable that large-scale commercial filmmaking has on the whole abandoned the craft of storytelling or the discipline of realism in favor of formula, fantasy and therapy -- well-designed, disposable consumer goods that can be shipped and sold around the globe. It will continue to do so and reap very happy returns. 
The standoff between cynicism and idealism -- Is the consent of the audience manufactured or freely given? Are we prisoners of Hollywood or its eager constituents? -- resembles a medieval theological dispute about predestination and free will. Neither position, by itself, offers a satisfying account of why we go to the movies, or of how they work their magic on us. The most alarmist view of the current state of movies is a variant of antiglobalist ideology: the hegemony of Hollywood is a baleful force, wiping out local traditions and absorbing everyone in a standardized, soulless universalism. But to emphasize only this aspect of the current situation is to miss the abundant signs of a contrary trend -- the flowering, around the world (including Hollywood), of a cinema that is full of surprise, provocation and insight, even if it often announces itself modestly in the midst of the surrounding noise. The same movements of capital that have threatened, and in some cases crushed, state-supported national film industries have also opened new possibilities for financing production. Money flows from the countries of the European Union, and from the Hollywood studios themselves, to support filmmakers in Iran, Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa. The idea that Hollywood's drive to hegemony is implacable and inevitable -- a constant worry in Paris and Rome -- might be met with raised eyebrows in Bombay or Seoul. Globalization, in other words, has two faces -- or rather, as many faces as can fit on the screen, and there are more screens than ever before.
A few years ago, around the time my own moviegoing became a full-time job, two giant multiplexes, with a mind-boggling total of 38 screens, opened on opposite sides of 42nd Street. The larger of the two, the AMC Empire 25, turns out to be part of a vast indoor leisure complex. You enter, in the usual way, via marquee and velvet ropes, but leave on a system of escalators that deposit you in the middle of a food court, surrounded by chain restaurants offering a panoply of mediocrity analogous to what often plays on the screens. Descending toward the sidewalk into the twilight, overhearing the idle, occasionally heated postmovie chatter, you feel you could be anywhere: like airports, modern movie theaters provide atmospheres of bland indistinguishability at once reassuring and profoundly alienating.
But you are, nonetheless, in Times Square, an undesignated landmark in the history of American moviegoing. Once you could have prowled the grind houses and discovered the as yet unrecognized masterpieces of the old studio system and the rough gems of Italian neorealism, as well as a cornucopia of cheap, flavorsome trash (some of which, in hindsight, would turn out to be art). And as you wander past Madame Tussaud's wax museum, with its movie-star replicas in the window, toward the ad-saturated 3-D science-fiction video game at the meeting point of Broadway and Seventh, you may feel a twinge of nostalgia for the old days -- for the smoky black-and-white world that still flickers occasionally on television and at Film Forum downtown. You are in a thoroughly branded environment, a dystopian corporate sublime rather like the shopping mall Tom Cruise hurtles through in "Minority Report." The billboards and plasma-screen building facades don't read your mind so much as empty it out, alienating you from your most basic sense of time, space and self. But there is nonetheless some pleasure in being swallowed up in these images, and also some pleasure in resisting them -- pleasures not unlike those you seek out at the multiplex. You look around, at the crowds hurrying past to line up for the 8 o'clock show, and you realize that your thoughts are a voice-over and that your mental lens has zoomed upward in a dizzying crane shot, to take in the milling, oblivious mob, in which you are at once a tiny speck and the center of attention -- camera, star and audience, just like in the movies. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: They found it at the movies: Cinema combines communal pleasure and solitary reverie. (Vincent Laforet)

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1422 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
Helping Workers Make Down Payments on Homes

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
FOR more than three years, Pamela and Bartholomew Isaac and their three young children lived in a cramped apartment in Amityville not far from Our Lady of Consolation Geriatric Care Center in West Islip, where Mrs. Isaac works as a dietary aide. 
 Last year, the Isaacs began looking to buy a house in the vicinity, but one of their main concerns was that they would not have enough money for a down payment. 
 Shortly after they began their search, however, Mrs. Isaac found that the geriatric center had just started a program, in partnership with federal and state agencies, that would assist employees with a down payment. Mrs. Isaac applied for financing through the program, and it provided her with most of the $10,000 down payment needed to buy a two-story, four-bedroom Cape Cod house in Amityville for $150,000. 
Monthly payments on the 30-year mortgage on the 1,303-square-foot house, including insurance and $5,348 in annual taxes, will be approximately $900, only about $50 a month more than the rent the family had been paying for three years.
The Isaacs are one of the first families on Long Island to benefit from the employer-assisted housing program -- called the Long Island Home Works Partnership -- whose goal is to help companies recruit and keep high-quality employees. Under the initial phase of the program, public money has been set aside that is expected to help in the sale of more than 50 houses. 
Before receiving assistance through the program, employees must meet certain criteria, including income ceilings, and attend counseling sessions "to help them know what they can afford and to protect them from going to predatory lenders," said Peter J. Elkowitz Jr., executive vice president of the Long Island Housing Partnership.
Fannie Mae, which is the nation's largest source of financing for home mortgages, introduced the program to Long Island three years ago and offers the technical advice and legal documents necessary to help the employers set up their loans.
"The program was set up to address the major barriers to affordable housing on Long Island:" down payment costs and a lack of knowledge about financial management, said Jacqueline O'Garrow, a senior deputy director at Fannie Mae's New York office. "If you can combine amassing funds and education through counseling, you can create a nice benefit that will attract employees."
More such programs are needed, said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a Commack-based business group. "Once the national economy gains momentum, we won't be able to achieve our potential in terms of future growth unless we keep our homegrown workers and attract those from the outside," she said. "This program will at least help those who have limited funds for a down payment."
The partnership currently includes 18 employers; Nassau and Suffolk Counties; the towns of Islip, Babylon and Huntington; the Suffolk County Community Development Consortium; the Long Island Association; Fannie Mae; the Long Island Housing Partnership; and the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation.
Banks that work with the program, which often involves lower down payments than are generally required, include Citibank, Astoria Federal Savings, HSBC, Fleet, J. P. Morgan Chase and the Bank of New York. 
Under the program, state and federal agencies match the funds of a participating employer toward the employee's down payment. The match may be as much as $3,000 from each government. The employee pays the balance of the down payment after the employer and the other agencies have made their loans. 
In addition, the state, whose program applies only to previously owned houses, provides up to $7,000 more for necessary repairs.
The towns and counties administer the federal money, and the Long Island Housing Partnership, which offers counseling to the prospective home buyers, administers the state funds.
The Isaacs provided more than $2,500 for their down payment from their own funds. They received $2,500 each from Mrs. Isaac's employer, the federal government and the state, which also provided $6,950 for repairs.
J. P. Morgan Chase, which holds the Isaacs' mortgage, provided $4,000 toward the closing through its closing cost assistance program, said Wesley A. Wainwright, a senior vice president for Chase's community development group. The program absorbs up to $4,000 to be used either for a down payment or closing costs. 
"We have found that people are asset-starved although they may have the income that could hold a mortgage," Mr. Wainwright said.
The state has $500,000 set aside for the program, according to Stephen J. Hunt, president of the Affordable Housing Corporation. The money is to go toward 30 homes in Suffolk and 20 in Nassau. 
Currently, there are five employers in Nassau and 13 in Suffolk participating in the program, according to Carol J. Woods, a project manager for the Long Island Housing Partnership. These include the Bay Shore School District, five facilities in the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System and seven under Catholic Health Services of Long Island, a nonprofit health service Computer Associates was a major employer instrumental in starting the program, she said.
Seventeen families have received federal funds through the program since it began, according to Joseph Sanseverino, Suffolk's community development director. State funds just recently became available, and the Isaacs are the first to get money from both public sources.
"We are so pleased that the Isaacs had the opportunity to buy their first home and be able to raise their family on Long Island," said Sister Audrey Harsen, president of Our Lady of Consolation, which is a member of Catholic Health Services. The geriatric center has pledged $10,000 annually to the program, she said.
According to Charles N. Guder, Catholic Health Services' director of benefits, the member organizations have agreed to "put out $2,000 to $3,000 for each grant to an employee in good standing that agrees to stay with the system for four years." 
To receive public funds, employees must agree to receive financial counseling, purchase a home within Nassau or Suffolk and secure a mortgage from a recognized lending institution. 
THE state and federal payments are considered deferred-payment interest-free loans that are to be repaid only if the home is sold within a certain period of time -- 5 years for the federal loan and 10 for the state. The loans are forgiven if the homeowner remains in the house for the prescribed period.
The appraised value of the house to be purchased can range as high as $259,350. 
There are two income categories for participating families. Under the first, a family of four whose income is no more than $66,400, which is 80 percent of the median income in Nassau and Suffolk, may apply for both state and federal funds. 
A second category, for those making 100 percent of the median income, applies only to state aid. The second category was set up "because many employees were over the 80 percent criteria yet were not wealthy enough to go out and buy a home," Mr. Elkowitz said.
"The main profession that the housing partnership assists with is the medical profession, such as nursing assistants, dietitians and custodians," Mr. Elkowitz said. Therefore, the majority of the housing required is in the vicinity of major hospitals, he said, as in Port Jefferson, a village with two hospitals and only eight miles away from Stony Brook University Hospital. 
Relatively modest houses with three bedrooms in the vicinity of the three hospitals range from $219,990 to $489,990 in Port Jefferson Station and average about $300,000 in Stony Brook, according to Ray Manzoni, of Manzoni Real Estate in Mount Sinai.
Theresa Sabatino, Babylon's director of community development, said many of the town's residents, like Mrs. Isaac, work at one of the three hospitals or numerous nursing homes in that South Shore area. 
The health industry is the fastest growing on Long Island, Dr. Kamer said. According to statistics by the State Labor Department for the 12 months that ended in September, Long Island had a net gain of only 600 jobs, she said. "In looking at the configuration, 2,600 of those jobs were in the health industry and 2,500 in social services, both of which offset the losses in manufacturing, transportation, communications and wholesale trade."
Examples of annual salaries in these industries are $31,601 for a mental health counselor, $17,466 for a home health aide and $31,423 for a dietetic technician.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pamela and Bartholomew Isaac and their children, Daniel, Shaniqua and Sarah, at their home in Amityville. (Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: REAL ESTATE (90%); CHILDREN (89%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (89%); MORTGAGE BANKING & FINANCE (88%); FAMILY (78%); GERIATRICS (77%); AGING (77%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (76%); MORTGAGE LOANS (76%); PUBLIC FINANCE (76%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (75%); LOW COST HOUSING SCHEMES (75%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (75%); RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY (73%); EXECUTIVES (68%); PREDATORY LENDING (68%) HOUSING; LABOR; MORTGAGES 

COMPANY: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSOCIATION (FANNIE MAE) (66%)

ORGANIZATION: FANNIE MAE 

INDUSTRY: NAICS522292 REAL ESTATE CREDIT (66%); SIC6162 MORTGAGE BANKERS & LOAN CORRESPONDENTS (66%)

PERSON: PAQUETTE, CAROLE 

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, USA (91%) UNITED STATES (91%) LONG ISLAND (NY); NEW YORK STATE
