 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
Correction Appended 
 Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 2A; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 8921 words

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY MOVIES; 
Santa, James Bond and Other Old Friends

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES (Compiled with the assistance of SUZANNE O'CONNOR) 

 BODY:
 November

BESOTTED -- Holly Angell Hardman wrote, directed and stars in a fantasy about a sorceress who arrives in a Cape Cod fishing hamlet intending to cast love spells on the villagers. The ensemble cast includes Amy Wright, Liam Waite, Susan Gibney, Jim Chiros and Richard Cox. Opened Friday.

DAUGHTER FROM DANANG -- In 1975, when Operation Babylift transported Vietnamese and Amerasian children from Saigon to families in the United States, one little girl separated from her mother was Mai Thi Hiep. A little more than 20 years later, the filmmakers introduce Heidi Bub, a young wife and mother who lives in Pulaski, Tenn. She is Mai Thi Hiep, and she has decided to return to Vietnam to see her mother. It's not exactly the joyous reunion she'd hoped for. The filmmakers, Gail Dolgin and Vicente Franco, won the grand jury prize for documentaries at the Sundance Film Festival. Opened Friday.

I SPY -- It doesn't have much to do with the old television series with Bill Cosby and Robert Culp. But like their predecessors, Eddie Murphy and Owen Wilson are a black man and a white man playing partners in espionage, and they use a similar cover story when they're making their clandestine international trips: Mr. Murphy is a professional boxer and Mr. Wilson poses as his agent. (Mr. Culp and Mr. Cosby were tennis champion and trainer.) Their assignment in this film is to find a missing stealth fighter. Betty Thomas, who's done a little of everything in the last few years ("28 Days," "The Brady Bunch Movie," "Dr. Dolittle"), directed. Opened Friday.

LOVE IN THE TIME OF MONEY -- "La Ronde" set in the 90's. Nine New Yorkers, including a prostitute, a bisexual art collector, a lovesick student and a lonely telephone psychic, are unknowingly linked -- despite supposed class barriers -- by love, business or both. The stars include Steve Buscemi, Jill Hennessy, Malcolm Gets, Carol Kane and Rosario Dawson. Written and directed by Peter Mattei, who was a writer for the children's series "Clarissa Explains It All." Opened Friday.

THE SANTA CLAUSE 2 -- Scott Calvin (Tim Allen) has been on the job as Santa for eight Christmases now, and he's doing a bang-up job, but this year his own son has turned up on the "naughty list." Not only that, but Scott has to marry soon. Action must be taken. In the process, there are lots of elves and general holiday magic. Eric Lloyd returns as Scott's son, Wendy Crewson as Scott's ex-wife and Judge Reinhold as her new husband. Michael Lembeck, who has not done a feature film before but directed on almost every sitcom in the 90's, directed. Opened Friday.

SANTA VS. THE SNOWMAN -- It's animated, it's 3-D and it's on giant Imax screens. John A. Davis, who did "Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius," directed this story of a lonely snowman who builds up a lot of resentment toward Santa Claus (voice of Jonathan Winters) and decides to do something about it. He declares war. But surely he'll learn some important lessons about self-esteem by the end. Ben Stein does the voice of the tour guide elf and Victoria Jackson the communications elf. Opened Friday.

TULLY -- Good brother, bad brother, imperfect dad. The theme of Hillary Birmingham's first film echoes films like "East of Eden," "A River Runs Through It" and "Hud." The older son, Tully, is played by Anson Mount, whom New York theatergoers may remember as Joshua, the Jesus figure, in Terrence McNally's much-talked-about "Corpus Christi." Bob Burrus plays the father; Glenn Fitzgerald is Earl, the shy brother; and Julianne Nicholson is Earl's friend. But Tully likes her too. Opened Friday.

THE WEIGHT OF WATER -- Josh Lucas has been pretty irresistible on screen lately (see his scenes with Reese Witherspoon in "Sweet Home Alabama"), and it's happening again in this parallel-centuries drama based on Anita Shreve's novel of the same name. A photographer (Catherine McCormack) and her husband (Sean Penn), a poet, travel to New Hampshire, where she's investigating a double ax murder from 1873. She begins to suspect that her husband is having an affair with the girlfriend (Elizabeth Hurley) of his brother (Mr. Lucas). Directed by Kathryn Bigelow, whose past work includes "Strange Days" and "K-19: The Widowmaker." Opened Friday.

FEMME FATALE -- Brian De Palma's latest is the story of a jewel thief (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos) who gives up her life of crime and reinvents herself as a respectable married lady. (Well, more than respectable. She's an ambassador's wife.) Then a former paparazzo (Antonio Banderas) blows her cover, which means it's time to move on to another identity. With Peter Coyote, Gregg Henry and Rie Rasmussen. Wednesday. A related article is on Page 13.

ONE GIRL AGAINST THE MAFIA -- An hourlong 1998 documentary about an Italian teenager who, after her father, a Mafioso, was killed, tossed aside the mob's code of silence and gave evidence to a judge. Directed by Marco Amenta. Shown with "Strange Fruit" (below). Wednesday.

SATURDAY NIGHT FEVER -- It has been 25 years since 23-year-old John Travolta strutted down the streets of Bay Ridge and instantly turned into the movie sex symbol of the disco era. There's a new print for this anniversary release, all the better to see those dance floor moves. The film was based on a New York magazine article by Nik Cohn about generally aimless young people whose lives revolved around Saturday nights at the club, which offered them their only chance for recognition. They do it all to the tune of Bee Gees songs like "How Deep Is Your Love?" With Karen Lynn Gorney and Donna Pescow. Directed by John Badham. Wednesday.

STRANGE FRUIT -- An hourlong film about the anti-lynching song that Billie Holiday made famous. Directed by Joel Katz. Shown with "One Girl Against the Mafia." Wednesday.

8 MILE -- Eminem makes his feature-film debut in just the sort of role you'd expect. He's a white teenager living on the poor side of Detroit with minimal prospects and hip-hop dreams. Kim Basinger plays his mother. The cast also includes Brittany Murphy, Mekhi Phifer, Eugene Byrd and Taryn Manning. Directed by Curtis Hanson, who's had some major successes in recent years ("Wonder Boys," "L.A. Confidential"). Friday.

ETOILES: DANCERS OF THE PARIS OPERA BALLET -- From Nils Tavernier (the 37-year-old son of Bertrand Tavernier), a backstage documentary about one corps de ballet. The film includes conversations with teachers, students, managers and stars; performance clips; and still photographs by Vincent Tessler. Variety called it "a touching group portrait of very dedicated, essentially lonely people." Friday.

FAR FROM HEAVEN -- The first time Todd Haynes directed Julianne Moore, they gave us "Safe" (1995), the story of a fragile California woman who seemed to be allergic to life. In this new film, Ms. Moore plays a buttoned-up 1950's Connecticut housewife whose husband is going through something he won't share with her. Ms. Moore won the best actress award for this role at the Venice International Film Festival last August. Dennis Quaid plays the troubled husband, and Dennis Haysbert is the gardener, to whom Ms. Moore's character turns for more than sympathy. The film is Mr. Haynes's tribute to Douglas Sirk, who did glamorous tear-jerkers like "Imitation of Life" and "Written on the Wind. Friday. A related article is on Page 22.

GOD IS GREAT, I'M NOT -- A romantic comedy starring Audrey Tautou, of "Amelie," as a fashion model looking for meaning in her life. She meets a nice Jewish man and decides she should convert to Judaism. Friday.

HUSH -- A contemporary Japanese comedy about a homosexual couple and the lonely young woman who tries to become a part of their lives. From the director Hashiguchi Ryosuke ("Like Grains of Sand"). Friday.

INTERVIEW WITH THE ASSASSIN -- Talk about a scoop. An unemployed news cameraman glimpses journalistic heaven when his older neighbor confesses that he has a secret: he was the gunman on the grassy knoll. Raymond J. Barry and Dylan Haggerty star. Neil Burger, whose resume until now consisted of a Yale degree and some one-minute spots for MTV, directed. Friday.

THE PHANTOM OF LIBERTY -- A new print of Luis Bunuel's outrageous 1974 collection of comedy vignettes, including one in which parents discuss their concern about their missing child, who is sitting right in front of them. Vincent Canby's review in The New York Times called the film brilliant, anarchic and "surrealism at its best." With Michel Piccoli, Monica Vitti and Jean-Claude Brialy. Friday.

THE RISING PLACE -- It's hard to decide which is the more dangerous idea for a young white woman in the Mississippi Delta in 1940 -- to have a soldier's child out of wedlock or to have a black best friend. Emily (Laurel Holloman) goes for broke and does both. The cast includes Elise Neal (as the best friend), Frances Fisher, Frances Sternhagen, Billy Campbell, S. Epatha Merkerson, Gary Cole, Alice Drummond and Tess Harper. Written and directed by Tom Rice. Friday.

ARARAT -- Charles Aznavour, Eric Bogosian, Christopher Plummer, Brent Carver and David Alpay in the story of an American family getting in touch with its Turkish past. The film within a film is a drama about the Armenian holocaust in the 1920's. Directed by Atom Egoyan, whose most recent works include "The Sweet Hereafter" and "Felicia's Journey." Nov. 15.

EL CRIMEN DEL PADRE AMARO -- Shades of "The Thorn Birds." In this drama, which has become the biggest box office hit in the history of Mexican film (not to mention the subject of serious controversy), a handsome, highly temptable young priest moves to a new post, encounters a teenage girl who develops a mad crush on him and soon has to admit the feeling is mutual. Then he's made aware of the power that the Roman Catholic Church can offer him. Gael Garcia Bernal ("Y Tu Mama Tambien") stars as the priest, with Ana Claudia Talancon as his love interest. Sancho Gracia plays an older priest who has drug connections and is having a longterm romantic affair of his own. Directed by Carlos Carrera. Nov. 15.

HALF PAST DEAD -- In Steven Seagal's newest action thriller, a criminal tries to get inside a prison rather than out of one. It seems a death row inmate buried about $200 million worth of gold on the inside. The cast also includes Ja Rule, Nia Peeples and Morris Chestnut. Directed by Don Michael Paul. Nov. 15.

HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS -- Last November, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" earned more than $90 million on its opening weekend. So naturally everyone is back for the second Potter movie. That includes the director, Chris Columbus; the screenwriter, Steven Kloves; and the distinguished cast headed by Richard Harris (who died Oct. 25), Maggie Smith, Robbie Coltrane and Daniel Radcliffe as Harry, the cutest school-age wizard in modern literature. There's a major new character, too: the Hogwarts school's new professor of defense against the dark arts (Kenneth Branagh). It's time for fall semester at Hogwarts, but someone doesn't want Harry to go back to school and has been keeping his friends' letters from him all summer. It is highly likely that new terrors await Harry and friends. Nov. 15.

HELL HOUSE -- For those who find standard Halloween behavior (pumpkin carving, trick or treat, dressing up like movie monsters and superheroes) too tame, there is George Ratliff's documentary about an unusual Pentecostal church in Texas. The church's annual haunted house doesn't bother with ghosts and witches and skeletons; it sets out to scare young people with the horrors of AIDS, abortion and school shootings. Nov. 15.

REVOLUTION NO. 9 -- A disturbed young man (Michael Risley) believes he's receiving messages from a commercial for a perfume called Rev 9. With Spalding Gray as a television director and Adrienne Shelly as the director's fiancee. Directed by Tim McCann, whose first film was "Desolation Angels," a drama about date-rape revenge. Nov. 15.

SINGIN' IN THE RAIN -- A half-century has passed since moviegoers first saw Gene Kelly ecstatically dancing down a Hollywood backlot version of a New York street in a downpour. The film is about a silent-movie studio in the 20's trying to make the transition to talkies. Debbie Reynolds, who was 20 at the time, is the aspiring, fresh-faced young actress who gets her big break. Kelly is her leading man, and Donald O'Connor is his partner and pal. Betty Comden and Adolph Green (who died Oct. 24) wrote the screenplay. Kelly and the great Stanley Donen were co-directors. There's a new print and the film is being screened in Dolby Digital Stereo for the first time. Nov. 15. A related article is on Page 11.

STANDING IN THE SHADOWS OF MOTOWN -- All about the Funk Brothers. They may not be world famous, but they have reportedly been heard on more No. 1 records than any other group, including the Beatles and the Rolling Stones. The Funks were sidemen to the Supremes, Marvin Gaye, Stevie Wonder and other Motown stars. Paul Justman directed. Nov. 15.

THE WAY HOME -- From Korea, the story of an obnoxious 7-year-old boy (Yoo Seung Ho) from the city who's sent to live with his grandmother (Kim Eul Boon) in a village far from everything. He's disrespectful and selfish, he throws food, and he steals his grandmother's things to buy batteries for his Game Boy. But there's a good chance Granny will be able to turn him around. Lee Jeong Hyang, whose earlier films included "Art Museum by the Zoo" and "A Place for Eve," directed. Nov. 15.

THE BURNING WALL -- German politics and the role of dissidents worldwide in the 20th century. Hava Kohav Beller directed. Nov. 20.

GOOD HOUSEKEEPING -- The filmmakers are promoting this comic drama as "the white-trash 'War of the Roses.' " It's the story of Don (Bob Jay Mills), a downscale, beer-guzzling husband who collects action figures, and Donatella (Petra Western), his Italian immigrant wife, who is having a nervous breakdown. Even her lover (Tacey Adams) doesn't understand her. Things get really ugly when Don divides the house in two by building a wall. Frank Novak, a first-timer, directed. Nov. 20.

BEYOND THE VALLEY OF THE DOLLS -- Call it a cult film or the nightmare that won't go away for Roger Ebert, the film critic, who wrote the screenplay. There's no real connection between this 1970 film and "Valley of the Dolls" -- either the novel or the 1967 movie -- except that women become addicted to liquor, drugs and sex. This is the story of an all-women pop group who move to Hollywood for fame and find substance abuse. The film was directed by Russ Meyer, the soft-pornography mogul who also did "Vixen!," "Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!" and "Mondo Topless." Nov. 22.

DIE ANOTHER DAY -- Forty years have passed since James Bond, secret agent 007, made his first appearance on a movie screen. The actor was the innately debonair Sean Connery and the film was "Dr. No." This is already Pierce Brosnan's fourth outing as Bond, and all the usual elements are in place. The luckiest, for the filmmakers, is that this is Halle Berry's first film since she won the best actress Oscar for "Monster's Ball." It seems unlikely that this Bond girl will take a lot of guff. The villain is a megalomaniac environmentalist (Toby Stephens, who was in "Possession" and "Space Cowboys"). The primary glamorous locales are Korea, Hong Kong, England and Cuba. There's a high-speed hovercraft chase through a minefield in the DMZ. Directed by Lee Tamahori, the New Zealand-born filmmaker who did "Once Were Warriors." With Judi Dench, Rick Yune and John Cleese. Nov. 22.

THE EMPEROR'S CLUB -- Kevin Kline stars as a dedicated classics teacher at a boy's prep school. Emile Hirsch, of "The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys," plays an arrogant United States senator's son who is trouble from the day he walks in. His influence turns his serious, well-behaved classmates into a herd of hooligans -- until the teacher finally gets through to him. This is a lot less like "Dead Poets Society" than it sounds. The film, based on Ethan Canin's short story "The Palace Thief" and directed by Michael Hoffman, is about the question of who molds a young person's character and whether some people are moldable at all. Edward Herrmann plays the headmaster and Rob Morrow is a fellow teacher with something up his sleeve. Nov. 22.

FRIDAY AFTER NEXT -- The sequel to "Friday" and "Next Friday" stars Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Marcus Raboy is the new director. Our heroes are back in the old neighborhood, working as security guards. It's Christmas, and a ghetto Santa steals all the presents. Nov. 22.

O FANTASMA -- A young trash collector in Lisbon with a varied sex life meets the macho motorcyclist of his dreams. The rest of the film is about his obsession with him. Joao Pedro Rodrigues is the first-time director. Nov. 22.

PERSONAL VELOCITY -- Rebecca Miller (daughter of Arthur Miller) directed and wrote this three-vignette film, based on her own short stories. All three heroines are trying to escape from controlling men in their lives. Kyra Sedgwick takes her three children and runs away from her abusive husband. Parker Posey is an adulterous cookbook editor. Fairuza Balk has a near-death experience and, on her way home to Mom, picks up a hitchhiker who's been beaten. The film won a cinematography award (for Ellen Kuras) at the Sundance Film Festival, a neat feat since it was done in digital video. Nov. 22.

POWER AND TERROR: NOAM CHOMSKY IN OUR TIMES -- America doesn't have many celebrity intellectuals, so Mr. Chomsky, 73, linguist, political philosopher and general dissident, certainly deserves a documentary. This one is based on a series of talks in California and New York last spring and a long interview at his office in Cambridge, Mass. If one particular message comes across, it is Mr. Chomsky's call for the United States not to operate with a double standard globally, to hold ourselves to the moral standards we demand in others and to a single definition of what constitutes terrorism. The film, produced in Japan, was directed by John Junkerman. Nov. 22.

THE QUIET AMERICAN -- They loved it at the Toronto Film Festival, but are most moviegoers in 2002 open to a drama with such unpleasant things to say about American foreign policy? Graham Greene's novel was published in 1955, just a few years after the French Indochinese War in which it was set. Joseph L. Mankiewicz made a 1958 film of it, with Audie Murphy and Michael Redgrave. Now Michael Caine takes on the role of the British journalist working in Saigon and Brendan Fraser plays the title role, a young idealist (but not innocent) abroad. Phillip Noyce, who must have felt like a change of pace after "The Bone Collector," directed. Nov. 22.

SMOKERS ONLY -- An Argentine film about a suicidal woman and a male prostitute who meet at an A.T.M. Cecilia Bengolea and Leonardo Brezicki star. Veronica Chen wrote and directed. Nov. 22.

TALK TO HER -- Elvis Mitchell, a New York Times film critic, could barely stop praising Pedro Almodovar's new picture when it was the closing-night feature at the New York Film Festival last month. Mr. Mitchell called it "a tragic comedy about need, its liberating and shackling power" and observed that everything in the film "falls into place with almost surreal delicacy." Two men meet at a clinic and become close friends, possibly because they are caring for their respective loves, both of whom are in comas. Nov. 22.

ADAM SANDLER'S EIGHT CRAZY NIGHTS -- Some people already think of Adam Sandler as a cartoon, so there's a certain logic to his doing an animated film. And he did write and perform "The Hannukah Song," so it seems appropriate that he has done what must be one of the few movies billed as a Hanukkah musical. Mr. Sandler does the voices of an elderly basketball coach and a marketing man for the New York Knicks, who strike up an unusual partnership. Other celebrity voices include those of Tyra Banks, Jon Lovitz, Kevin Nealon and Rob Schneider. Directed by Seth Kearsley, whose resume includes the animated sitcom "Dilbert." Nov. 27.

EXTREME OPS -- You never know what's going to happen when you fly off to a glamorous film shoot in the Austrian Alps. One group of daredevil extreme skiers accidentally photographs a Serbian war criminal (Klaus Lowitsch) hiding in the mountains, and he's not happy about it. Luckily the heroes are in excellent shape to ski and snowboard for their lives. The cast includes Devon Sawa, Bridgette Wilson-Sampras, Rupert Graves and Rufus Sewell. Directed by Christian Duguay, who did the 1999 television movie "Joan of Arc." Nov. 27.

SOLARIS -- George Clooney in outer space. Steven Soderbergh, who has been on a roll ("Ocean's Eleven," "Traffic," "Erin Brockovich") if you don't count the baffled reactions to "Full Frontal," wrote and directed this sci-fi drama about a space-station crew reacting strangely to a nearby planet. It is based on the novel by Stanislaw Lem, as was the 1972 film of the same name by Andrei Tarkovsky. Among other things, they're seeing dead people -- but usually dead people they like. Mr. Clooney's co-stars include Natascha McElhone and Jeremy Davies. Nov. 27.

TREASURE PLANET -- Disney in outer space. The studio turns Robert Louis Stevenson's classic novel "Treasure Island" into an animated film set on a spaceship. Jim Hawkins is still a cabin boy, but Long John Silver is a cyborg. The ship's adventures include encounters with supernovas and black holes. Directed by Ron Clements and John Musker. With the voices of Martin Short, David Hyde Pierce, Emma Thompson, Brian Murray and Joseph Gordon-Levitt. Nov. 27.

WES CRAVEN PRESENTS: THEY -- When a movie starts out with a perfectly happy young woman like Julia (Laura Regan), something is sure to go seriously, quickly wrong. For Julia, it's the return of the night terrors she experienced as a child. Now they're back, other people are getting them and -- gasp! -- they could be real. Luckily, Julia is studying psychology. Ms. Regan's co-stars include Marc Blucas and Ethan Embry. The film was written by Brendan William Hood and directed by Robert Harmon. Wes who? Nov. 27.

DEAD OR ALIVE: FINAL -- The year is 2346, and in Yokohama humans and androids live peacefully side by side. But this is a dictatorship, and humans are forced to use birth control. Someone has to do something to bring down Woo (Richard Cheung), and luckily there are a couple of action heroes (Riki Takeuchi and Show Aikawa) available. Directed by the veteran filmmaker Takashi Miike. Nov. 29.

RABBIT-PROOF FENCE -- Phillip Noyce again, this time directing a drama based on a real program that was in effect in Australia for decades. Beginning in 1905, Aboriginal girls were taken from their homes and families in the outback, shipped to faraway Australian cities and trained to be servants. This is the story, based on Doris Pilkington Garimara's book, of three girls who fought back and set out to escape, walking the 1,500 miles home. Kenneth Branagh stars, along with Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury and Laura Monaghan. The government-sanctioned kidnappings continued until 1971. Nov. 29.

INTERSTATE 60 -- Bob Gale's film, about two friends on a strange road trip, is a blend of comedy, drama and adventure with just a touch of sci-fi. The only problem is that the guys' chosen route, Interstate 60, doesn't exist. But it's rife with social symbolism. Gary Oldman, Kurt Russell, Michael J. Fox, Chris Cooper and James Marsden star. Mr. Gale, whose past films include "Back to the Future" and "Bordello of Blood," was, for years, Robert Zemeckis's writing partner. November.

December

MASSOUD, THE AFGHAN -- Ahmed Shah Massoud, a charming 48-year-old ex-architect who turned his attentions to politics and war, was the leader of the Northern Alliance, the Afghan opposition to the Taliban. He was assassinated, by killers masquerading as journalists, two days before Sept. 11, 2001. Christophe de Ponfilly, a French journalist, had been working on this biographical documentary for some 16 years. Dec. 4.

ADAPTATION -- Nothing makes most writers happier than writing about themselves. Charlie Kaufman is a successful screenwriter whose other new film is "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind." Susan Orlean is a successful author whose books include "The Orchid Thief," a nonfiction best seller. This film, which is about Mr. Kaufman's attempts to adapt Ms. Orlean's book for the screen, is written by Mr. Kaufman. Nicolas Cage stars as Mr. Kaufman (most writers also enjoy being played by movie stars) and the incomparable Meryl Streep as Ms. Orlean. It's probably an excellent sign that the director is Spike Jonze, who also directed Mr. Kaufman's "Being John Malkovich." Chris Cooper plays the book's title character. John Cusack, Catherine Keener and the director David O. Russell make appearances as themselves. Dec. 6.

ANALYZE THAT -- A lot has happened since Paul Vitti and Dr. Ben Sobel last met (three years ago, in "Analyze This"). Vitti (Robert De Niro), the mob boss, appears to have gone insane in Sing-Sing. He needs his old psychiatrist, Dr. Sobel (Billy Crystal), and the F.B.I. wouldn't mind if Sobel could tell them whether Vitti is faking it. So they release Vitti into Sobel's custody -- as patient and house guest. You can imagine how the good doctor's wife (Lisa Kudrow) feels about that. Harold Ramis is back as director, but his team of screenwriters for the original film included the playwright Kenneth Lonergan. This time Mr. Ramis and Peter Steinfeld did the honors. Dec. 6. A related article is on Page 3.

BLACKBOARDS -- This is a drama about two unemployed teachers traveling along the Iran-Iraq border, with blackboards strapped to their backs, hoping to find students. If the students can't pay, they'll accept food and shelter instead. Unfortunately, very few people are interested in learning to read or write. But the blackboards come in very handy as stretchers. Directed by Samira Makhmalbaf ("The Apple"), daughter of one of Iran's best-known directors, Mohsen Makhmalbaf ("Kandahar"). Dec. 6.

EMPIRE -- John Leguizamo stars as a drug dealer determined to go straight. So he leaves the South Bronx for Wall Street, but soon learns that his new career has its ugly side too. Directed by Franc. Reyes, a former musician and choreographer. Dec. 6.

EQUILIBRIUM -- Christian Bale and Emily Watson star in a futuristic drama set in a world where the penalty for emotion is death. The benefit of this is that there's no more war. The problem is that all things that might evoke emotion -- including art, music and poetry -- are forbidden. But one day the man in charge (Mr. Bale) misses his dose of Prozium, gets a taste of feelings and decides to change the world. With Angus MacFadyen and Taye Diggs. Written and directed by Kurt Wimmer, who was also a co-writer of "The Recruit." Dec. 6.

KAANTE -- A Hindi film inspired by Quentin Tarantino's "Reservoir Dogs" and made with an American crew. Amitabh Bachchan, the Paul Newman of Bollywood, stars as one of six complete strangers who team up to commit the perfect crime. When it turns out that one of the six is an undercover cop, things get ugly. The cast also includes Sanjay Dutt, Sunil Shetty and Kumar Gaurav. Sanjay Gupta directed. Dec. 6.

RUSSIAN ARK -- An unusual tour of the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, Russia, with a 19th-century diplomat as guide -- through the museum and through Russian and European history. The gimmick (or technological tour de force, depending on how you look at it) is that the whole thing was filmed in one uninterrupted shot. Alexander Sokurov directed. Dec. 6. A related article is on Page 6.

ABOUT SCHMIDT -- Maybe Jack Nicholson isn't the first actor you'd think of to play a retired, widowed insurance man from Omaha whose idea of a wild adventure is to get into the Winnebago and drive to his daughter's wedding. But Mr. Nicholson has pulled it off. When this drama had its premiere as the opening-night selection of the New York Film Festival in September, Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, called the role "this great actor's least flamboyant performance," one that expressed "a sorrowful awareness of human complexity whose emotional depth matches anything he has done in the movies before." This bittersweet film, based on a novel by Louis Begley, is directed by Alexander Payne, whose earlier, highly distinctive films were "Citizen Ruth" and "Election." Hope Davis plays Mr. Nicholson's daughter and Dermot Mulroney her fiance. Kathy Bates is the fiance's oversexed mother, who really enjoys her hot tub. Dec. 13.

EVELYN -- Desmond Doyle is nothing like James Bond. Pierce Brosnan plays Desmond, an Irish father of three whose cheating wife has just abandoned the whole family. Because Desmond is unemployed, his children are taken away from him, and this drama, set in the 1950's, is about his struggle to get them back. His co-stars include Alan Bates (as his lawyer), Julianna Margulies, Aidan Quinn, Stephen Rea and Sophie Vavasseur (as the title character, Desmond's daughter). Directed by Bruce Beresford, who is best known for "Driving Miss Daisy" and "Breaker Morant." Dec. 13.

THE HOT CHICK -- The latest body-swapping comedy. A mean but popular high school girl -- the head cheerleader, in fact -- wakes up in the body of a 30-year-old man (Rob Schneider). Chances are she'll learn to be kinder to her fellow humans. With Anna Faris, Matthew Lawrence, Rachel McAdams and Eric Christian Olsen. Mr. Schneider's most recent starring roles were in "Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo" and "The Animal." Directed by Tom Brady, who directed "The Animal" and has a real guy's-guy TV resume ("Men Behaving Badly," "Home Improvement," "Sports Night"). Dec. 13.

INTACTO -- Some people have all the luck. And in the world of this Spanish thriller directed by Juan Carlos Fresnadillo, that's literally true. Which wouldn't be so terrible except, as it turns out, the lucky ones stay that way by stealing other people's good fortune. Finally one of the hard-luck cases decides to fight back and chooses as his target a man who just survived a plane crash in which everybody else died. The imposing Max von Sydow stars, with Leonardo Sbaraglia and Eusebio Poncela. Dec. 13.

MAID IN MANHATTAN -- Ralph Fiennes and Jennifer Lopez in a romance that's part "My Fair Lady," part "Pretty Woman." He's a golden-boy politician staying at a very nice hotel. She's a maid at the hotel, a single mom from the Bronx, but he mistakes her for a rich guest and asks her out. This relationship can't go beyond tonight, she tells him. He gives her that sexy Fiennes smile and explains, "Then you should have worn a different dress." Wayne Wang ("Smoke," "The Joy Luck Club," "Anywhere but Here") directed. Dec. 13. A related article is on Page 1.

STAR TREK NEMESIS -- Data, the android, has a twin and Captain Picard, the human, has a clone, which needs his blood. The cast of television's "Star Trek: The Next Generation" is together again, for the fourth time on the big screen, on a diplomatic mission to the Romulans' planet. Earth is on the verge of being destroyed, but then isn't it always? With Patrick Stewart, Jonathan Frakes, Brent Spiner, LeVar Burton, Michael Dorn, Gates McFadden and Marina Sirtis. Directed by Stuart Baird, who began his career as an editor on films like "Superman," "Maverick," "Lethal Weapon" and "Tommy." Dec. 13.

DEVILS ON THE DOORSTEP -- A wartime comedy about two Japanese prisoners in a tiny Chinese village. Directed by Jiang Wen, who also did "In the Heat of the Sun." Dec. 18.

THE LORD OF THE RINGS: THE TWO TOWERS -- Back to Middle-earth, for the second film of Peter Jackson's Tolkien trilogy. Frodo (Elijah Wood) and Sam (Sean Astin) are still on the road to Mordor, on their way to destroy the one true ring. It goes without saying that the whole cast is back, because Mr. Jackson just went ahead and made all three films at once. It was a bit of a risk, but the first part, "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Rings," made a bundle of money, and this one probably will too. With Ian McKellen as Gandalf and Cate Blanchett as queen of the elves. Dec. 18.

ANTWONE FISHER -- It's the sort of thing you wouldn't believe if you saw it in a TV movie. A security guard who works at a movie studio writes a screenplay and asks a big star to look at it. And the movie actually gets made. It happened to Antwone Fisher with a screenplay about his past as a sailor with a violence problem trying to overcome a brutal childhood. Denzel Washington directed the film and appears in it. Mr. Fisher is played by Derek Luke. Dec. 20. A related article is on Page 13.

GANGS OF NEW YORK -- Leonardo DiCaprio, directed by Martin Scorsese. Mr. DiCaprio plays Amsterdam Vallon, a hoodlum in mid-19th-century New York. And that was not a tranquil time: the usual corruption and turmoil were stirred further by war. (Historians say the 1863 Civil War draft riots were the largest uprising in the city's history.) Vallon is fresh out of prison and eager to get even with his father's killer, Bill the Butcher (Daniel Day-Lewis). This all takes place in Five Points, the city's most dangerous neighborhood at the time. The screenwriting team is first-rate: Steven Zaillian, Kenneth Lonergan and Jay Cocks. The cast also includes Cameron Diaz, John C. Reilly and Jim Broadbent (as Boss Tweed). Moviegoers have been waiting for this one a long time, and Miramax rescheduled it again recently to avoid conflict with Mr. DiCaprio's other holiday film, DreamWorks' "Catch Me if You Can." Dec. 20.

MORVERN CALLAR -- It all starts when a supermarket clerk (Samantha Morton) wakes up Christmas morning to find that her boyfriend has committed suicide. Showing resiliency and a talent for opportunism, she takes his A.T.M. card and his unpublished novel (after putting her name on it) and goes to Spain. It's a drama from the young Scottish filmmaker Lynne Ramsay, known for her film "Ratcatcher," about coming of age during a garbage strike in Glasgow. Ms. Ramsay has also won two jury prizes at Cannes for her short films. Dec. 20.

NARC -- When it was shown at the Sundance Film Festival in January, Elvis Mitchell, writing in The New York Times, described it as a compelling police thriller with "the velocity of a hot slug from the barrel of a gun." The film, written and directed by Joe Carnahan ("Blood, Guts, Bullets and Octane"), is heavily influenced by Quentin Tarantino, particularly his "Reservoir Dogs." Ray Liotta stars as a cop investigating his ex-partner's death, and Jason Patric is a suspended narcotics officer. With Busta Rhymes and Chi McBride. Dec. 20.

THE 25TH HOUR -- Spike Lee's latest stars Edward Norton as a drug dealer during his last two days of freedom before going to prison for seven years. Mr. Lee's last feature film was about a modern-day minstrel show ("Bamboozled"). With Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rosario Dawson and Anna Paquin. Based on a novel by the screenwriter, David Benioff. Dec. 20.

TWO WEEKS NOTICE -- Hugh Grant and Sandra Bullock in a romantic comedy is a screen partnership that has to be given a try. It could be a delightful trip back to 1930's screwball comedy. Or a visit to perkiness hell. Mr. Grant plays a multimillionaire and Ms. Bullock is his lawyer, but he's so helpless he asks her to pick out his neckties. Finally she's had enough and quits, but agrees to find her replacement (Alicia Witt, who was the younger daughter on the sitcom "Cybill"). Mark Feuerstein is Ms. Bullock's character's boyfriend. Written and directed by Marc Lawrence, whose last two screenplays were less than stellar ("Miss Congeniality" and the Steve Martin-Goldie Hawn remake of "The Out-of-Towners"). This is Mr. Lawrence's directorial debut. Dec. 20. A related article is on Page 14.

THE WILD THORNBERRYS MOVIE -- Eliza Thornberry, an animated 12-year-old who can talk to and understand animals, has been the star of her own Nickelodeon series since 1998. This is her first big-screen appearance, although "Rugrats Meets the Thornberrys" is already scheduled for 2003. Eliza (the voice of Lacey Chabert from "Party of Five"); her parents, who are nature-documentary filmmakers; and her best friend, Darwin the chimpanzee, have to deal with poachers in the African jungle. Other celebrity voices include those of Rupert Everett, Marisa Tomei, Tim Curry, Brenda Blethyn, Lynn Redgrave and Obba Babatunde. Directed by Jeff McGrath and Cathy Malkasian. Dec. 20.

BLIND SPOT: HITLER'S SECRETARY -- It isn't every day you hear from someone who was with Hitler in his bunker at the end. In 1942, Traudl Junge was a young German woman looking for work when she was offered employment as one of the Fuhrer's secretaries. She was just too curious to refuse, she tells this documentary's directors, Andre Heller and Othmar Schmiderer. When the film was shown at the New York Film Festival this year, no one mistook it for a technical marvel, but critics acknowledged its enormous power. Elvis Mitchell, writing in The New York Times, said that its strength was Ms. Junge's "plain-spoken quality about being so close to ultimate evil." And it's true, she says, that Hitler was crazy about his dog. (Ms. Junge died earlier this year at 82 after a long battle with cancer.) Dec. 25.

CATCH ME IF YOU CAN -- Steven Spielberg directs Leonardo DiCaprio. And it's a true story about a remarkable con man. If you had seen Frank Abagnale Jr. at an airport back in the Sinatra-Playboy-swinging-bachelor days, handsome and authoritative in his pilot's uniform, surrounded by pretty young flight attendants, you might have felt a pang of envy. But Mr. Abagnale wasn't a pilot. He wasn't a doctor either, or a college professor, but he managed to pass himself off in both those professions, too, while writing $2.5 million worth of bad checks. Actually, Frank was a high school student. Tom Hanks is the F.B.I. agent determined to apprehend him. Christopher Walken is Frank's supportive father. The real Mr. Abagnale recently wrote his second book. Dec. 25.

THE LION KING -- Same lions, same story, bigger screen. When this Disney animated film had its premiere in 1994, Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, described it as "visually enchanting." She also wrote that it had "the feeling of a clever, predictable product." Well, it sold. Now the story of a royal lion cub who runs away from his homeland after his father's death is being released in a large-screen format. With the voices of James Earl Jones (the king), Jeremy Irons (the king's evil brother), Jonathan Taylor Thomas and Matthew Broderick (Simba, the heir apparent), Nathan Lane as a smart-aleck meerkat and Ernie Sabella as the warthog. Dec. 25.

PINOCCHIO -- Four years have passed since American moviegoers discovered Roberto Benigni in his Oscar-winning film, "Life Is Beautiful," a comedy about a World War II death camp. Now he turns to a less sensitive subject, Carlo Collodi's fairy tale about the little wooden puppet who longs to become a real boy. The problem is that Pinocchio is a chronic liar and falls in with bad companions (donkey boys). Mr. Benigni directed, wrote the script (with Vincenzo Cerami) and stars as Pinocchio. (He cast adults in all the other children's roles, just for balance.) Carlo Giuffre plays Geppetto, the lonely old puppet maker who would love to be a single dad. Nicoletta Braschi, Mr. Benigni's wife (and his co-star in "Life Is Beautiful"), plays the Blue Fairy. We can only hope she'll come through earlier than she did for Haley Joel Osment in "A.I." Dec. 25. A related article is on Page 3.

CHICAGO -- So Bebe Neuwirth and Ann Reinking aren't good enough for Hollywood? They knocked the socks off the theater critics and audiences six years ago in the Broadway revival of the deliciously dark Kander and Ebb musical about women behind bars and the tabloids that write about them. Now Catherine Zeta-Jones is Velma Kelley and Renee Zellweger is Roxie Hart, murderers competing for all that tabloid publicity. James Naughton's role as Billy Flynn, a slick lawyer who knows a thing or two about razzle-dazzle, has gone to Richard Gere. Queen Latifah plays the gruff prison matron, John C. Reilly is Roxie's meek husband and Christine Baranski is the newspaperwoman Mary Sunshine (a role played onstage by a large man in drag). Rob Marshall, who did the inspired 1999 television version of "Annie," directed. Dec 27.

CONFESSIONS OF A DANGEROUS MIND -- The bizarre story of Chuck Barris, former producer of "The Dating Game" and producer and host of "The Gong Show." Sam Rockwell plays Mr. Barris, who declared in a 1984 memoir that he had lived a double life as a C.I.A. agent. George Clooney makes his directorial debut and also plays a C.I.A. recruiter. With Drew Barrymore and Julia Roberts. Written by Charlie Kaufman. Dec. 27.

THE HOURS -- Finally, Michael Cunningham's breathtaking Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about Virginia Woolf and two women who identify with her comes to the screen. Meryl Streep stars as a contemporary New Yorker watching a close friend (Ed Harris) die of AIDS, Julianne Moore is a 1950's wife and mother who isn't sure she's in the right job, and Nicole Kidman is Woolf herself, working on her novel "Mrs. Dalloway." Stephen Daldry, who did 'Billy Elliot," directed. The screenplay is by the playwright David Hare. The cast also includes Claire Danes, Toni Collette, Jeff Daniels, Stephen Dillane, Eileen Atkins, Allison Janney, Miranda Richardson and John C. Reilly. Dec. 27. A related article is on Page 1.

MAX -- Max Rothman (John Cusack) was an artist before the Great War. Now, in 1918, he's back in Munich and he has lost an arm, so he has to devise a new career. At a gallery he opens, he meets another aspiring artist suffering from what-do-I-do-with-my-life anxiety. His name is Adolf Hitler, and he's played by Noah Taylor, who made such an impression six years ago as the young David Helfgott in "Shine." The brave director, daring to suggest that Hitler may not have always been a complete monster, is Menno Meyjes, the Dutch screenwriter who wrote "The Color Purple." Molly Parker plays the title character's wife; Leelee Sobieski is his mistress. Dec. 27.

NICHOLAS NICKLEBY -- Douglas McGrath, who gave us the elegant 1996 film of Jane Austen's "Emma," with Gwyneth Paltrow, turns his attentions to Dickens. The title character (Charlie Hunnam, currently stalking Katie Holmes in Stephen Gaghan's "Abandon") is a boy forced into reduced circumstances after his father's death. His mother takes the family to London to seek help, but Nicholas is sent away to Dotheboys Hall, a school that's more like a prison run by Wackford Squeers (Jim Broadbent), a headmaster who's more like a warden. Luckily, Nicholas finds a friend. The impressive supporting cast includes Christopher Plummer, Jamie Bell, Tom Courtenay, Timothy Spall, Anne Hathaway, Nathan Lane, Barry Humphries (in Dame Edna mode) and Alan Cumming. Dec. 27.

THE PIANIST -- Roman Polanski is back in a big way. He returned to his native Poland to make this very personal Holocaust drama, and it won the top prize, the Palme d'Or, at the Cannes Film Festival this year. He has already called it "the most important film in my career." Adrien Brody plays Wladyslaw Szpilman, a musician who managed to survive World War II by hiding in and around the Warsaw ghetto. Mr. Polanski himself escaped the Kracow ghetto at the age of 7. Ronald Harwood ("One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich") wrote the screenplay, based on Szpilman's book. With Thomas Kretschmann, Frank Finlay and Maureen Lipman. Dec. 27. A related article is on Page 6.

SONNY -- Nicolas Cage makes his directorial debut in a drama set in 1980's New Orleans. James Franco (who was so great at playing James Dean on TNT that he may be typecast forever) stars as a young man home after his military service and determined not to fall back into his old life. That consisted of being the star attraction at his mother's brothel. With Brenda Blethyn, Harry Dean Stanton and Mena Suvari. Dec. 27.

LOVE, LIZA -- Gordy Hoffman wrote this screenplay for Philip Seymour Hoffman, his brother, and it won the Waldo Salt screenwriting award at the Sundance Film Festival. Mr. Hoffman, the actor, stars as a man whose wife has committed suicide; he deals with it by developing an addiction to sniffing gasoline. He turns to his mother-in-law (Kathy Bates) for support, but nothing can make him open and read his wife's suicide note. Directed by Todd Louiso. Dec. 30.

January

BLUE COLLAR COMEDY TOUR -- Jeff Foxworthy, who made his name by telling audiences "You might be a redneck if" you had certain habits, like putting the new television set on top of the old one, is probably the best-known comedian in this concert film. Other working-class stand-ups on the tour include Bill Engvall, Ron White and Larry the Cable Guy. C. B. Harding directed. Jan. 10.

DRUMLINE -- Nick Cannon, who has his own Nickelodeon television series, stars as a Harlem drummer who finds himself in a marching band at a Southern university. With Orlando Jones as his teacher and Zoe Saldana as his girlfriend. Charles Stone directed. Jan. 10.

P.S. YOUR CAT IS DEAD -- It's about time somebody made a film of James Kirkwood's very black comedy about a man whose life is falling apart. His career is crashing, his girlfriend is leaving him, his cat is in the hospital and he's alone on New Year's Eve. Then a gay burglar pays a visit. Steve Guttenberg directed and stars as the unlucky protagonist. Lombardo Boyar, a newcomer, plays the burglar. The cast also includes Shirley Knight, Tom Wright, Cynthia Watros and A. J. Benza. The novel was published in 1972 and turned into a play that ran both on and off Broadway. Kirkwood died in 1989, best known at that point for having been co-writer of the book for "A Chorus Line." Jan. 10.

THE SETTLERS -- From Israel, a documentary about seven Jewish families in Tel Rumeida, a hillside settlement in Hebron. Mostly they go about their daily lives, trying to pretend their Arab neighbors aren't really there and trying to ignore the military presence that is all around them. Directed by Ruth Walk. Jan. 15.

CITY OF GOD -- This drama was a huge hit in Brazil when it opened in late summer. It's the story of two boys growing up in the dangerous Ciudade de Deus housing project in Rio de Janeiro. One overcomes his background and becomes a photographer. The other doesn't and becomes a drug dealer. With Matheus Nachtergaele, Alexandre Rodrigues and Seu Jorge. Directed by Katia Lund and Fernando Meirelles. Jan. 17.

DIVINE INTERVENTION -- Israeli soldiers doing Busby Berkeley dance routines? A Palestinian turning herself into Wonder Woman? Elia Suleiman's unexpected comedy about the struggle in the occupied territories offers those sights and other examples of absurdity and surrealism in the middle of bitter reality. It won the jury prize at the Cannes Film Festival. Jan. 17.

A GUY THING -- Let's say an engaged young man (Jason Lee) wakes up the morning after his bachelor party to find himself in bed with a beautiful stranger (Julia Stiles). Well, he vaguely remembers she was one of the party's dancing girls, wearing a grass skirt and a floral-lei bra. She also turns out to be the cousin of his fiancee (Selma Blair). His desperate attempts to keep the secret (although, as the audience learns, "nothing happened") constitute the plot of this romantic comedy, directed by Chris Koch, who did the egregious "Snow Day." One of the screenwriters is Greg Glienna, who was a co-writer of "Meet the Parents." With James Brolin and Julie Hagerty. Jan. 17.

KANGAROO JACK -- Two Brooklyn pals take on the job of delivering some mob money to Australia. Unfortunately a kangaroo runs away with it. Jerry O'Connell and Anthony Anderson star as the inept deliverymen; David McNally directed. The cast also includes Christopher Walken and Dyan Cannon. Jan. 17.

KIRA'S REASON: A LOVE STORY -- When this Danish film was shown at the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art earlier this year, Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, called it "a disturbing, somewhat repellent portrait" of an unhappy young wife who suffers from extreme mood swings. Kira (Stine Stengade) comes home after a stay at a mental institution early in the film, and she and her husband (Lars Mikkelsen), a successful builder, try to reconstruct their life. Directed by Ole Christian Madsen. Jan. 17.

NATIONAL SECURITY -- Martin Lawrence plays a hostile security guard and Steve Zahn plays a cop who's done him wrong. Directed by Dennis Dugan, who did "Happy Gilmore," "Big Daddy" and "Saving Silverman." Jan. 17.

SIN EATER -- Heath Ledger as a conflicted young priest who travels to Rome to investigate the death of his mentor. The strange thing is that the body was covered in arcane religious symbols. The likeliest suspect is a "sin eater," an ancient figure who absolves unforgivable sins, killing the sinner in the process and handily allowing great evil to go unpunished. (That would explain a lot.) Written and directed by Brian Helgeland, a co-writer of "L.A. Confidential," who also directed Mr. Ledger in "A Knight's Tale." With Mark Addy, Shannyn Sossamon (who was also in "A Knight's Tale") and Peter Weller. Jan 17. A related article is on Page 14.

CHAOS -- Coline Serreau, who directed the original, Cesar-winning "Three Men and a Cradle," gives us a mix of melodrama and screwball comedy. Catherine Frot and Vincent Lindon play a Parisian couple who, on their way to a dinner party, see a young prostitute (Rachida Brakni) being beaten by three men. When the men actually smash the young woman's face into the couple's windshield, the husband rolls up the windows and drives away. The wife, who doesn't think that was very nice, locates the prostitute, nurses her back to health and re-evaluates her own life. Meanwhile, back home, both the husband and their teenage son (Aurelien Wiik) are behaving badly. In France, the film made an overnight star of Ms. Brakni, 25, who won the Cesar for best young actress. Jan 29.

GARAGE DAYS -- The hopes and dreams of a garage band in Australia. With Kick Gurry and Maya Stange. Directed by Alex Proyas, who has gone for darker topics in the past ("The Crow," for instance). Jan. 29.

I'LL BE THERE -- A burned-out 80's rock star gets a chance for a fresh start when he learns he has a teenage daughter from a long-ago fling. The musician is played by Craig Ferguson, who also directed. The daughter is played by Charlotte Church (yes, the young soprano). Jan. 31.

LAWLESS HEART -- A gay restaurateur's death affects a whole circle of people. Bill Nighy and Douglas Henshall star. Written and directed by Neil Hunter and Tom Hunsinger, whose first film project was "Boyfriends," about seven gay men on a weekend at the beach. Jan. 31.

LOST IN LA MANCHA -- This probably would have been just another "Making of" documentary -- if Terry Gilliam's $32 million "Adventures of Don Quixote," with Johnny Depp as the windmill-tilting protagonist, had ever made it to the screen. Instead the production, based in Madrid, was one of those ill-fated projects in which everything went wrong, from interpersonal relationships to the weather. Keith Fulton and Louis Pepe directed. Their previous collaboration, also about the making of a Gilliam film, was "The Hamster Factor and Other Tales of 12 Monkeys." Jan. 31.

THE RECRUIT -- Colin Farrell as a C.I.A. agent whose mentor (Al Pacino) tells him there is a mole in the agency and assigns him the job of discovering who it is. Directed by Roger Donaldson, who did "Thirteen Days" and "No Way Out." Jan. 31.

AMEN -- Costa-Gavras's first film in five years is the story of German Christians' efforts to expose Hitler and his "final solution" genocide. The film focuses on one real man, Kurt Gerstein (played by Ulrich Tukur), a chemist who is horrified to learn that the gas he helped create as a disinfectant is being put to more sinister use. Mathieu Kassovitz plays a fictional Jesuit who lends a helping hand. Pope Pius XII does not come off well here. Mr. Costa-Gavras, who directed "Z" and "Missing," is not one for avoiding difficult political issues. January.

BETTER LUCK TOMORROW -- Ben and Virgil have a real scam going. They're honor students and model teenagers, so their parents reward them with total freedom, and maybe they shouldn't. Parry Shen and Jason Tobin play the bright but far from perfect young men in this dark suburban coming-of-age comedy. Directed by Justin Lin, whose first film was "Shopping for Fangs," the story of a budding werewolf. With Sung Kang, Roger Fan, John Cho and Karin Anna Cheung. January.

BIKER BOYZ -- The milieu is the world of underground motorcycle clubs. Laurence Fishburne stars as Smoke, an undefeated racer. Derek Luke, who also plays the title role in "The Antwone Fisher Story," plays the prodigy who could end Smoke's string of championships. With Eriq La Salle, Kid Rock, Kadeem Hardison and Lisa Bonet. January.

COWBOY BEBOP: THE MOVIE -- Mars in the year 2071, and the outer-space bounty hunters Spike Siegel and Jet Black are on the job. They're looking for the bad guys responsible for a huge tanker explosion, partly because there's an equally huge reward. These are the animated lead characters of "Cowboy Bebop," a Japanese anime series on the Cartoon Network, where it's scheduled at night for grown-up viewers. It's a little bit western, a little bit samurai and a little bit "Jetsons" all at the same time. Directed by Shinichiro Watanabe. January.

All dates are subject to change.

Compiled with the assistance of SUZANNE O'CONNOR.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An annotated listing in the Holiday Movies section on Nov. 3 included a publicist's misspelling of the surname of an actress in "Good Housekeeping," which opens on Wednesday as "Better Housekeeping." She is Petra Westen, not Western.

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 2; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1970 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
An Enduring Elitist and His Popular Museum

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
HIS image is a cliche by now: the sonorous, accented baritone on the audioguides, the imperial director in the impeccable suits. The Sun King of Fifth Avenue. He has occasionally felt compelled to make disparaging remarks about contemporary art, increasing the reactionary image. The other day I heard a grumpy art history professor in Illinois, a self-described child of the 1960's, call from the stage of a lecture hall for a weekly denouncement of him and his museum in the press.
 At least people still care. 
 At 66, Philippe de Montebello is celebrating his 25th anniversary as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- probably the longest tenure by any major American museum director -- having taken over from Thomas Hoving. Mr. Hoving the populist, Mr. de Montebello the elitist. That's the familiar chestnut, even though the label of staunch conservative attached to the latter is a bit misleading.
The cover story of a recent Harvard Magazine cited Paul Sachs, the legendary Harvard museum director and teacher, who almost a century ago predicted "ideological dilemmas" that every American director today knows about. "Entitlement versus access," Sachs said, "excellence versus equality, private revelation versus public instruction." 
You could put this more simply: people can agree about two things when it comes to art museums now, that they're popular, notwithstanding post-9/11 blues, and that they are suffering an identity crisis.
Their popularity has come at the cost of obscuring, or at least complicating, their fundamental mission. As J. Carter Brown, the former director of the National Gallery in Washington, put it shortly before he died this summer, museums "are hugged so tight by the great bear of the public that they are gasping for breath."
They're elitist to some. They're shopping malls to others. They should reach out more. They pander. It depends on whom you ask. It used to be that everyone simply regarded them as places to see art. That was enough. Plenty, in fact. Now, as an American Association of Museums report some years ago dictated, they must "help nurture a humane citizenry equipped to make informed choices in a democracy and to address the challenges and opportunities of an increasingly global society."
Mr. de Montebello has been around long enough to have seen the former museum era give way to the present one. In the process, he has become a de facto standard bearer for traditional values and a lightning rod within the rarefied confines of art professionals and academics. Partly the lightning rod role is a result of his public manner, which puts some people off. Partly it is that everybody who cares about art cares about the Met, which is embodied by Mr. de Montebello. But it's also that he says, straight out, what museums can and can't do, which other directors often won't. 
A director's job today is not what it used to be. The quaint age of gentlemen collectors like Sachs inviting aspiring connoisseurs to his home to fondle Trecento ivories and Persian miniatures so that they, too, might become museum directors, are gone. Fund-raising, politicking, administration and construction are areas of expertise that directors must master now: many museum directors spend more time with contractors, publicists and accountants than with artists and sometimes even with their own curators. They must market the commodity of the art museum. Museums, created to save great art -- as institutions of permanence -- having now joined themselves to the broader entertainment business, are beholden economically to the cult of novelty: new buildings, new exhibitions, whatever will attract the attention of new audiences. These are the priorities.
"One should be practical and not too pious," Mr. de Montebello cautioned a conference of art historians several years ago. "Commercialism and development activities do help pay the bills." But museums that merely market themselves as another brand of entertainment, like movies or baseball games, are committing virtual suicide, he said. "In an increasingly prosaic and materialistic world where the factitious holds sway, especially with the growth of the new electronic media, it is the mystery, the wonder, the presence of the real that is our singular distinction and that we should proudly, joyfully proclaim." 
The museum exists to provide an experience unlike any other in life, Mr. de Montebello thereby reminded his colleagues; it exists to give people something they can't get elsewhere. Of course art is elitist. The glory of the art museum is that anyone who walks through the door becomes an elitist, too. Museums don't make people into better citizens. Hermann Goring was a connoisseur. Museums show people what beauty looks like -- or what tastemakers at a given moment decide is beautiful -- and through this encounter, people may or may not gain a larger, more humane view of civilization.
But pragmatism, even more than ideology, is the crux of Mr. de Montebello's approach, and pragmatism, for an administrator of a large cultural institution, is never as straightforward as it may sound. For one thing, it entails diplomacy. Several times a year, curators at the Met meet, as they've been doing since Mr. Hoving was director. Back then, the idea was strength in numbers. It was them against him.
Nowadays, Mr. de Montebello is occasionally asked to these meetings. If you want to see how the atmosphere has changed inside the museum, administratively, since he took over, that obscure little detail is not a bad place to look. Curators seem to trust him. Trustees trust him. He has learned to defer to experts who know more than he does about art -- and when to defer -- which he did not always know how to do gracefully when he began. 
Hoving was publicly a populist, privately autocratic. Mr. de Montebello is closer to the reverse. Everyone languished in Mr. Hoving's shadow. He made the Met over in his own outsize image, transforming a sleepy giant into a rich public spectacle, sometimes thrilling, often exasperating, richocheting from crisis to crisis, permanently in turmoil, frequently in the headlines. Art museums in the United States lurched into the modern era thanks significantly to him -- they became mass entertainment palaces, targets of social, civic and racial debate.
And not incidentally, the Met also bought some great art, an activity that Mr. Hoving treated almost as sport. He was a big game hunter, bagging a Velazquez. But Mr. de Montebello has pushed many of Mr. Hoving's ideas forward more forcefully than Mr. Hoving ever dreamed of. This is the paradox of his supposed conservatism. But he has done so without the chaos and distress, by changing the operational ethos within the Met to match more closely his own personality: a little hoity-toity on the outside, but more adaptable in private.
Under him, the museum -- its collections, particularly of Asian and modern art, its galleries, its exhibition schedule, its attendance, its shops, educational programs, conservation studios and endowment, not to mention all the things that go along with running an increasingly vast institution, meaning the teams of lawyers, publicists, fund-raisers and volunteers -- everything has grown, to a point where Mr. de Montebello now sometimes wonders aloud, and with reason, whether the place has become too big.
There have been bad shows along the way, some of them done to pay the bills; and much of the renovation and expansion of the building has been disappointing, banal, even shoddy. That is Mr. de Montebello's most significant failure. His exhibitions of contemporary art have been few and clearly an afterthought, which might be acceptable in a city with so many other museums devoted to what's new, except that it is a lost opportunity to mix new and old in a way that only the Met could do. This relative neglect of the new is also a sign of indifference toward the museum's important, devoted audience of artists, for many of whom the place is almost like a second home.
But at the same time the museum has stuck pretty well to the core principle that art museums, as opposed to universities or department stores or history museums, present and preserve great art -- that's their job. They have a mission that is special and inseparable from the dispensing of aesthetic pleasure. Other museums sometimes forget this or feel obliged to adapt themselves to outside pressures with other interests. Money has given the Met the ability to be independent, and to his credit, Mr. de Montebello does not confuse independence with personal privilege.
Take modern art, again. The department, under its chairman, William S. Lieberman, is knocked regularly not just for its contemporary shows but also for its oddball acquisitions and warren of architecturally infelicitous galleries. But Mr. de Montebello's private antipathy for much modernism notwithstanding, he has made sure that the Met has accumulated a collection of art into the 1950's, anyway, that is excellent, through major donations that Mr. Lieberman has tirelessly cultivated. Someday, should someone separate wheat from chaff, the strengths of this collection will become more obvious.
"It's not my field, but I do try to follow modern art, strangely enough," Mr. de Montebello says. "I acquired Bill Lieberman to acquire the collections. I'm a very institutional person at heart. I believe in the Met as a great encyclopedia. So it's irrelevant whether something is to my taste. Modern art was an institutional gap. It would be foolish not to collect it." 
The other day, when asked to define his own legacy, Mr. de Montebello drummed his fingers on his desk. "I calmed the storm," he said. After Mr. Hoving, he explained, that was his challenge. "Putting in the right structures, staffing, healing the rift between staff and administration," he continued, as if he were a middle manager of a division of a widget company. "That's what I'm most proud of. I've been pretty good at avoiding public crises. I've done more shows in one year than Tom ever dreamed of doing. I've surprised myself how enterprising I have been, which I don't think would have been the case if he had not opened the door for me.
"If I had succeeded his predecessor, Jim Rorimer, I would probably have been more like Rorimer. He was a micromanager. You couldn't paint a wall without his approval. He directed a museum half the size of the one I direct today."
Mr. de Montebello's accomplishment, you might say, has been to combine Rorimer's circumspection with Mr. Hoving's open-door expansionism, providing a useful model for museum directors today who feel pressure to broaden their programs but not lose touch with what museums traditionally do best. 
"Change is a commodity I believe art museums should use with the utmost circumspection" is how Mr. Montebello puts it. The result, and despite the museum's inevitable, obvious flaws, is that he has been in charge of one of the few reliable cultural monuments of global reach.
He now plans to stay at least another four years, he hopes through the completion of the renovations to the Greek and Roman galleries, the construction of a new restaurant and other changes to the building. After that, he'll be 70 and see whether the trustees still want him. Comfortable in the job, he has no desire to give it up now, and perhaps he knows that whoever succeeds him will not have the authority or experience to stand up to the challenges of commercialization and compromise that threaten every other museum director in America and can only increase at the Met. Apres lui, le deluge, perhaps. 
Meanwhile, he says: "Either you become more autocratic or you relax. I'm much less imperious now. I know pretty much what I'm doing. I have nothing to prove to my staff anymore. That's the virtue of longevity."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Philippe de Montebello, left, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 25 years, sitting in a museum gallery, and Thomas Hoving, above, Mr. de Montebello's predecessor. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times); (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)(pg. 22)

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1682 words

HEADLINE: What Saved Collingswood? Teamwork 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

DATELINE: COLLINGSWOOD 

 BODY:
IT'S Saturday night and Haddon Avenue, the main drag is this South Jersey town, is hopping. The line of customers is out the door waiting for tables at Tortilla Press. Over at Purple Iris, shoppers are browsing through bins of pricey garden tools and lawn decorations. A younger and hipper crowd wanders into Grooveground to listen to a band and sip espresso.
 Only five or six years ago, it was a very different scene in Collingswood, a town of 14,000 wedged in between impoverished Camden and affluent Haddonfield. The downtown area was declining, losing a battle with the shopping malls, with as many as 30 to 40 percent of storefronts vacant. The best restaurant in town was a tiny luncheonette, and thrift stores were the most common enterprises. One of the most prominent structures in town was the old brick Collingswood elementary school, a boarded-up eyesore. 
 Now, though, there are no unoccupied spaces for rent downtown. The school, its windows restored, has been reborn as the home of Kitchen & Associates Architectural Services. Thirty new businesses opened in the town last year, and 15 more will open by the end of this year. Residential real estate values have recovered, too, and this little town is once again a desirable place to live. Mayor James Maley Jr. is fielding phone calls from more businesses that want to move in and from other Jersey towns that want to copy the Collingswood success story.
That story concerns one dying town that managed to recover from a bad case of the blahs and inject new life into its commercial district.
How did it happen?
Mayor Maley's summation of the story sounds much like a line from a hit movie of a few years ago.
"If you get good stores and businesses, the people will come," he said.
In fact, Collingswood's success owes to aggressive hard work by local officials and merchants and, perhaps even more, to state legislation that provides for the creation of special improvement districts. 
The legislation, enacted in 1984, allows towns to assess commercial property owners an additional tax, based on property evaluation, and to use the proceeds to create a management corporation for the town and for community development like security, lighting, sidewalk repair, building renovation, recruiting new businesses and promotion. Collingswood is one of 53 towns in the state, including Red Bank, Atlantic City, Elizabeth, Cranford, Clifton and Freehold, that have designated special improvement districts. Collingswood raises about $200,000 a year through its assessment, which business property owners seem largely grateful to pay.
And the town is still going out wooing other businesses.
"We learned how to recruit businesses to come in to the community," Mayor Maley said. "We put a team together, and we work. The way it works is personal contacts, personal contacts, personal contacts. We have people meet with government. We work on deals, and the business people in town make themselves available. We are constantly working."
Volunteer groups pitched in, too, behind the goal of bringing the town back from empty storefronts and sliding property values. Volunteers will paint and clean up the facade of a building if the business owner provides the materials.
Through grants and low-interest bank loans, the town has improved lighting and renovated buildings. It also began to promote weekend events to draw more people into its center, closing 10 to 12 blocks to hold fairs and festivals with foods, arts and crafts. 
"I've seen the renaissance in Collingswood first-hand, and it is just amazing," said Susan Bass Levin, the state's commissioner for the Department of Community Affairs and a former mayor of nearby Cherry Hill who often shops in Collingswood. "It's all about putting a package together. It starts with a mayor who says, 'I want to build a coalition.' "
Collingswood's downward slope began in the late 60's. Jerry Chambers, a native who has worked on Haddon Avenue for 38 years and now owns Eck's Jewelers there, remembers a bustling array of restaurants, drugstores with soda fountains and other busy stores as well as neighborhoods filled with large, middle-class families. About 60 children lived on his block.
"The downtown at one point was incredible," he said. "But it really suffered through the 70's."
Soon, many homes were sold to absentee owners who converted them into apartments and duplexes and then neglected them. Businesses went belly up when they could not compete with the Cherry Hill Mall, which opened in October 1961, and other neighboring malls. The thrift shops moved in along with other businesses that quickly failed. The real alarm went off for Mr. Chambers, he said, when his parents said they were thinking of leaving the community.
As it happens, they stayed. About 20 years ago, others who had stayed, business people like Mr. Chambers and John Gagliardi, who has owned a hair salon on the avenue for 32 years, began meeting to lay the ground work for the big changes that came over the last five years. They took on projects as simple as planting trees downtown and began lobbying people to the way of thinking that downtown could not continue to drift. Something had to be done.
"They realized that and a lot of other suburban towns did not," said Mr. Maley, a lawyer who has lived in Collingswood since 1982. He still has the advertisement for the three-bedroom Dutch colonial with the finished basement that he and his wife bought for $72,500. Mr. Maley, one of three town commissioners since 1989 and the mayor since 1997, is credited by many town residents as the engine that drove Collingswood to much of its current success.
What the commissioners eventually decided had to be done was the creation of the special improvement district, in 1999.
Not every town has embraced the concept and its extra tax on business property owners. Bound Brook, for example, tried it but did away with it. A proposal was defeated in Haddonfield in the mid-1990's. And in Haddon Township, where an assessment was approved last spring, resistance is still evident, as in a "No SID" sign posted on one merchant's door.
But for the most part towns have benefited from it. In Red Bank, the state's sterling example, the business vacancy rate has rebounded to less than 1 percent today from 37 percent 12 years ago, said Mayor Edward J. McKenna Jr. In Red Bank and well as in Atlantic City, which started a special improvement district in 1993, recruiting is seen as a big part of the package.
The money from the assessments helps, according to Ms. Bass Levin, but the more important aspect is the uniting of the town for the purpose of rebuilding.
"Once a town makes the commitment, it works," she said. "The hurdle is getting everyone to agree that you need to take action. It has to be everyone in this together."
Everyone in Collingswood seemed to realize that town residents could not be the only shoppers. They knew they had to lure people from nearby suburbs and even Philadelphia, which is about eight miles away. One of the biggest worries now is that success will escalate rents for commercial space.
When Mark Smith and Lydia Cipriani were looking for a place to open Tortilla Press, a 46-seat Mexican restaurant, they were impressed with the efforts to draw them to town. They opened on Haddon Avenue at the end of July in the space formerly occupied by the luncheonette.
"The main decision-making factor was the way the business community and the commissioners sold us on coming to Collingswood," Mr. Smith said. "They have a really good vision. They are positive and upbeat about the area. They were incredibly supportive in making the deal happen. Having seen Collingswood 10 years ago and seeing it now is amazing. It blows me away."
Other newcomers include Eat Your Peas, a children's clothing boutique, and HALO, a funky gift store. Villa Barone, a popular Italian bistro, moved into space formerly occupied by an appliance store. Merchandise & Hardware, which sells fashionable hardware and furniture, was a pet store. A gas station is being removed to make way for Bobby Chez, a gourmet takeout specializing in crab cakes.
As another sign of success in the community, the publisher David Hunter, who puts out a community newspaper called What's On in Haddonfield and a South Jersey arts paper, started What's On in Collingswood in mid-October. 
Mr. Hunter said he had been looking for another South Jersey town and decided that Collingswood, with so many new businesses, was the most promising.
"When five or six new restaurants open, something is going on," he said.
Another thing going on is an upswing in the housing market.
Philadelphia Magazine noted in a September column that Collingswood was the "new spot for shops" and that 30-somethings from Center City Philadelphia were crossing the river and heading to Collingswood to raise their families.
Silvia Hatzell, of Main Street Realty in Collingswood, says friends who used to tease her for living in Collingswood are now moving in, themselves.
"It was tougher to sell houses here six years ago," Ms. Hatzell said. "Everyone wants to live here now."
These days the town is being compared to other hot spots.
Robert Sanabria, who owns a California-style restaurant in Marlton called Food for Thought and plans to open Word of Mouth in Collingswood in early November, said: "At first I was apprehensive because it is next to Camden. but I saw it was an up-and-coming town" that now reminds him of Manayunk, a resuscitated neighborhood in Philadelphia, or New Hope, the big antique, restaurant and tourist mecca in Bucks County, Pa.
Valerie Boothroyd, a Haddon Avenue renaissance pioneer, opened her furniture restoration business, The Painted Cottage, six years ago, before it became apparent that the avenue would become so tony.
People used to ask her why she chose Collingswood rather than a town like New Hope. But she sensed the potential here, she said. And now, what with her love for Collingswood, its Saturday farmers market and its community spirit, her point of comparison is even farther afield.
"It's so Paris here," Mrs. Boothroyd said.

A sign, right, praises a town program that secured a low-cost loan to convert the house from a duplex to single family. And below, a gathering at HALO, a gift store in downtown Collingswood.
