HEADLINE: A Change in Chairman for the Pequots 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AS a boy, Michael J. Thomas couldn't wait to turn 16 so he could leave his home at the Mashantucket Pequot Reservation in eastern Connecticut. But 18 years later as the Mashantuckets prepare to elect a new leader today, Mr. Thomas is the heir designate of the current chairman of the Tribal Council and only announced candidate for the position.
 Mr. Thomas said his chief priority as leader would be to build housing for some of the Mashantuckets who want to move onto the reservation, where the tribe operates the Foxwoods Resort Casino, which makes an estimated $1 billion a year. But he said also high on his list is better relations with the tribe's neighbors, who have opposed expansion of the casino and the reservation. 
 "There is no need for us to be as insular as we have been historically," Mr. Thomas said. "There is a tone that I would set a chairman that is more open and more based on communications, and more focused on moving past points of disagreement towards areas of potential agreement."
He said he hopes to reach a point where, even if the tribe and the neighbors cannot agree on something, they would "be able to disagree without being disagreeable."
In the past the tribe has been accused of being guarded, even furtive about its plans for development of the reservation, although the current chairman has been moving more in the direction that Mr. Thomas laid out. Kenneth M. Reels, who took office four years ago, has held a series of public meetings to explain the Mashantuckets' positions on various issues and has worked closely with local elected officials. 
Local officials said it was encouraging even that Mr. Reels announced he was stepping down, and Mr. Thomas announced he would run for the office.
"The tribe has always been very secretive about its elections, so Michael's press conference was a real step out of the normal for them," said Preston First Selectman Robert Congdon. "I think it's a good sign."
Mr. Congdon said he will work closely with whomever is elected, and he does not want to appear to be taking sides in an internal matter such as an election, particularly since there have been reports that Richard A. (Skip) Hayward, a former chairman, might also seek the seat. Mr. Hayward declined requests for an interview.
"But I agree we need to work together more than we have in the past," Mr. Congdon said. "I think we're getting some encouraging signals."
Mr. Congdon also noted that the Mohegan Tribe, which operates the nearby Mohegan Sun casino, has had a different relationship with its neighboring towns from the start. He noted, for example, that the Mohegans are in the middle of building a water line that will not only serve the casino, but also other local towns.
"They're really going out of their way to be good citizens," Mr. Congdon said. "That kind of model is sitting seven miles away, and I think the Mashantuckets, as well as the towns of Preston, Ledyard and Stonington, need to learn from it."
Mr. Reels, who is still seeking re-election to the council, said it was a difficult decision not to run for a third term as chairman.
"I've always tried to put the tribe first, and I think we've empowered the next generation to the point where there's a younger council member who can do a better job, and knowing that I felt it was time to step down," Mr. Reels said. "I think I still have a lot to offer, but I feel that we can move forward with Michael Thomas as chairman."
Mr. Reels is 42, while Mr. Thomas, who was the youngest tribal member ever elected to the council nine years ago, is 34.
Mr. Reels said the finances of the tribe are also in better shape than they were four years ago, which has made him feel more comfortable turning over the reins. He said that when he took over, the tribe was considering a major redevelopment project in nearby Norwich, and it ran a shipyard in New London, but it had no business plan for either undertaking, and the shipyard had lost about $70 million over the few years it operated.
"There was a lot of good publicity from the shipyard, but was that publicity worth $70 million?" Mr. Reels said. "And now we have a project in Norwich that's not so ambitious, with the state and the city contributing about $7 million. The tribe is stronger financially than it has ever been, and we've paid down about a quarter-billion dollars of debt."
But it has not been completely a period of retrenchment. Under Mr. Reels, the tribe has started construction of a $9 million office and warehouse complex in Stonington, two golf courses near the casino, and a huge commercial laundry operation in the Norwich Industrial Park.
"When people come into a lot of money they tend to waste a lot of money," Mr. Reels said. "We've been there, we've gotten through that period, and now we're focused on producing wealth and taking care of our assets. We've put things on a sound financial footing."
Mr. Reels said he also believed in term limits, and while that is not the rule among the Mashantuckets, "I like to lead by example, and if I feel that way, I have to act that way."
Mr. Reels said he was appointed to the tribe's Economic Development Committee this year and will be active as the tribe continues to develop businesses.
"We're talking to some big companies about potential partnerships, and that's where I would like to put my time," Mr. Reels said. "I want to make sure that as we build out the resort, we don't waste any money."
The tribe is considering a $700 million expansion project that will include "Pequot Island," a water-themed resort on the reservation. He would not reveal more details of the plan, but said many projects were approved in the past based on simple artist renderings, but the tribe wanted more information this time.
"The membership is beyond pretty pictures," Mr. Reels said. "We want to see the financial impact it will have on the tribe if we borrow money: What's the interest rate, what kind of return can we expect, that sort of thing."
Mr. Thomas said, historically, gambling has been a cyclical business, and the tribe must develop Foxwoods as a true resort, with attractions that will bring people to Mashantucket even if the interest in gaming wanes. But he said that as the tribe moves forward it must focus more than ever on what will yield the greatest return on investment, and what will have the longest life span as an attraction.
"There is the potential for more growth," Mr. Thomas said. "But we also understand the need for the tribe's finances to be stable if we are going to take care of our citizens."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kenneth M. Reels, right, the outgoing chairman of the Mashantucket Pequots, who run the Foxwoods Resort Casino, above, has endorsed Michael J. Thomas, below, to replace him. Mr. Thomas said he plans to seek better relations with the towns around the casino. (C. M. Glover, above, and Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation)

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
U.S. Savings Bonds at a High Point

BYLINE:  By KARL RUSSELL 

 BODY:
Suddenly, United States savings bonds are looking very good.
 While many investors continue to lose money in the stock market, owners of savings bonds are seeing some attractive yields. 
 The yield on the most widely held savings bond -- the EE series, the kind people used to give as gifts -- is currently 3.25 percent. That's far above the average yield on a one-year certificate of deposit, now 1.73 percent, and much better than rates on money market or savings accounts. 
Downturns in the stock market generally bolster bond sales, as investors flee to safety. But the Treasury Department has also made it easier to buy savings bonds by offering them online, at www.treasurydirect.gov. It has also tried to make the bonds more appealing by inscribing "patriot bond" on some of them. KARL RUSSELL

Graph tracks United States savings bonds ownership, measured in billions, since 1992.

HEADLINE: The View From/New Canaan; 
Stepping Into a Role Without Missing a Beat

BYLINE:  By LEAH NATHANS SPIRO 

 BODY:
IT was only his ninth day on the job, but already there was a crisis. Curt R. Welling, the new chief executive of AmeriCares, an international relief organization, was reading a morning paper in his office in downtown New Canaan when he came across a banner headline on Oct. 17 that read: "North Korea Says It Has a Program on Nuclear Arms."
 Mr. Welling immediately knew that an AmeriCares mission to deliver aid to North Korea in several weeks was in jeopardy. 
 "It certainly puts our mission up in the air," Mr. Welling said as he scrambled to consult with his staff and the State Department.
But as the day of departure neared, AmeriCares decided that the mission, scheduled for next Saturday, would proceed.
AmeriCares, founded in 1982 by Robert Macauley, has airlifted and shipped medicine, medical supplies and food to more than 137 countries around the world. North Korea has been receiving shipments since 1997.
But North Korea is not the only country preoccupying Mr. Welling and the organization these days. Southern Africa is another of his concerns. After a fact-finding mission in September, the organization learned that the AIDS epidemic and famine are devastating countries from Malawi to Zambia.
Mr. Welling is worried that the world does not know the extent of the problem.
"The combination of the magnitude of the disease profile there and the magnitude of this famine has the potential to create a crisis of absolutely horrific proportion," he said. 
Worrying about famine and the AIDS epidemic in Africa seems light years away from the time Mr. Welling spent agonizing over his next deal on Wall Street, where he worked for 23 years.
Mr. Welling, 53, was an investment banker with First Boston Corporation and with Bear Stearns & Company. He was also the chief executive of SG Cowen Securities, a division of a French bank.
His earlier offices boasted stunning bouquets of fresh flowers, plush carpeting and magnificent views of Manhattan. Today, he is getting by with nicked metal filing cabinets, a 1960's era wooden desk and a window office overlooking a parking lot.
"There were no people more self-important than investment bankers, including me," he said.
Yet, Mr. Welling has hit the ground running. With a staff in New Canaan of about 60, and with hundreds of volunteers, he has already scoured Fairfield County for a new headquarters building that will be able to absorb roughly a dozen new employees and perhaps AmeriCares huge warehouse in Milford.
Mr. Welling has started a regular Monday morning staff meeting and he is also in the midst of a careful examination of the basic mission and management of the organization.
"The few changes he has made have made a big difference," said Elizabeth Griffin, AmeriCares' director of communications. "He's re-examining every facet of how we operate."
For Mr. Welling, a 22-year resident of Wilton, the change from investment banker to nonprofit chief executive did not seem unusual. He was the president of the board of Spence Chapin Services, an adoption and child services group, and chairman of the Wilton Board of Finance. He is still involved with the Adirondack Council, a wilderness preservation group in upstate New York where he grew up.
Landing at AmeriCares, which has an annual budget of $450 million, was both serendipitous and providential, he said.
After stepping down as chief executive of Princeton eCom, an electronic bill payment service in Princeton, N.J., a friend called and asked him to send a resume, which was then forwarded to an AmeriCares board member.
Meanwhile, AmeriCares was in dire need of finding a new leader to carry forward the mission of Mr. Macauley, a former entrepreneurial paper broker.
Even before he started AmeriCares 20 years ago, Mr. Macauley was involved in relief missions. During the finals days of the Viet Nam War, he was moved by a tragedy. On April 4, 1975, a United States military plane carrying Vietnamese orphans to the United States to be adopted crashed in the jungle in Viet Nam.
With little hope of the survivors being immediately rescued, Mr. Macauley chartered a Boeing 747 with a personal check for $10,000 to pick up the children and fly them to San Francisco, where their adoptive parents were waiting. By then, his check had bounced and he had to mortgage his home several times to pay the balance of $241,000.
Several years later, in 1981, Pope John Paul II called Mr. Macauley to Rome and asked him to get medical supplies into his home country of Poland, which was under martial law. Mr. Macauley, who is not Catholic, completed the mission.
Today, at age 78, he is still the chairman, but he is in declining health.
Mr. Welling did not know much about AmeriCares, except through his church, where he had participated in one of AmeriCares domestic programs called Homefront Day, which attracts some 9,000 local volunteers who help elderly and economically strapped residents fix up their homes. Despite stiff competition, the AmeriCares board chose him.
In the Macauley tradition, the main focus of AmeriCares is responding quickly to international emergency medical emergencies around the world by airlifting and shipping medicine, medical supplies and nutritional items that include vitamins, powdered milk and infant formula.
Domestically, AmeriCares focuses mainly on the local community. Besides Homefront Day, AmeriCares runs free clinics in Danbury, Norwalk and is opening one in Bridgeport. The organization also runs Camp AmeriKids in upstate New York for children from the tristate area with AIDS.
The organization responded on Sept. 11. Within 24 hours of the attacks on the World Trade Center, AmeriCares had four Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopters ferrying rescue teams and materials to the area. The organization also raised $9 million, which it promptly spent on the rescue effort.
For Mr. Welling, one of his biggest challenges will be fund-raising. Mr. Macauley's connections will certainly help. For one, he went to kindergarten in Greenwich with George Bush Sr., and Barbara Bush is the AmeriCares ambassador-at-large.
Mr. Macauley has perfected a way of thanking his corporate donors, whose contributions of medicine and medical supplies are the backbone of the organization. Every year the organization holds a hangar party at the Westchester County Airport.
After an evening of dinner and dancing, the guests change into jeans and board a plane for a whirlwind tour of some of the clinics and orphanages the organization has helped.
Since the hangar, beverages and air travel are donated or discounted, the party helped to raise $15,000 this year, Ms. Griffin said.
After only a few weeks on the job, Mr. Welling received a welcome surprise. The Chronicle of Philanthropy, a trade publication, raised AmeriCares' ranking from 20th on its list of top 400 philanthropies to 12th.
The list ranks charities based on how much money and donated products they raised from private, non-governmental sources, which include individuals, foundations and corporations. AmeriCares raised $463 million.
"It's a remarkable accomplishment," said Stacy Palmer, editor of the Chronicle of Philanthropy. "It was a very hard year."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, Peter Browne, left, and Philip Tu taking inventory at the AmeriCares warehouse in Milford. Top right, Curt R. Welling, on the job taking a look at supplies. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COMPANY: BEAR STEARNS & CO INC (65%)

ORGANIZATION: AMERICARES FOUNDATION (59%) AMERICARES FOUNDATION

PERSON: MCCAULEY, ROBERT; WELLING, CURT R; SPIRO, LEAH NATHANS

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
A Surge of Home Buying on Monmouth's Seashore

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
A COUPLE of years ago, just as the stock market was cresting and before it came crashing down in successive waves, Lynn Wyckoff and her husband, Robert, decided to use their retirement savings to buy a house by the sea.
 At the time, Mrs. Wyckoff recalled, it seemed quite daring to invest in Monmouth County real estate, rather than, say, a "nice mutual fund." For one thing, the couple was selling the family home in East Brunswick to move into an eight-bedroom 1906 structure needing major renovation and restoration. For another, the new house was in Asbury Park -- a town with so many boarded-up buildings and problems that sharp-tongued shore regulars sometimes referred it to as "Beirut by the sea." 
 "But my husband knew the area from years ago, when his family summered in Neptune," Mrs. Wyckoff said. "I fell in love with this town, its historic buildings on the ocean, its beautiful white boardwalk."
A redevelopment plan for Asbury Park's beachfront area was being readied, and there were already lots of pioneers looking to renovate and revive the hard-luck town responsible for some of Bruce Springsteen's rough edges. The first wavelet of New Yorkers, many of them gays, had begun buying beat-up beach houses to rehab as second homes, a pattern of improvement that has been continuing for about five years now, according to local real estate agents. 
"When we decided to buy down here, we told our friends they should join us," Mrs. Wyckoff said. "They come to visit and they love it, but none of them actually bought houses."
Now, Mrs. Wyckoff is reveling in her almost fully restored brick manse with its grand staircase and its crystal chandelier from Czechoslovakia and its wraparound porch that catches the ocean breeze -- and sighing over the plight of pals. "One couple we know invested their money at the same time we did, but they went with the stock market," she said. "They lost over $200,000."
The Wyckoffs paid $190,000 for their house and roughly the same amount to restore it. When work on the home is complete, it will be worth more than $800,000, local market experts say.
Rosemarie Villanova, a Coldwell Banker agent in Ocean Township, said she has had at least a dozen clients buying homes or second homes in the past year who told her they were getting their money out of stocks and putting it into real estate on the shore.
"People investing now are a little bit late," said Donna Fahey-Waters, Ms. Villanova's colleague at Coldwell Banker. "Prices have taken off, in every price range of house and condo. There is no such thing anymore as somebody being able to say, 'Get me a little condo for $100,000.' "
FOR Monmouth County, the average price per transaction is 18 percent higher this year than last year, said James R. Johnson Jr., manager of Weichert Realtors' office in Sea Girt. Spurred by this, Weichert plans to open new offices in up-and-coming Brielle and in Spring Lake, where the median sales price is currently $1.7 million, and where one property sold for close to $12 million earlier this year, Mr. Johnson said.
In Spring Lake this year, there have been several cases in which homes were purchased for $400,000 to $700,000 and then the new owners knocked them down and built big new houses on the property, according to Mr. Johnson.
Despite the rising prices, there are still deals to be had, sales agents agreed. And Monmouth County is still in the process of being discovered.
"I sold a house in Monmouth Beach to a couple from New York," said Ms. Fahey-Waters, "and they just had their wedding in Rumson last month. There were a number of people there who had never seen the area -- many from New York -- and people were saying, 'This is New Jersey?'
"It's getting so we're almost not trying to tout it any more," Ms. Fahey-Waters said. "O.K., not really, but things have absolutely taken off."
In Spring Lake, Mr. Johnson of Weichert said he sensed the market might be beginning to cool. "There are suddenly more properties on the market -- a total of 61 right now -- with prices ranging from $539,000 to just shy of $5 million," he said.
But the market in most towns -- Belmar, Sea Girt, Cedar Lake, Wall, Manasquan -- is steadily warming, agents say. 
Ms. Villanova cited the Shark River Hills section of Neptune as being exceptionally hot right now. The town has smaller homes, and even waterfront properties are affordable -- $379,000 to $400,000 -- she said. Also, West Allenhurst and Ocean Township, which share borders with Asbury Park, are in this category, she said.
Ms. Villanova said she was seeing three types of customers: "There are the people from outside the area, who come to the area in the summer and then discover it is a year-round community. They start coming here in the fall, and then spending most of their weekends here, and then they decide this is where they want to be. 
S OME people want to move out of northern New Jersey. They may be downsizing -- not retired, but selling homes because their children are grown, and maybe preparing for retirement. They want to buy a home or second home before prices go any higher.
"The third type of buyer is an investor looking for deals. There are places in Bradley Beach, the northern end of Belmar, Neptune, Asbury Park, where it's possible to pick up summer homes at affordable prices."
Some are making over unheated beach houses for themselves; others are engaged in "flipping," Ms. Villanova said -- buying houses that need work, often doing the work themselves, and then reselling.
Ms. Villanova said she recently had a client who bought a bungalow in Neptune 10 blocks from the water for $78,000. "You walked in and could see right through the roof -- pick out the stars in the sky," she said. The buyer has redone the interior and installed heat and central air, and it is now on the market for $180,000."
In the summer of 2000, Stuart Z. Koperweis bid on a boarded-up Asbury Park house that was in foreclosure. "You know, this town is interesting," he had said to his wife. "It reminds me of Jersey City, but on the shore." At the time, Mr. Koperweis was the president of the Economic Development Corporation in Jersey City. He is currently a development consultant and is employed as president of the Greater Asbury Park Chamber of Commerce.
Mr. Koperweis paid $151,000 for the 3,200-square-foot structure on Seventh Avenue, five blocks from the ocean, which had been converted into a three-family home. He reconverted the house to a single-family, and appraisers now estimate its value at close to $450,000, Mr. Koperweis said. "The house across the street just sold for $490,000," he said, "and it needs work. And a house a block away sold last summer for $600,000."
Mr. Koperweis, however, sees his house as a place to stay for a long time. "After college, it could be my kids' summer house," he said, "or our retirement home, or theirs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lynn Wyckoff on the porch of her eight-bedroom home in Asbury Park, where renovation is almost complete. (Lara Solt for The New York Times) Map of New Jersey highlights Monmouth.

HEADLINE: POLITICS; 
In Bids for Governor, Final Stumping in Pivotal Westchester

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
AS Westchester County goes, so goes the state. As a political adage, it lacks the rhythm and renown of the old saw about Maine and the nation. But in local circles, it has been just as reliable a prediction formula. 
 Watchers of statewide elections say that Westchester has long been considered the most accurate bellwether county in New York. Its demographics are strongly representative of the state. Westchester is favored by pollsters in predicting statewide reaction to candidates and issues, and political strategists scrutinize voter trends in the county to determine campaign strategies. Campaigns regularly conduct focus groups to study voter attitudes. Westchester is said to be the most pivotal of the state's suburban areas, and probably the single most strategic territory in statewide elections. 
 "It is literally the swing county," said Brian J. Nickerson, a political science professor and director of the Michaelian Institute of Public Policy at Pace University in White Plains.
Westchester mirrors the state's proportion of upstate, suburbs and city. Politicos break the state down into three main voting blocks. Upstate traditionally votes Republican; New York City traditionally votes Democratic. The suburbs are often politically divided -- "swing" territory -- and can be the most intense political battleground.
"It's become a cliche now: Westchester as a bellwether because the electorate reflects the state's diversity," said George S. Latimer, a Democratic county legislator from Rye and chairman of the county's Democratic Committee. 
"You have people who work on Wall Street on the same block as people who work right in town," said Mr. Latimer, who traversed the state and county for months during his unsuccessful campaign for lieutenant governor earlier this year. "If your message resonates here, it generally reflects how it's going to do statewide."
So, with Election Day on Tuesday, a last big push for campaigns is taking place this weekend throughout Westchester. Ground operations are in full effect this weekend for the three main gubernatorial candidates: Gov. George E. Pataki, the Republican incumbent; H. Carl McCall, the Democratic challenger; and the billionaire businessman Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate. There are commercials on television, literature in the mail, campaigners at train stations and supermarkets, and foot soldiers going door to door. 
Volunteers for Mr. Pataki will be looking for converts in solidly Democratic areas like Mamaroneck, Scarsdale and Mount Vernon. Mr. McCall will concentrate on Republican strongholds like Mount Pleasant, Eastchester, Harrison and Peekskill. And Mr. Golisano will try to pick off disaffected voters in Yonkers, a city with a mostly Democratic enrollment but where voters tend to elect Republicans.
Westchester can often be tricky for political strategists to predict. It was long Republican-dominated, but in recent years Democrats have outnumbered Republicans almost 3 to 2. Still, voters do not blindly vote the party line. They are known for being familiar with the issues and tend to put issues before a party. For example, many Irish and Italian people who migrated to Westchester after World War II remain Democrats, but vote conservatively on issues and could favor Republicans.
Kieran Mahoney, a Republican political strategist, noted that Westchester has a large number of voters who do not declare a political party, so the county becomes a petri dish for determining which issues are important to voters.
Michael R. Edelman, a Republican political consultant in Westchester for 25 years, said, "If you take Westchester, you're going to take the state." Geographically and politically, he said, the county sits between the liberal city and the conservative upstate.
Mr. Mahoney posits that a Republican cannot win in the state without winning Westchester. He has worked each of Mr. Pataki's gubernatorial campaigns. In 1998, Mr. Pataki won 53 percent of the statewide vote, compared to 32 percent for Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat and the former New York City council speaker. In Westchester, Mr. Pataki won 59 percent to 33 percent. In 1994, Mr. Pataki beat Mario M. Cuomo by getting 49 percent of the vote, to Mr. Cuomo's 45 percent. In Westchester, the count was 50 percent to 47 percent.
Mr. Mahoney attributed much of Mr. Pataki's success to his familiarity with the suburbs, particularly Westchester. Mr. Pataki remains active in Westchester Republican circles. He is from Garrison, in lower Putnam County, and was Peekskill mayor and became a state senator from the area.
"Part of the reason he does well in the suburbs is that he understands Westchester, and that's knowledge he can export when he's trying to win other suburbs," Mr. Mahoney said. 
The importance of winning Westchester is not lost on Mr. McCall's campaign. Steven A. Greenberg, a campaign spokesman, said Westchester is considered crucial to winning. He said that when Mr. McCall was elected state comptroller in 1994, he won only seven of the state's 62 counties: four in the city, two upstate and Westchester.
"He lost 55 counties, but he carried the city and Westchester, so he carried the state," Mr. Greenberg said.
CANDIDATES conduct polls to determine which parts of their platform to emphasize to particular voting blocs. They are likely to emphasize different issues to urban dwellers just north of the Bronx than to apple-growers in northern Westchester. Urban voters are generally concerned with social services and financing for mass transit, while suburban dwellers focus on property taxes, education and the environment.
Mr. Pataki has been visiting the county recently, most notably courting county leaders on a tour of the Hudson River. Mr. McCall, whose political stronghold is New York City, has an active campaign office in White Plains but has not made very many personal appearances. But his running mate, for lieutenant governor, is Dennis Mehiel, a former chairman of the Westchester County Democratic committee.
Mr. McCall has called for closing the Indian Point nuclear power plant, which appeals to many local voters. Mr. Pataki has not called for a shutdown but has largely managed to avoid major criticism. He has also avoided blame for economic and budget woes, despite Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat, attributing the county's $1 billion budget deficit to Albany. Mr. Spano has angered some Democrats by appearing with Mr. Golisano at a recent public event.
"You have some city, some suburb and some rural," said Richard Berman, Manhattanville College president, who runs the college's poll, which canvasses Westchester. "It's a rich county, but there are large lower-income cities. You have the poorest of poor and richest of rich, and all the ethnic groups. You have every kind of demographic here, by income, religion, race, gender, political party and education level."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 3 about voting patterns in Westchester misstated the county's projected budget deficit, invoked as an issue by County Executive Andrew J. Spano. It was $121 million. (A billion dollars was the cost for programs mandated by the state and included in the county budget of $1.37 billion.)

Pataki, to right of Mayor Keith Austin of Briarcliff Manor, gets his endorsement. Tom Golisano at news conference in White Plains. (J. Gregory Raymond); (Susan Farley for The New York Times); (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

 Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2563 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Service Upgrade By N.J. Transit Fuels Gains Around Stations

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR, N.J. 

 BODY:
MARGOT SAGE-EL, the owner of Watchung Booksellers here, said she has noticed an increase in the numbers of visitors to her store since the Manhattan Direct trains began running on Sept. 30.
 "There is a buzz; it's like we are more connected to the city," she said. "It is bringing people in during the day, including kids getting off the train. It used to be four trains in the morning, four in the evening and nothing else." 
 There are in fact 59 trains a day stopping at the station a few minutes' walk from her bookstore, compared with 26 before the development of the new service. Trains run approximately hourly in each direction during the day, with additional trains during morning and evening rush hours. 
Ms. Sage-El's store is adjacent to the Watchung Avenue station, one of six in this suburban township where new electric trains whisk riders into New York's Pennsylvania Station in about a half hour. 
Officials and real estate executives in Montclair and other towns on the rail line say the new service has helped to increase housing prices by attracting people who want the advantages of suburban living without a punishing commute into Manhattan. It has also stimulated commercial development -- an estimated $200 worth has taken place in Morristown since the train service began there in 1996 -- with new stores and office conversions opening near train stations. This has raised the hopes of local officials trying to revive downtown shopping areas that grew up around the train stations about a century and a half ago.
New apartment-style housing projects are under way in several towns. And one developer, Cary Heller, has hitched his activities to the rail revival with stores in the South Orange train station and building conversions in Maplewood and Montclair.
Unlike some later suburban developments, which simply sprawled housing across former farm fields without much focus or sense of community, the towns along rail lines tend to have distinct personalities and distinctive shopping areas. In addition to commercial developments, these towns are including cultural facilities, like live stages, in their renewal plans.
Because the roads in the region are choked with traffic much of the time, the value of rapid rail travel and proximity to stations has grown. 
"A lot of people say they want to be within walking distance to a train station," said Joyce Slous, a saleswoman at the Burgdorff residential real estate agency, which has an office in the Watchung Plaza, near the station. "The values are higher closer to the train."
Before the development of the Midtown Direct trains, New York bound commuters could stay on the trains only as far east as Hoboken. There they had to transfer to the underground PATH trains, or more recently ferries, for the remainder of the trip. Since the schedules of the surface trains and the PATH lines did not seem to be coordinated, commuters wasted time standing around the PATH station at Hoboken. And since the attacks of Sept. 11 drove many jobs that were formerly downtown to Midtown, the PATH trains have been unusually crowded.
The effects of the new rail service are most apparent in such towns as South Orange, Maplewood and Morristown, which are on the main branch of New Jersey Transit's Morris and Essex line and have had Midtown Direct since 1996. Dingy areas in and near the train stations have been replaced with lively stores selling food and drink, which are flanked by sidewalks with tables and chairs where people gather.
"We knew the new service was going to be a boost for the community," said William R. Calabrese, president of the Board of Trustees of the Village of South Orange, effectively its mayor. "The town grew around the train station, and we knew we had to rebuild around the station."
In addition to the new station stores, which face the main downtown shopping area, plans are well under way for a new arts center on the other side of the station on a space once occupied by a lumberyard and fuel oil delivery company, Mr. Calabrese said. The center would include five movie screens, a live stage and banquet facilities.
In addition, he said, a new supermarket is planned on the site of a former ShopRite market, along with 80 apartment units. Another 12,000 square feet of new retail space and 60 more apartments are planned where an automobile dealership was once located. All are within a minute or two from the train station on foot and, Mr. Calabrese said, have financing and have been approved by the Board of Trustees. 
In Maplewood, one stop to the west, property values have increased as the improved train service has attracted buyers, and many existing residents have been prompted to improve their properties, said Victor DeLuca, the mayor. "Having the train and its connection to New York is like boarding a subway in one of the city's boroughs," he said.
The downtown shopping district is attracting new types of stores, particularly restaurants. "People get off the train and meet someone for dinner," he said.
Since the downtown district is full, there is little opportunity for development, Mr. DeLuca said. For that reason, he said, town officials are trying to move the local post office out of downtown so the site can be used for more small businesses eager to have a presence in the area.
The Maplewood Concierge Company at the train station handles such things as dry cleaning, film developing and grocery purchases for harried commuters, who drop off their orders in the morning and pick up the goods in the evening. Like several other towns along the train line, Maplewood operates a jitney service for residents living too far away to walk to the train.
Maplewood has long had groups vigorously promoting community harmony and fighting racial tipping. Ellen Greenfield, a Maplewood resident who is a member of the South Orange-Maplewood Community Coalition on Race, said South Orange and Maplewood, which share a high school and have similar housing stock, are tolerant of alternate lifestyles. "We have nontraditional families here, including mixed-race couples and gay couples," she said. "The idea is to make everybody comfortable." 
Tolerance has had a financial payoff, said Barbara Heisler-Williams, executive director of the coalition. She said the assessed value of houses in Maplewood increased 19.4 percent from 1999 and 2000, while the value in South Orange went up 22.7 percent. She said that was a larger increase than in places like Chatham Borough and Chatham Township, traditionally considered more prestigious areas to live.
In Morristown, "everybody wants to be near the train station," said Jay Delaney, the mayor of the municipality that was a summer country retreat for New York's wealthy in the Gilded Age. Now, he said town houses priced close to $1 million each are being built near the Morristown station, from which a trip into New York takes about 60 minutes.
ALTHOUGH new housing is the most obvious impact of the new service, commercial developments are another spinoff, as demand rises for space for stores and other services, said Michael Fabrizio, executive director of the Morristown Partnership, a business development group.
He said there has been $200 million in private development in the town since the Midtown Direct trains started running and more projects are in the planning stages. He noted that the old Macy's store on the town's central square, about a half mile from the train station, sat idle for eight years before reopening last year as a Century 21 store.
The town is working with the state's Transportation Department to build a "transit village" on a parking lot adjacent to the train station. In place of a surface lot with 300 spaces, the development is to have 8,000 square feet of retail space, 200 units of housing and a parking deck that can accommodate 400 cars.
"Parking lots are almost by definition underutilized," Mr. Fabrizio said. "Now we will have a new ratable for the town and a model for New Jersey Transit in other places." He said approval by the planning board was expected before the end of the year, with construction expected to commence in the spring.
To the north and east in Montclair, trains began operating on the Montclair Connection a few weeks ago after decades of wrangling. According to local lore, the first suggestion of linking the two once-independent railroad lines, which were about one-third of a mile apart at their closest point, was made by planners in the late 1920's. The actual connection finally opened on Sept. 30.
Montclair's official history notes that the town was developed around rail lines. The railroad first arrived in 1856 and within a few years commuters could board a train in an area now known as Lackawanna Plaza, change trains in Newark, board a ferry in Hoboken and be in Manhattan in an hour and 20 minutes.
But this line did not serve the northern part of the town, known as Upper Montclair, so in 1873 a separate railroad was built with five stations in what had become the township of Montclair.
Over time the original line was electrified and became the Montclair branch of the Morris and Essex line, with one station in the township. The other line, known as the Boonton line, was used by diesel locomotives. Trips on both lines ended in Hoboken.
As plans were made to provide direct service into Manhattan, the logic of having a connection in Montclair for the two lines, both now operated by New Jersey Transit, became more powerful. The five stations in the township that had been served by diesel trains were electrified, a new station was built at Bay Street and the tracks of the Boonton line were connected to the end of the Montclair branch. The remainder of the Boonton tracks and several stations along the line are now unused.
Part of the reason for the long delay is that the connection had to run through one of the few areas of low-income housing in a generally prosperous region. Some of those in the neighborhood, which includes many minority residents, were displaced by demolition and others now face rapidly rising rents as well-off commuters seek housing near the Bay Street station.
"We fought the connection," said Robert Russo, mayor of the township, which has a population of about 36,000. "We don't have one central station like South Orange or Maplewood. We are the only town with tracks running through it and six stations. The impact is going to be enormous."
Development in nearby Bloomfield, which describes itself as a "working class" township, unlike some of its wealthier neighbors, is also being affected by the new train service. Plans are under way for a $160 million mixed residential and retail development centered on the Bloomfield train station. 
MR. HELLER, the principal of Sym Heller Development and Management, has made a business of following the improvement in rail service. He developed the new stores in the South Orange station, converted a printing building in Maplewood to office use and redeveloped an old supermarket about two blocks from the Bay Street station in Montclair to multiple retail use.
Currently, he is converting an old General Motors auto dealership building in Montclair's down-at-the-heels automotive row just east of Bloomfield Avenue, a major road in the area. Opened as Whitbeck Motor Sales in 1913, the dealership sold Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Cadillacs until being adversely impacted by the development of the Lackawanna Plaza shopping center in the mid-1980's.
That development took away the dealership's surface parking and blocked many of its showroom windows, according to Mr. Heller, making it difficult to attract customers to buy or service cars. 
He has removed many of the renovations done to the building, exposing brick structural piers and massive wooden trusses supporting the roof. He is converting it to office space and notes that it is a short walk from the Bay Street train station. Part of the space is already leased, he said.
Mr. Heller said the developments in the older suburbs along the railroad line are an extension of what has been happening in cities along the Hudson River. "Jersey City and Hoboken started as transportation hubs and became places to live and commute into New York," he said.
Mr. Heller said that even before the Manhattan Direct service was instituted, he had planned to develop the 13,000 square feet of retail space in the South Orange station, but he said the new service persuaded him to build a higher quality installation and lease to tenants like Starbucks and a bakery, rather than a sandwich shop. 
Steven D. Plofker, a lawyer and developer with offices in the Walnut Street train station in Montclair, said he thinks some areas of his town were ready for redevelopment even without the new rail service. One of his projects is another old auto dealership across a small triangular park from Mr. Heller's building.
Like Mr. Heller, Mr. Plofker is converting his old building to office space, preserving the roof trusses and skylights. "This is a neighborhood in transition," he said. "It used to be just a junkyard and used cars."
But a few blocks away, in a neighborhood of substantial single-family homes, he has another project that may benefit from its proximity to the Bay Street station. He is converting a factory, built in the days before zoning, into eight loft apartments that emphasize their industrial heritage.
He has chopped the middle out of the building so the complex will have a courtyard and is leaving the metal roof support trusses open. The floors are polished concrete, the wiring is in metal conduit attached to the masonry walls and the kitchens will be stainless steel. "We are trying to have an industrial look, and I like to leave the guts of things exposed," he said.
Mayor Russo said it was likely that most train-related development in Montclair would occur near the Walnut and Bay Street stations, since the stations farther up the line are closed in with housing and established retail development. A senior citizen housing project is nearing completion near the Bay Street station, and a new firehouse is planned nearby.
He said the town hopes to assist the few hundred residents of the older apartment buildings nearby, but admitted it might be difficult to resist economic forces. "We don't want people who have been living there for 10 or 20 years to be forced out because their rent has doubled," he said.
Some developers are eager to remove existing tenants so the generally run-down buildings can be rehabilitated to a condition more appealing to commuters. One owner of four buildings tried to empty them, saying the heating boilers were in a dangerous condition. The town blocked that attempt, but others are likely to follow. "People are looking for us to help, and we may buy a few abandoned properties for use as low-income housing," Mr. Russo said.
Meanwhile, the retail corridor along Bloomfield Avenue has been designated as an area in need of redevelopment, meaning the town can seize a property if the owners do not improve it. 
But Mr. Russo said the town is not eager to seize anything and is hoping the new train service and the residents he believes it will attract will persuade owners of some of the pockets of deteriorated stores to fix them up or sell to buyers who will.
"Things are happening that are at least partly driven by the train," he said. "I'm very positive about the future."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 3 about the effect of improved New Jersey Transit service on the downtown areas of several towns misstated the amount of commercial development in Morristown since 1996. It was $200 million, not $200.

63 of 812 DOCUMENTS

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: Look Who's Minding The Till in Camden 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
THE FIRST big surprise was that Governor McGreevey chose an official as high up as his righthand man, State Treasurer John E. McCormac, to become chairman of the 15-member Camden Economic Recovery Board to oversee a $175 million state revitalization program here. The second big surprise was that Mr. McCormac was willing to take the job, and enthusiastically.
 "There's something about this one that absolutely gets to me," Mr. McCormac said last Tuesday, days after presiding over the recovery board's first meeting. "I really feel motivated by this responsibility. It's an opportunity to make a difference in people's lives that someone in accounting or treasury doesn't always get a chance to do." 
 Moreover, a recent clarification from the state Supreme Court on its impending decision on publicly financed projects has given Mr. McCormac and others reason to move more quickly than ever on the recovery package.
In a city that not only is the state's poorest but also has a reputation for allowing money to filter into the wrong hands, putting the state's top money man in charge of allocating more than $175 million in state funds to various recovery projects makes a lot of sense. Proponents of the revitalization program hope that the state treasurer will mind the till as well as send a message to skeptical legislators (and their taxpaying constituents), the residents of Camden and private business.
"Camden has fundamental problems in its governance, and that starts with its financial governance," said State Senator Wayne Bryant of Camden, a sponsor of the legislation that created the revitalization program. "These are crucial times, and dollars aren't so plentiful. By putting John in charge, it's sending a message to taxpayers throughout the state that it's going to be done right."
In fact, some Camden leaders who may have been critical of state intervention in the past now recognize the need for an outside party at the helm.
"If the state's going to put that much money in Camden, they definitely want to be sure it's spent properly and it goes where it's supposed to go," said the Rev. James C. Jones, president of Concerned Black Clergy of Camden, who was quick to point out that three of Camden's last four mayors have been indicted on charges of financial improprieties.
The legislation is partly intended to encourage private enterprise to reinvest in this downtrodden city. Mr. McCormac said he hoped his presence at the head of the table -- as well as that of the state Community Affairs commissioner, Susan Bass, Levin and the Economic Development Authority chairman, Anthony Coscia, who are also members of the recovery board -- would help attract private investors.
"When you can make a pitch and the state treasurer and the head of community affairs are listening to you, it makes a difference. These are people who know how to leverage funds," said Mr. McCormac, who considers his task in Camden among his top assignments, right after managing the state's budget.
Day-to-day planning and the carrying out of the revitalization program will still be the responsibility of Melvin Primas, the state-appointed chief operating officer, who was officially hired and given a $175,000 annual salary at the Economic Recovery Board's first meeting, on Oct. 25. Mr. McCormac says he expects to be in touch daily with Mr. Primas and to attend all the board's meetings. 
From where Senator Bryant sits, having Mr. McCormac involved increases the potential to attract more private dollars and to tap into additional state funds if needed. The need for this might arise, he said, if, say, money has been allocated for a project to rebuild roads and sewers but then it is found that a bridge needs to be reinforced, too.
"The second-most-powerful person in the state after the governor is the treasurer," Mr. Bryant said. "He controls the purse strings, so having him there can be very helpful. He won't need to be brought up to speed' he'll already know what need to get done."
Mr. McCormac said he was especially moved by a two-hour tour of Camden last month that took him past Camden's success stories along the waterfront -- like the baseball stadium and the aquarium -- and then through the boarded-up neighborhoods in South Camden. 
"It was eye-opening," he said. "I thought, 'God, it needs help.' "
The board's next order of business, Mr. McCormac said, will be selecting a master planner from seven proposals.
While legal challenges to elements of the revitalization program still pose potential obstacles, a clarification by the Supreme Court on a broader issue is actually spurring the board to move faster.
Two weeks ago, the court heard arguments regarding the legality of the state's raising money through bond issues without voter approval. The court's decision on this question could affect numerous publicly financed projects, but when the state treasurer and the state attorney general asked the court if its ruling would apply to projects for which financing was already in process, the court said there would be no retroactive clause.
Senator Bryant said that upon learning of that ruling, he suggested the next day that Governor McGreevey go forward with the bond issues that will raise money for the Camden program.
"We have to move on it before they make their decision," the senator said. "The court won't come out with its ruling until early next year. We'll beat them."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "God, it needs help," said State Treasurer John E. McCormac, top right, on a tour of blighted Camden streets like that above. As chairman of the Camden Economic Recovery Board, Mr. McCormac will be working with Melvin Primas, right, chief operating officer of the recovery program. (Photographs by Tim Shaffer); (Michael Quan)

HEADLINE: SENIORITY; 
Older Voters Hear More Than War Drums

BYLINE:  By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
YOU might never know it from the nightly news, but the election on Tuesday is particularly important for older Americans.
 How the vote goes for the House and the Senate will help determine the kind of prescription drug coverage that retirees may receive, and whether conservatives can continue their drive to at least partly privatize the Social Security system. The new Congress will also face deep problems in Medicare, as well as the problem of the millions of people without any health insurance -- including many older Americans who are not yet eligible for Medicare. 
 But these domestic concerns have been drowned out, at least on the national level, by the Bush administration's constant talk of war with Iraq. Even that talk was drowned out for a while by the Washington-area sniper. 
"Bush has been very successful in focusing on Iraq," said Mark Weisbrot, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington. "Back in August, the Democrats were ahead on issues like the economy and Social Security. Lots of economic and social issues, as well as the corporate scandals, were pushed off the front pages by Iraq."
The White House may have changed the channel with the national news media, but has it also done so with voters?
We'll find out on Election Day. But a two-week car trip through the South last month left me skeptical that many voters have been diverted. In fact, it reinforced my faith in most voters' ability to see through news-media hype and political smoke screens from both parties. It's easy to get the impression that the Washington-New York media axis and great sections of the rest of the country are parallel universes with different realities.
Despite scant news coverage in the national news, economic and social issues are dominating many races around the country. That is clear from local television news and local political advertising: Republicans and Democrats are slugging it out over issues like Social Security privatization and prescription drug coverage. Recent polls have indicated that concern about the economy is growing.
"I wish we could have the Democrats run the economy and the Republicans run foreign policy and national security," one older voter, a Republican, told me in Louisiana. He said he disagreed with his party's efforts to privatize Social Security by allowing investments in stocks.
The power of older voters is traditionally strong in nonpresidential election years, when many younger voters take a pass. This year should be no exception, as the faltering economy and stock market pinch the pocketbooks of retirees and workers contemplating retirement.
Most people who have 401(k) plans received their third-quarter statements last month, and for many the news was not good. The Louisiana Republican with whom I talked said his 401(k) account lost $7,000 in the quarter.
There's also a lot of angst over Medicare, which continues to cut payments to doctors. These payments were reduced 5.4 percent last January and are expected to fall an additional 4.4 percent in January 2003. That is causing more doctors to refuse to take new Medicare patients. 
That problem -- together with the rising costs of prescription drugs, for which many older people have no coverage, and the fact that 41.2 million people have no health insurance whatsoever -- will command the attention of the new Congress. Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a conservative Democrat who often supports Republicans on social issues, has said in recent interviews that the American system of medical care "is collapsing around us." For the first time, he has called for universal coverage.
Prescription drug coverage is so popular that virtually no candidate for Congress opposes it. The issue is how comprehensive it will be and whether it will contain price controls. Democrats generally favor a comprehensive plan with such controls and run by Medicare; most Republicans want a less-expensive limited-coverage plan run by private insurance companies, and with no price caps. The outcome of the election will almost certainly decide whose plan prevails.
MR. WEISBROT, who is also the co-author of "Social Security: The Phony Crisis" (University of Chicago Press), says that while the medical care system is critically in need of reform, Social Security will be solvent for decades to come with only minor tinkering. Yet the rhetoric coming from Washington often indicates otherwise.
"For almost 20 years, politicians of both parties have pretended, for political gain, that there is a big problem with Social Security," he said. "So a lot of people have become convinced there really is a problem."
He says that those who push privatization to solve the "problem" are often the "ideological descendants of people who were opposed to Social Security when it was created in the 1930's" or represent Wall Street interests who want the commissions that investing Social Security money in stocks would bring.
Here's a sobering thought: Mr. Weisbrot and the Center for Economic and Policy Research (www.cepr.
net) have calculated that if the most modest of the various privatization plans had been put into effect at the beginning of 1998, the Social Security system would have lost $45 billion in the stock market by now.
But don't expect to hear that on the evening news. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Andra Roy, Gregory Chernack

 BODY:
Andra Marie Roy and Gregory Scott Chernack were married last evening at the Willard Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Joel I. Braude performed the ceremony. 
The Rev. Matthew J. Hillyard, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.
 Mrs. Chernack, 31, was until May the nominations clerk on the Senate Judiciary Committee in Washington; she also received a law degree that month from Catholic University of America. She graduated from Centenary College of Louisiana in Shreveport. Her parents, Joan and Normand Roy, live in Shreveport, where they are partners in Roy Real Estate, a residential brokerage firm. The bride's father also operates a realty appraisal and consulting business there. 
 Mr. Chernack, 31, is an associate at Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, the Washington law firm. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard and received a law degree from Yale. He also received a bachelor's degree in government and politics and a master's degree in philosophy, politics and economics from Oxford University. He is a director of the District of Columbia Public Library Foundation. 
The bridegroom is a son of Nancy Chernack and Dr. William Chernack of Bernardsville, N.J. His mother is a member of the board of the Women's League, the fund-raising arm of the Daughters of Israel Geriatric Center in West Orange, N.J. His father, an allergist, practices in Morristown, N.J., and is an assistant clinical professor of pediatrics at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York.

HEADLINE: PULSE: LOS ANGELES -- P.S.; 
A Hula Hoop Of Diamonds

 BODY:
 Thirteen years ago, Courtney Wagner (son of Robert) and best friend Anita Ko toiled away behind the jewelry counter at Fred Segal in Santa Monica and got to thinking: Why not create our own line? 
 The dream bore fruit last November with Wagner & Ko's circle necklace, an orb of either an inch or 1 1/4-inch in diameter made of diamonds or sapphires ($1,100 to $2,200). Thanks to recession-proof actresses like Cameron Diaz and Gwyneth Paltrow (who has bought six in the last four months), monthly sales have gone from about 10 last winter to about 40 now, Ms. Ko said. (Available at Maxfields and Tracey Ross in Los Angeles, Fred Segal in Santa Monica, and at Kirna Zabete in New York.)

SECTION: Section 4; Column 6; Editorial Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 156 words

HEADLINE: Nuclear North Korea 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Nicholas D. Kristof well understands our dearth of options in dealing with North Korea now that it has become a nuclear power ("The Greatest Threat," column, Oct. 29). But it has already proved worse than useless to negotiate a deal, as Mr. 
Kristof advocates. After all, what happened to the last deal? 
 Do what we may in the way of appeasement, we can be sure that Yongbyon will be turned into "a nuclear assembly line" and that the cash-starved country will sell its weapons to the highest bidder as it has threatened, because it has nothing else to sell.
In view of this, international sanctions are still our best bet, backed by a threat of destruction if North Korea uses its nuclear weapons or its powerful army against our allies.
Aren't we glad that Iraq has not yet reached the intractable point that North Korea has, and that there are still means of prevention there?

ALLAN R. SHICKMAN
St. Louis, Oct. 29, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
Latest Exit to Brooklyn

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
TIME was, you could stroll into a smoke-steeped bookstore on the Lower East Side, gamble a few bucks on a new novella by a budding writer-slash-anarchist who lived down the block, wander into the murky bar next door, and eavesdrop on that same writer trying to pry beer money from his editor.
 Those were the heady final years of the 20th century, before the dot-com bubble burst, when squatters still squatted, and the neighborhood's unruly township of tenements gave rise to a crackling literary scene inspired as much by punk rock as by Allen Ginsberg. Titles like "I Listen: A Document of Digital Voyeurism" by a techno-artist who called himself Spaceworm tried to subvert the rules of publishing, committing to print something as radical as the unedited transcripts of intercepted cellphone calls. 
 "It was one of those rare moments," said Bob Holman, a downtown literary figure who runs the Bowery Poetry Club. "There was a feeling that the anarchic punch of punk could have an effect beyond the art world. You could see a breakdown of the old hierarchies." 
But that moment withered. Due largely to the pressures of gentrification, the punks of publishing have been squeezed out of their turf on the Lower East Side and are setting up shop in various neighborhoods in Brooklyn. Like music clubs and other cultural exports that once defined the neighborhood's energy, indie presses have seen their rents rise and their audiences migrate across the East River. 
Underground magazines and books have been published on the Lower East Side since the 1960's. But the publishing scene had largely faded by the early 90's, until a small group of entrepreneurs from the music world revisited the genre. 
Among them were Gary Hustwit, a record promoter from San Diego who moved to New York in 1998 to jump-start Incommunicado Press, a micropublisher that billed itself as "the last hope for American publishing." Within days of arriving, he stumbled upon his future, an empty storefront adjoining Tonic, a music saloon on Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street.
The 800-square-foot space soon became a punk-publishing fortress. The back of the store was stuffed with desks and computers. The front looked like an anti-Barnes & Noble, cluttered with Gen-X memoirs, manifestoes against globalization, spoken-word CD's and do-it-yourself zines printed at the local copy shop. This was literature with (sometimes smudgy) soul, not mere off-the-shelf lit-product marketed like soap.
"During the day, from 10 to 6, we would run Incommunicado Press," said Mr. Hustwit, 37, who wears a goatee. "At 6, the publishing house staff would leave, and the bookstore staff would arrive and stay till midnight. We had a lot of drunken impulse buys."
Around the corner, in a dank basement on Suffolk Street, was Soft Skull Press, run by Sander Hicks, the front man for the hard-core punk band Subterfuge. "I was somewhere between being a squatter and a working-class hero," said Mr. Hicks, who was also the building's superintendent. He was 25 when he started the press in 1996, after gaining his publishing sea legs behind the counter of a Kinko's on West 12th Street.
Soft Skull made headlines in 1999 when it picked up "The Fortunate Son," a biography of George W. Bush that St. Martin's Press had dropped after learning that its author, J. H. Hatfield, had a criminal past. Soft Skull went from its usual print runs of a few hundred copies to an initial run of 25,000. "It's weird to be an anticapitalist capitalist," Mr. Hicks said. "We were coming from punk rock. But I was infused by the excitement of the creative dynamo of capitalism."
THE first rumblings of change began about two years ago, and they started with Incommunicado, for whom the attractions of capitalism spelled the demise of its creativity. In addition to issuing about 10 new books a year, Incommunicado recorded poetry and story readings, and distributed them over the Internet. "Authors like Rick Moody would come to Tonic," Mr. Hustwit said, "and we would go downstairs to where the wine barrels were and record a short story there because the acoustics were good."
The Web site on which the material was distributed, MP3lit.com, soon caught the eye of Salon.com. In 2000, just before the dot-com bubble burst, Mr. Hustwit sold his company to Salon, mostly for stock options then valued at $5 million. "I wish I could buy a car with what that is worth now," he said.
Soft Skull absorbed Incommunicado's titles and took over the bookstore. Its publishing schedule picked up, to some 12 titles a year. They ranged from "Online Diaries," the journal entries of Beck, Courtney Love and others during the 1995 Lollapalooza rock tour, to "Get Your War On," a series of comic strips by David Ress that satirize the war on terrorism.
But the book parties ended this summer, when Soft Skull was kicked out of Tonic. Commercial real estate trends suggested a better use for the space. "We broke down the wall and moved part of a bar there," said Melissa Caruso Scott, 31, who runs Tonic with her husband, John.
Richard Nash, 32, who became Soft Skull's editor at large last fall, scouted for other space on the Lower East Side, but everything he saw was too small and too expensive. Besides, in his estimation, the downtown scene had run its course, and his core readership of 20's and 30's culture vultures had moved on. "The next logical step was to find something in Brooklyn," said Mr. Nash, who lives in Williamsburg. "When Soft Skull first started, we were all hipsters who lived and worked in the Lower East Side. Now we're all in Brooklyn."
Last Friday, Soft Skull opened its new home in Boerum Hill, a sunny corner storefront on Bond Street near Atlantic Avenue. A bodega sits across the street, but nearby neighborhoods can be risky at night. "It was an opportunity to jump ahead of a curve, rather than follow a curve," he said.
Soft Skull already has good company. Akashic Books, whose co-founder in 1997 was Johnny Temple, the bass guitarist in the band Boys Against Girls, had relocated from the Lower East Side to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, several years earlier. 
"Brooklyn is not as commercialized as Manhattan," said Mr. Temple, who started Akashic in an East Village apartment with money his band received after signing with Geffen Records. "There's a thriving literary community in Brooklyn coming out of the young punk scene and outcast types. Fort Greene also has an incredible literary history. Walt Whitman lived here."
In addition, Brooklyn is home to several independent presses that have emerged in recent years, including Words Like Kudzu in Greenpoint, which has published five titles of experimental fiction. The Clovis Press bookstore at 229 Bedford Avenue is gaining a reputation as Williamsburg's answer to the St. Marks Bookshop in the East Village.
In publishing, as in other fields, it almost feels as if Brooklyn and downtown Manhattan are trading places. 
"Culturally, it has shifted," said Beau Friedlander, the publisher of Context Books, a small TriBeCa publisher. "I've pitched and sold more books on the L train in Brooklyn, just running into people." Still, Brooklyn is untested as a place to nurture alternative publishing. For one thing, the scene is scattered among several neighborhoods, said Marvin Taylor, director of the Downtown Collection at the Fales Library at New York University, which houses a large archive of independent press works from the mid-1970's to the present. 
"We think of downtown as a physical and metaphysical space," Mr. Taylor said. "But it's still not clear to me what Brooklyn is."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "When Soft Skull first started," says Richard Nash, its editor at large, far left, "we were all hipsters who lived and worked in the Lower East Side. Now we're all in Brooklyn." Before moving, Soft Skull was a veritable punk-lit fortress, left, next to the saloon Tonic. LENGTH: 943 words

HEADLINE: Business; 
Global Issues Flow Into America's Coffee

BYLINE:  By KIM BENDHEIM 

 BODY:
A BUZZ in California has caught the attention of the world's biggest coffee companies.
 In a growing movement reminiscent of the grape boycott in the 1970's, antiglobalization and human rights advocates in California have been promoting the purchase of Fair Trade certified coffee -- coffee that guarantees a so-called living wage to poor coffee farmers in developing countries. An estimated 25 million of these farmers have suffered because raw coffee prices have fallen below the cost of production. 
 Students in California have helped to pressure the Sara Lee Corporation, the maker of the Hills Bros. and Chock Full O' Nuts brands, to start buying small amounts of Fair Trade coffee. On Tuesday, voters in Berkeley, Calif., a longtime redoubt of student activism, will vote on a measure that would require the city's restaurants and supermarket cafes to restrict sales of brewed coffee to blends that are Fair Trade, organic or shade grown, which are considered more environmentally friendly than conventional, mass-produced varieties. Violators could face $100 fines and six-month jail terms. 
Major coffee companies have denounced the Berkeley measure. But at least one, Procter & Gamble, which sells the Folger's brand, said it would work with beverage servers to comply if the measure passed.
Fair Trade coffee, a pet project of the antiglobalization movement, has become a growing segment of the $55 billion coffee industry. Although Fair Trade coffee is only about 2 percent of the global supply, sales rose 36 percent last year in the United States, the biggest single market for coffee. About 7,000 retail outlets across the country sell Fair Trade coffee, according to TransFair USA, a nonprofit group in Oakland, Calif., that monitors food company compliance with Fair Trade standards. 
Last week, Green Mountain Coffee, a wholesaler in Waterbury, Vt., signed an agreement to sell Fair Trade coffee under the Newman's Own Organics label, the food company owned by Paul Newman, next year in supermarkets nationwide.
The economic argument for Fair Trade coffee got a lift in September when Oxfam, the British charity, released a report saying that a global oversupply of coffee had pushed prices to their lowest levels in 100 years, adjusted for inflation, impoverishing millions of coffee farmers in developing countries. In Latin America, Africa and Asia, the report said, farmers are paid roughly 24 cents a pound for beans, while the four multinational companies that buy nearly half of the world's coffee -- Sara Lee, Kraft, Procter & Gamble and Nestle -- sell those beans at an average price of $3.60 a pound and "are laughing all the way to the bank." 
Fair Trade coffee, which can cost more than double the price of conventional blends at the checkout counter, is comparable in quality and price to premium blends. Small farmer cooperatives are guaranteed to receive about $1.25 a pound for Fair Trade coffee. 
To help these farmers, Oxfam proposed to the International Coffee Organization, a group of 40 major importers and exporters, that it cut the oversupply, and help raise prices, by destroying stockpiles of the lowest-quality beans.
Organization members generally oppose that approach, arguing that stimulating demand is a better way to raise price than reducing supply. Many also reject the Fair Trade approach, saying it supports prices artificially and could worsen the glut.
"Fair Trade isn't a viable solution," said Gordon Gillet, Nestle's senior vice president for purchasing and exports. "First, it favors the few and, secondly, it provides an incentive to farmers to increase coffee production at a time when they should perhaps be seriously considering alternative crops."
Anneke Theunissen, a spokeswoman for Fairtrade Labelling Organizations International, the group that oversees Fair Trade certification, disagreed. "At this moment, Fair Trade labeling is the only way for the disadvantaged small farmers to survive in the market," she said. 
As for the Berkeley initiative, the industry has largely dismissed it as a quirky extreme, saying customers should decide what coffee they want.
"Berkeley has always distinguished itself, to put it politely, by a surprising originality," said Francois-Xavier Perroud, a Nestle spokesman.
BERKELEY, though, may be a natural place for the coffee controversy to percolate. The city is known as a coffee Mecca where couples go to coffee houses on dates rather than to bars, and where drinkers debate the merits of one roast over another the way the French debate the merits of wines. Peet's Coffee and Tea, a famous Berkeley roaster, was the training ground for the founders of Starbucks, the biggest and most successful coffee bar chain in the world. Both were early sellers of Fair Trade beans, along with other coffees.
The Fair Trade movement began in 1997 with the establishment of the Fair Trade Labeling Organizations International in Bonn. Its founders hoped to offset the effects of global economic forces on poor countries by establishing a set price for certain commodities like coffee and cocoa. 
The value of global coffee exports has fallen by an estimated $8 billion since the 1997-98 crop year because of a glut in a market that was once regulated but is now mostly free. The biggest increase in supply came from Brazil and Vietnam, low-cost producers.
Robert Nelson, president of the National Coffee Association, a trade group that represents the coffee industry in this country, called Fair Trade certification one small answer to the oversupply issue.
"We need broader-based initiatives to really make a difference in the crisis," he said. "There is no one magic bullet."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Coffee growers in Peru, top, have joined the Fair Trade movement. Shops like A Cuppa Tea, in Berkeley, Calif., promote its products. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times); (Pilar Olivares/Reuters)
