SECTION: Section 1; Column 6; National Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1726 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS; 
IN POLL, AMERICANS SAY BOTH PARTIES LACK CLEAR VISION

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JANET ELDER

 BODY:
The battle for control of Congress moved into its final stretch with Americans unsettled about conditions at home and threats from abroad, but saying that Democrats and Republicans have failed to offer a clear vision about how they would lead the nation, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
 The poll also found an emerging divide between Democrats and Republicans in their perception of the state of the nation and the problems it faces this fall. More than twice as many Republicans as Democrats -- 63 percent compared with 27 percent -- said the country was heading in the right direction. Democrats were twice as likely as Republicans to say the economy was the primary issue that would determine their vote. 
 These findings come in the closing days of a campaign that has failed to stir much interest among voters. Nearly half said they were less enthusiastic about voting this time than they have been in past Congressional campaigns. 
But the poll suggested that if many voters were uninspired with the candidates, many were worried about where the country was heading, and about the challenges the next Congress would face. Americans expressed concerns about a worsening economy, the prospect of a war with Iraq and terrorist attacks at home. In one sign of disquiet, a substantial majority, 66 percent, said they believed life would not be better for their children than it was for them.
The final poll of this campaign suggested some difficulties for Democrats as they seek to win back control of the House, a goal that party leaders have in recent days described as daunting, while maintaining control of the Senate. Despite a flurry of speeches, advertisements and policy papers issued by Democratic leaders over the last month, barely a third of respondents said the Democrats had presented a "clear plan for the country" in the fall campaign. About 4 in 10 respondents said the same thing about the Republican Party.
In one closely watched if imprecise measure of the overall partisan strength of the two parties, 47 percent of likely voters said they would vote for a Republican in next week's Congressional contest, compared with 40 percent who said they would vote Democratic. The margin of sampling error for that question was plus or minus five percentage points.
But that question, known as a generic ballot question, is a measure of national sentiment, and does not necessarily reflect how Americans will vote in the governor's races around the country and in the handful of close Senate and House races that will ultimately determine the control of Congress.
The concern among Democrats about the nation's direction and the economy suggests that Democratic voters might be more motivated to cast their ballots on Tuesday and respond to the ambitious get-out-the-vote drives that have been organized by the Democratic Party, aimed in particular at voters who are distressed about the economy. 
President Bush, who has invested so much of his own political capital in the outcome of the elections, remains extremely popular with voters. In this poll, 62 percent of respondents said they approved of how he was handling his job, though that is down markedly from his 74 percent rating of last summer.
The nationwide poll of 1,018 Americans, including 795 registered voters, was taken from Oct. 27 to Oct. 31. The margin of error for the overall poll was plus or minus three percentage points.
The poll found that the political significance many Democratic and Republican analysts in Washington ascribed to the vote in Congress on the Iraq resolution might have been overstated. Nearly two-thirds of respondents said they had no notion of how their representative had voted on the Iraq resolution that passed Congress last month. Twice as many voters said that a candidate's position on the economy was more important to them than how that candidate had voted on Iraq.
The poll came at the close of an extraordinarily competitive campaign for Congress that will determine whether a single party, the Republicans, will control the White House, the Senate and the House for at least the next two years. The Republicans now have a six-seat edge in the House, while the Democrats held a single-seat margin in the Senate until the death of Paul Wellstone.
As a final measure of just how competitive these contests are, President Bush turned his weekend into a nonstop campaign swing, visiting states and Congressional districts that remained close in these final days. A visit by Mr. Bush, White House aides said, produces a bounce of support for the Republican candidate that can last for two or three days, so this last weekend of trips has taken on particular significance.
Yet for all the attention being showered on these races by the president and the national political committees this weekend, the poll found that many Americans remained unmoved by the contests before them -- and unimpressed with the candidates and what they are saying. About 40 percent of voters said they were less enthusiastic about voting in this election than in previous Congressional elections.
"There used to be more enthusiasm and the issues were clearer," Claire Forst, 50, a nurse from Brooklyn, said in a follow-up interview. "Now you just feel that there is no reason to go out to vote because whatever happens, it's not going to matter anymore."
At the same time, Americans are clearly unsettled about the problems facing the nation. More than half of all respondents said they believed the nation was heading in the wrong direction; by a similar margin, Americans said the economy was in fairly bad or very bad shape. In this latest poll, 59 percent of Americans said they believed an attack on Iraq would worsen the threat of a terrorist attack in the United States, an increase of 9 points from a month ago.
"Saddam scares me," said Linda Annan, 53, a clerk from Lancaster, Pa., who is a Democrat. "Going to war scares me. The economy has me concerned." 
Chris Spensberg, 49, a Republican from Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., said, "With the economy and the world situation with Iraq and terrorism, you don't really have a notion that anybody has a clear-cut answer to take care of them."
The economy continues to be the issue of principal concern among the electorate: 15 percent of respondents named it as the most important issue. By contrast, just 2 percent of respondents named terrorism and 2 percent said foreign policy.
In one sense, that is precisely what Democratic strategists had hoped for in laying out a plan this year to win back control of the House, in the belief that voters would turn to Democrats at a time when they were concerned about the nation's economic health.
But for whatever reason -- the success President Bush had in focusing attention on Iraq, or what some Democrats say is the party's failure to offer its own economic plan -- there is little evidence to date that the Democrats have been able to take command of the issue. The nation was evenly divided over which party was more likely to make the country prosperous: 38 percent of respondents named Republicans, while 39 percent named Democrats.
There were still some clear differences among voters in how they viewed the strengths of the parties. By a three-to-one margin, voters said Republicans were more likely than Democrats to provide the nation with a strong military. By nearly the same margin, voters said Democrats were more likely than Republicans to make certain that prescription drugs were affordable to the elderly. 
For Mr. Bush, there has, over the last month, been a slight increase -- to 35 percent from 27 percent -- in the number of people who say he is "paying enough attention" to the economy. The rise coincides with a period in which the White House made a concerted effort to portray Mr. Bush as concerned with that issue. At the same time, 54 percent of respondents in this poll said they approved of the president's handling of foreign policy, among the lowest figures since the World Trade Center attack of last September.
Still, as always, there was mixed evidence of the degree to which Mr. Bush benefited Republican candidates, and how much weight his appeal for a Republican Congress might carry. 
Nearly half of voters said it was "better for the country" to have divided government. About 40 percent said the president was not a factor in their vote, while 31 percent said they considered their vote to be one of support for Mr. Bush and 19 percent considered their vote to be in opposition to him. 
"I really support Bush," said Nona Hesson, 58, a retired teacher from Kerrville, Tex., who is a Republican. "If the Republicans get control of Congress, I think it would be a lot easier for Bush to get his point across." 
But, Ms. Hesson added: "I don't want things to just be railroaded through. I think if we had equal representation in Congress, it would be the best solution, rather than one party having main control."

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sunday through Thursday with 1,018 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 795 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age, and education. 
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error. Variations in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.
Complete poll results are available at nytimes.com.

SECTION: Section 10; Column 1; Job Market; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 725 words

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Joblessness, a Bit More His Than Hers

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
WHO, exactly, are the unemployed these days? It's not that easy to get an answer.
 You might think the government knows, and it does, sort of. Or will, eventually. The federal government does a telephone survey each month so that it can calculate the official unemployment rate. 
 But the number of people questioned is tiny. And even so, it will be months or years before researchers analyze all the data. Critics also point out that many unemployed people don't have telephones, or aren't around to answer them.
 Then there are anecdotal descriptions. Some commuters have a simple definition of the unemployed: the people they used to see on the train every morning who aren't filling the seats anymore. PTA leaders may see the unemployed in a sudden surge of volunteers, people who used to be too busy to pick their children up at school.
 You may notice the unemployed holding "office hours" at Starbucks, or using the computers at the public library to perform job searches. They may be the new faces turning up at the food bank, or the people haunting storefront employment agencies, desperate storefront employment agencies, desperate for even a day's pay.
 Another way to get a snapshot of the jobless, if not a complete portrait, is to look at who has been receiving unemployment insurance benefits. It is only a sketch, because many people who are out of work do not qualify for benefits; they worked only part time, perhaps, or for too short a stretch, a made too little money.
 "At least half of the unemployment are not reflected in the data," said James Parrott, deputy director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research group. At the same time, he noted, certain industries like construction usually have a lot of workers receiving benefits, because their employment is seasonal.
 The data have other quirks. The New York State Department of Labor releases 12-month moving averages, so it's not clear how many people were getting benefits in August, only how many were getting benefits, on average, in the 12 months ending in August. And August is the most recent month of available data.
 So the following picture is not panoramic. 
 But given all those caveats, here is the typical unemployed person in New York City: male, between the ages of 25 and 34, with a high school degree, and a previous job in a white-collar service-sector (in something like advertising or accounting or computer services).
 That would have been the picture the previous year (the "before 9/11" year), too, but with one different. A year ago, the typical unemployed person would probably have been a woman.
 Unemployment in New York City is divided remarkably equally between men and women, at least according to the benefits data. A year ago, 49.4 percent of recipients were male; now, about 50.6 percent are.
 The number of people of both sexes receiving benefits has soared by 58 percent in the 12-month period, to an average of 95,360 from 60,440; the rate of increase among men has just been slightly higher than the rate for women.
 There have been some other interesting changes, too. People with "professional" jobs, as the labor department defines them, are now the second largest group of unemployed people, after blue-collar workers; a year ago, clerical workers were No. 2.
 And there has been a surge in unemployment among the highly educated. Though their numbers are still small, those with more than four years of college rose by 68 percent, to 6,250, on average, in the latest 12 months. The number of unemployed people with four years of college almost doubled, to 18,050.
 The industries that produced all these unemployed people are the ones you might expect: business services, manufacturing (especially apparel and printing), retailing, finance and construction. The drop in tourism also created an increase in laid-off workers at hotels, restaurants and airports.
 Men dominated the construction layoffs; women lost the majority of manufacturing jobs (because of the garment industry) and were also harder hit by cutbacks in the finance area, which includes banking.
 And of all the employers tracked by the Labor Department, only one produced fewer laid-off workers this year than it did the year before. It's also the one the least connected to the New York economy. It is, of course, the federal government. Somehow, that just figures.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1053 words

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Preaching the Gospel According to Dave & Buster

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
THE instructor had flown in from Dallas and was teaching the class in a corner of the billiards room. The students were a dozen young men newly hired for the security staff, and the smallest, judging by appearances, might be able to squeeze into a XL shirt.
 Today's lesson: How do to deal with difficult customers. 
 It was the last day of the two-week training period, and the goal was to imbue 300 new employees of the newest Dave & Buster's restaurant with the chain's way of doing things. This branch, on Veterans Memorial Highway in Islandia, is the 32nd branch of the Dallas chain, which promotes itself as the "ultimate place for big 'kids' to play." 
The Dave & Buster's chain attracts about a million customers a year with its blend of sports bar, video arcade, billiards parlor and nightclub. The chain falls into the category the restaurant industry calls "eater-tainment," pulling in customers with better than bar food and an array of games, drinks and distractions.
Dave & Buster's arrival on Long Island was preceded by Jillian's, a competitor with locations in Westbury and Farmingdale. 
Like many large companies, Dave & Buster's has its own way of doing things and its own lingo, and both were heavily emphasized in the days of training leading up to the restaurant's opening on Sept. 18. 
The first few weeks of operation are crucial, said John Mirabal, the general manager of the Islandia restaurant. If customers are disappointed, they will not return, so Dave & Buster's, like many chains, puts substantial effort into getting its openings right.
"We pay constant attention to the details so that nothing goes wrong," said Mr. Mirabal, who had been the general manager of the chain's branch in Honolulu. 
Mr. Mirabal said he worked closely during the summer with the other members of the opening team to make sure that things went just so. 
"We say 'thank you' a lot," said Paul Martinez, the team's coordinator. "We expect each guest to hear the words 'thank you' at least 30 times in the course of their visit."
As Mr. Mirabal, Mr. Martinez and other managers scurried about attending to last-minute details, in the billiards room, Will Carr was teaching the security staff ways of keeping order and handling customers who may have had too much to drink. 
The emphasis is not on enforcing rules, like the one that proscribes smoking, but on treating customers as if they were friends paying a personal visit, Mr. Carr said. He emphasized the distinction between customers and guests.
"McDonald's has customers and Wal-Mart has customers," he said. "Dave & Buster's has guests."
The new employees, many of whom had worked as bouncers at bars or nightclubs, grappled with the concept. "This is what?" Mr. Carr asked aloud, gesturing at the walls around him. The question drew blank stares.
"This is your home," he continued. "People who come to your home are what?"
One of the students tentatively replied, "Guests?"
"Guests!" Mr. Carr said, with the enthusiasm of a speaker certain that a troubling question has, at last, been put to rest. "They are guests. We treat them, and one another, with respect. You wouldn't chase after a guest to your home and tell them you have a no-smoking policy, would you? At Dave & Buster's we are ladies and gentlemen serving ladies and gentlemen."
It was a phase new employees would hear over and over.
On opening day, the company's founders, Dave Corriveau and Buster Corley, attended the ceremonies. "We would have been in this market a long time ago, but until recently we couldn't secure a location on a budget we could pay," Mr. Corriveau said. 
Moving into Long Island, Dave & Buster's followed the store-opening process it has developed over the 20 years it has been in business, tweaking it here and there to meet local needs. In mid-July, an advance team led by Mr. Mirabal arrived and opened a recruiting center in Stony Brook. Situated strategically near the state university campus, the center was close to a ready supply of prospective part-time employees. On Aug. 1, the hiring center moved to Islandia. Throughout August the company continued to advertise for employees and to post notices on employment Web sites. Representatives attended a series of career fairs and job expos.
"The toughest part is having to explain to people what Dave & Buster's really is, until they've experienced it for themselves," said William P. Jacobus, the chain's director of beverage operations and a member of the opening team.
Mr. Jacobus spent part of his summer recruiting the kitchen staff in the culinary programs at local colleges. The cooking staff and other kitchen employees then received up to three weeks of training, Mr. Jacobus said. Bartenders received two weeks, as did security captains. Other employees received a week or less.
"I've opened 19 stores, and I don't see much anymore that surprises me," Mr. Jacobus said. "Long Island is pretty much like our other markets. I did notice that people seemed to already know one another from earlier jobs when they got here. I think the labor pool for this industry is pretty established."
Bridget Bain, the special-events sales manager in Islandia, said she and her staff spent the summer and early fall introducing themselves to large companies within a 10-mile radius and becoming active in local business groups. Despite the slow economy, she said, the effort was beginning to pay off, although she would not say how many meetings or events had been scheduled at the new location. 
"We had a wonderful week last week, and each week bookings continue to grow," she said on Monday.
John Donaldson of East Hampton said he came to Dave & Buster's in Islandia nearly every weekend, meeting a friend from Kew Gardens, Queens. "It's sort of a halfway place to meet for her and for me," he said. "The food is better than your average sports bar, the service is great, and there are plenty of things to do after you finish eating. It's a complete evening."
Mr. Donaldson, a manager at the East Hampton Business Services center, said he was intrigued by the promises the chain made before the Islandia location opened. "It all sounded different and appealing and turned out to be what they said it would be," he said. "There really was nothing like it before they arrived. I tell people it's like Chuck E. Cheese's, only for adults."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kyle Abbe, left, a training specialist for Dave & Buster's restaurants, and his kitchen trainees giving encouragement to Rosarito Gervasi as she got ready to send out a dish to corporate judges before the opening of the restaurants' Islandia branch. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 6; Column 3; Magazine Desk; Pg. 67

LENGTH: 4492 words

HEADLINE: The Thinking Inside The Box 

BYLINE:  By Lynn Hirschberg; Lynn Hirschberg is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
 In September we asked Leslie Moonves, president and C.E.O. of CBS and head of UPN, Jeff Zucker, president of NBC Entertainment, and Chris Albrecht, chairman of HBO, to imagine a perfect television schedule. Starting from scratch, with unlimited funds and access to talent, how would they build their fantasy network universe? Just before the Emmys, as their new fall shows were starting to appear, Moonves, Zucker and Albrecht met at the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Los Angeles to talk about an ideal TV reality and why it's so hard to achieve. 

The Fantasy-Land Do-It-Yourself Whatever-You-Want Network

JEFF ZUCKER: You're really tan.
LESLIE MOONVES: You know what? I haven't gone away. I have a place in Malibu, and I tan very fast. So--.
ZUCKER: He's really tan.
MOONVES: Thank you. It's that Bob Evans look.
LYNN HIRSCHBERG: O.K., the game here is, you have a clean slate. You have no schedule. And at least initially we're going to pretend, Chris, that you work in an environment that involves advertising.
CHRIS ALBRECHT: O.K.
HIRSCHBERG: You're not at HBO.
ZUCKER: You're busted.
MOONVES: Yeah, none of this highfalutin stuff anymore.
HIRSCHBERG: But then we'll let you two play at running HBO. So you're starting from scratch. You have all the money and talent you want. How do you create a network?
ALBRECHT: I think the first thing you need is a plan, a target for your business model. And that's not just, how much are you going to spend and what are you going to charge the advertisers, but whom are you going after? More and more, that question determines a lot of what people are programming. The hardest target is to try to please everybody. The idea that there's a model 18- to 49-year-old person is ridiculous. I don't know any 18-year-old who likes the same thing as a 49-year-old except in very, very, very, very rare cases. So I would try and find a different targeted demo -- probably young men, probably young women, although those groups are pretty fickle. Or maybe I would even target an older, more upscale audience. But I would avoid the get-the-biggest-number-of-eyeballs-into-the-tent-at-all-given-times measure of success, because I think it's the hardest way to go.
MOONVES: I slightly disagree with you. I think you cannot be all things to all people all the time, but at certain times of the day you can be. You can have a show that is targeted for 60-year-olds on Sunday at 7 o'clock. And on Thursday at 8 o'clock you can be going after 22-year-olds. I think the idea is to be diverse -- and I don't mean just racially, although that is important. I still remember what Brandon Tartikoff said when everybody was giving him credit for "Hill Street Blues" turning around the network. He said it wasn't "Hill Street Blues"; it was "The A-Team" that really did it. "Hill Street" got all the Emmy Awards, but "The A-Team" brought viewers to "Hill Street." You know, "Fear Factor" and "West Wing" can live successfully together. "Survivor" and "60 Minutes" can live successfully together. "Taxicab Confessions" and "The Sopranos" can live successfully together.
ZUCKER: I think we want to appeal to the demo that the advertisers are trying to reach, which is most likely 18-to-54. But at the same time, I would also like this fictitious network to be as broad as possible and have as many people under the age of 18 as over 54.
MOONVES: Hold it. He has just disputed everything NBC has stood for in the last 30 years.
ZUCKER: That's not true. That's not true.
MOONVES: Jeff ZUCKER has come around to the right way of thinking.
ZUCKER: A broadcaster should be exactly that, broad-caster. I've learned this from my friend Les. I believe the No. 1 priority is to deliver those 18- to 54-year-olds. Because that's what the advertisers want. And you notice I expanded it to 54, by the way.
MOONVES: That's good.
ZUCKER: But having said that, I believe that we should also try and appeal to as many people as possible. That's all I'm trying to say. And I actually would say, for Les's benefit, that we haven't been smart enough about that in recent years.
MOONVES: I'm speechless.
ZUCKER: Which is a stunning fact, right there. But I do believe you have to get the younger people first, because they're the hardest group to reach.
MOONVES: Well the big hits will attract everybody. You know, the 60-year-olds are watching "Survivor," and the 14-year-olds are watching "Survivor."
ZUCKER: That's the only way a network becomes a hit.

All Hits Are Surprises
MOONVES: You need a monster hit -- and the irony is, all hits are surprises. You don't know that "Sopranos" is going to change the world, that "Friends" is going to change the world, that "Survivor" is going to change the world.
HIRSCHBERG: I think Chris knew "Sopranos" would.
ALBRECHT: Not a clue.
MOONVES: "Survivor" was a fluke. Both "Big Brother" and "Survivor" were experiments.
ZUCKER: Most hits are flukes. Most hits probably almost didn't get on the air.
MOONVES: When NBC put "E.R." on the air, they did not like the testing. Julianna Margulies died in the first episode. Then, holy mackerel, she's testing -- maybe we better put the oxygen back on and let her live.
ALBRECHT: On "Hill Street," two guys actually died in the pilot. Then the show got on the air, and all of a sudden they were just seriously wounded. That show kind of limped along the first year until it got how many Emmy nominations?
ZUCKER: Well, the other problem in creating this perfect network schedule -- if there's ratings involved -- is waiting out the great shows. Before, shows could finish last in the ratings and eventually become hits. But it's much harder for that to happen today.
HIRSCHBERG: Well, say you could wait. Would you start with a drama, or would you start with a comedy? Jeff, you have this famous line--.
MOONVES: He has a famous line?
ZUCKER: Don't give me any openings. Oh, what I've said is, "Yes, I wish I had 22 Aaron Sorkins creator of 'The West Wing' ," because we would do 22 hours of "The West Wing." But the fact is, I can't afford it either financially or creatively, because there aren't 22 Aaron Sorkins.
HIRSCHBERG: Well, let's say there were five.
ZUCKER: Well there are five Aaron Sorkins. One of them's doing "The Sopranos," and one's doing a series for Les, and one's doing a series for us. Even so, I would start my new fantasy network with a comedy. Because I think, especially today, a comedy is much harder to find. And I think that with advertisers there's much more of a quest for a big, great comedy. I would try and target it younger, because it's harder to find the younger people, and if you make it a hit, everybody else will come. I don't think you have to stay in the "Friends" formula or anything like that.
MOONVES: They've been saying that for eight years.
ZUCKER: Exactly. NBC's biggest problem is they keep saying, "Find the next 'Friends."' There is no next "Friends." There will be a next great show.

Alchemy in the Golden Age of Drama
MOONVES: You know, when we start development, and people say, "What are you looking for?" We really say, "We're looking for everything." I don't know where my next hit is coming from. If you ask me today what will be on the schedule next May, I wouldn't even come close to having a clue.
HIRSCHBERG: You know that "Star Search" will be on.
MOONVES: Right -- may it be as successful as "American Idol." But, remember, we had it first. When you look at the past few years at CBS, it's a combination of "Survivor," "C.S.I." and "Raymond." Those are our three bright, shining lights. And they're all in very different genres and very different styles of shows.
HIRSCHBERG: But are advertisers or audiences looking for something specific?
MOONVES: Well, Jeff's correct. I think this is the golden age of drama. I don't think there has ever been a time in the history of network television that there've been more great dramas across the board. But comedy has had a rather fallow period. And what everybody is looking for is, What is the next breakout comedy?
ALBRECHT: Whether it's a comedy or a drama, you're looking for your signature show. Something that not only brings people in but says a little bit about what you stand for, to the audience and to other creative people. What "The Sopranos" did was show people what was possible.
ZUCKER: I think Chris has a really good point. Whether it's "Sopranos" or "The West Wing" or "C.S.I." or "Raymond" or "Survivor," we each have had signature series. I think that that's critical.
HIRSCHBERG: Do you ever initiate ideas?
ZUCKER: I might have a lot of crazy, wacky ideas, but the best ideas actually walk in the door.
MOONVES: Yeah, I think our skill is better as an editor and a sifter-through of material.
ALBRECHT: I don't do anything on a show. I don't write a show. I don't direct a show. I don't produce a show. I don't act in a show. I don't edit a show. So my idea of a show is almost sort of useless. I don't do anything.
HIRSCHBERG: Don't you help with casting? You said yes to James Gandolfini, which was a daring, nonnetwork sort of choice.
ALBRECHT: There were three people tested for the role: Stevie Van Zandt; a guy named Michael Rispoli, who played the don that Junior ends up inheriting the family from; and Gandolfini. Rispoli was funny, and I thought, Well, it could be him. The other guy's scary. And big. And mean. Ultimately, the question was, Who would Tony Soprano really be? That was the only way we could finally make a decision, because the room was split.
MOONVES: Supposedly, Anthony LaPaglia had the part when "The Sopranos" was at Fox.
ZUCKER: That's right.
ALBRECHT: For me to come up with an idea is almost useless, because then I'm like some nonwriting executive producer who's trying to get people to do what's in my head, when what I really want them to do is what's in their heads. I just want what's in their heads to be really good.
HIRSCHBERG: So even in a fictitious network, you're sort of stuck -- you're dependent on Aaron Sorkin or David Chase creator of "The Sopranos" . Is there anybody that's not on your schedules that you would all dream of working with?
ALBRECHT: I love Letterman. I think he'd be the perfect guy on HBO. I'd probably have him do some version of what he does.
MOONVES: Sorry, you can't have him. Others have tried.
ALBRECHT: I think that Dave is unique in the sense that he has tremendous credibility with lots of different constituencies. The rest of the stuff -- you know, I was in Florida at a convention for HBO, and Peter Roth FedExed me the "West Wing" pilot, because he didn't think it was going to get on the air. But I said I didn't think that it was right for HBO.
HIRSCHBERG: Why not?
ALBRECHT: It's a great drama for network television because it's kind of almost really about something. But it stays in a somewhat safe territory.

You Love Larry David, but Would You Want to Marry Him?
HIRSCHBERG: Jeff, who would you want to work with?
ZUCKER: I think Larry David co-creator of "Seinfeld," now star and creator of "Curb Your Enthusiasm" is a brilliant guy, and he's obviously had tremendous success at several series. And so he might be somebody that we could turn to for this comedy that we're going to use as a building block.
MOONVES: Larry's good. "Curb Your Enthusiasm" may be my favorite comedy on the air.
HIRSCHBERG: And it's on HBO. But "Curb Your Enthusiasm," there's an interesting question--.
ZUCKER: Would it work on the network?
MOONVES: It is probably too off for CBS right now. I think the advantage that HBO has is, they're looking to attract subscribers. It's a different attitude than attracting a mass audience.
HIRSCHBERG: Jeff, you want to work with Larry David, but would you put on something like "Curb Your Enthusiasm"?
ZUCKER: I'm going to ask him to develop the next comedy.
MOONVES: He wants "Seinfeld."
ZUCKER: I think "Curb Your Enthusiasm" is a great show. I don't know if it would be the anchor comedy that we want to build this network on. But I want Larry to create the next one, and I'm happy to leave it up to him to figure out what that is.
ALBRECHT: But if you think that it's really funny, and if you like Larry David, why wouldn't you put it on and see what happens?
ZUCKER: I think we should keep on programs that we think are terrific that don't necessarily have a big audience to begin with. But I think we can also have a gut as to whether it's ever going to find that big audience.
MOONVES: The old days of sitting with a 9 share because it's going to grow to a 15, those days are over. We're in a 500-channel universe. The die is cast in six weeks. You can make a move or two and see if it has a shot. But you know pretty well.
ZUCKER: That's the difference between our universe and HBO.

Never Another 'Everybody Loves Raymond'
ALBRECHT: So you think what happened with "Everybody Loves Raymond," where it built over time, couldn't happen even now?
MOONVES: Exactly. We were a 12th-place network at the time "Raymond" was on. It was Friday night, 8 to 9, where we were dead anyway. Then we flipped it a couple of times, and it showed some life. Unfortunately you can't have the patience for the builds anymore. In your ideal world, where I have all the money in the world, and I don't have a corporation looking down on me, maybe I could be more patient.
ZUCKER: Especially when you're at a network that is having some success, I don't believe that it's possible for a "Cheers" or a "Seinfeld," both of which languished in their youth, to happen today. It's a shame. Comedies take time, and they have to find their voices and get their legs.
MOONVES: Ironically, networks that are doing a lot worse can be a little bit more patient. "Raymond" may not have lasted on CBS today because we're doing better than we were six years ago.
ZUCKER: Which is why, actually, it is possible for a network that's down to eventually come up.
MOONVES: But it takes longer than it did before. A lot of times people say, "Why'd they cancel that show so quickly?" We have our reasons. We've seen the next five episodes. We've seen the producer running around losing control of the show, having no good scripts.
ZUCKER: Absolutely right. We have more information than the audience.
MOONVES: Sometimes you say, "My God, I could leave this show on for 12 years -- they're not going to know where the bathroom is."

How to Make a Network Executive Really, Really Jealous
HIRSCHBERG: All right, now you guys get to run HBO.
ZUCKER: Thank God.
MOONVES: Can I go to Wimbledon?
HIRSCHBERG: What do you envy about HBO?
MOONVES: Money, time--.
ZUCKER: Money, time, the ability to only do 12 or 13 episodes at a time.
HIRSCHBERG: Is it harder to do fewer?
ALBRECHT: Well, it's harder to do good. I think mediocre is really easy. And bad is easiest of all. Basically, it's not like we only want to do 13. We'd take 26 "Sopranos" if those guys could do it.
MOONVES: But you have the luxury to be able to accept only 13. I need 24 "C.S.I."'s every year. I can't afford my year if I don't have them. You figure out what the cost of a show is, and what advertising rates will be for originals and for repeats. If I cut the number of originals and had more repeats, that number would not make any sense anymore.
ALBRECHT: But on a hypothetical level, could you do 12 weeks of "West Wing" at 9 o'clock and then 12 weeks of "C.S.I." at 9 o'clock?
ZUCKER: Well, it becomes a financial issue. The economics of the broadcast business are based on accumulating 100 or 150 episodes so the studio can recoup its money in syndication and get a second wind out of the show.
MOONVES: And there's a fear that you may lose your audience when you only have 12 or 13 episodes. If you don't call the girl for a date a couple of times more during the year, she's going to go out with somebody else.
ZUCKER: And to go back to what else I envy, not only is HBO able to order 13 episodes, but they're basically programming with original series one night a week. Sunday.
ALBRECHT: Yeah. And we have a lot of movies--.
ZUCKER: No, listen. This is envy. It is nice to be able to promote one night of series. It really is. But we do seven nights a week. Or six, plus Saturday.
MOONVES: And I'm sick of this "It's not TV, it's HBO." By their own definition, they're not in our business! I want to bring back the Cable Ace Awards.
ALBRECHT: Oh, my God, the worst of the worst. That was when you knew you were in cable.
HIRSCHBERG: When did you start going to the Emmys?
ALBRECHT: I think it's 10 years ago.
HIRSCHBERG: How important have the Emmys been for you?
ALBRECHT: Well, first let me say that all our programming decisions are judgment calls. I have no idea if "The Sopranos" makes money for HBO, because we don't sell directly to anybody.
ZUCKER: You don't ask people if that's why they buy the channel?
ALBRECHT: We don't know who the new subscribers are. We sell to the cable operator. We try to do special acquisition campaigns to get new subscribers based around the premiere of "The Sopranos," and to a certain extent, you can see what kind of impact it had. But I guarantee you that's not millions of people. And what they're doing is, they're buying a deal. You actually have no idea if when "Sopranos" is off the air those people disconnect. So the challenge for us is trying to figure out where to spend our money. Networks have instant feedback that tells them if the job that they need done is being done. I have no feedback.
HIRSCHBERG: Are the Emmys feedback?
ALBRECHT: I think the Emmys help us gain a certain credibility. Does it translate into subscribers? I don't know. Certainly fewer people watch the Emmys today.
MOONVES: Fewer people watch because HBO's winning all the awards.
ZUCKER: Because fewer people have seen those shows than network shows. But the other thing that I'm envious about, since we're on this bandwagon, is the unbelievable amount of money HBO gets to spend on promotion. You spent more money promoting a series like "Band of Brothers" than we spend on a series.
ALBRECHT: That's not true. If I were to buy the air time that you spend promoting a new series, it would far exceed the money that I spend.
ZUCKER: But you spend money on our air.
MOONVES: "Band of Brothers" is different. "Band of Brothers" wins Emmy awards. It is possible, probable, that it brings subscribers to HBO. If I have a miniseries, and it wins the Emmys, big deal. I'm not going to get more viewers on CBS.
HIRSCHBERG: If you ran HBO, would you try another night of original programming?
ALBRECHT: Well, we've tried to expand. But we spend half a billion dollars a year on theatrical movies, and I have no idea if they're going to be good, bad, who they're going to appeal to. There's no consistent lead-in that you can use on any other night of the week. Because one movie may have been a hit with men. One movie may have been a hit with women. One movie may have been an adult movie. One movie may have a teen movie. All of those pieces can really drive you crazy.
HIRSCHBERG: Can you imagine a time when HBO would not be dominated primarily by movies?
ALBRECHT: Just like these guys are worried that if they only had 12 episodes of "C.S.I.," then viewers would say, "Hey, it's not on anymore; let's watch 'Will and Grace,"' we need to make sure that we're the first pay service in every home. What Starz wants, what Showtime wants, isn't to be in more homes than HBO. They want to be in all the homes that HBO's in.
ZUCKER: HBO is helping Showtime and Starz.
ALBRECHT: Believe me, if you look at our profits over the next couple of years, they'll go up. If you look at Starz, they'll go way up, because their programming costs are fixed, and they're getting in a lot more homes because of package deals with HBO.
ZUCKER: You know, you never say that HBO's most successful show is "G-String Divas."
ALBRECHT: "G-String Divas" is not our most successful show.
ZUCKER: Oh, come on.
ALBRECHT: It actually didn't get nearly the ratings I thought it would. "Real Sex" gets great ratings.
MOONVES: Well, "Real Sex" is a good show.
ZUCKER: We'd get killed for that show. The media really doesn't focus on those shows on HBO. They focus on their terrific series.
ALBRECHT: Every once in a while somebody will say, "I don't know what the big deal about HBO is -- you people forget they still have garbage on like 'Real Sex' and--."
ZUCKER: Yeah, I try saying that sometimes.

Networks Find a Way to Feel Good About Themselves Once Again
HIRSCHBERG: On the fictitious network, would you want TV movies?
ALBRECHT: You have to have a balance between the staples -- long-running series and the things that you can event-ize, be it a movie or a miniseries. Things that let you focus a lot of attention on your product. And nothing can create as big an event as broadcast network television. Nothing. It's free in every home in America. It's a 24-hour promotional platform. It's part of the family. It combines consumer advertising, consumer product and entertainment. And when something happens on broadcast television that's an event, it's unlike anything.
MOONVES: Network television can still aggregate an audience like nothing else in this country. There's nothing better than that communal experience.
ZUCKER: Whether it's the Super Bowl or the 9/11 movie that Les did or the finale of "American Idol" or the finale of "E.R." Even the series premiere of "Sopranos" will still be dwarfed by the World Series or the Super Bowl.
HIRSCHBERG: How important for this fictitious network is it to own a single night? Because HBO owns Sunday night to some degree.
ALBRECHT: We don't own Sunday night. We do well on Sunday night.
HIRSCHBERG: But a fewer number of hours can mean more pressure.
ZUCKER: Well, the problem for Chris now that I don't envy -- I envy all those other things -- but I think that the series that come behind "Sopranos" and "Sex and the City" are going to be judged against those series.
ALBRECHT: Well, I think the hard thing is, if a show fails on CBS or NBC, the show fails. If--.
ZUCKER: To big articles and big headlines.
MOONVES: Chris, if "The Wire" fails, it will not get nearly as much attention as we would if "American Dream" or "Without a Trace" fails.
ALBRECHT: But I think there's a certain bubble for HBO, and part of the bubble is perception. That stresses me out.
MOONVES: Well, there's something exciting about the immediacy of network TV, there's no question about it.
ZUCKER: It's why I actually like the fact that we get graded every morning.
HIRSCHBERG: Les, do you like that, too?
MOONVES: I like it better now that I'm an A student. When I was getting D's when I first came to CBS, it was very hard to read the ratings at 6 a.m.
ZUCKER: Well, it certainly determines your outlook for the day.

Perfect Pitch
ALBRECHT: When you put shows on the air at a network -- because I've never sat in those rooms -- what's the line between "I believe in the show" and "I believe the show's going to be a big hit"?
MOONVES: It depends. When you're scheduling 22 hours a week of prime time, the line gets very blurry. You have to be able to appreciate a show like "Full House" as well as "E.R." or "C.S.I." or "The Sopranos."
ZUCKER: I think that's absolutely right. You have to have a combination of shows that you would watch and shows that everyone else would watch.
ALBRECHT: But Les, when you saw "Full House," because you made that show when you were at Lorimar, did you think it was funny?
MOONVES: Yes, it was funny. It was cute. But I didn't have the same reaction as I had to "Friends." I will race home and see "The Sopranos." That's appointment television, which I think is what we're all looking for.
ZUCKER: Besides, you can make a good pilot, but it doesn't mean you're going to make a good series.
MOONVES: You've heard the joke where the guy dies and God says, "O.K., you get your choice of places." One place is idyllic, with beautiful women and water, and the other place is awful. The guy picks the beautiful place, and he shows up there and it's a mess. He says, "Where's the place you showed me?" God says: "Well, I showed you the pilot. This is the series."
ALBRECHT: But there's this myth that there's this huge pool of really talented out-of-work creative people that are just waiting for the call, and that somehow--.
ZUCKER: We're ignoring them.
MOONVES: I can't believe when a producer comes in and says, "Look, we really want to do a good show." I say, "You're at the wrong network." If somebody says that, they're an idiot. I mean, that's stupid. "Now, this really is going to be a good show." I have heard that probably 10 times.
ALBRECHT: The hardest thing to do in show business, by far, is to create and execute a high-quality, successful, long-running television series. And if you add comedy on top of it, that's even harder. To me, the hardest thing to do is "Friends" and "Raymond." There is nothing harder, not making a big movie, not anything.
MOONVES: Comedy pitches are about execution. "Cheers" -- it's eight people in a bar. The question is, How do you execute? What is "Friends" about? It's six people that live in an apartment building.
ALBRECHT: And every comedy pitch starts the same way. They'll start to lay out who the characters are. There's this wacky this and this eccentric that and this really funny--.
MOONVES: Amateurs call up and say: "You know, the place I work is so funny. It's a shoe store, and we've got this wacky guy in the back who's a midget." No, don't put in a midget, please. Comedies are about execution.
HIRSCHBERG: What's the best pitch you've ever heard?
MOONVES: The best pitch I ever got was Mark Burnett's pitch on "Survivor," because I had resisted it. I didn't even want to see him. And this guy totally sucked me in. He wove a great story.
ALBRECHT: Last year David Milch co-creator of "N.Y.P.D. Blue" pitched us the most amazing idea for a series set in ancient Rome. It was kind of a cop thing. And I was totally mesmerized. I knew I was going to pass on the idea, because we actually already were developing something set in ancient Rome. But it was the best pitch I ever heard.
HIRSCHBERG: You were already doing something set in ancient Rome?
ALBRECHT: Yeah. So I said, "O.K., we have to pass on that, but I've got to do something with you, because you're brilliant."
ZUCKER: Which is why he's now doing a western.
ALBRECHT: Yeah. This was probably the only time I gave somebody an idea. I said, "You know, I think the country's really ripe for a great western."
ZUCKER: And now everybody seems to be developing one.
HIRSCHBERG: What was the best pitch you ever heard?
ZUCKER: Probably Graham Yost with "Boomtown." It was a great pitch, just all the different storytelling techniques that he wanted to use. We knew right then that this was going to be a very, very serious contender.
MOONVES: And "Boomtown" is different. "E.R." was just a hospital show, but it was probably the best pilot ever shown.
ALBRECHT: The pilot doesn't really matter, though.
MOONVES: And the fact that the best season of "Friends" is the ninth is incredible. It's a miracle when something works.
ZUCKER: A miracle.
MOONVES: Finally, something we agree on.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dreaming out loud: Leslie Moonves (CBS and UPN), Jeff Zucker (NBC) and Chris Albrecht (HBO). (Bryce Duffy); Signature shows like "C.S.I.: Miami," "Friends" or "E.R.," tell viewers whate each network stands for. (Robert Voets/CBS; Danny Feld for NBC; Warner Brothers Television): You never know which show will change the TV world: "Everbody Loves Raymond," "The Sopranos," "Survivor." (Spike Nannarello/CBS; Barry Wetcher/HBO; Monty Brinton/The Associated Press/CBS. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: TELEVISION PROGRAMMING (90%); TELEVISION INDUSTRY (90%) TELEVISION 

COMPANY: NBC UNIVERSAL INC (93%); HOME BOX OFFICE INC (92%)

INDUSTRY: NAICS515120 TELEVISION BROADCASTING (93%); SIC4833 TELEVISION BROADCASTING STATIONS (93%)

PERSON: LESLIE MOONVES (92%) MOONVES, LESLIE; ZUCKER, JEFF; ALBRECHT, CHRIS; HIRSCHBERG, LYNN 

GEOGRAPHIC: LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (79%) CALIFORNIA, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (79%)

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 3; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1120 words

PERSON: Gary W. Loveman 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Applying Science to the Casino

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
FOR many Las Vegas casinos, the conventional wisdom is that the key to success is to build huge copies of the world's wonders, then add sequins. But to Gary W. Loveman, it's about figuring out where to put the fishhook.
 It's also about using the latest science and business intelligence to do so. 
 Mr. Loveman is the newly named chief executive of Harrah's Entertainment, the Las Vegas-based company that operates the Harrah's casinos. He has been at the company for four years as president and chief operating officer. But before that he was a business professor at Harvard, and, while not strictly analogous, his presence in the gambling industry represents a culture clash as jarring as hillbillies in Beverly Hills. 
Far from espousing the "if you build it huge, they will come" axiom of his executive forebears in Las Vegas, Mr. Loveman has a philosophy grounded in M.I.T. training and Harvard case studies. For example, he is fond of noting Wal-Mart's discovery that its stores sell more Band-Aids if they are stocked next to the fishhooks; he is now pushing Harrah's to collect and mine customer data to figure out where to place slot machines and blackjack tables, and what promotions work best to increase betting.
"We've tried to make a science out of understanding very carefully what provocations are meaningful to customers," Mr. Loveman, 42, said. "In a sense it's the equivalent of Wal-Mart putting the right product in action alley."
The question is whether Mr. Loveman can translate his vocabulary of "decision logic" and "empirical data" into additional profits. Further, will employees and managers continue to buy into the unconventional approach, and his relatively highbrow demeanor? 
"The industry is filled with a lot of rough-and-tumble people," said Steven Kent, a gambling-industry analyst at Goldman Sachs. "The trick is for him to get managers to buy into a system they didn't grow up in."
That said, Mr. Kent added that Mr. Loveman is willing to "shake things up and make a decision based on profitability, not history."
Harrah's has fared well as a result, Mr. Kent noted. Last month, the company, which operates 26 casinos across the country, said its revenue rose to $1.13 billion, in the third quarter, up 11.9 percent from the period a year earlier. The company, despite having less opulent casinos than its Vegas neighbors, has focused successfully on a middle-tier market: mom-and-pop gamblers who bet less money than high rollers but bet more consistently, Mr. Kent said.
Things did not look so good for Harrah's in 1997, when Mr. Loveman was still a Harvard professor. The company, which has 40,000 employees, was being beaten in several markets, Mr. Loveman said, and was spending too much on promotions to attract gamblers in Las Vegas.
Mr. Loveman said he learned all of this when Harrah's asked him to teach its managers new strategies to improve their performance, something he did for several companies while he was teaching at Harvard. Not long afterward, Philip G. Satre, the chief executive of Harrah's, hired him as chief operating officer, then named him company president last year. On Jan. 1, Mr. Loveman will succeed him as chief executive; Mr. Satre, 53, will remain chairman.
In terms of personal income and glitz, it has been the career-change equivalent of trading a Honda Accord for a Ferrari, which is what Mr. Loveman did when he left the ivory tower for sin city. His annual pay rose to $3 million from $120,000, and he can use a corporate jet to shuttle between Las Vegas and Boston, where he lives on weekends with his wife, Kathy, and three children.
What is consistent is that he is still maniacally competitive. As a youth in Indianapolis, he attended a basketball camp run by Bob Knight, then the coach at Indiana University, but when he was the only member of his squad not to make the camp's all-star team, he quit the sport. He turned his attention to tennis and said he became one of the top 25 players in Indiana.
He received a bachelor's degree from Wesleyan University in Connecticut, where he fed his love of music by working at the college radio station and organizing concerts. After a stint as an economic researcher at the Federal Reserve Bank, he went to M.I.T. to study economics, completing a Ph.D. dissertation on causes of the protracted unemployment in Europe in the 1980's. Upon graduation, he accepted a business professorship at Harvard.
"When he told me he took a job at Harrah's, I said, 'You're kidding,' " said Bruce Miller, a lawyer in Boston and a longtime friend of Mr. Loveman's. "We all have a preconceived notion about what those guys in Vegas are all about; we've all seen 'Casino.' "
Mr. Loveman said he didn't gamble until he was 32. But he said the casino business suits his personality. "It's a competitive tonic," he said of Las Vegas. "I get a report card every day."
When Harrah's hired Mr. Loveman, the company had sown the seeds of science; it was collecting data on customers through "Total Reward" cards that they slip into a slot machine or give to a dealer. The cards record playing habits and correlate them with the gambler's age, sex and name. Mr. Loveman was responsible for interpreting the data from casinos and using it to attract gamblers, said Mr. Kent, the Goldman Sachs analyst.
Mr. Loveman found that the company could reduce its costs and achieve the same results by tailoring promotions to individual gamblers. Some customers would show up if they just got an offer for a free room, whereas others needed the inducement of show tickets. He said his approach is a combination of the "decision-science based marketing" used by credit card companies and epidemiological research, using controlled tests, with placebos, to give only what is necessary to change a gambler's behavior.
SOME Harrah's managers who were steeped in the culture of Las Vegas resisted the approach. Mr. Loveman responded by ridding the company of resisters -- and bringing in his own people. He recently hired a Rhodes scholar to be the assistant manager of a casino in Lake Charles, La. One of the first executives he brought in was Rich Mirman, a former Booz Allen Hamilton consultant whom Mr. Loveman met while at Harvard. Mr. Mirman runs marketing at Harrah's.
More change is on the way. Mr. Loveman said he planned to use his customer data to focus promotions even more narrowly. One person might get a coupon to use a particular slot machine at a given time, for example.
Ultimately, he added, he wants his industry to emulate the sophisticated retail operations, like Wal-Mart, that use customer data in innovative ways to improve their businesses. "I would be humbled to be in the same sentence as those guys," he said of Wal-Mart.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary W. Loveman, named chief executive of Harrah's Entertainment, has brought a Harvard business professor's perspective to gambling. (Jim Grant for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Why Business Needs a Strong S.E.C.

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST 

 BODY:
MEMO to chief executives:
 What a mess. Corporate America has been rocked by scandal, yet the Securities and Exchange Commission is run by someone who seems awfully ginger about cracking down, and his agency is starved for funds. We can only imagine morale over there. 
 What to do? Get your lobbyists in gear and to demand a bigger, better-funded S.E.C. You're laughing? Go ahead, but here are some incontrovertible reasons why saving the S.E.C. is a matter of vital self-interest for you. 
* Eliot Spitzer. State attorneys general everywhere took notice when Mr. Spitzer, their counterpart in New York, found his face on the cover of Fortune magazine for his aggressive pursuit of financial malfeasance. Sure, the securities business is focused in New York, but it's not just about New York. Massachusetts is suing Credit Suisse First Boston, accusing it of using its ratings on stocks to reward companies for hiring it to underwrite their stocks and bonds; the state is demanding an end to the cozy relationship between investment banking and research departments in the industry. States have regulated securities for years, but not like this. Do you want to be subject to the varying laws, whims and political aspirations of 50 egos in 50 states? If the vacuum in Washington persists, rest assured that you will be.
* Stock prices, especially yours. You're supposed to serve your owners, and your owners want high share prices. Heck, so do you; otherwise, what good are all those options that come with your paycheck? But if investors lack confidence in corporate financial statements, or suspect that executives bestow investment banking business based on receiving first dibs on hot initial public offerings, they will be less willing to risk their money on stocks. That means lower earnings multiples, lower share prices and higher capital costs. Those can be a drag on the entire economy, but even if that doesn't matter to you, remember: it hurts shareholders, including you.
* That mean Street. You may think you're better off without a strong S.E.C., but you're not, because you need a watchdog on Wall Street. Remember the 1980's? How about Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky? Or think back to the days before there was an S.E.C., when manipulators wrecked companies. John Kenneth Galbraith has suggested that institutional dysfunction on Wall Street played a major role in the crash of 1929. While a strong S.E.C. is no guarantee of orderly securities markets and free-flowing capital, it's hard to believe it wouldn't help.
* History. While we're looking in the rear-view mirror, let's acknowledge that an understaffed, low-budget S.E.C. is nothing new. From the earliest days of the agency, in the 1930's, scarcity shaped its approach. Without the money or the staff to do more, William O. Douglas, the chairman, had to rely on hollow threats and on self-regulation by Wall Street. Things went downhill from there; the agency remained largely invisible until the 1970's, when Stanley Sporkin made headlines as its chief of enforcement. But the stakes are much higher now. Stock ownership is more widespread, money moves at the speed of light and the financial world is much more complex.
* No pain, no gain. As S.E.C. chairman in the 1990's, Arthur Levitt raised the agency's profile, attacked Wall Street conflicts of interest, struggled to improve corporate accounting, made public companies share information with everyone, not only with favored analysts, and demanded plain English in investor materials. Business Week called him the small investor's "best buddy." During his watch, stock ownership (and prices) soared. Coincidence? Maybe. But having an activist S.E.C. didn't seem to do any harm. And those were golden days, when everybody made money so fast it didn't seem to matter how much was pilfered.
Times have changed. Now, more than ever, all of us need an ably led S.E.C. that has enough money to do its job.
So, chief executives, it's time to call your pals in Washington. After all the money you give them, they'll be happy to hear from you.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (David G. Klein)

HEADLINE: Nonstop Nights Out Of Mayor Workaholic 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
WHEN you are the richest politician in America, have a seemingly endless appetite for conversation, comfort food, golf and the art scene and you run a city where somebody wants you for cocktails six nights a week, mixing business with pleasure is not much of a problem.
 Last week, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wanted to have a chat with the state's most important legislators about the city's budget woes, he did not hop aboard a northbound Amtrak. Instead, the mayor whisked the two leaders, Joseph L. Bruno and Sheldon Silver, aboard his private plane and took them to Bermuda, where they played a few rounds at the island's finest resort and spent the night at his palatial estate. 
 When the mayor needed quality time with the three city commissioners most under the gun -- police, fire and education -- he invited them and their wives to Noche, a cavernous tropical outpost in Times Square, for ceviche and a dessert of tres leches. On nights when he is feeling especially ambitious, Mayor Bloomberg can hit a book party and two charity events and still make it to Staten Island for chicken and mashed potatoes at a favorite restaurant, American Grill, with the borough president, friends or an aide. 
Not since John V. Lindsay has New York City had a mayor whose after-dark life was so active and varied as Mr. Bloomberg's. 
On any given night of the week, he races between events -- sometimes four to an evening with a costume change -- and then to dinner with people he feels contribute to the city. Many of these outings are strictly mayoral -- presenting a proclamation at the New York Is Book Country reception, for example -- while others are for groups that Mr. Bloomberg supported when he ran Bloomberg L.P., like arts philanthropies.
Almost any New York mayor has access to celebrities, sports figures and other bright lights, because of the job title. Mr. Bloomberg's situation is less typical. His prominent friends, including Henry A. Kissinger and Kofi Annan, were mostly gathered before he was mayor. He is more intrigued, it seems, by getting to know people he had almost no previous contact with -- fire chiefs, recycling experts, counterterrorism advisers. 
"In his company, his evening life was an extension of his day," said Patricia E. Harris, deputy mayor for administration. "As mayor, it is the same thing. Usually, his dinners are used to thank people or to promote New York or to listen."
Unlike Mayor Lindsay, who favored the "21" Club, passing time among movie stars and any patrician trappings his mayoralty could lend him, Mr. Bloomberg, whose estimated wealth is $4.8 billion, is just as happy in a burger joint as sipping a Bellini at Cipriani. So it was that Caroline Kennedy found herself sitting at the Neptune Diner in Queens with the mayor, after they flew into La Guardia from Washington.
While Mr. Bloomberg has been spotted by tabloid gossip columnists roughly a dozen times in the last two months -- at the Dia Center, holding a book party for Arthur Levitt, the former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, for instance, or waving away Graydon Carter's cigarette smoke at a dinner party at the Four Seasons -- many of his evenings are spent away from the camera, with few in the know about what goes on. One Saturday night, for example, the mayor had dinner with a fire department chief and his family at Gracie Mansion. 
While Mr. Bloomberg still gets to the occasional Park Avenue dinner party, his days as a party-hearty sybarite (among his more famous parties at Bloomberg L.P. was one with a seven deadly sins theme) appear to be behind him. Old friends looking to go for a steak on the Upper East Side are often surprised when the mayor suggests Thai food in Queens or chicken in Staten Island instead. Pamela Silvestri, who owns the American Grill in West Brighton, Staten Island, wrote to Mr. Bloomberg during the campaign, urging him to come in. He has ever since. "They are always punctual and very easy to deal with," Ms. Silvestri said of Mr. Bloomberg's posse. 
Last week notwithstanding, the mayor does not have time to make use of his many homes. He has not been to his apartment in London in two years or his place in Colorado since last Christmas and has used his home in Bermuda a handful of times since he was elected.
"Mike is meeting people, making contacts and networking during the day and the night," an aide said. "He hates the weekends. The joke at the company is that his favorite day was Monday." 
Naturally, many of the people who knew the mayor as a corporate chief want him at their events as mayor. It is not always easy. The fashion designer Arnold Scaasi, for instance, called the mayor and implored him to attend a party for a retrospective of his work at the Fashion Institute of Technology. "I've known him for at least five or six years," said Mr. Scaasi, who met the mayor when they were doing work for Literacy Partners, which teaches adults to read and write. "He has a great sense of humor and is extraordinarily intelligent. Who wouldn't want to socialize with him?"
The mayor's office receives dozens of requests from groups wanting Mr. Bloomberg to speak, to cut a ribbon or to help celebrate an anniversary. His office weighs each request, seeking a mix of organizations, but often favoring charitable groups that the mayor supported in the years he was at Bloomberg L.P. "What you might think of as social is him continuing to be loyal to people and organizations," said Ms. Harris, who used to run Mr. Bloomberg's charitable giving.
One night in late September, the mayor hopped from a meeting about Sept. 11 at the Marriott Financial Center (6:15 p.m.) in Lower Manhattan, where he spoke, to Jimmy's Downtown, a Midtown restaurant (7:15), for the smoke-free happy hour, and stopped by his Upper East Side town house to jump into a tuxedo before heading for the Sheraton Hotel on Seventh Avenue to receive an award from the United Nations Association at 8. On most of his nights out, Mr. Bloomberg is home by 11:30. He arrives at the office the next day by 7 a.m., to prepare for his daily staff meeting at 8. 
Mayors have had a passion for socializing -- Jimmy Walker, who served in the 1920's, once quipped: "It's a sin to go to bed on the same day you get up." Edward I. Koch loved to hit the movies and to give dinner parties at Gracie Mansion, and David N. Dinkins spent many a night on the formal dinner circuit. Rudolph W. Giuliani enjoyed monthly town hall meetings in all boroughs and going to the opera, and there is no question that he would have attended 80 percent of the events on Mr. Bloomberg's public schedule. But Mr. Giuliani's private hours were almost always spent in the company of his closest aides.
"We would all be at the hall until really late, and then the mayor would get up and say, 'O.K., time for dinner,' and we would all go," a Giuliani aide said. "It was always simple, neighborhood places."
Unlike most of his predecessors, Mr. Bloomberg does not live at Gracie Mansion, the mayoral home on the Upper East Side, and so he spends less time socializing there than other mayors. Instead, the mansion is used as an upscale municipal catering hall, where city commissioners, agencies and, several times a week, the mayor himself give dinners. He was, for instance, host of a cocktail party at the mansion for people who contributed to the city's commemoration of Sept. 11. 
Mr. Bloomberg also gives frequent dinners at his town house on East 79th Street, where he mixes with old friends and new, including state senators, city commissioners and always a big name from the arts world. ("Friend" is a term he uses broadly: if you have ever eaten any meal larger than a snack with Mr. Bloomberg, you get that designation.) 
His town house dinner parties are catered, often by Glorious Food. They have to be. The kitchen pantry chez Bloomberg is stocked with little more than peanut butter and a can of coffee. Rare is the night that Mr. Bloomberg orders in Chinese food -- generally only when he visits his youngest daughter, Georgina, at the home of his former wife, Susan, with whom he remains friendly.
Restaurateurs are happy that the mayor likes to eat out, especially as many of them struggle in an embattled economy. Mr. Bloomberg travels light -- his security detail is small -- is unobtrusive, and his parties tend to be low-maintenance and fun, several restaurant owners said.
"You didn't feel that the mayor was cut off from the rest of the operation," said David Emil, who owns Noche, where the mayor has eaten twice in the last month. Mr. Emil, who once had a banana split at a dinner party at the mayor's home, was inspired to put the dessert on his menu, he said. "He really seemed at ease and comfortable and talked to a lot of people outside the restaurant after," Mr. Emil recalled. "He made me feel that he understood the life he was living in New York, and that felt good to me."

GRAPHIC: Photos: LONG DAY'S NIGHT -- Mayor Michael R. SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 822 words

HEADLINE: Learning to Love Deficits 

BYLINE:  By Michael M. Weinstein; Michael M. Weinstein is director of programs for the Robin Hood Foundation, an antipoverty group, and a former economics columnist for the Times.

 BODY:
After a four-year absence, the federal budget deficit has returned -- and so has the politically contorted debate over it.
The deficit is $159 billion for the year that ended Sept. 30. Democratic leaders warn that the current deficit is a danger to the economy and prevents the government from spending federal dollars on pressing social needs. The Bush administration dismisses the importance of the deficit, noting that it amounts to only about 1.5 percent of gross domestic product. Not so long ago, these positions were reversed. Liberals said deficits could be used to energize a sluggish economy and to pay for projects that produce long-term economic benefits. Conservatives preached fiscal rectitude. 
 Liberals were right then, wrong now. How did this change of heart come about? 
 In the late 1980's and early 1990's, deficits were large, eventually reaching about 5 percent of gross domestic product. To address the problem, President George W. Bush raised taxes in 1990. Partly as a result of that tax increase, Mr. Bush lost the 1992 presidential election to Bill Clinton, who signed a deficit-reduction package in 1993. Each package cut deficits by more than $400 billion.
By all economic calculations, that should have been enough. But what started out as a prudent call by Democrats and Republicans for fiscal restraint soon tumbled toward a mindless fervor for zero deficits. And that tumble has had profound consequences for public policy and the plight of the country's poorest families. By discarding plans to raise federal spending on training, education and infrastructure for the sake of balanced budgets, mainstream Democrats took on the fiscal coloration of conservative Republicans.
Yet the economic case for zero deficits is nearly nonexistent. For starters, the goal of zero is arbitrary. The measurement of deficits takes no account of inflation or growth: a $100 billion deficit poses less threat to the $11 trillion economy of today than it did to the $6 trillion economy of the early 1990's.
The case against deficits improves only slightly when it comes to their effect on private investment. When the government spends more than it collects -- in other words, runs a deficit -- it borrows the difference. The purpose of cutting deficits is to reduce the amount of money that government siphons out of capital markets and away from private investors. Less private investment can result in less job training and research and development.
But what if the government borrows for exactly those same purposes -- paying for federal programs that train unskilled workers or build the Internet? There is no economic principle that says such public investments cannot be at least as pro-growth as the private investments they replace.
The pluses and minuses of federal borrowing, then, depend entirely on what is done with the borrowed money. Public borrowing can be economically smart -- or so most liberals used to preach.
Some still do. Dean Baker of the Center for Economic and Policy Research estimates that running deficits of $200 billion a year would, at worst, reduce national income by little more than 1 percent, and most of the pain would not be felt for decades. In fact, if the government were to invest the borrowed money wisely, modest deficits could easily do more economic good than harm.
Now it is conservatives who increasingly step forward to put deficits in their proper place. R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, says that eliminating the current deficit would knock a fraction of a percentage point off interest rates -- nowhere near enough to trigger a surge of private investment. Besides, economists point out, the country could run deficits of $200 billion a year with impunity, because at that rate the country's debt would not grow faster than the economy.
So why have liberals and conservatives switched positions? Political expediency. Republicans now embrace deficits so they can hand a tax holiday to a small sliver of very rich Americans. Democrats preach zero deficits to block the Republican tax-cutting frenzy. Democrats' motive may be noble. But their rhetoric -- ridiculing deficits and exaggerating the financial threat posed by the modest deficits expected in Social Security -- is bogus.
That rhetoric has come back to haunt them. Despite years of spectacular growth, low inflation and a modest federal debt, Congress -- including many Democratic members -- still pleads fiscal poverty. It could afford to spend more money to train unemployed workers, for example, or to extend unemployment insurance payments during the current economic stagnation. But it refuses to pay for these sensible programs out of benighted fear of running modestly higher deficits.
In fact, Congressional Democrats are worried about the wrong issue. The return of deficits poses far less threat to the nation than policies that grow out of antideficit rhetoric. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: POLITICAL PARTIES (91%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (91%); BUDGET DEFICITS (91%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (90%); US PRESIDENTS (90%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (90%); TAX INCREASES (90%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (90%); BUDGETS (90%); PUBLIC DEBT (89%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (89%); NATIONAL DEBT (78%); CONSERVATISM (78%); LIBERALISM (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (77%); POOR POPULATION (77%); TAXES & TAXATION (74%); ELECTIONS (73%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (73%); TAX LAW (67%) FINANCES; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; TAXATION 

PERSON: BILL CLINTON (73%); GEORGE W BUSH (67%) WEINSTEIN, MICHAEL M
