SECTION: Section 4; Column 4; Week in Review Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 942 words

HEADLINE: The World; 
To Iran, Iraq May Be The Greater Satan

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: MADRID 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH'S vision for Iraq is a bit like that of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the father of Iran's revolution. After Iraq invaded Iran in 1980, the ayatollah described Saddam Hussein as part of an evil alliance, calling him "a pro-American mercenary" and "an infidel" and urging the Iraqi people to overthrow him. 
 "If you can kill Saddam before we execute him, stab him in the back!" he told Iraqis. "Paralyze the economy! Stop paying taxes! This is a war between Islam and blasphemy!" 
 After Mr. Hussein withdrew most of his troops and declared a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war in 1982, the ayatollah rejected it, vowing to install an Iranian-style Islamic republic in Baghdad. It was 1988, the year before he died, that he gave up trying.
In their public stance today, the Iranians are being a lot more circumspect about changing Iraq's regime by force, now that the country proposing to do so is the United States. So as Americans prepare for war against Iraq, a huge question looms: Can the United States and Iran work together, or can they at least stay out of each other's way? Whatever their animosities, history suggests that the two sides know how to dance around each other in the shadows, making it possible that each can work toward mutual goals while never acknowledging cooperating with the other.
In any action to disarm Iraq, the preference of the Bush administration, as officials have long described it, would be not only to rid Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction, but also to rid it of President Hussein. Various administration officials have spoken of installing a government that reflects the will of the Iraqi people and conforms to Washington's vision of what a modern Middle Eastern nation should look like.
Is that offensive to Iran? On the surface, of course. But in the shadows, perhaps not.
Last week, Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, was in Madrid reiterating Tehran's official line: Iran is vehemently opposed to any war against Iraq, only the Iraqi people can determine their destiny, and "if there is a war, we can take no sides and help no one." 
But other voices in Iran have begun suggesting that an American invasion might not be such a bad thing.
Mr. Khatami's brother, Mohammad Reza Khatami, deputy speaker of Iran's parliament and a voice of the reformist constituency that brought the president to power, said a few weeks ago, "The day that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is toppled will be among the happiest days for the Iranian people, no matter how this occurs."
Jafar Golbaz, a deputy in parliament, went further: "It will be the happiest day for all Iranians to see Saddam toppled, no matter by whom. Tehran may even decide to cooperate with the United States if it receives assurances that its interests will be respected."
So what will Iran do if war comes? President Khatami, despite his statements to the Europeans that a unilateral war to topple Mr. Hussein would destabilize the whole region, also suggested that Iran would not oppose any decision by the Security Council. He said in Madrid that there should be support from the United Nations if "there need to be further steps taken."
In fact, Iran has done just fine by sitting on the sidelines when Iraq was threatened before. In 1990, it refrained from interfering with the American-led coalition that expelled Iraq from Kuwait. It ignored American violations of its air space along its western border with Iraq and did not retaliate when American missiles inadvertently fell on its side of the border.
Even more significant was Iran's decision not to get involved after the war, when Iraqi Shiite Muslims in the south and Iraqi Kurds in the north rose up against Mr. Hussein. One argument raised in Washington against going to war with Mr. Hussein is that war could ignite a Shiite rebellion that the Shiites of Iran could use to dismember Iraq. 
But Iran, like Iraq's other neighbors, fears the instability such a dismemberment would bring to the border, to oil markets and to Iraq's majority Shiite population, who are Arabs, not Persians.
Similarly, in the American-led war against Afghanistan, Iran benefited by doing less, rather than more, despite its antipathy for the Taliban. It gave support to the American-backed Northern Alliance and cooperated in creating a new government in Kabul. While some American officials have said Iran harbors Al Qaeda, Iranian officials say their country, with the help of American intelligence data, has rounded up and expelled 250 Qaeda members.
If Americans pour into Iraq and stay to shape a government, Iran will almost certainly want some say about the outcome, if only because it wants to avoid feeling encircled. American influence is already strong in Afghanistan to the east; Pakistan to the southeast; the gulf Arab states to the south. Even Russia counts itself an American ally.
But fear of encirclement has not prevented the Iranians from working with the Americans on Iraq. 
When the administration organized a meeting of the six main Iraqi opposition groups in Washington in August, a representative of Ayatollah Mohammad Bakir al-Hakim, a senior Iraqi Shiite cleric living in Iran, was at the table. Meanwhile, Iran's navy is quietly cooperating with American vessels in the Persian Gulf, channeling boats suspected of smuggling Iraqi oil and dates away from Iran's shores so Americans can intercept them.
"We are condemned to be neighbors," Iran's foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, once said of Iran and Iraq, meaning that Iran will have to coexist with whatever regime is in power in Baghdad. These days, at least a few Iranians seem to be suggesting much the same about America.

GRAPHIC: Photo: War with Iraq left Iran bitter. In July, mourners marked the return of a P.O.W.'s body. (Associated Press)

LENGTH: 736 words

HEADLINE: Let Them Come to Berlin 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BERLIN 

 BODY:
I haven't been to Berlin since since the opening of the Berlin Wall, so when I arrived at my hotel near the Brandenburg Gate, my first question was: Where's the wall? My German friend explained that the only trace left is a cobblestone path that snakes across Berlin, drawing a line in the pavement where the wall once ran. It's easy to cross that line without even knowing it.
 And therein lies the core of the crisis between America and Germany today -- triggered by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's use of anti-Bush and anti-Iraq-war rhetoric to win re-election, then fueled by a German minister comparing President Bush to Hitler and now capped by Mr. Bush's refusal to answer two letters from the German leader. 
 Would somebody please bring back the Berlin Wall? Since World War II, America and Germany have had many disputes, but always within limits, because both sides a saw dangerous foe on the other side of that wall -- the Communist totalitarians -- and realized we needed to fight together. There is still a dangerous foe out there -- now it is religious totalitarians -- and we still need to fight together. But without the wall clearly defining our side and the enemy's, all sorts of lines are being crossed.
What is most shocking about the German election is not how the Chancellor ran against America, it's how popular that theme was here. Two things are feeding this. One is the new anti-Americanism, a blend of jealousy and resentment of America's overwhelming economic and military power -- the "Axis of Envy," as Josef Joffe, editor of Die Zeit, calls it. The other is the new anti-Bushism -- resentment of the often contemptuous, unilateralist, anti-green instincts of the Bush team -- which was crystallized by Dick Cheney's August speech suggesting that any U.N. inspections of Iraq were useless and America may have to act alone. "The Cheney speech had a decisive impact on the German election," said Friedburt Pflueger, a top official of the pro-U.S. C.D.U. party, which got creamed.
Bottom line: Many Europeans today fear, or detest, America more than they fear Saddam. That's crazy, but it explains why Mr. Schroder easily moved from raising legitimate questions about how to handle Iraq to taking Germany out of any war against Saddam under any conditions. This put Germany to the left of Saudi Arabia, which at least says it will support an Iraq war if it is approved by the U.N. It was the kind of rhetoric that leaves Americans thinking Europeans won't use force under any conditions, and therefore are a danger to themselves and to us.
It is time for both sides to knock it off. We need each other. As Germany's thoughtful foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said to me, "We are facing a new totalitarianism -- the totalitarianism of Al Qaeda and bin Laden," which has emerged from the crisis in Islam. And the goal of these religious totalitarians "is to destroy the open society everywhere and the economy that it's based on."
The war against the religious totalitarians can't be fought with just armies or walls. It must be fought with police, intelligence sharing, development aid, peace diplomacy, and military operations. To win this war the open societies must each play to their strength -- America's hard power and Europe's soft power.
When Germany says it's willing to provide the peacekeeping force in Kabul, that is a huge help for us. When Germany funds the expansion of the European Union to lift from poverty ten new democracies of Eastern Europe, that is a huge help to us. But at the same time, some things are true even if a Texas cowboy believes them. I'm still not sure what the right way is to handle Iraq, but I am sure that ruling out war there, under any conditions, against a murderous U.N. outlaw like Saddam is wrong.
With a nod to J.F.K., my motto today is simple: "Ich bin ein New Yorker." We are all New Yorkers now. Wherever you live, if you believe in the open society, if you cherish a world of freedom, you are now in World War III -- a war against the new totalitarians, who strike at our businesses, discos, airports and theaters in an attempt to get us to shut ourselves in and our societies down. Either we fight this war together, or we lose it together. To those who forgot what it takes to defend the open society, let them come to Berlin -- let them walk the winding path where the Wall once stood and recall the collective effort that brought it down. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The Nation: Spin City; 
The Surprises Began Before the First Vote Was Cast

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHO would have thought that the fate of the Senate and many of President Bush's legislative ambitions might depend on Walter F. Mondale, who stepped out of semi-retirement to run for the seat of the late Paul Wellstone? And who would have imagined that Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey would abruptly abandon his re-election bid just weeks before the election and clear the way for an archrival, former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, to step in?
 Those late entries were a stunning turn in what had already been a relentlessly perplexing campaign season. The results in midterm elections are often confounding, but this go-round has a greater than usual sense of urgency and potential for chaos. The last time the balance of power in both the House and Senate was so precarious was during the Eisenhower administration. In the Senate alone, where Democrats hold control by a one-vote margin, more than a half-dozen races could swing either way. 
 Even Wednesday morning might not bring certainty because of the close races, possible recounts, runoffs and new vigilance toward voting irregularities after the wild 2000 contest. (And don't even count on knowing by Thanksgiving.) 
"The correct analysis on the Sunday before this election is, 'Who knows?' " said Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, a mastermind of the Republican takeover of the House in 1994. "This is the least decided election in my lifetime."
Of course, all the tumult could end with a whimper. The House could stay (barely) Republican and the Senate stay (barely) Democratic. Yet other possibilities exist that have colossal implications for the careers of politicians and lobbyists in the capital, and, most important, for how the nation is governed.

The G.O.P. Dream
Ever since Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont defected from the Republican Party in 2001 and gave control of the Senate to the Democrats, Republicans have been plotting their comeback. The most obvious way they could reassert themselves is by wresting back committee chairmanships. Mr. Jeffords, for one, is chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee and is popular among environmentalists. He could be replaced by Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, a frequent antagonist of the Environmental Protection Agency who would most likely press the administration's drive to change clean-air laws. 
The area where Republican control would make the most immediate difference is in confirming judgeships. Republicans would move swiftly to undo the Democrats' successful efforts to put off -- or sometimes sink -- Mr. Bush's judicial nominees. Democrats have used their narrow majority on the Judiciary Committee to block those Bush nominees they have deemed too conservative. White House officials have even said that if the Republicans regain control of the Senate, Mr. Bush would renominate Priscilla R. Owen, the Texas State Supreme Court justice whose federal appellate court candidacy was defeated by Democrats on the committee who objected to her antiabortion rulings, among other decisions.
"If we gain control of the Senate, you'll clearly see a lot more judges," said Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican and Judiciary Committee member. "The judges have been stalled in the Judiciary Committee. That would change dramatically."
Those judges could change the law on several fronts, including environmental disputes over control of natural resources, the reach of states to regulate abortions and the division of power between states and the federal government.
If the House, Senate and White House are all Republican, that would certainly enhance the potency of Mr. Bush as he embarks on his re-election campaign. While a Republican House and Senate would not roll over for the White House agenda, it would be far easier for Mr. Bush to champion big issues that he could run on in 2004, like passing a Medicare drug benefit to his liking (that would neutralize the Democrats who have pressed for a more ambitious approach), creating a homeland security agency that would give the president wide control over its employees, approving new tax cuts and limiting damages that could be awarded in medical malpractice cases.
Democrats are so worried about losing power that they are already mulling options should there be a 50-50 outcome in the Senate. For example, they have set their sights on recruiting Senator Lincoln Chafee, a moderate Republican from Rhode Island.
Mr. Chafee refuses to entertain such notions, but others are not giving up. "There's no pressure on Lincoln," Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat. "I'd call it encouragement. He would be more Democratic than I would be."

A Democratic Heaven
The prospect of the Democrats recapturing the House may seem more unlikely than the Democrats holding onto the Senate, but it is a far more frightening possibility for the White House. That is because while in the Senate little can be accomplished without a majority, in the House the rules afford the party in charge far more power to set the agenda -- and essentially push the minority party into the corner.
The chairmanships of important committees would shift from some of the most conservative lawmakers to some of the most aggressively liberal, including Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, who would likely take over the Ways and Means Committee, and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, who is in line to head the Judiciary Committee.
Some Democratic lawmakers have said that if they had control they would demand that Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Committee, appear before them to explain the controversies over his efforts to appoint a board to oversee the accounting profession.
"Every committee will be much more aggressive," Mr. Rangel said. Saying that "a lot of the progress that we have made under the Clinton administration has been destroyed," Mr. Rangel pledged to press for health care legislation, raising the minimum wage, extending unemployment benefits and other measures aimed at helping the poor and middle class.
Mr. Gingrich, who knows better than anyone how the opposing party could use Congress to badger the White House, said he would expect Democrats to try his playbook. "The Democratic majority would try to weaken the administration," he said. "You'd have Democratic chairmen on television announcing various and sundry investigations."
An even scarier prospect for the White House would be if Democrats win both the House and the Senate. Yet for all the tumult that would cause for Republicans, the reality is that the president always has his veto pen.

The Status Quo
Short of a Republican sweep, this might be the preferred outcome for Mr. Bush. If the Senate stays Democratic but with a paper-thin margin, Democrats would not have that much clout anyway. But in his re-election drive Mr. Bush could campaign against obstructionism in the Senate.
As exasperating as it is for Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, to preside over a Senate that is so closely divided, it is better than the alternative. Asked how life is for Mr. Daschle with a one-seat majority, his friend Richard Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said: "Better than with a one-seat minority. If he does nothing but stop them from doing bad things and wrong things, it's worth it."

The Switcheroo
What if Republicans take over the Senate and Democrats regain the House? It's never happened before, but that doesn't mean it's impossible. Such a turnabout could tarnish the reputations of Mr. Daschle and the current speaker, J. Dennis Hastert.
"If we lose -- if we go down more than five seats," said Representative Mark Souder, an Indiana Republican, "there would probably be a complete reanalysis for someone the conservatives find acceptable" to supplant Mr. Hastert. Then again, Mr. Souder said, leaders are not always elected because of ideology. He said maybe Mr. Hastert would remain because he has helped raise so much money for his members. "A lot of this isn't a sweeping, 'What's best for the party?' but how much money did you raise?" he said.
Mr. Daschle would have even more explaining to do if his South Dakota protege, Senator Tim Johnson, loses, and that costs the Democrats control. But there would be one upside for Mr. Daschle: he would no longer have to worry so much about taming his unruly flock of Democrats. That could free him up to take on several of his Democratic colleagues and run for president.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Christoph Niemann)

HEADLINE: The World: After Hussein; 
Controlling Iraq's Oil Wouldn't Be Simple

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
THERE is still some dispute over the extent of Saddam Hussein's chemical or biological weapons, but one thing beyond dispute is that he has oil. Lots of it. Five times more proven reserves than the United States, the second biggest supply after Saudi Arabia, and more waiting to be found.
 For many of the countries most immediately involved in the debate over whether to invade or not to invade Iraq, including Russia, France, Saudi Arabia or China, the fate of that oil is a critical national interest. 
 Yet oil does not loom large in public debates, at the United Nations or elsewhere. At the White House, suggestions that oil is a consideration are still treated as unseemly. 
"The only interest the United States has in the region is furthering the cause of peace and stability, not his country's ability to generate oil," said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman. But wouldn't a victorious American army end up administering Iraq's oil fields? "I wouldn't even try to start guessing what the military may or may not do," Mr. Fleischer replied.
No serious expert believes the charge made by Mr. Hussein that Washington's one real goal is to seize his oil. That, argues Philip K. Verleger Jr., a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, would be "an economic gamble of enormous proportions," given the deplorable state of the Iraqi oil industry, the enormous costs of rebuilding the country, and the uncertainty over the future.
But 112 billion barrels of proven reserves is also something nobody can overlook. So even if it's not only about oil, or even mainly about oil, Iraq's "ability to generate oil" is always somewhere on the table, even if not in so many words.
But what is at stake is not an instant bonanza that so vast a reserve might suggest. Oil is a complicated and expensive business, and experts agree that Iraq would need something in the vicinity of $5 billion and at least three years to repair the ravages of 20 years of war and sanctions, and to resume the explorations abandoned in 1980, the year it invaded Iran.
The last report by United Nations experts, in March 2000, said Iraq's capacity had fallen from a peak of 3.5 million barrels a day to 2.8 million, and would continue falling without prompt action. 
Even if the flow resumed in the absence of United Nations sanctions, which allow Iraq only to barter its oil for food and other basic commodities, repairing the rest of the country and paying off its huge debts (if in fact a future government assumed them) could well absorb the bulk of the proceeds.
"People have lost perspective," said Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "They think all Iraqi oil is up for grabs. The way I think about it is there is clearly an oil element, but it is not the decisive one."
"Nobody even knows if there will be a rehabilitated Iraqi national oil company," Mr. Yergin continued, "or whether it will be the vehicle to extract Iraq out of its debts. No company will write a check for a million dollars without some sense of stability, without knowing who to negotiate with."
Yet the very fact that there are so many unknowns may drive the countries with a serious interest in the future of Iraq and its oil -- Russia, France, China and Saudi Arabia most prominent among them -- to seek some assurance that they and their concerns will be taken into account by a victorious America.
Russia is a case in point, with something to lose -- and gain -- at every juncture of an American war on Iraq. The immediate effect is likely to be a steep increase in oil prices, benefiting Russia's oil-driven economy. Beyond that, Russia's interests get more complicated.
Iraq still owes Russia from $7 billion to $10 billion for arms purchases during the war with Iran, and Russian oil companies, with their history of cooperation with Iraq, are poised to be major players in any revival of the Iraqi oil industry.
Lukoil, Russia's biggest oil company, signed a 23-year deal with Iraq five years ago to rehabilitate the country's southern oil fields, a deal potentially worth billions. 
At the same time, Russia is worried that an eventual increase in Iraqi oil production could drive prices down.
Perhaps even more worrisome for President Vladimir V. Putin is that if the United States secures a private gas pump in Iraq, he might be denied the energy cooperation on which he has placed his hopes for a new relationship with Washington and the West.
So Russia finds itself in a conundrum, opposed to a war that could undermine its best claim to serious global influence, but aware that it cannot sustain a long and serious disagreement with Washington over an issue like Saddam Hussein's future that the United States considers critical.
"Iraq opens up everything the Russians have agonized over in the past 10 years," said Toby T. Gati, who served as a special assistant to President Bill Clinton for Russia and is now a senior adviser with the Washington law firm Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. "It raises a question in their minds about American intentions, about which they can do little." 
"So the real issue," Ms. Gati continued, "is American power -- how do countries safeguard their interests in a unipolar world, where Washington's attitude is that what's good for America is good for the world?"
Similar questions over American intentions can be heard in Paris, Riyadh and many other capitals. Youssef M. Ibrahim, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, said some countries -- like Saudi Arabia -- might start looking for ways to block what they perceive as an American threat in Iraq.
"The Saudis are saying to themselves, the Americans are going to invade Iraq and turn it into their private pumping station," Mr. Ibrahim said. "So what can they do? One, they can wait three years and see, or two, they can wage a war right now. The only war they can wage is to open all the valves." That, he said, would drive many competitors out of business by dropping prices precipitously.
But for the Saudis, as for the Russians -- and the French, who also have a longstanding relationship with Iraq -- the risk of ending up on the wrong side of Washington and of whatever government it supports in Iraq ultimately leaves no real alternative but to fall in line behind the United States. So their tactic, at the United Nations and other forums, is to do what they can to impress their national interests on Washington, and to press as hard as they can for Washington not to go it alone.
"So it is about oil, about what the Middle East looks like after Saddam, which is about which countries get to play," Ms. Gati said. 
For now, the fear in foreign capitals is that those who do not back Washington will not get to play.
As for the rest, Mr. Fleischer probably was as good a guide as any when he said, "I think that it's impossible for anybody to speculate about anything and everything that could possibly happen under any military scenario."
The next sign may come in early December, when the State Department will hold meetings with the Iraqi opposition on the future of their oil.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many countries worry about who would control Iraq's oil after an invasion. Above, a refinery in Baghdad. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: FLORIDA; 
Black Turnout Could Be Critical for Democrat

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Two days after a boatload of Haitian migrants made a desperate journey for the Miami shore, Bill McBride, the Democratic candidate for Florida governor, swept through the Miami neighborhood known as Little Haiti on Friday to denounce their detention and perhaps pick up a few votes.
 "If you don't care about this, then your heart is just too hard," Mr. McBride told the crowd of more than 100 cheering Haitian-Americans at a community center. "We should not be locking people up who are seeking freedom." 
 In recent days, Mr. McBride, a Tampa lawyer and first-time candidate, has intensified his focus on potential black voters. Often accompanied by some of the state's most prominent black political figures, he has made appearances at black churches and schools in poor neighborhoods to talk about overcrowded classrooms and the need for a more inclusive state government. Mr. McBride is also scheduled to attend services at black churches on Sunday with Al Gore and Bill Clinton.
In the homestretch of his campaign to unseat Gov. Jeb Bush, Mr. McBride is keenly aware that his candidacy is dependent upon huge support from black voters, particularly in South Florida. "I think it's the key to a big turnout, and if we have a big turnout I'll win," Mr. McBride said on his way out of the Haitian community center.
Indeed, large black voter turnout was an important factor in Mr. Gore's close race in 2000 with the governor's brother, George W. Bush. It is expected to be just as important for Mr. McBride in on Tuesday if he expects to offset the governor's solid Republican base in crucial areas like the Florida Panhandle.
"African-Americans make up about 11 percent of Florida registered voters," said Alan Stonecipher, communications director for the McBride campaign. "Their role is going to be vital, no question about it. If there is high turnout with every other group and not with African-Americans it would mean that our ability to win becomes less likely." 
Democratic strategists say Mr. McBride must pull off a tricky balancing act in the final days of the race by continuing to reach out to the black communities in South Florida while not neglecting the crucial I-4 corridor from Daytona Beach to Tampa Bay in Central Florida. That area is considered critical to state elections because it has a heavy concentration of swing voters.
"He needs to energize the Democratic base," said Jim Krog, a lobbyist who ran the 1990 and 1994 campaigns of Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat. "They've got to look for every tool they can to do that. I'd use Janet Reno; I'd use Bill Clinton. I'd use the churches, those folks whom the African-American community identifies with as their champions. I would attempt to get those champions involved in the next few days." 
Mr. McBride is executing just such a game plan, but it may not be enough to overcome Governor Bush's lead, his solid support among Republicans and his popularity with another critical constituency, the state's sizable Hispanic population, particularly Cuban Americans in South Florida. Mr. Bush had a 49 percent to 43 percent lead in a poll conducted Saturday through Thursday by several Florida newspapers owned by The New York Times. 
"I think in a very close election, which this is, both those demographic groups are very, very critical," Mr. Krog said. "The Hispanic vote, in particular the Cuban vote, is very important for Bush."
Although Mr. Bush has alienated many blacks in the state with his policies on affirmative action and his role in the 2000 presidential election, in which African-American voters were disproportionately disenfranchised, Mr. McBride has not been entirely successful in shoring up the black vote. With his strategy of running a largely one-issue campaign focused on public education, Mr. McBride has not consistently hit Mr. Bush on issues that resonate with many black voters.
In a recent televised debate, for instance, Mr. McBride made only passing reference to the crisis at the Florida Department of Children and Families, for which the governor has been widely criticized. The agency, which Mr. Bush promised to fix as a candidate four years ago, admitted in April that it had lost a 4-year-old black Miami girl and had not noticed her absence for more than a year.
State black luminaries are trying to project a united front for Mr. McBride. But they acknowledge that defeating Mr. Bush will not be easy.
"I've just been telling everyone I see, in a Burger King drive-through or just picking up my dry cleaning, to make sure they vote," said State Senator Kendrick Meek, a Democrat and one of the state's black political power brokers.
Mr. Bush has managed to gain the backing of some black residents and community leaders in the state. This week, several dozen African-American community leaders, pastors and families endorsed Mr. Bush at a news conference in the low-income Liberty City neighborhood in Miami. And last week, The Broward Times, a 24,000-circulation African-American newspaper in Coral Springs, endorsed Governor Bush, the first time in the paper's 13-year history that it has supported a Republican.
"I met with McBride several times, and he didn't address the issues," said Keith Clayborne, editor of the paper.
"We asked him about issues of economic development. How would you assist black enterprises? It was a very vague response that didn't address the question. His answer was always we have to beat Jeb Bush, because he knows in the black community Jeb Bush is a huge negative. "McBride has not taken any program that Jeb has implemented and said he has a better plan for it," Mr. Clayborne said.
Mr. Bush's supporters say that they do not expect the governor to receive huge support among black voters, but that he can win enough of those votes to chip away at the large numbers Mr. McBride will need to win. "We feel it will be a double-digit number, north of 10 percent," said Al Cardenas, chairman of the Florida Republican Party. "We're very encouraged by it." 
Mr. McBride's main supporters contend that the Republicans are simply putting on a good game face, realizing that Mr. Bush will be in trouble on Election Day if black voter turnout is overwhelmingly high. But the McBride backers seem less certain that will happen.
"Let me put it this way, nobody's declaring victory," said State Senator Daryl Jones, one of the state's most popular black elected officials, who was defeated by Mr. McBride in the Democratic primary and is now campaigning for him. "The Republicans are not saying they're going to win, and the Democrats are not saying they're going to win. No one knows; this one is way too close to call."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill McBride, right, campaigned Friday in the Little Haiti neighborhood in Miami alongside Stephen Baptiste, a community leader. (Associated Press)

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 1191 words

HEADLINE: Life With Microsoft Still Stifling for Rivals 

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
At the end of a four-and-a-half-year court battle and distracted by a gloomy high-technology economy, Silicon Valley today largely took Microsoft's victory in a federal antitrust case on Friday as a foregone conclusion.
 Living with Microsoft has increasingly meant staying away from markets that the company controls as a result of its desktop computer software monopoly and looking for niches that are not likely to attract Microsoft's attention. 
 Indeed, many executives here said they were more concerned with what Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of the Federal District Court in Washington chose not to think about when she approved the company's settlement with the Justice Department. Rather than focus on her relatively narrow ruling on how Microsoft manages its Windows operating system, these executives said they were more concerned about competing with Microsoft in an ever-expanding range of markets from hand-held computers to providing Internet service. 
"Now the gloves are off," said Jonathan I. Schwartz, an executive vice president who heads software efforts at Sun Microsystems. "The industries that need to be concerned will include media companies, retailers and financial institutions."
Microsoft, Mr. Schwartz warned, now has new targets that are not technology companies, and in the wake of a narrow ruling that allows it great freedom in new markets, the nature of the competition would soon become far broader.
"The impact of this ruling won't be felt in Silicon Valley because the Valley has already suffered the impact of Microsoft's monopoly," he said. Sun has long been one of the most outspoken critics of Microsoft and is locked in a private antitrust lawsuit with the software company over the licensing of Sun's Java programming language.
Executives at other software and hardware companies here also said they had been resigned to a judgment in support of the settlement with few additional restrictions on Microsoft.
Mitchell E. Kertzman, the president and chief executive officer of Liberate Technologies, an interactive television software company based in San Carlos, Calif., said the ruling was a "nonevent."
"In the Valley, people were disgusted, but not shocked," he added. "We assumed that this was the way we would have to live with Microsoft."
Indeed, the battles for control of the personal computer operating system and the Internet browser that the court's ruling dealt with are for the most part viewed here as being long over.
The bruising battles over the rise of the commercial Internet that led directly to the antitrust lawsuit have also given way to a restructuring of the Valley that in many ways resembles an earlier era, executives said.
"The climate today feels exactly reminiscent of the late 1980's," said Jim Breyer, the managing general partner of Accel Partners, one of the Silicon Valley's leading venture capital firms. "From an industry structure standpoint, it's as if you've dialed the clock back 13 years with both I.B.M. and Microsoft being in a better position than at any time in the past decade."
The Valley, he said, is now in one of those periods between major technological disruptions, when no one is certain what the next breakthrough will be.
By ruling narrowly on the question of how Microsoft can exploit its monopoly in personal computer operating systems and largely rejecting charges that Microsoft repeatedly tried to extend that monopoly into new markets, the judge insured that her ruling would have little impact on Valley's current economy and technology, executives said.
At the same time, underscoring Microsoft's continued overwhelming presence in the personal computer industry, neither Apple Computer nor Hewlett-Packard, the Valley's leading PC makers, would comment on the case.
Although Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, has largely resisted opportunities to criticize Microsoft publicly during the case, Apple did provide government witnesses who testified about Microsoft threats and pressure.
While Hewlett-Packard has publicly been one of Microsoft's strongest allies during the court case, some executives at the company privately reached out to reporters to point out instances of Microsoft's use of pressure tactics to control the industry.
The continued silence of powerful companies on the case was seen as evidence by some in the industry that the court ruling has done little to rein in Microsoft's economic power.
"People have been reluctant to talk about Microsoft consistently for the past five years," Ken Wasch, president of the Software and Information Industry Association, an industry trade group, said in an interview.
Later, in a statement, Mr. Wasch said that "we listened to the same testimony that Judge Kollar-Kotelly did, and we are perplexed that she didn't recognize that Microsoft's anti-competitive behavior now extends far beyond the browser, into a range of other technologies and markets." He urged state attorneys general who had sought strict penalties against Microsoft to appeal Judge Kollar-Kotelly's decision.
Whether that happens or not, many companies in Silicon Valley are likely to continue spending more time struggling to survive in markets that Microsoft doesn't dominate.
Although Microsoft has been a fierce competitor of Sun's in the field of programming languages, executives at companies in fields where Microsoft has faired poorly, like hand-held computing, said they had a more immediate concern: the slumping economy.
"People are concerned about other problems today," said Donna Dubinsky, the chief executive of Handspring, a maker of hand-held computers based Mountain View, Calif. "I don't think this is people's No. 1 problem today. There are greater concerns."
For others here, Microsoft has always been a force to be contended with, but it is still one that generates ambivalence.
Randy Komisar, a veteran technology entrepreneur and lawyer, said that his first assignment when he joined the pioneering notepad computer maker Go Corporation in 1991 had been to determine whether or not to sue Microsoft.
Microsoft had negotiated with the start-up firm while secretly planning a competing product. Microsoft killed its version after Go had failed -- in part because of Microsoft's plan to enter the market.
"We felt pretty violated," Mr. Komisar said. Yet the company did not sue, deciding it had little chance for a significant legal victory against the much larger company.
Today, Mr. Komisar said he still feels ambivalent about Microsoft. On the one hand, it is one of the few bright lights in a grim economy that badly needs some signal of strength. At the same time, he sees Microsoft using its monopoly in PC operating systems to bully its way into other markets, like the hand-held computer market.
"The good news," he said, "is that Microsoft has been proven to be a monopoly and that means that the Justice Department can stick its fingers in more easily" if Microsoft bullies too ferociously in the future.
Mr. Schwartz of Sun Microsystems echoed those sentiments.
"The glass is clearly half full," he said. "Every customer I talk to knows that Microsoft is a potential competitor and a problem." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

PERSON: JONATHAN I SCHWARTZ (66%)

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 1; Column 3; National Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2302 words

HEADLINE: FEUDING FOR PROFIT: Rap's War of Words; 
In Rap Industry, Rivalries as Marketing Tool

BYLINE:  This article was reported by Lola Ogunnaike, Laura Holson and John Leland and was written by Mr. Leland. 

 BODY:
Six years after the violent deaths of the rap stars Tupac Shakur and the Notorious B.I.G., which some in the industry consider the culmination of a war of words between rival East Coast and West Coast rap camps, the world of platinum-selling hip-hop remains fascinated by threats and insults. Indeed, taunts and menace have often served as provocative come-ons for a $1.6 billion industry.
 Now with rap album sales even more depressed than the music industry as a whole, these rivalries may hold a key to its turnaround. This month the rap world is counting on four heavily promoted CD's by major stars to salvage the year. 
 Many people, from teenagers to the heads of giant media companies like Sony and Vivendi Universal, are looking to these albums as an indication of whether rap can rebound and remain the vital form -- and the cash cow -- it has been for the last decade. 
And as always, the feuds, exacerbated in an era of corporate consolidation, are stirring the buzz and whipping up enthusiasm.
The current talk is about bad blood between Ja Rule and DMX, who in recent interviews and forthcoming albums have taunted and belittled each other. And in the semi-autobiographical movie "8 Mile," which opens Friday, the character played by Eminem is beaten up by rival rappers, who carry a battle of words off the stage and onto the street.
The killing in Queens last week of Jam Master Jay of the group Run-DMC revived headlines of rap killings and blood feuds of the past, though it is far from clear what occurred in this latest case.
Whether the style is called rap or hip-hop, underneath all the feuds is the question of money.
"Companies make out well," said Bert Padell, an accountant whose clients include Madonna, Run-DMC and others. "Managers make out well. Artists don't make out well." Mr. Padell said it was common for a performer with an album generating $17 million in sales to wind up with as little as $70,000 before taxes. When the performers feel compelled to use that money in competitive flossing, or showing off, tempers can flare. 
After more than two decades of growth, hip-hop album sales hit a wall last year, declining about 15 percent to 89 million in 2001, from a peak of 105 million the previous year, according to the Nielsen SoundScan company, which tracks sales figures. Album sales for the music industry were down overall, but less -- 3 percent in 2001 -- reflecting both the recession and the growth of free Internet file-sharing services. For the first six months of 2002, sales of hip-hop albums were down almost 20 percent from the same period last year, compared with a general industry drop of 13 percent. Once driven by surprise breakthroughs by new performers, the genre has come to rely on a few bankable stars whose recordings require ever-escalating budgets.
Hilary Rosen, the chief executive of the Recording Industry Association of America, blamed rap's slump on its success: as its influence spread, fans could get hip-hop flavors from rock or pop albums. 
For the music business, which last year sold $13.7 billion worth of albums, hip-hop accounted for 12 percent of sales. Even with this dip, rap has provided some of the industry's few bright spots. The three top-selling albums this year according to Nielsen SoundScan -- "The Eminem Show" by Eminem, "Nellyville" by Nelly and "Ashanti" by Ashanti -- are rap or rap-inflected. This month's major albums are by Eminem, Missy Elliott, Jay-Z and Ja Rule.

The Rapper
Leaving the 'Hood, But Still Staying Close
Many hopes rest on 26-year-old Jeffrey Atkins, known as Ja Rule, whose fourth album, "The Last Temptation," is scheduled for release on Nov. 19. He also stars opposite Steven Seagal in an action movie called "Half Past Dead," which opens Nov. 15. 
Interviewed in a SoHo recording studio last week, Ja Rule communicated the positive side of success with $250,000 worth of jewelry, and the negative side with a switchblade he calls Valley. The studio, owned by Ja Rule's record label, Murder Inc., is called the Crack House.
He said he needed the knife for protection. "If I was Justin Timberlake, I wouldn't have to walk around with a gun and knife," he said, referring to the lead singer in the boy band 'N Sync. "But I'm not. I'm Ja Rule." 
Ja Rule embodies the contradictions of a modern hip-hop performer, trying to balance thug bona fides with the embrace of the corporate mainstream. The father of two, married to his high school girlfriend, he has collaborated with Jennifer Lopez, Mary J. Blige, Mariah Carey and others. 
But as his fame has grown, so has his fear for his life. A jealous former neighbor, an overzealous fan, anyone is a possible threat, he said. "It's sad, because that feeling is mainly towards my black people," he said. "When my white fans come around, I don't feel uneasy, like they want to harm me. But when I'm around a whole group of black people, a defense comes on," he said. "That's the tragedy of this."
He added, "Don't get it wrong -- we love our ghettos and our ghettos love us, but there are always the one or two knuckleheads that you have to watch out for."
Many rap stars try to straddle two worlds, enjoying newfound wealth while remaining close to their roots. Fans, white and black, like their rappers to be close to the street. "If you're not from the 'hood," he explained, "they don't feel you're a real rapper."
Ja Rule, who grew up in Hollis, Queens, now lives in a wealthy New Jersey suburb. He bought his mother a home nearby and two other homes as real estate investments. But, he said, like many of his peers, he found his new community lonely and sterile. "You have no choice but to go back to your 'hood because that's where your friends are, that's where your love is," he said.
The straddle can be precarious. "The streets is like our drug," he said. "That's what I'm trying to explain to the white audience. This is our addiction that we can't get away from and this is what drags down the rap star. It's like the actual drug that drags down the rock star."
Ja Rule said that like many other rappers he had overcome not just the difficulties of his youth, but also an early record deal that brought him recognition but little money. He is currently in litigation with the company. Because he has only recently started to really get paid, he said, he is not apologetic about his jewelry, which included a $100,000 Rolex watch. "I know people probably look at me and think this is senseless," he acknowledged. "But when you're dealing with what you call new money -- which is what I am -- to spend is still very fun for me. I'm still enjoying it."

The Numbers
Big Sums in Advances Get Whittled Away
In a Manhattan office cluttered with sports memorabilia, Mr. Padell, the accountant, outlined the economics of a typical hip-hop deal, with the caution that no two deals are identical. Not all rappers, he said, had the advantages of Ja Rule, who also makes money as a writer, as a frequent guest performer and as a partner in a record company aside from his albums.
"Let's say you're a successful artist -- your last album sold, say, 1.5 million copies," he said. A performer with such a track record might negotiate an advance against royalties of around $1 million. This, he conceded, sounds like a lot of money.
"But . . . " he continued.
He started ticking off expenses.
Out of their advances, performers pay for all recording costs, including studio time and personnel. As hip-hop has become more successful, album sales and radio airplay increasingly depend on big name producers like the Neptunes, Timbaland and Jermaine Dupri, who charge anywhere from $35,000 to $100,000 per song. Many rappers also call in other artists for duets or cameo appearances at $10,000 to $50,000 a song, Mr. Padell said. The performer also pays for the rights to any digital samples, which vary widely in cost.
In all, Mr. Padell put recording costs at about $700,000 -- all paid for by the artist -- leaving $300,000, still a lot of money.
"But . . . " he said again.
Out of this figure, the performer's manager gets 20 percent, or $60,000; the business manager or accountant takes 5 percent, or $15,000. The lawyer, who negotiated the deal in the first place, might get 5 percent of the entire advance, or $50,000.
After these fees the artist has $175,000.
Of this, about $70,000 would be due in taxes, leaving $105,000 for making it to near the top of the hip-hop game. True, many performers also get money for concert appearances or publishing fees. But in turn, Mr. Padell said, his hip-hop clients often support a network of parents, siblings and friends, and many of them tithe to their churches.
Mr. Padell said that performers who make a 500,000-copy gold album, might end up with more money working for UPS.
Many of these costs apply to musicians working in any genre, but the high costs of producers, the short careers, the pressure to support family members, and the competitive flaunting of wealth weigh heavily on hip-hop acts. As one hip-hop executive explained, a rock band can show up at a music event in a Honda. If a rapper does not have the latest expensive SUV, his or her star appears to be on the wane, which can be career death.

The Industry
Companies Need Hits By Nurture or Merger
The real money in rap is made by media giants like Sony, Bertlesmann and Vivendi Universal. In the mid-1990's the major music companies shifted to a strategy of selling music around the world rather than just at home, and they merged to grow. The largest mergers of the era involved the creation of Vivendi Universal, which acquired what were once Island, Def Jam, Interscope, Geffen, A&M, Polydor, MCA and other labels, and in the process acquired many of the top rap acts. At the same time, AOL Time Warner sold its share in Interscope after shareholder controversy over its rap portfolio.
Vivendi Universal has 9 of the Top 20 rap albums this year, and its stars include Ja Rule, Eminem and Ja Rule's rival, DMX.
Lyor Cohen, chief executive of the company's Island Def Jam Music Group, said he missed the simpler practices of the 1980's. "When I first started working with artists like L. L. Cool J, the barrier to entry was low," Mr. Cohen said. "There were no videos. No radio. But you could walk into a club and get the D.J. to spin your album and sell one million units. Now the barriers to entry are high. You can't do that anymore. And the higher the stakes the harder it is."
Two executives said that even five years ago a rap album by a newcomer could be made for $75,000, while an established star might spend $500,000. They said a comparable new act today would spend $500,000, and the star more than $1 million.
Chris Schwartz, who founded the label Ruff House in the 90's, blamed consolidation for raising costs and dampening creativity.
He said the megacompanies needed huge, safe hits, the equivalent of sequels in the movie business. "They spend enormous amounts of money to make market share," he said. "So now the first year you get a hiccup, it's a big hiccup."
Yet Mr. Cohen said consolidation was good for both his company and for hip-hop. "It shows the economic strength of the music," he said.
In large measure because of hip-hop, the Universal Music Group distributes one in three records sold in the United States. "They've been able to ride over the decline in the global market because of the strength of its rap and hip-hop," said Michael Nathanson, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, the boutique New York brokerage firm.

The Feud
Fights and Jabs Whip Up the Fans
Top rappers and executives, including Jay-Z, Nas, Snoop Doggy Dog, Eminem and Jermaine Dupri, have advanced their careers through battles of insult. Some of the talk is dazzlingly clever, much of it inflammatory, and all of it disseminated and promoted through the record companies.
Much of the beef, or animosity, is purely promotional. "People have nothing else to talk about," said Corey Smyth, who manages Talib Kweli, De La Soul and other hip-hop acts, who have not engaged in this kind of jawboning. "As long as it doesn't turn violent, to me it's a good thing."
Ja Rule's feud with DMX began over timbre: both have gravelly voices, and DMX accused his rival of stealing his style. As it escalated, Ja Rule taunted DMX about drug use; DMX questioned Ja Rule's sexual orientation. Ja Rule ends a rhyme on his forthcoming album, "You're mad at the world or just me, because I'm on top of the world?" He accused DMX of attacking him for the sake of publicity. "He's cold right now and he's trying to get a little heat going by making dis records about me," he said. "But I'm not having that."
DMX promises a song called "Ruled Out."
Feuds create publicity at little or no expense. Nas returned to the charts last summer through a running beef with the more successful Jay-Z. "The rivalry was the spark for one of rap music's most celebrated comebacks," said Elliott Wilson, editor of the hip-hop magazine XXL. Sales of Nas's album "Stillmatic," unspectacular before the feud, jumped to more than 1.6 million copies.
Ja Rule and DMX both record for Island Def Jam labels. Mr. Cohen, the chief executive, said that it is the companies' responsibility to make sure beefs like theirs don't go beyond words. "The moment you see it, you deal with it," he said. "They have a great opportunity to change the socioeconomic course of their families for generations to come, and we remind them of that."
Back in the Crack House, Ja Rule, weary but optimistic, weighed the price of success. "Who's really getting the money?" he asked. "Who's really shedding the blood and who's getting the money? We're the soldiers, we're on the front lines, we're not in the Pentagon or the White House."
He added, "Hopefully, I'll die old and be able to laugh about all this. I'll start putting together my Vegas lounge act now."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: NEW JERSEY; 
Plenty of Verbal Jabs and Punches in Final Senate Debate

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
New Jersey's two main candidates for United States Senate met last night for their only broadcast television debate, and their 60-minute discussion was packed with enough combative exchanges and impromptu jibes to fuel an entire campaign.
 Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican, pounded away at the voting record that Democrat Frank R. Lautenberg compiled as a United States senator from 1983 to 2001, blaming Mr. Lautenberg for higher taxes, an under-funded military and weakened intelligence-gathering services. He also said that Mr. Lautenberg shared responsibility for the fact that New Jersey sends more in taxes to Washington than it receives in federal aid. 
 "We are last, New Jersey is always last," Mr. Forrester said. "I provide a better vision for moving New Jersey out of last place."
But Mr. Lautenberg, who appeared unfocused and ill prepared during portions of a debate with Mr. Forrester on cable television Wednesday night, dominated much of last night's discussion by citing a flurry of statistics from a yellow legal pad and tossing in several offhand remarks at his opponent's expense. Mr. Lautenberg claimed credit for bringing back billions of dollars in federal aid for New Jersey transportation projects and education programs. He also accused Mr. Forrester of favoring a plan to use Social Security funds to give a tax cut to the wealthiest 1 percent of Americans.
When Mr. Forrester offered himself as an alternative to the "failed policies of the past," Mr. Lautenberg said that Mr. Forrester really sought to help conservatives restrict abortion rights, curtail gun control laws and force taxpayers to pay for cleaning up toxic waste dumps, instead of the companies that created them.
"If we let the polluters off the hook, if we give our tax benefits to the wealthiest among us, if we fail to make sure that we have the kinds of programs to get rid of guns in our society, to get rid of our environmental disaster that we have hanging over us, then we will have not served the public well," he said during his closing statement.
Mr. Lautenberg, who replaced Senator Robert G. Torricelli on the ballot last month and quickly built a steady lead in the polls, tried for weeks to avoid debates altogether, or schedule them so they would be seen by a minimal number of viewers. After Wednesday's cable television debate, Republican Party officials publicly described Mr. Lautenberg's performance as "incoherent." Privately, some Forrester aides suggested that Mr. Lautenberg, 78, might be too old to effectively serve a six-year term.
But at tonight's debate, hosted by Gabe Pressman and broadcast on WNBC-TV, Mr. Lautenberg put Mr. Forrester on the defensive several times. When Mr. Forrester gave a lengthy response, Mr. Lautenberg wryly chided him for delivering a "filibuster" and a "dissertation." 
When Mr. Forrester criticized his record on defense issues, Mr. Lautenberg, a World War II veteran, responded by issuing a challenge.
"Tell me, tell this audience, what you've done in your 49 years on this earth to make our country safer," Mr. Lautenberg asked Mr. Forrester, who has no military experience. "How many times have you prevented a terrorist from attacking us?"
Mr. Forrester replied: "Well I happen to believe, senator, that one of the things I did was get Bob Torricelli out of the Senate. I happen to think that was in our interest."
Before the debate, both candidates spent the day addressing party loyalists at get-out-the-vote rallies. About 500 people attended a rally in Newark where Bill Clinton praised Mr. Lautenberg for helping his administration bring economic prosperity to middle class Americans.
Mr. Forrester's campaign suffered a setback, when President Bush declined a request to campaign in New Jersey this weekend. Campaigning in Perth Amboy yesterday, Mr. Forrester said he was grateful the president campaigned for him in September and was confident that he would nonetheless defeat Mr. Lautenberg.
"We've had such support, including the president, that I could not ask for more," Mr. Forrester said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas R. Forrester, left, the Republican candidate for United States Senate, and Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democrat, after the debate. (Michael Nagle for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1650 words

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Refinance and Earn Miles. But Is the Deal for You?

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
LIKE many other homeowners, Ming-Bong and Susy Lee took advantage of the decline in interest rates and refinanced the mortgage on their three-bedroom home in Belmont, Calif., this year. The Lees, who actually refinanced twice, say they are saving nearly $200 on their monthly payments. But that wasn't the only benefit.
 The couple and their two young sons, Bryan and Brandon, also got a trip to Hawaii. It was among the perks offered to Mr. Lee through his frequent-flier program at United Airlines: for every $10,000 in mortgage money borrowed, he received 1,250 miles. (The Lees declined to disclose the size of their mortgage but said the total amount borrowed for the two refinancings was just about enough for four free round-trip coach tickets to Maui.) 
 Frequent-flier partnerships between airlines and mortgage lenders are not new. United and American Airlines were among the first to have them, in 1996. But more and more lenders, brokers and real estate companies have been teaming up with airlines and travel companies, hoping to cash in on the strong mortgage market. The Mortgage Bankers Association predicted last week that lenders would make a record $2.42 trillion in home loans this year. 
Among the more recent partnerships, Lending Tree entered into agreements this year with United, Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines, US Airways, Six Continents Hotels and American Express. E-Loan, the online broker that the Lees used in February and September, signed a deal with United last year and with Delta Air Lines this year. Delta Corporate Services, no relation to the airline, which provides real estate broker referrals, last year hooked up with Hilton Hotels.
While these partnerships give consumers more opportunities to add points or miles to their reward programs, they may not be the best way to shop for mortgages, experts say. And some states restrict the use of mileage for certain transactions. Most of the lenders involved in such partnerships are among the largest in the country, and "they're not noted for their particularly aggressive pricing," said Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage research firm in Butler, N.J. 
"Rates at these institutions are not necessarily the lowest, cheapest rates in the business; they are average at best," he said.
For instance, he said, the average rate last week on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at branches of Bank of America, CitiMortgage, Countrywide Home Loans and GMAC, all participants in rewards programs, was 6.27 percent, compared with an average of 6.23 percent charged by 144 nonparticipating lenders surveyed randomly.
Mr. Lee, 38, a manager at a computer software company, said he did shop around initially, but ultimately chose E-Loan in each refinancing. He said he is satisfied with the 6 7/8 percent rate he received on his 30-year jumbo mortgage in his last deal. Could he and Mrs. Lee, 34, a homemaker, have received better terms elsewhere? Perhaps, though they probably wouldn't have gotten the free trip to Hawaii.
Despite the added perks, the mileage deals have yet to take hold in a big way. Randy Petersen, the publisher of InsideFlyer, a magazine specializing in travel loyalty programs, estimates that only 51,000 frequent fliers, out of a total of 20 million active program members, have participated in mortgage deals.
"People's habit typically is to read their local newspaper about refinancing, and to refinance with someone they know locally," he said. "And the programs haven't been around in a refinancing boom like this; this is something relatively new."
Mr. Petersen said that the vast majority of the mortgage program participants struck their deals in the last 18 months, a time of generally declining interest rates.
Many airlines and travel companies have included some information about the programs in mailings to members. But that may not be enough.
"I'm in the dark about the programs," said Hugh F. Kelly, a real estate consultant from Brooklyn who is a member of the loyalty programs at Delta, American and Hilton. "Once you know about them, you have to go through multiple levels of clicking on their Web sites to get to them, and you also have to know exactly what you're looking for. The programs are hobbled by their presentation."
Joe Kennedy, the president of E-Loan, said Mr. Kelly's complaints were valid. "Even though these offers are very attractive, most frequent-flier program statements are loaded with offers, and they're lost in the blur."
For example, the frequent-flier program of American Airlines alone has partnerships with more than 125 companies in a wide range of industries, in addition to its arrangements with Countrywide Home Loans and Cendant Mobility Real Estate Services.
ONE of the largest programs is run by Lending Tree, which acts as an exchange for 189 lenders and 650 real estate brokerage companies. The company and its five airline partners offer miles for both loans (mortgages, refinancing and home equity) and real estate transactions -- the actual buying and selling of the home. Frequent fliers get 1,250 miles for every $10,000 of a loan; in addition, if they buy or sell through Lending Tree, they get 3,000 miles for every $10,000 of its price.
Lending Tree also has different bonus programs for participants in the Six Continents travel loyalty program, which is for guests of Holiday Inn, InterContinental and Crowne Plaza hotels, and for participants in American Express Membership Rewards, who receive points only for buying and selling homes.
Mortgage partners with programs similar to Lending Tree's include E-Loan, Bank of America, Countrywide, GMAC Mortgage and U.S. Bank Home Mortgage. In addition to its program for real estate transactions, American Express has arrangements through Membership Rewards and its banking unit with PHH Mortgage Services. Diners Club works with CitiMortgage, allowing members to redeem points to cover the closing costs of a mortgage and receive other mortgage-related discounts. Diners Club and CitiMortgage are both part of Citigroup. 
Real estate companies with travel deals include GMAC Real Estate, Cendant, PMP Relocation Services and Delta Corporate Services.
TO find out if their travel loyalty programs participate in such deals, consumers can check their Web sites; they usually list all the participating partners, including real estate and mortgage companies. The deals can be arranged online or offline, depending on the company.
But there are some caveats. First, the offers are sometimes limited. GMAC Real Estate, for example, caps its bonuses at 125,000 miles, while home-equity offers through GMAC Mortgage are not available in certain states. Members of the American Airlines frequent-flier program who decide to buy a home through Cendant are restricted to brokers in its real estate network, most of whom are affiliated with Coldwell Banker, Century 21 and ERA, all Cendant brands. In addition, the laws of some states -- including New Jersey, Kansas, Kentucky, Nevada and Oregon -- prohibit deals that feature miles for the actual purchase or sale of homes, though they are allowed for mortgage deals.
Then there's the matter of redeeming mileage awards for free airline tickets or other rewards. Airlines sometimes impose blackout dates and other restrictions, particularly to popular destinations like Florida.
Greg Cassity, 37, an information technology consultant and member of Delta's frequent-flier program, says that is one of his concerns. He recently received nearly 250,000 bonus miles for selling one house and buying another in suburban Atlanta through Lending Tree.
Mr. Cassity said he wants to redeem the miles for two Delta tickets to Ireland for himself and his wife, Sheryl, 41, a finance manager at Coca-Cola. He also hopes to get free airline tickets for other family members. But he said he has had problems in the past with blackout dates and seat availability when he has tried to redeem miles on short notice. "My only reservation going forward is on the Delta side -- how much trouble I will have booking flights using SkyMiles," he said. 
Mr. Petersen of InsideFlyer said mileage redemption has not been a problem for most travelers this year. "Airlines have not cut back the number of free awards," he said. "More frequent fliers are using awards in a fragile economy." 
Ultimately, said Douglas G. Duncan, the chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, people considering a loan through a travel loyalty program should thoroughly research and shop for the best rates -- and analyze their personal needs.
"If the consumer is the kind of person who never travels anywhere, this is not the right product," he said. But for those who like to travel, "it might well make sense."
"If all is equal, and one lender as a last effort throws in the frequent-flier miles," he said, "that may well tip the balance to that lender offering the best deal."

A Bonus at the Closing
Looking for a loyalty program that provides points or frequent-flier miles for home borrowing or real estate transactions? Following is a list of some lenders and real estate companies and the programs with which they are affiliated.
* Bank of America. Alaska Airlines and America West Airlines.
* CitiMortgage. Diners Club.
* Countrywide Home Loans. American Airlines and Hilton Hotels.
* E-Loan. Delta Air Lines and United Airlines.
* GMAC Mortgage. Northwest Airlines.
* GMAC Real Estate (real estate broker). Delta, Northwest.
* Lending Tree (mortgage broker). Continental Airlines, Delta, Northwest, United, US Airways, Six Continents Hotels.
* Lending Tree (real estate broker). Continental, Delta, Northwest, United, US Airways, American Express, Six Continents.
* PHH Mortgage Services. American Express. 
* U.S. Bank Home Mortgage. Northwest.
* Cendant Mobility Real Estate Services. American Airlines.
* Delta Corporate Services. Hilton.
* PMP Relocation Services. United.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ming-Bong Lee of Belmont, Calif., earned enough frequent-flier miles by refinancing his mortgage to take his family on a trip to Hawaii. He refinanced through E-Loan. (Thor Swift for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Column 2; Editorial Desk; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: A Surplus of Ideas for a Budget Deficit 

 BODY:
The magnitude of the fiscal crisis facing New York City is difficult to overstate: With a total city budget of some $42 billion, $24 billion of which comes from city revenues, the city faces a deficit of between $5 billion and $6 billion for the year beginning July 1. The Op-Ed page asked several analysts for suggestions on how the city might bridge the gap.

By Diana Fortuna
Diana Fortuna is president of the Citizens Budget Commission.
 In the face of an unprecedented budget gap, New Yorkers deserve more creative options than a choice between higher taxes and reduced services. The best alternative is to deliver municipal services more efficiently. 
 First, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should abandon notoriously inefficient work practices that have persisted through good times and bad. The city can save $200 million annually, for example, by modernizing procurement procedures, essentially replacing paper purchase orders with online transactions. Savings are also possible in more visible public services. In the Police and Fire Departments, overtime is routinely budgeted for predictable tasks that could be staffed more cheaply. Also, uniformed workers fill thousands of jobs that could be performed more efficiently by civilians. The city could make many of these changes without reopening union contracts.
The city should also bring municipal workers' fringe benefits into line with standard public and private practice. The city pays 100 percent of the cost of comprehensive health insurance for its workers, retirees and their families. Most companies and other governments (including the federal and New York State governments) require some contribution toward premiums. If the city required premium contributions, it could save more than $500 million annually.
Of course, this change could only be made through collective bargaining with the city's unions. But now is the time to act -- not just because the city faces such a dire fiscal crisis but also because all the city's contracts with its unions (except for the teachers' union) are up for renewal.
New York is already one of the nation's most expensive local governments. Before the mayor and City Council raise taxes or reduce services, they need to explain what steps they are taking to make government more efficient.

By Ronnie Lowenstein
Ronnie Lowenstein is director of the New York City Independent Budget Office.
Since neither the state nor federal government seems ready to ride to the city's fiscal rescue, a combination of spending cuts and tax increases is likely. While spending cuts can be harmful, raising taxes in a high-tax city like New York can also have negative repercussions.
At least two principles should guide our consideration of potential tax increases: fairness and long-term competitiveness. The tax increase that comes closest to meeting both these criteria is restoration of the commuter tax, which would bring in more than $400 million a year. A commuter tax reduces the incentive for individuals who work in the city to reside in the suburbs, and it is also equitable, both because commuters have higher average incomes than city residents do and because it seems fair to have individuals who work here and use local services bear some of the costs.
Increasing the city's tax on personal income is another option. Either increasing the base rate for high-income filers from 3.2 percent to 4.2 percent or adding a 10 percent surcharge for all filers would each raise about $550 million annually. The advantage to raising income taxes is that the increases fall most heavily on high-income residents, who are best able to pay. At the same time, however, many of New York's highest income residents are particularly mobile, and could continue to work in the city but avoid city personal income taxes by residing elsewhere.
The city could also consider raising the property tax rate by 10 percent while loosening limits on property tax assessment increases that have pushed a disproportionate share of the burden onto owners of apartment and office buildings. The rate hike would increase tax revenues by roughly $1 billion a year, and loosening the assessment limits would over time make the property tax more fair. The city also needs to examine the structure of its business income taxes, which have not kept pace with long-term growth in corporate profits.
There is certainly no question that taxes matter. But so do services. Dirtier streets, rising crime and dilapidated parks can be as much a disincentive to living or working here as rising taxes. Higher taxes may be necessary to keep an adequate level of services. Carefully choosing among possible tax increases can minimize the damage to the city's economy.

By Abe Lackman
Abe Lackman, who served as city budget director in 1994, is president of the Albany-based Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities.
The severity of the budget crisis facing the city and state can best be compared not with the city's near bankruptcy of the mid-1970's, but with the situation during the Depression. In times such as this, many will instinctively seek answers to the usual questions: How much will spending have to be cut? Which taxes will have to be raised? Instead, a better way to set sensible policy for the long run is to ask which services and priorities should be protected or possibly even enhanced.
The future of New York City depends on maintaining the city's capacity to survive -- and thrive -- in national and world markets. Two priorities are essential: To preserve the city's physical infrastructure and to build on its intellectual infrastructure.
New York City must ensure that its roads, bridges and transportation systems are in good repair. Deferrals in bridge and road maintenance would be unwise, for example. We also need to move forward with an integrated transportation hub in lower Manhattan, the key to redevelopment of the region. At the same time, New York must protect its human capital in its many colleges and universities, independent laboratories, research hospitals, libraries and museums.
In biotechnology particularly, New York possesses a regional advantage. Consider that the city is home to more than 100 members of the National Academy of Sciences and eight private research universities and institutions in the city are among the top 100 recipients of funding from the National Institutes of Health.
Before city policy makers become mired in a frenzy of budget cuts and tax or fare increases, they should first decide how best to identify -- and build on -- our strengths. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: BUDGETS (95%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (91%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); BUDGET DEFICITS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); MAYORS (89%); TAX LAW (89%); LABOR UNIONS (89%); TAX INCREASES (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); TAXES & TAXATION (89%); FIRE DEPARTMENTS (78%); CITIES (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); OVERTIME (72%); PUBLIC EMPLOYEE COLLECTIVE BARGAINING (72%); COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGREEMENTS (72%); COLLECTIVE BARGAINING (67%); EMPLOYEE HEALTH PLANS (67%); TEACHER UNIONS (66%); HEALTH INSURANCE (65%) FINANCES; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING

PERSON: MICHAEL BLOOMBERG (58%) FORTUNA, DIANA; LOWENSTEIN, RONNIE; LACKMAN, ABRAHAM M
