 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 5, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section A; Column 2; National Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1043 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: MINNESOTA; 
For Minnesota, A Late Debate In a New Race

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Nov. 4 

 BODY:
The debate today was billed as youth vs. experience, vigor vs. wisdom, a last-minute showdown pitting iconic elder statesman vs. can-do up-and-comer. It became a feisty verbal joust of "Norm" vs. "Mr. Vice President," the terms the candidates used to address each other symbolizing the new choice voters face.
 Walter F. Mondale, the 74-year-old former senator, vice president and ambassador to Japan who was tapped last week to replace the late Senator Paul Wellstone, took control early with pointed, partisan attacks that painted his opponent, Norm Coleman, as a right-wing tool of the White House who could not be trusted. Mr. Coleman, 53, the former mayor of this capital city, refused to get rattled, repeatedly reciting his record as a jobs-builder and respectfully observing that Mr. Mondale's was precisely the kind of tone he hoped to change in Washington. 
 Just hours before the polls opened, the candidates in Minnesota's strange, shortened Senate race met for the first time this morning in an hourlong debate at the historic Fitzgerald Theater here, staking out distinct positions on abortion, taxes, war against Iraq, prescription drug benefits and education. With the shock and sadness of Mr. Wellstone's Oct. 25 death in a plane crash shadowing the closely watched race, both candidates agreed that the choice was about competing visions for the future.
"It's not about Vice President Mondale's age, it's not about my age, it's about the age in which we live," Mr. Coleman, the Republican, said in his first chance at the microphone. "I will be a champion for 21st-century thinking."
Mr. Mondale, the Democrat, asked, "Which future?" and added, "Will it be the one where we're working for the people?"
When Mr. Coleman brought up the double-digit inflation, long lines for gas and increased taxes that characterized Mr. Mondale's term as Jimmy Carter's vice president, from 1977 to 1981, his opponent countered with Mr. Coleman's new campaign slogan, which became the debate's mantra: "This election is about the future."
"It's not about the collapse of the shah in 1979, it's not about Afghanistan in 1980," Mr. Mondale said. "It's about Afghanistan and Iraq and the real world today."
Angry over the exclusion of minor-party candidates from the rare day-before-the-election debate, Gov. Jesse Ventura tried to upstage the event by appointing, as it began, an interim senator to fill Mr. Wellstone's seat, a move that could determine control of the Senate during the lame-duck session starting on Nov. 12. Mr. Ventura chose Dean Barkley, a state planning commissioner from Mr. Ventura's own Independence Party who twice ran for the Senate on the Reform Party line.
"If you consider life experiences outside of government and politics, my appointee may be better qualified than either of the two major-party candidates," Mr. Ventura said. 
Broadcast live on CNN, the 10 a.m. debate opened the last of five days of precision campaigning for Mr. Mondale, who headed off to a noontime rally in a frigid Peavey Plaza in Minneapolis, with Soul Asylum providing the backbeat and Jessica Lange the star quality. Mr. Coleman dashed from the theater to a rally in Mankato with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York before setting off on an overnight bus tour through 14 cities and towns.
During the debate, Mr. Mondale frequently leaned forward in his chair, wagged his finger at his opponent and spoke to him like a scolding father. "No, no, no, Norman," he interrupted during a discussion of the proposed Homeland Security Department. When Mr. Coleman began a point with, "The question is----" Mr. Mondale cut him off, saying: "No, I'm asking questions now. Why do you take this hard line?"
Mr. Coleman did not get riled, sticking to a careful, measured script. "This is the tone that you don't want to see in Washington," he said after one outburst. "This is the tone that has resulted in where we are today." 
In an exchange about abortion -- the Democrat said he would reject judicial nominees who opposed Roe v. Wade, while the Republican said he had no litmus test -- Mr. Mondale said, "This is about fundamental principles and not tone."
He also noted a shift in strategy by Mr. Coleman, a former Democrat, who ran an aggressive, negative campaign before Mr. Wellstone's death. "You have a campaign here that is a poster child for what is wrong with politics," Mr. Mondale said. "Norm, we know you, we've seen you, we've seen you shift around."
Mr. Coleman kept his composure. "We've each governed," he said. "I did it in St. Paul. We didn't raise taxes for eight years. We added 18,000 jobs." Referring derisively to the Carter era, he added, "The times of raising taxes and more government regulation are over."
Each man had his own goals in the confrontation: Mr. Mondale, with snappy responses and a sharp command of contemporary issues, tried to defuse criticism of his age and long hiatus from elective office. Mr. Coleman, with his steady, deferential manner, sought to garner more of the kind of plaudits he has received for running a positive campaign since the plane crash.
Mr. Mondale sounded some national Democratic themes, including a call for corporate responsibility. Mr. Coleman said, "You can't be talking about special interests," drawing distinctions between the populist Mr. Wellstone and Mr. Mondale, who has spent recent years sitting on several corporate boards. "You can't be playing the class warfare card."
Emphasizing that he has spent his life in Minnesota, Mr. Mondale suggested that Mr. Coleman, who was born in Brooklyn, was a puppet of the White House, which had propelled him into the race. But Mr. Coleman, who repeatedly dropped references to his two years of campaign travel throughout rural Minnesota, said that if his victory helped Republicans regain control of the Senate, "the president will owe me big time."
As the hour wore on, the way the men referred to each other became more pronounced. The younger debater uttered not one "Fritz" or even "Mr. Mondale" while the elder candidate never called his opponent, "Mayor," just "Norm" or "Norman."
Afterward, Mr. Coleman explained by saying simply, "I have a great respect for the vice president." Mr. Mondale, when asked about it, said, "That's his first name."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Norm Coleman, above, the Republican candidate for the Senate in Minnesota, leaving Fitzgerald Theater in St. Paul after yesterday morning's debate. Walter F. Mondale, right, the Democratic candidate, attended a noon campaign rally in Peavey Plaza in Minneapolis. (Photographs by Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)(pg. A22) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LENGTH: 814 words

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, Subdued End To Improbable Senate Race 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TOMS RIVER, N.J., Nov. 4 

 BODY:
After an improbable campaign marked by ethical debacles, legal battles and a midstream change of candidates, the United States Senate race in New Jersey neared its end today on a surprisingly subdued note.
 Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican nominee, was met by relatively sparse crowds as he made appearances at centers for the elderly and shopping districts across the state. The Forrester campaign even canceled a scheduled event at a shopping center in Jackson. A press release cited "inclement weather," but the weather, though cloudy, was dry, and a Forrester aide later conceded that too few people were there to make it a worthwhile stop. 
 Not until a 6 p.m. rally did Mr. Forrester see his first sizable crowd of the day: 300 people at a Republican rally at a Holiday Inn here. They heard Mr. Forrester predict that he would surprise the pundits and pollsters by winning on Tuesday.
Frank R. Lautenberg, who has led in virtually every poll since he became the Democratic nominee last month, was also greeted with polite but hardly overwhelming welcomes at campaign stops. Mr. Lautenberg said he was optimistic about his chances, but he did not dispute the notion that the public seemed more numbed than energized by the race.
With the Senate race at the top of the ballot, some New Jersey political analysts predicted that the turnout could be an all-time low.
Such indifference seemed unlikely two months ago, when Senator Robert G. Torricelli, who was admonished by the Senate Ethics Committee in August, was still furiously seeking re-election. The race was closely watched by party officials in Washington and was considered one of a handful that might determine whether Democrats keep their single-seat margin in the Senate.
After Mr. Torricelli withdrew on Sept. 30 and a weeklong legal battle cleared the way for Mr. Lautenberg to enter the race, polls have swung in his favor, but the race has generated little enthusiasm.
"It was like an opera that starts out with a bland overture and reaches its peak in the middle," said Ross K. Baker, a political science professor at Rutgers. "By the time it's over, everyone has sung their songs and are lying dead on the stage."
Mr. Forrester's campaign advisers said they believed a low turnout would give him a chance at an upset. Most polls have indicated that Republicans are more highly motivated than Democrats, and because Mr. Lautenberg is a former three-term senator, Mr. Forrester's aides said Mr. Forrester would win a large majority of the undecided voters.
"Our people are motivated," said Bill Pascoe, Mr. Forrester's campaign manager. "After 18 years in public office, people know Frank Lautenberg, so the undecided are really saying that they don't want to vote for him, and I think they'll be the difference that allows us to win."
Mr. Lautenberg said he thought the lethargic tone of the campaign's final days was attributable, in part, to uncertainty about the economy.
Walking from table to table at a campaign stop at a diner in Cherry Hill this afternoon, he received cordial handshakes and words of encouragement, but little of the raucous enthusiasm that comes at the end of many hard-fought campaigns.
Some Republicans were gleeful that only 500 or so people attended a Lautenberg rally on Saturday in Newark, though it featured former President Bill Clinton, the Democrats' biggest star.
Mr. Lautenberg said he felt that the low-watt ending to the race was a sign that his campaign had succeeded in informing voters that Mr. Forrester's positions on issues like gun control, the environment and abortion rights were more conservative than those of most New Jersey voters.
"People know where he stands, and that's why I feel optimistic that the outcome is likely to be very good for us tomorrow," Mr. Lautenberg said.
He ended his day with a rally at Shiloh Baptist Church in Trenton, attended by about 350 people.
While the 13 members of New Jersey's House delegation face re-election, only the race in the Fifth District, where Marge Roukema retired after 22 years in office, has generated much attention. There, Assemblyman E. Scott Garrett, a Republican, is facing Anne R. Sumers, a Democrat.
Two county executive races will also be closely watched, in part because they have been dominated by debates over whether New Jersey should build a sports arena in Newark. In Essex County, Candace Straight, the Republican, has tried to harness sentiment against the arena and use it against Joseph N. DiVincenzo, a Democratic freeholder.
In Bergen County, where some residents and business owners worry that the economy will suffer if the Nets and Devils sports teams move to Newark from the Meadowlands sports complex in East Rutherford, both Dennis McNerney, a Democratic freeholder, and State Senator Henry P. McNamara, a Republican, have often competed over who could register the strongest objection to the plan. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LENGTH: 1443 words

HEADLINE: Fresh Groceries Right Off the Assembly Line 

BYLINE:  By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
FOR the last four months, FreshDirect, an elaborate new online food delivery service, has been gradually working its way into ZIP codes in New York City. And some of those who are still beyond its reach are eager to try it. 
 "I logged on and found out that it would not be in my neighborhood in Brooklyn until February, and I was so disappointed," said Gabriela Meriles, a publicist who works in Manhattan. "I hate going food shopping so now I'm waiting with bated breath." 
 On the face of it, what is tempting her sounds like nothing new. But FreshDirect is unlike the defunct delivery services Kozmo and Urban Fetch. It is also more than just a supermarket taking orders online, like Albertson's and Safeway on the West Coast, Marsh in Indianapolis, Hy-Vee in Des Moines and D'Agostino in New York. And it is entering the New York market on tiptoe, instead of starting full steam ahead like Webvan, a similar company that failed after three years. 
"E-groceries are becoming part of the consumer's lifestyle," said Mark Hamstra, the retail and financial editor of Supermarket News, a trade publication. He added that the services are generally not profitable.
Three years and $100 million in the planning, FreshDirect has its own warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, with a 15,000-item inventory of proportionately more perishable items than in supermarkets, often of higher quality and at lower prices. Fragile Comice pears ($1.39 a pound), perhaps the trickiest item that this reporter ordered a couple of weeks ago, were ripe, buttery and unblemished.
Still, as Nicholas D'Agostino Jr., the chairman of the D'Agostino supermarket chain, suggested, "What's a ripe banana to me might not be a ripe banana to you." 
Christopher Bonanos, an editor at New York magazine who lives in Murray Hill and has ordered from FreshDirect several times, said he thought the service was superior to what's in supermarkets. "Just how fresh everything was stunned me," Mr. Bonanos said. "There's a loss of the experience of choosing your tomato, but it's clear that the stuff they sell hasn't been sitting around for a week. And the prices are terrific." 
Fish was the biggest surprise. It's generally on a par with what is sold in some of the city's fine fish markets and can be even better. FreshDirect's fillet of cod, for example, at $8.99 a pound, was pearly moist and silky after cooking. A lovely halibut steak was $12.49 a pound. Citarella charges $12.99.
Many of FreshDirect's customers say they are using the service because food shopping in Manhattan can be agonizing. But the question is whether discerning food shoppers will trust it.
"Does the foodie want to shop this way?" asked Joseph Gurrera, the owner of Citarella. "The business we do by telephone is minimal but thousands of customers come into our stores."
Joseph Fedele, the founder and chief executive officer of FreshDirect and a former partner at Fairway in Harlem, said shoppers could learn to rely on the quality of his merchandise and to forgo the rituals of looking, squeezing and sniffing. "Nobody really learns anything when they pick up a cantaloupe and smell it," he said. "And most of the time if they want cantaloupe they'll buy it no matter what."
Michael Coskun, an owner of the Garden of Eden stores, is not convinced. "We're dealing with a very demanding, very picky clientele, a customer who wants to see what they buy," he said. "I wish them luck."
In fact, not everything from FreshDirect was like those incomparable pears. Some of the Italian prune plums in this reporter's order were too soft, an avocado took several days to ripen, beautiful green beans had no flavor, and rather mangy bunches of grapes were overripe, falling off their stems.
Many of FreshDirect's prices for name-brand groceries are lower than in local supermarkets, but the choices, especially for nonfood items, are far fewer. On the Web site yesterday, a 15-ounce box of Cheerios was $3.79, compared with $4.49. Muir Glen organic tomatoes were $1.99 for a 28-ounce can, instead of $2.49. But a half-gallon of Organic Valley milk was $3.59, compared with $3.39 in a local deli. FreshDirect has its own bakery, but its decent-quality bread is shipped parbaked and frozen. 
Mr. D'Agostino questioned the economics of delivering food from a centralized warehouse. "We fill Internet orders but from the individual stores that deliver in the neighborhood," he said.
But what sets FreshDirect apart is that it is not just sending out boxes of merchandise pulled off supermarket shelves. Mr. Fedele said that 83 percent of FreshDirect's orders are for fresh food: produce, seafood, meat, dairy, delicatessen and prepared food from its own kitchens. Supermarkets, he said, which typically have 20 percent of their space refrigerated, are not set up to sell as much fresh food.
Even Peapod, a grocery delivery company that says it is profitable in four of its six markets, sells mostly supermarket-quality food at supermarket prices, about 50 percent of it fresh. It was acquired by Royal Ahold, a Dutch company that also owns the Giant chain in the Washington area and has a warehouse system in Chicago, its original market. In Washington, it uses the Giant warehouse. The company delivers in the Northeast through Stop & Shop, another Royal Ahold company.
Mr. Fedele has bragging rights when it comes to refrigeration. He has 12 refrigerated zones that occupy more than three-quarters of FreshDirect's 300,000-square-foot warehouse. Fish goes to one of seven refrigerated receiving docks directly from the producer, without stopping at a wholesale market. It is stored in a 29-degree room and is portioned to the customer's order by one of 65 fish cutters. It then goes into a refrigerated truck, so it is kept cold until it reaches the customer. Meat is also handled carefully. In terms of food safety, especially avoiding cross-contamination, the warehouse is state of the art. Produce is stored in several temperature zones, up to 65 degrees for bananas and tomatoes that need ripening. 
More than 1,000 men and women work in sweaters and coats from about 1 a.m. to 7 a.m., pulling orders off computers, then cutting and packing the meat, bagging the produce and putting the orders in boxes. (Some customers have complained about having to dispose of those big boxes.)
Each customer has a bar code. It's Amazon.com with lettuce and mayo, down to suggestions of other items to accompany an order. Some Roquefort with those pears?
When an order is placed, the customer selects a two-hour delivery window, starting at 4:30 p.m. Earlier deliveries are only made Saturdays and Sundays. The order has to have been placed by midnight the night before, eliminating any notion of last-minute shopping. There's a $40 minimum per order and a $3.95 delivery fee. New customers get discounts.
Mr. Fedele said he has 8,000 customers, 78 percent of whom have reordered, and is adding 500 new ones a day. The average order is about $100.
FreshDirect's Web site is user-friendly and informative, and the options for custom-tailoring are almost mind-boggling. How the meat is to be cut, what rubs or marinades to go with it, whether the whole fish is to be split or not, with or without head and tail, are just a few. It provides recipes, too. Coffee, which is roasted and ground to order and costs about $5.99 a pound, can be custom-blended. 
There are glitches. This reporter's recent order, which included Braeburn apples, was confirmed by e-mail just an hour before delivery. When it arrived at 5 p.m. there were no apples. Two chocolate chip cookies, baked on the premises, were sent instead -- small compensation to a cook who planned to whip up an apple crisp that night.
But Mr. Fedele acknowledges that the service is still being fine-tuned. FreshDirect is being rolled out gradually, starting with the parts of the city closest to its warehouses and offices. First Roosevelt Island, then Battery Park City, a neighborhood that can be easily reached from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, then other parts of Queens and then, about a month ago, Murray Hill. Two weeks ago, the service was extended to parts of Midtown, east of Fifth Avenue and as far north as 59th Street, as well as the Gramercy Park area.
Mr. Hamstra of Supermarket News said, "E-groceries will only work in a densely populated market like San Francisco or New York." 
For now, customers have praised the promptness of FreshDirect's deliveries. But it remains to be seen whether that will continue once a few more ZIP codes, on the Upper West Side, for example, or Riverdale in the Bronx, are added. Not to mention the effect of winter storms or basic New York gridlock.

GRAPHIC: Photos: COOL JOBS -- Craig Kominiak, left, works in the rare warmth of the bakery at the mostly refrigerated FreshDirect warehouse in Long Island City, Queens. Maria Vera, middle, cuts cheese to the specifications of a customer's Internet order. Ana Bermeo, below, needs gloves to prepare orders for the trucks, bottom. (Photographs by Michael Nagle for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1156 words

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
Sedona, Ariz., Takes on the Big Boys of Sculpture

BYLINE:  By Patricia Cohen

DATELINE: SEDONA, Ariz. 

 BODY:
Like a lot of artists who first encounter the sprawling vermilion-and-indigo landscape and soulful Native American carvings, Gary Allen Brown was taken with the Western aesthetic when he moved to the northern Arizona desert four and a half years ago from Chicago. "I went to a Navajo reservation" he said, studying ancient rock carvings and drawing Kokopelli, the Indian fertility symbol whose silhouette can be found in almost every hotel lobby, tchotchke shop and gas station.
 "I went through that stuff and I realized that was absolutely not me. What do I know from bear claws? I'm just a Jewish boy from the North Side of Chicago." 
 After that false start, Mr. Brown, who had come here to reinvent himself as a sculptor after 17 years in the sign business, began creating sinuous wood and metal sculptures.
That he was displaying his work for the first time at the annual Sedona Sculpture Walk in October is curiously appropriate, for the sculpture festival is also trying to reinvent itself. For 14 years the exhibition has essentially been a small, local affair aimed at wealthy tourists interested in the upscale equivalent of a T-shirt or key chain souvenir.
But last year, the new executive director of the Sedona Arts Center, Karen Ely, decided to take the festival to a new level, hoping to turn it into the nation's largest, most successful juried sculpture exhibition.
How to define success, though, isn't obvious. The art shown at the Sculpture Walk represents an enormous body of work that is made and bought by millions of people but is mostly ignored by newspapers, art magazines, critics and museum curators. Many art critics dismissively categorize much of the work as kitsch. Yet there are hundreds of these sorts of exhibitions, art fairs, festivals across the country, and they account for a sizable portion of the art that is produced and loved in the United States.
To the organizers of the Sedona Sculpture Walk, success is defined not only in quality but in dollars also. What's the take at the end of the show? Thus, transforming a local festival into a nationally known event is as much about marketing as about art.
The problem facing the organizers is like that of the first-time job seeker who needs experience to get a job, but can't get experience without a job. Without serious buyers, it's tough to get top-notch artists; and vice versa.
"We're looking for the real arts patrons," Ms. Ely said bluntly. "We want people who are going to buy."
To find moneyed art lovers, the arts council hired a marketing firm to spread the word in New York, Chicago, Boston and Los Angeles.
They also moved the festival to the new Sedona Cultural Park, a large outdoor amphitheater and grounds with a spectacular background of towering red rock buttes and mesas. The inconvenient location was a virtue: attracting art lovers who would go out of their way to see the show was more important than racking up many tourists who happened to be strolling by.
Organizers also timed the exhibition to coincide with a big draw concert: Tony Bennett.
Right away, Ms. Ely realized that they had to exhibit many more kinds of sculpture, she said: "We had a plethora of figurative bronze and cowboys and Western themes. I wanted more diversity in the style and the medium." So a call went out to artists in art magazines and sculpture periodicals, a Web site was set up, and organizers started visiting shows and galleries, seeking new artists. Ms. Ely traveled, for example, to a sculpture symposium in the aptly named Marble, Colo., famous for the milky white rock that was used in the Washington Monument and the Tomb of the Unknowns. There she signed up eight artists.
The model is Loveland, Colo., something of a mecca for bronze sculptors in particular, with two world-class bronze foundries. The annual sculpture festival there is the largest outdoor juried sculpture exhibition in the country and attracts more than 180 sculptors and 20,000 to 25,000 visitors, said Polly Juneau, the president of the board of the Loveland High Plains Art Council. Sales for the two-day show typically run over a million dollars.
Clearly, Sedona has a way to go.
The number of participants grew from 67 in 2001 to 90 this year, with 30 percent from northern Arizona, 50 percent from the four corners area where Arizona, Utah, Colorado and New Mexico meet and the rest from elsewhere. More than 3,000 visitors attended. But sales were disappointing. Ms. Ely said she had hoped the total would top $200,000. Instead, a preliminary total of $60,000 worth of sculptures were sold.
"It was nowhere near where we hoped," she conceded, blaming the recession and the doddering stock market. "That was pretty disappointing. But we also feel we got the right people there, the right buyers."
While Ms. Ely did manage to attract one ceramic artist, one neon and two glass sculptors, much more common under the taut white tents were bronze sculptures of Indians in full headdress and cowboys reeling back on horses, miniature coyotes and mammoth frogs and all manner of bronze cherubic children and maidens on a swing.
Veteran favorites like Joe Beeler, a founder of the Cowboy Artists of America -- a boys-only club that is committed to the Western tradition of Charles Russell and Frederic Remington and is considered the most prestigious organization of Western artists in the country -- shared a tent with the group's newest inductee, John Coleman. There one could see the familiar figure of Kokopelli, backpack slung over a shoulder, flute in hand, executed by Mr. Coleman with much more grace and skill than the usual fare.
What was striking amid the professionals was the number of people who turned to sculpture late in life. Joyce Killebrew, 55, was a firefighter with the Forest Service. When she was stationed in a watch tower in the early 1990's, she began taking clay with her and started sculpturing. After a Colorado forest fire on Storm King Mountain killed 14 people in 1994, Ms. Killebrew created a larger-than-life memorial of three firefighters.
Charles Taube built doors and gates before an accident in 1997 left him with only 30 percent use of his left hand and arm. Now he fashions snakelike coils of wood. Sedona is his first exhibition and though he hasn't sold anything yet, he did find a gallery interested in displaying his work. "I just sat it on the desk," he said, and the owner said, "O.K."
And then there is Andreas Schwab, who was raised in Switzerland and was an automobile mechanic here. He had tinkered with the Jaguar and the Mercedes owned by Charles Loloma, a renowned Hopi jewelry craftsman. Mr. Schwab remembers showing Mr. Loloma one of his sculptures of an Indian. "They're old Europeans in feathers," Mr. Loloma told him, urging him to study the facial features of Native Americans closely. "I've been working on it ever since," Mr. Schwab said.
The same could be said of the Sculpture Walk itself; it's a work in progress.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A sculpture by Jack Kreutzer at the Sedona Sculpture Walk in Arizona last month. It was moved to the new Sedona Cultural Park this year. (Edward Sutton for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section F; Column 5; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1403 words

HEADLINE: Out of the Kitchen, Into the Vineyard 

BYLINE:  By HUGO LINDGREN 

DATELINE: MATTITUCK, N.Y. 

 BODY:
ABOUT three years ago, David Page had a life-altering brainstorm. It happened in the basement of his restaurant Drovers Tap Room, an offshoot of Home, the West Village place he and Barbara Shinn opened in 1993 and had run ever since.
 It was summer and humid, and miserable in the basement. The air-conditioner was out; the garbage, piled nearby, was going rank. Mr. Page was talking on the phone with a man about running the little vineyard he and Ms. Shinn had just bought on Long Island, the next piece of their Home mini-empire. They were talking salary. 
 "I suddenly realized," Mr. Page said, "that I was going to pay this guy to have a better life than I had." 
So changes were made. And that's why a few weeks ago, instead of working the line in the tiny kitchen at Home or punching figures into a calculator, Mr. Page found himself contentedly driving a green John Deere tractor, hauling a load of bright yellow lugs packed with merlot grapes. Ms. Shinn, who might have been running the front of the house at Home, as she did for almost a decade, was directing a 10-member crew in meticulously handpicking grapes.
This was the first harvest for Shinn Vineyards, and besides representing a shift in lifestyle for Mr. Page and Ms. Shinn, it marked the beginning of their quest to be part of the North Fork's evolution into a major wine region.
The founders of the Long Island wine industry, Alex and Louisa Hargrave, established Hargrave Vineyard, in Cutchogue on the North Fork, in 1973. They planted 17 acres of classic European grapes -- cabernet sauvignon, pinot noir and sauvignon blanc -- in potato fields and soon went on to make commercially acceptable wine. Hargrave was followed by Lenz and Pindar, both in 1979, and Bedell, among others, in 1980.
These early producers set their sights high. Their idea was not only to create successful wines and wineries but also to lay the foundation for an entire wine region. 
Which is where Mr. Page and Ms. Shinn enter the picture. Much as they adore the dusty splendor of North Fork farm country, they did not move there to hang out and make O.K. wine, just as they did not open Home to hang out and make O.K. food.
In their view, the variations in the maritime climate and topography of Long Island can be exploited to make subtle and complex wines that can stand up to wines from almost anyplace in the world.
Mr. Page is 44 years old, and Ms. Shinn is 40. They met in Berkeley, Calif., 15 years ago; he was a cook, she was an artist and a waitress. They moved to New York together in 1990. They had little money and no prospects but a faith in traditional American cuisine that bordered on the evangelical.
They are a deeply earnest couple, like characters in a Robert Redford movie, and they arrived in New York at just the right moment. They scrounged enough cash to open Home on Cornelia Street, then a seedy lane in a city crawling out of recession, and set about educating their little part of the world in the wonders of skillet-fried chicken and homemade ketchup. Some scoffed, found it overly cute, but Home became a beloved institution, albeit a small one, with 30 seats indoors and 30 outdoors.
The economy picked up, comfort food became a fad and Mr. Page and Ms. Shinn were out ahead of it. They began to diversify, opening a takeout shop, Home Away From Home, and Drovers, a bigger, louder, cheaper version of Home. They wrote a cookbook, "Recipes From Home," bought North Fork farmland and entered negotiations to buy a motel and restaurant nearby.
And then they stopped dead in their tracks and ended the negotiations. "As excited as we'd been to get to New York, we just ended up almost losing ourselves, these crazy workaholic days," Ms. Shinn said.
"New York is like a machine," Mr. Page added. "And we became part of it without even knowing we had."
Shortly after coming to New York, they visited the North Fork, fell in love with the produce and wine and started promoting both at Home. In 1996 they were married in a sauvignon blanc block at Paumanok Vineyards in Aquebogue.
Deciding that winegrowing was their future, they sold Drovers and the takeout place, and Mr. Page's brother, Chris, moved to New York from Wisconsin to manage Home. "We needed to hold on to that," Mr. Page said. "It's our cash cow."
Their 22 acres are tucked between Long Island Sound and Route 48 in Mattituck. They sold the development rights to the town of Southold, ensuring that the land would never be built on, and used the money to plant grapes: cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc, malbec, petit verdot, semillon, two clones of sauvignon blanc and five clones of merlot.
They have planted 16,000 vines, and hope their first harvest will yield about 500 cases of wine, a tiny amount, which they plan to sell through a mailing list. Though they hope to rise to 2,000 cases within a decade, they will still be a boutique operation, the vineyard equivalent of Home. Ms. Shinn, who served a field internship at Bedell, is the vineyard manager.
This growing season had plenty of what passes for drama in the agricultural world. There was no plague of locusts, but it was a little too dry, and birds and wasps damaged some grapes. When autumn arrived and the fruit got too wet, mold became a prime concern, though not much developed.
"It's like a restaurant -- you know something is going to go wrong; you just don't know in advance what it's going to be," Ms. Shinn said. "The advantage of the vineyard is that it's mother nature -- you can't control it. You just have to relax."
Harvest work is extremely tedious, particularly when you avoid the labor-saving benefits of a picking machine, a choice Mr. Page and Ms. Shinn made: machines don't differentiate between good and bad grapes. 
At dawn, they collected their workers, mostly Guatemalans, from a parking lot in Greenport, 11 miles eastward. They gave each one clippers, and the crew worked down the rows, checking and cutting each cluster and gently laying them into the lugs. Ms. Shinn worked alongside them with her own clippers, occasionally spacing out the workers so that they talked less and picked more. Her Spanish isn't too good; neither is their English. The harvest ran from mid-September through Sunday.
Mr. Page collected the filled lugs, stacked them on a flatbed truck and hauled them to the nearby Lenz Winery, where their winemaker, Eric Fry, works. Eventually, Mr. Page hopes to be his own winemaker, but developing a palate and technical knowledge takes time. So for the foreseeable future he and Ms. Shinn will depend on Mr. Fry, who consults for a dozen vineyards.
Mr. Fry's technical ability is greatly admired on the North Fork. He has worked there for 14 years, and his wines -- red, white and sparkling -- have been quite successful. He is 50 years old, wears a shaggy beard and long hair and is often seen in overalls and shredded Champion sweatshirts. His lack of pretense is so complete that it is practically a pretense. It is on his faith in Long Island that Mr. Page and Ms. Shinn base their own.
"I have a bias against everything Californian," Mr. Fry said with a provocative air. "Those big, clumsy, awkward wines with too many tannins and too much alcohol, I don't care for them. What we're able to do here with our cooler climate is make a subtler wine, with less alcohol and more fruit expression. It's better."
When Mr. Page brought one morning's worth of merlot over to Lenz, the grapes were dumped into a destemmer, which mashed them. The mixture -- juice, skins and seeds -- was pumped into a stainless-steel tank, where yeast was added and the journey toward wine began. After fermentation, it would be transferred to barrels, where it would spend months and maybe years, monitored by Mr. Fry. 
If all goes well, Shinn Vineyards' first vintage should be ready for consumption in late 2004 -- about five years since that epiphany in the Drovers basement.
After his trip to Lenz, Mr. Page loaded the lugs on the flatbed and drove back to his farm. He talked about the mini-empire he had owned in the city and why he didn't miss it.
"What I remember from opening night at Drovers was how many people came up to me and asked what I was going to do next," he said. "It was as if we were at a party to mark the closing, not the opening. I didn't know what to say. But now if anyone ever asks me that question ever again, I can point to the vineyard and say, This is it, nothing comes next."

GRAPHIC: Photos: TIME TO INHALE -- David Page's Long Island grapes are becoming wine. (Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times)(pg. F1); FIRST HARVEST -- David Page and Barbara Shinn hope for a 500-case yield from their North Fork vineyard -- a boutique operation like their restaurant, Home. (Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times)(pg. F9)

HEADLINE: U.S. Port Security Plan Irks Europeans 

BYLINE:  By GREGORY CROUCH 

DATELINE: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Tom Ridge, the United States homeland security director, arrived here today, hoping to shore up support for a program intended to fight terrorism. Instead, he wrestled with disclosures that the European Union was considering disciplining member countries that are taking part in the American program, fearing that it could create havoc in the shipping industry.
 The European Union is concerned about two-country agreements that the Bush administration has reached with eight nations in Europe and Asia, allowing United States Customs officers to select cargo containers for the inspection of hazardous material before they are shipped to the United States. 
 Some of the program's elements, the Europeans fear, could put exporters at a disadvantage and increase congestion and shipping costs on the Continent, according to correspondence between European Union and United States officials. 
Mr. Ridge said the container security initiative by the customs service was intended to prevent terrorists from smuggling a destructive weapon in one of the six million sea containers shipped into the United States each year. He said he was working to resolve some of the issues raised by the European officials.
The European Union is considering the possibility of beginning infringement procedures against countries that have signed on to the initiative, including the Netherlands, Germany, Belgium and France, according to Mr. Ridge and union officials. 
"We regret this action because these are our friends and allies," Mr. Ridge said. 
Some European Union diplomats are described as annoyed that the Bush administration chose to approach individual countries to take part in the antiterrorism program instead of making it a Europe-wide effort.
"Customs policy in Europe," Jonathan Todd, a union spokesman, said, "is coordinated by the European Commission."
Mr. Ridge said the Bush administration negotiated agreements with individual countries because this was more expedient. He recalled a conversation with Clifford M. Sobel, the United States ambassador to the Netherlands.
"I've got the port, I've got the government, give me a day or two and we'll make it happen," Mr. Ridge quoted Mr. Sobel as having said, adding that it took a bit longer than that to reach an agreement with Dutch officials.
The Bush administration says the container initiative is a top priority because a nuclear or chemical attack originating in a cargo container could paralyze global shipping, possibly even crippling the world economy for a time.
"This is an issue of national security," a United States Customs spokesman, Dennis Murphy, said. "Our objective is to get this done as quickly as we possibly can. We don't have the luxury of time here."
Rotterdam is the first city to play host to United States Customs officers. Four are currently working alongside Dutch inspectors, developing risk profiles and screening procedures to turn up possible shipments of radioactive substances, biological agents or chemical weapons. 
The inspectors sometimes use a large X-ray device to examine the interior of a container without having to open it. Since the customs officers arrived in September, Mr. Ridge acknowledged, they had yet to find anything.
European Union officials are concerned that the program's incentives favor those ports that sign the agreements and penalize those that either refuse or are too small to take part. For instance, once a cargo container has cleared United States and Dutch inspections in Rotterdam, it is more than likely to have a quicker ride through customs in the United States. But cargo leaving a French port like Marseille, which is not a party to such agreements, can expect to face potential delays when it reaches American shores.
A result, some European officials say, is that companies shipping goods to the United States will start rerouting their cargo to ports like Rotterdam, depriving others of business and potentially creating bottlenecks in some shipping regions.
Customs officials indicated that another European country had agreed in principle to sign the initiative. An announcement could come as early as this week.
A Dutch customs official said his country realized that the United States agreement was not just a way to prevent terrorist attacks. "It's good for business," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United States homeland security chief, Tom Ridge, left, discussing cooperation in Rotterdam yesterday with a city official, Wim van Sluis. (Associated Press) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: California Pours on the Yield To Draw Investors to Its Bonds 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The difficult part of the biggest municipal bond sale ever finished without a hitch yesterday as the State of California offered investors very high yields on the new bonds.
 The $6.3 billion in California municipal bonds, which is part of a $11.3 billion issue, will pay interest rates on its highest-rated triple A bonds that are as much as a quarter of a percentage point higher than an index of comparable triple A municipal bonds. 
 William M. Fitzgerald, head of fixed-income investing at Nuveen Investments in Chicago, said J. P. Morgan, the lead underwriter, "came out with some higher yields to make sure the deal was going to get on the radar screen."
When asked if the high yields were a lot for California to pay, he said, "Yes, that is a lot. But that is the reason we found it attractive." Nuveen ordered several hundred million dollars of the California bonds. 
Mr. Fitzgerald said that California had to offer a nice premium to buyers because of the difficulty of attracting enough capital to such an enormous bond sale. In addition, he said a higher yield was necessary to overcome investor distaste for the complex structure of the bonds.
The new municipal bonds, issued by the California Department of Water Resources, are needed to pay for electricity bought during the energy crisis of 2000-2001. At the time, the money to pay for the electricity was borrowed from the state's general fund.
The sale of the $6.3 billion part of the bond issue began on Friday with orders from brokerage firms that want to sell the bonds to individual investors, who are likely to be interested in the high tax-exempt yields. The 4.57 percent yield on the uninsured 10-year note in the issue is half a percentage point higher than the taxable 4.07 percent yield on the Treasury's 10-year note. The after-tax yield for an investor in the 30 percent tax bracket is 6.53 percent.
The retail orders totaled $1.5 billion, $775 million for the insured bonds that are rated triple A and $750 million for the bonds that have lower investment grade ratings of A3 from Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ from Standard & Poor's.
Last week, California sold $4.25 billion in floating rate municipal bonds and on Thursday the state will sell the last part of the issue, $715 million in taxable municipal bonds.
Yesterday, J. P. Morgan sweetened the deal a little to attract enough institutional investors to complete the sale of insured and uninsured bonds. So, for example, the 5.14 percent yield on the bond maturing in 2018 offered in the retail sale was raised to 5.21 percent for institutions. Because the demand was so high, that yield was lowered to 5.20 percent in the final pricing.
"The difference between last Friday's yield and today's reflected overall market conditions declining" as interest rates moved higher, said Peter J. Hill, head of public finance at J. P. Morgan. He said that retail investors will get the higher yields set yesterday.
The fees for the underwriters will be $55 million to $60 million.
The interest and principal on the California bonds will be covered by a monthly surcharge on customers of the state's investor-owned utilities. One risk is that there are several lawsuits challenging how the surcharge will be set.
In the Treasury market yesterday, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 4.07 percent, from 4.04 percent Monday, as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 6/32 to 102 15/32. The downturn in the bond market came as stocks rose and investors awaited a widely expected interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve today. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: News Corp. and Its Fox Units Have Solid Quarterly Results 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
The News Corporation reported strong quarterly results yesterday, propelled by torrid growth at the company's cable and broadcast television operations.
 Results at both the News Corporation and its separately traded Fox Entertainment subsidiary, which includes most of the company's United States operations, surpassed analysts' expectations as the companies' television units profited from trends including a modest rebound in the advertising market. 
 The results of all media companies, including the News Corporation, were hurt in the period a year earlier because of the effect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. That weakness is helping make the latest batch of quarterly results from many media companies appear especially strong. 
The weakness, however, did not obscure the strong performance at each of the company's three main United States television operations: the Fox network, its local broadcast stations and its pay-television channels, which are distributed by cable television and satellite systems.
This summer, the company's Fox broadcast network reversed its ratings slide of recent years with its hit program "American Idol." While the network is still unprofitable, the unit's operating loss narrowed to $8 million in the company's first financial quarter, ended Sept. 30, from $43 million during the quarter a year earlier. The network's revenue increased by 32.5 percent, to $424 million from $320 million in the same interval.
Earlier this year, the News Corporation's Fox News pay-television channel surpassed AOL Time Warner's CNN in the ratings. Led by Fox News, the company's pay-television channels continued to add subscribers even as the company charged cable and satellite operators higher monthly rates for the use of its networks.
Those two trends combined to generate 27.6 percent revenue growth at Fox Entertainment's pay-television operation, to $523 million from $410 million. The unit swung to an operating profit of $83 million in the latest quarter compared with a $16 million operating loss in the period a year earlier.
As the company acquires more local broadcast stations, it is able to consolidate them into local "duopolies" and cut costs. Combined with a resurgence in the advertising market, that strategy pushed operating income at Fox Entertainment's local station group to $209 million, more than double the $78 million figure in the period a year earlier.
"We're extremely pleased with the performance of both the television network and the local stations in the quarter," Peter Chernin, president of both the News Corporation and Fox Entertainment, said through a spokesman yesterday. Mr. Chernin is largely responsible for the companies' day-to-day television operations.
"They both benefited from a stronger advertising environment as well as stronger programming on the network and the benefits of our duopoly strategy in local markets," he said.
Most of the News Corporation's other units did not fare as well as its United States television operations.
The company's filmed entertainment sector, which includes the Fox film studio, reported operating income of $100 million, down from $122 million in the period a year earlier. In the year-earlier quarter, the company released the blockbuster film "Planet of the Apes" and had no comparable hit in the latest quarter.
Operating income declined at the company's newspaper operation, largely because of a price war in Britain.
"The first-quarter results resoundingly confirm the strength of our company," Rupert Murdoch, chairman of both the News Corporation and Fox Entertainment, said in a statement yesterday.
"It is this strategy that saw us through the difficult economic times of the past two years and that now positions us for robust and sustained growth going forward," he added.
For the company as a whole, the News Corporation reported that revenue increased 11.8 percent, to $3.8 billion from $3.4 billion in the period a year earlier. Earnings soared to $162 million, or 12 cents an American depository receipt, from $73 million, or 6 cents an A.D.R., in the quarter a year earlier.
Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had predicted earnings of 10 cents a share.
The News Corporation announced its results after the close of the markets in New York. During regular trading, the company's American depository receipts rose 5 cents, to $25.65. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Investors Return to the Office Building Market

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Investors are pouring more money into commercial real estate this year. But, in an unusual economic environment largely created by the confluence of low interest rates and poor fundamentals, they are concentrating their spending on a narrow universe of well-located office buildings with stable leases. 
 A collective tunnel vision has divided the country into two real estate markets. One market, concentrated mostly in Manhattan and Washington, has high demand for buildings with existing leases that will keep them occupied no matter what happens to the economy over the next few years. The other is characterized by paltry demand for buildings where the leasing market has been deteriorating. 
 The goal is to buy a steady, though not necessarily particularly lucrative, stream of income, according to investors, brokers, money managers, lawyers and analysts who specialize in commercial real estate transactions. 
The trend is evident in a comparison of the changes in the median price per square foot for office buildings nationwide, which has risen only about 2 percent the last year, and the average price per square foot, which has risen about 9 percent, according to data from real estate research firms and interviews with specialists. Sales of prime properties like 399 Park Avenue in Manhattan, which was sold for $1.06 billion this year, skew the average number higher but leave the median largely unaffected.
"Leased buildings are going for higher prices, unleased buildings are almost illiquid," said Steven A. Means, a principal of Means Knaus, an office building investor and developer that is based in Dallas and operates nationally. What buyers want, he said, is a "building leased for an amount of time that people perceive will take them through the dip."
When the change in office building prices is measured by median price per square foot it is evident that "estimates of cash flow are lower, therefore pricing hasn't jumped up as much," said Robert M. White, the president of Real Capital Analytics, a consulting and research firm based in Manhattan that tracks and tries to identify the buyers of properties worth $5 million or more.
The median price per square foot has risen to $154.50 in the nine months ending in September for the 768 building sales tracked by Real Capital Analytics from $151.61 for the 939 buildings tracked in the comparable period a year earlier, an increase of 1.9 percent. When measured on an average price per square foot basis, however, the difference is much greater. The average price per square foot in central business districts rose to $206 in the nine months ending in September from $188 in the comparable period the year before, an increase of 9.5 percent. A similar increase occurred in the suburbs, where the average price per square foot rose to $143 from $132, an increase of 8.3 percent. The building on Park Avenue sold for $630 a square foot, a number that greatly altered the average because the building has 1.25 million square feet of office space.
"It's only for well-located, well-leased, institutional quality properties," said Richard T. Leider, a private developer in the Pacific Northwest. "But for those properties that meet the criteria, there's a lot of demand."
One Boston Place is a fitting example of investors' willingness to pay escalating prices for stable leases. When the Blackstone Group of New York and Walton Street Capital of Chicago bought the 770,000-square-foot office tower in Boston for $184 million in September 2000, 13 percent of the space was vacant, and asking annual rental rates were $60 to $80 a square foot. TIAA-CREF, the large pension system, agreed to buy the building in August for $267 million, an $83 million profit for the previous owners, at a time when 19,250 more square feet had been leased and the building was only 10.4 percent vacant. The sale went through even though rental rates had fallen to $40 to $55 a square foot, dampening the buyer's rate of return.
Private partnerships and local investors have been the most aggressive buyers, according to Real Capital Analytics.
Among real estate investment trusts, SL Green Realty, which concentrates nearly all its investment around Grand Central Station, Penn Station and Times Square, one of the most robust leasing markets in the country, has spent the second most amount on acquisitions. It has bought $483 million of office property so far this year, compared with $339.6 million in all 2001. Only Boston Properties, the buyer of 399 Park Avenue, has spent more, a total of $1.2 billion.
The income that office buildings in general generate has steadily declined in the same period. Nationally, office vacancy rates have risen to 17.2 percent, including sublease space, from 15 percent in January and 9.2 percent in January 2001, according to research by Merrill Lynch. That has pushed average annual asking rents down to $32.18 a square foot, from $33.67 six months ago and $35.65 a year before that.
The firm expects vacancy rates to rise to 17.9 percent by the end of the year and expects rental rates to decline another 5 to 10 percent over the next year and a half.
Investors are clearly eager to get into the office building market, keeping prices stable and rising in those few places with solid leasing fundamentals, like Midtown Manhattan, where opportunities to buy buildings come about infrequently and much of the recent construction has been built for big, solid tenants like Bear, Stearns and Conde Nast, and Washington, where the expanding federal government soaks up more space. Analysts and brokerage firms said there had also been demand for certain buildings in Boston, Miami, San Diego and Philadelphia.
"What's not clear is what's going on elsewhere," said Leonard G. Sahling, a real estate analyst for Merrill Lynch, noting that there have been too few transactions in other markets to make investors' intentions evident (unless the lack of transactions does, in itself, make investors' intentions evident).
Timothy J. Welch, executive managing director of the commercial real estate services concern Cushman & Wakefield, said a market for less well-leased properties was beginning to form as buyers and sellers were coming to accept that the doldrums in the leasing market were lingering and pervasive.
"You can get sellers to sell at prices below what they were holding out for," Mr. Welch said. "Buyers, on the other hand, there's simply more of them."
One reason for the increased investment in office buildings over all is the decline of stock prices. But the primary impetus is low interest rates. What is lost in future income, the theory goes, can be made up in low borrowing costs.
"Because it is a tangible asset, unlike dot-coms, people have more comfort," said Jeffrey A. Moerdler, a real estate lawyer in New York with the firm Mintz, Levin, Cohn, Ferris & Popeo. "People are bidding up the purchase prices by being willing to take a lower rate of return."
Lack of supply has also driven prices higher for certain buildings, analysts said.
"While there's been greater investor demand, there haven't been a lot of properties out there to buy," said Mr. White of Real Capital Analytics. "The prices finally got interesting to sellers, and they're rushing to get office buildings out there."
There were only $15.8 billion worth of office buildings on the market in the first half of this year, compared with $19.1 billion in the period in 2001. In the third quarter of this year, though, $11.6 billion in new offerings emerged.
Patrick J. Corcoran, an analyst who covers commercial mortgage-backed securities and real estate loan and credit issuers for J. P. Morgan Chase, views the escalating prices of certain office buildings as a reward to property owners and developers for suffering the caution of their lenders for the past decade. "Pessimism always rewards you," he said. "The market can look and see that the only problem we've got is a recession, and that is a problem we can fix."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One Boston Place is an example of investors' willingness to pay escalating prices for stable leases. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times) Chart: "For Top Buildings, Top Dollar"While the median price per square foot for office buildings nationwide has been rising slowly, the average price has increased much more significantly. This reflects strong demand for particularly desirable properties. Graph compares average price for office space and median price for office space per square foot from September 2000 to September 2002. (Source: Real Capital Analytics)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

PERSON: BRICK, MICHAEL

HEADLINE: North Korea Says It May Restart Missile Tests After Talks Fail 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
North Korea warned today that unless relations with Japan are quickly normalized it would resume its testing of ballistic missiles. 
 The thinly veiled threat was issued by an unidentified Foreign Ministry spokesman less than a week after the first high-level talks between the countries in two years, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, ended in an angry stalemate. 
 The statement today said the "relevant organs" would "reconsider the moratorium on the missile test-fire in case the talks on normalizing the relations between North Korea and Japan get prolonged without making any progress, as was the case with the recent talks." 
North Korea shocked this country in 1998 with a surprise test of a Taepodong intercontinental ballistic missile, which over flew Japan. North Korea said the test was a satellite launching and has refrained from testing for several years. It reaffirmed a self-imposed moratorium on missile testing six weeks ago in a meeting between North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan. 
Mr. Koizumi, who is attending a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, today dismissed the warning, saying it did not figure in any government-to-government communication, and expressed confidence that Japan's diplomatic engagement with the North would bear fruit. "I believe North Korea will not do anything to trample the spirit of the Pyongyang declaration," he said. 
During Mr. Koizumi's one-day meeting with Mr. Kim, the North Korean leader pledged not only to continue to observe its missile test moratorium, but also to abide by all international obligations regarding nuclear weapons. 
The meeting seemed to put the countries on a fast track toward establishing diplomatic relations. Since the demise of the Soviet bloc, North Korea has suffered famines and increasingly severe economic hardships. In preparatory negotiations, Japan offered large financial incentives to the North to change its repressive, militaristic behavior, promising a major aid package in case of normalized relations. 
Since the Sept. 17 meeting, the United States announced that North Korea had acknowledged the existence of a uranium-based nuclear weapons development program, which the United States says violates international commitments made by the North in 1994. 
The principal issue separating Japan and North Korea had been North Korea's kidnapping of 13 Japanese citizens, beginning in the late 1970's, for use as language trainers in a spy program. Washington's insistence that North Korea eliminate its secret weapons program before receiving Japanese economic assistance has revived tensions. 
The five survivors among the 13 kidnapped Japanese, who are now visiting Japan for the first time in a quarter century, have become a political and emotional football. 
Following the stalemated talks with Japan, North Korea has resumed calls to the United States to normalize relations, saying it will surrender its nuclear program if the United States will guarantee the North's security. 
Even as it sends out feelers like these, however, North Korea's official media continue to issue belligerent statements. 
Washington's position means that if North Korea "puts down arms, it will receive sugar," the Workers' Party daily said in an editorial, adding, "This is an unbearable insult." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Cablevision Speeds Up Access To Digital-Television Service 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Cablevision Systems, the nation's No. 7 cable provider, announced yesterday that it had significantly accelerated its deployment of digital-television service and that a New York City investment firm had agreed to invest $75 million in the company.
 While Cablevision has been one of the industry's leaders in introducing high-speed cable modem access in recent years, the company has been a laggard in introducing digital service, which can provide additional channels, superior sound quality and on-demand video services. 
 Of the 4.3 million homes the company can serve, barely 1.5 million had access to digital television before last month. Cablevision announced yesterday that it extended its digital capability to 750,000 additional homes last month and plans to offer the service to close to 1 million more homes this month. By the end of November, it plans to offer digital television to about 3.3 million homes in its service area, in and around New York. 
Apparently, that sort of growth attracted the Quadrangle Group.
Cablevision announced that Quadrangle, a private investment firm, had agreed to make its investment in the company in exchange for preferred stock. People close to the deal said that the interest rate associated with those securities had not been determined and that the investment would give Quadrangle the equivalent of less than 2 percent of the company's equity.
Steven Rattner, who was a reporter for The New York Times in the early 1980's before becoming an investment banker, is now one of Quadrangle's managing principals. He is to join Cablevision's board.
"We think the market has grievously undervalued the cable industry in general and Cablevision in particular," Mr. Rattner said in an interview yesterday. "We think Cablevision has great assets and that the market has not realized that." The stock, which traded as high as $76 early last year, closed yesterday at $12.99.
In what appears to be a coincidence, Quadrangle last year tentatively agreed to invest in the new YES cable network, which carries Yankees games, before pulling out of that deal at the last minute. Now, Cablevision is the only cable provider in the New York area that is not carrying YES.

HEADLINE: Sharon Calls for Israeli Elections Within Next 90 Days 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon announced today that Israel would hold elections early next year, eight months ahead of schedule, as he reluctantly invited an intense political contest that Israeli officials said was likely to freeze any diplomacy on the Palestinian conflict for now. 
 "Everything -- everything -- is now on hold until after the election," a senior Israeli official said. That would include the "road map" for achieving peace and a Palestinian state in 2005 that President Bush recently submitted to Mr. Sharon and the Palestinian leadership. 
 Mr. Sharon's announcement resounded like a starter's pistol, sending adversaries sprinting to microphones and television cameras. Israel's politics, relatively stable through 19 months of unity government, convulsed in a campaign over the country's security and limping economy -- all against the backdrop of a possible attack by the United States on Iraq. 
Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Sharon's chief right-wing rival in the forthcoming elections, who earlier said he was accepting a previous offer to become Mr. Sharon's new foreign minister, criticized Mr. Sharon's stewardship of the economy but refrained from a direct attack on his security policies. 
The leader of the Labor Party, Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, continued to make an issue of the expansion of settlements at the expense of the poor, the reason he gave for leading Labor out of the government last week. "There will be no peace without taking down settlements," said Mr. Ben-Eliezer, the defense minister in the unity government. 
Trying to position himself at the center of Israel's politics, Mr. Sharon criticized rivals to the right and the left as irresponsible or self-interested, forcing him to choose elections as the "least bad option."
Mr. Sharon gave up his attempt to form a majority government five days after the left-of-center Labor Party bolted from his coalition. He accused his potential right-wing allies of making demands to harden policy toward the Palestinians that would have jeopardized Israel's relationship with the United States.
Mr. Sharon also repeated criticism that Labor broke the coalition out of political ambition. Mr. Ben-Eliezer is in a tough three-way race to hold on to his leadership of the party, in a primary set for Nov. 19.
Last week, while trying to tighten his depleted coalition, Mr. Sharon offered the Foreign Ministry to Mr. Netanyahu to shore up his right-wing support and to blunt Mr. Netanyahu's political threat by turning him into a subordinate. 
But Mr. Netanyahu volleyed the political dilemma back at the prime minister by conditioning his acceptance on Mr. Sharon's calling early elections -- accepting the post, in other words, on condition that Mr. Sharon put his own job at risk, and saving the government while ensuring its demise. 
Today, Mr. Netanyahu said his condition had been met. 
From the high-profile platform the prime minister has now given him, Mr. Netanyahu will fight Mr. Sharon for leadership of their party, the Likud. Mr. Netanyahu supports exiling Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and he opposes creating a Palestinian state.
Mr. Sharon has endorsed the eventual creation of a Palestinian state, and while in favor of exiling Mr. Arafat he has said he is constrained from doing so partly by a promise to Mr. Bush not to harm the Palestinian leader.
Before Mr. Netanyahu formally accepted the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Sharon drew an implicit contrast between his rival and Shaul Mofaz, a former chief of staff who has agreed to serve as defense minister. "He rallied to the flag without preconditions," Mr. Sharon said of Mr. Mofaz. 
Under Israel's parliamentary system, each voter selects a party, not a candidate, in casting a ballot. Seats in the Parliament are then awarded to each party based on their proportion of the national vote. After the election, Israel's president, Moshe Katsav, will select one member of the Parliament -- most likely the leader of the party with the most seats -- to form a new government and serve as prime minister. 
As coalitions have formed and shattered, Israel has had five prime ministers in the last seven years. The first, Yitzhak Rabin, of Labor, was assassinated, shot in 1995 by a Jewish extremist opposed to his efforts to reach peace with the Palestinians. Mr. Ben-Eliezer echoed a campaign theme of Mr. Rabin's from 10 years ago when he said today that it was time for "a change in priorities."
One potential problem for Mr. Ben-Eliezer is that, as Mr. Sharon's defense minister for 19 months, he was a partner in expanding settlements as well as a supporter of Mr. Sharon's other priorities. Israel's left has been all but moribund since February 2001, when Mr. Sharon soundly defeated Ehud Barak, the former Labor prime minister, after Mr. Barak tried and failed to make peace with Mr. Arafat.
Mr. Ben-Eliezer dwelled today on the state of Israel's economy, which is emerging as the foremost issue in the campaign. Buffeted by the worldwide technology collapse and a devastating loss of tourism dollars because of the conflict, Israel is suffering an economic contraction and an unemployment rate above 10 percent.
On Sunday the government issued a report that nearly one in five Israelis and more than one in four Israeli children were living in poverty. The poverty line was set at a monthly income of $934 for a couple with two children.
Mr. Ben-Eliezer's competitors for the Labor post are Haim Ramon, a seasoned politician, and Amram Mitza, the mayor of Haifa and a former general. Both have staked out positions to Mr. Ben-Eliezer's left.
Mr. Sharon is popular nationally, but Mr. Netanyahu, who speaks American-accented English and has cultivated a slashing debate style, has made himself a formidable challenger on the right. 
Mr. Netanyahu was careful to declare today that he did not want "to say anything bad" about the prime minister. But he perhaps did so by implication when he talked about his own plans to run for prime minister, saying, "I intend to form a government of solutions."
Mr. Netanyahu also stressed the state of the economy. "The country is facing imminent economic collapse," he said.
The date for the Likud primary has not been set. But by late December each party must submit to the Parliament its list of those it wants to occupy any seats it wins in the elections, ranked according to the party's preference. The primary must take place before then to establish the rankings. Mr. Sharon and Mr. Netanyahu are competing for the first ranking on the list.
By law, the elections must take place within 90 days. They are expected in late January or early February.
Labor's departure deprived Mr. Sharon of 25 seats in Parliament, leaving him with a minority of 55 seats and vulnerable to a majority vote of no confidence.
Mr. Sharon survived three votes of no confidence, but he faced a future of perpetual dickering in the Parliament to erect other temporary bulwarks against such threats, including a new no-confidence motion filed by Labor over the poverty report. 
Mr. Sharon had tried to turn his new coalition into a slender majority of 62 seats by bringing in the seven seats of the National Union--Israel Beiteinu faction led by a radical nationalist, Avigdor Lieberman. But that effort failed. Mr. Sharon referred bitterly today to a speech on Sunday by Mr. Lieberman in which he said no new unity government should be formed after the elections.
"I will not surrender to political blackmail from any party," Mr. Sharon said, alluding to a "long list of demands" from Mr. Lieberman.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel yesterday called for elections within 90 days after the Labor Party withdrew from his unity coalition. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Embattled S.E.C. Chairman Resigns Under Pressure
Harvey L. Pitt, the embattled chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission who has been under fire for a number of missteps, resigned last evening, a spokeswoman for the agency said. The timing of Mr. Pitt's resignation, tendered just as politicians and Americans from coast to coast were following election results, seemed likely to be viewed as no coincidence.
 Mr. Pitt had come under heavy fire for not informing S.E.C. commissioners and the White House that the new chairman of an accounting oversight board, William H. Webster, had headed the audit committee of a company facing accusations of fraud. Page A1.

Profit Drops 32% at HealthSouth
The HealthSouth Corporation said that unfavorable publicity and lower Medicare payments for physical therapy services led to a 32 percent drop in third-quarter profit, to $53.6 million, or 13 cents a share, from $79.1 million, or 20 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $1.09 billion, an increase of 1.7 percent, from $1.07 billion a year ago. C4.

As part of an inquiry into hospital mergers, federal regulators are seeking information about the 1999 merger of two Missouri hospitals owned by Tenet Healthcare. C4.

Market Rises Ahead of Elections
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 106.67 points at 8,678.27. The Nasdaq rose 4.63 points to 1,401.17. The Standard & Poor's index advanced 7.04 points at 915.39. C8.

About $6.3 billion in California municipal bonds, which was part of a $11.3 billion issue, will pay interest rates on the highest-rated triple A bonds that are as much as a quarter of a percentage point above an index of comparable triple A municipal bonds. C8.

The Institute for Supply Management said its index of nonmanufacturing activity fell to 53.1 in October, from 53.9 in September. C2.

European Airlines Turn Profit
Having cut costs, pared back schedules and laid off many employees, some of Europe's largest airlines are starting to post fatter-than-expected profits, even as air travel remains weak. World Business, Section W.

United Airlines reached an agreement with a German bank to restructure $500 million in debt that had been due within weeks. C12

Cablevision Speeds Digital Service
Cablevision said that it had significantly accelerated its deployment of digital-television service and that the Quadrangle Group had agreed to invest $75 million. C5.

Good Quarter at News Corporation
Results at the News Corporation and its separately traded Fox Entertainment subsidiary, which includes most of the company's United States operations, surpassed expectations as the companies' television units profited from trends including a modest rebound in advertising. Peter Chernin, above, president of both the News Corporation and Fox Entertainment, said the companies had benefited from stronger advertising. C8.

Tyco Said to Reconsider 2 Directors
Tyco's board is considering whether to renominate two directors who had planned to step down after fraud charges were brought against the company's two former executives, people involved in discussion said. C2.

Editor in Chief Quits TV Guide
The editor in chief of TV Guide, Steven Reddicliffe, has resigned. He had been editor of the guide for seven and a half years. C3.

Odd Embrace of Songs and TV Ads
Songs with lyrics that once shocked or rocked have now become the perfect accompaniment to TV commercials. Advertising. C3.

Investors Return to Office Market
Investors are pouring more money into commercial real estate this year. But they are concentrating their spending on a narrow universe of well-located office buildings with stable leases. Commercial Real Estate. C6.
