HEADLINE: A Low-Cost Model Is a Big Headache for Ford 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
The Ford Focus might be the most error-prone car in the industry.
 The low-cost car, which was introduced in 1999, has had a total of 11 safety recalls and is the subject of five defect investigations by federal regulators. And two new recalls this week, including a wiring problem that could, in worst-case situations, cause engine fires, raise even more questions. 
 The five pending investigations into the Focus account for at least 7 percent of the entire defect investigation caseload of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, according to official documents. The two most serious investigations involve a suspension problem that causes a loss of steering control and a problem with the fuel tank that leads to stalling. 
Officials at the Ford Motor Company say the two latest recalls, which they initiated, will address some of the problems, including the suspension defect. Company executives have acknowledged that the Focus has had problems since it was brought over from Europe in 1999, but they say newer versions of the car are much improved. 
"It didn't do as well as it should have when it came over from Europe, but we concentrated a lot of resources into improving the quality and reliability," said Todd Nissen, a Ford spokesman. The number of warranty repairs has fallen 40 percent since the car came to the United States, Mr. Nissen added, and one Ford measure says defects are down 35 percent. To reassure new customers, Ford has started offering five-year, 100,000-mile power-train warranties for 2003 models. (The standard bumper-to-bumper warranty is three years, 36,000 miles.)
"Early on it had problems," Mr. Nissen said. "We are still dealing with those problems. These recalls affected the first two model years, but we've improved since then."
Clarence Ditlow, the director of the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer advocacy group, said Focus was the second-most recalled automobile in the industry's history, after the General Motors X-Car in the 1980's, though Ford officials questioned his calculation. The traffic safety agency does not compile recall data that way.
Mr. Ditlow also believes Focus could potentially be vulnerable to aggressive "lemon laws" in Arkansas, Kansas and Ohio. 
"When you have a car that has so many safety recalls that it might fall within lemon laws, you have a seriously defective vehicle," he said. "It is one of the worst launches of all time."
Problems for the Focus add to Ford's troubles, from plummeting market share to the ravaging effects of a price war, a sinking stock price and lowered credit ratings. It is also trying cut billions of dollars in annual costs while restocking its product lineup and mending its battered reputation on the quality front.
Focus, the 11th-best-selling automobile in the nation last month, is a cornerstone of Ford's product line. William Clay Ford, Jr., the chief executive and Ford family scion, made a personal pitch for Focus in one of his recent TV spots, comparing it to none other than the venerable Model T.
The company pitches Focus as a first purchase for young people, but for some young buyers it has not made a good impression.
Two years ago, Scott Robinson, a 30-year-old intern at an architectural firm in Hawaii, bought a green 2001 Focus ZX3. It was his first new car. 
"I knew it was out in Europe and got really good reviews," he recalled. "I test-drove it and it handled real nice and drove real nice and it seemed like a real nice car. But it turned out to be the car from hell."
His Focus is due back in the shop this week; his visits are so commonplace he is on a first name basis with his dealer. First, there was "the classic brake problem, squealing."
"Then there was the stalling problem," he said. "It stalled twice on the highway. Then I was having problems with the fuel economy. I was only getting 175 miles a tank as opposed to 250 or 300."
He continued. 
"My front disc brakes, my first set wore out in 12,000 miles and now I'm going on my second set and I only have 24,000 miles on my car. Then my front rotors warped; I had to get those changed. And the suspension is making weird noise. But that's the second time I've been in for that."
After all that, Mr. Robinson said that when the car worked "it's a really fun car to drive." 
Indeed, many customers and reviewers praise Focus for ride and handling beyond its starting price of less than $13,000.
"This is one of only a few economy cars we look forward to driving," wrote Csaba Csere, the editor of Car and Driver magazine, in a review that named Focus one of the 10 best cars in the industry. 
For Ford dealers, plenty of problems with Focus mean extra profits from repairs, with Ford paying the bill for recalls and warranty work. But that hardly means they are content. 
"Going back to Firestone, the dealers made money on the recalls," said Jerry Reynolds, owner of Ford dealerships in Texas and Oklahoma and former chairman of the Ford National Dealer Council. He was referring to the safety problems involving Ford Explorers and Firestone tires.
"But also, that's not the way you want to make your money," he added. "You lose customers over it, and you have to do a lot more selling when customers come in to convince them these cars are good cars."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alfonso Floyd checked Focus window seals at a plant in Wayne, Mich., earlier this year. The Focus has had quality problems. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: War and Politics 

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
The perception that Washington remains hostile toward Islam is helping drive the victories of some religiously oriented parties across the Islamic and Arab world, experts in the region said today.
 Most Islamist parties have been gradually gaining supporters for years as secular parties have failed to solve grinding economic and social problems. 
 But their sudden gain in votes in recent elections in Pakistan, Bahrain, Morocco and Turkey is being viewed as a sign that voters -- at least in those few countries that actually allow free elections -- want to assert pride in their faith to the outside world.
"The population in Turkey, the population in Pakistan or the population in Morocco did not vote for Islamic parties just because they believe they have the capacity to solve social and economic problems," Muhammad Darif, a professor of political science at the Hassan II University law school at Mohammedia, Morocco, said in a telephone interview. 
"Arab and Muslim populations think the war against terrorism is nothing but a war against Islam, the culture of Islam, the Arab culture," Professor Darif added. "The Islamist parties have been able to exploit this."
The recent election results may serve as an opportunity or a risk for the United States, the experts said. They said working with moderate Islamic groups could give Washington credibility it lacks, while opposing them would only fertilize already blooming anti-American sentiment.
"If the U.S. considers anyone who talks about Islam a criminal and pushes the Turkish military to suppress them, it will deprive itself of an ally," said Abdelmonem Said, the director of Al Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies in Cairo, speaking of the victorious Justice and Development Party in Turkey.
Although no single pattern fits all four countries, the results in each of the elections gave religiously oriented parties far larger margins than expected. 
In Turkey, the winning party is likely to be the first in years to be able to govern without a coalition partner, as it is expected to take more than 360 of the 550 seats in Parliament.
Voters in Pakistan and Bahrain last month also gave religious parties a significant voice in their Parliaments. Islamist candidates took 78 of 392 seats in Pakistan's Parliament, while such parties control about half of the 40 seats in the newly elected assembly in Bahrain.
In Morocco, Islamist groups took 42 of 325 seats in elections in September, up from 14 in the last election.
In Bahrain, most of whose people belong to the Shiite branch of Islam, Parliament -- the first elected in nearly 30 years -- would most likely have been completely run by Islamist candidates but for a boycott by the widely popular Shiite organization. It urged voters to stay away to protest constitutional changes that widened the king's powers.
Although the United States Navy fleet for the Persian Gulf region is headquartered in Bahrain, the presence of the base was not even raised as an election issue.
"The government's bad management and poor performance gave the chance to the religious groups to operate and get support," said Sawsan Shair, a columnist for the daily Al Ayam in Bahrain. "Their members have been operating for almost 10 years -- building clinics, sponsoring orphans, distributing aid and food and medicine."
The same is true to an extent in Pakistan, although there hostility toward the American presence in the region, and Gen. Pervez Musharraf's support for Washington's campaign against terrorism, were open campaign issues for the religiously oriented parties.
"Issues of identity and Islamic pride are there, and the war on terrorism was a contributing factor," said Rasul Bakhsh Rais, a professor of political science and international relations at the Lahore University of Management Science. But he and others asserted that it was not the main factor.
"There is a deep sense of betrayal among all Muslim people that their elites, their governments, their institutions have all failed them," Mr. Rais said. "People have moved away from the mainstream parties hoping that the religious political parties will provide them with a better alternative."
In Morocco, the most ardent Islamist groups are banned, so those candidates running were allied with the government and unlikely to attack it outright for any links to the West. But they did manage to get the message across in a subtle way by talking about the need to preserve Islamic identity and protect the Muslim world.
That issue seemed to play little role in Turkey, where the overwhelming sentiment among voters was an ardent desire to throw out of office anyone associated with the country's collapsing economy. 
The Youth Party, for example, which actually ran something of an anti-American, anti-International Monetary Fund platform, failed to make the threshold of 10 percent of the vote needed to get into Parliament.
The victorious party in Turkey, led by men who recast themselves from Islamists to social conservatives, has taken moderate foreign policy positions. It favors continuing membership in NATO and joining the European Union.
Those would be anathema to more radical religiously oriented groups in the region, especially the Muslim Brotherhood, the root stock of all such groups in the Arab world.
"They are isolationist, parochial," said Mr. Said. "Their point of view is that we have to keep in mind that we are in permanent conflict since the time of the Crusades until now."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT; 
Rowland Defeats Curry and Wins a Third Term

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Wednesday, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland won a third consecutive term Tuesday night, a feat not achieved in Connecticut in more than 180 years, defeating his Democratic challenger, William E. Curry Jr.
 At 1 a.m., unofficial returns showed Mr. Rowland ahead by 12 percentage points, 56 to 44, with 97 percent of the 771 election districts reporting. 
 The governor, a moderate Republican, ran a campaign that portrayed him as an experienced, steady executive dedicated to improving the state's relatively high-performing schools, and as a reasonable negotiator who could work with a Legislature led by Democrats but, as he so often put it, "hold the line on spending."
At 10:45, Governor Rowland declared victory to a crowd of supporters at the Hartford Hilton and praised his campaign as "probably the most positive campaign in the United States of America." The 45-year-old governor promised to continue making education a priority, particularly for the 300,000 children he said were born in Connecticut during his last term.
"What we need to do over the next four years is to make sure these 300,000 kids have the best education in the country," he said. "This is a time for us to raise expectations and understand that we can be the best in the country. My commitment to the people of the state is that I will never, ever, let you down." 
Mr. Curry, 50, a former state comptroller who lost to Mr. Rowland by three percentage points in the 1994 race for governor, had attacked his opponent as corrupt and not the right leader for the kind of honest, reform-minded government Connecticut voters really wanted. Mr. Curry's major promises were a $730 million property-tax cut, increased education aid to cities and towns and a clean government free of the kind of insider favors and politics that he accused Mr. Rowland of perpetuating.
Looking bitterly disappointed, Mr. Curry addressed supporters before 10 p.m. Tuesday night at the Polish National Home, a club in Hartford, and said he was deeply proud of his campaign. "I ran on the issues I wanted to," he said. "I wouldn't take back a second of it." 
Despite a solid victory for the governor, experts said Mr. Curry might have had a real chance of beating Mr. Rowland this year -- especially with the state and national economies in turmoil -- had he been able to get his message out to more people, more often. 
However, having raised just $1.3 million -- only one-fourth of Mr. Rowland's campaign treasury and less than even Connecticut's secretary of the state raised for her re-election effort -- Mr. Curry could not compete in the all-important theater of television advertising. 
Mr. Rowland saturated local and even some New York City airwaves with commercials stressing a positive, tranquil message about a Connecticut a step ahead of other states, while Mr. Curry was barely on the screen at all. His last television commercial aired weeks ago, leaving Mr. Curry to run an essentially anachronistic campaign of kissing babies and shaking hands. 
"He never really was able to match Rowland's television ads, and that put him constantly in catch-up mode," said Scott McLean, associate professor of political science at Quinnipiac University, in Hamden. 
Other political experts said Mr. Curry squandered early chances to offer voters alternative to the governor's track record on taxes, urban revitalization, education and health care. 
"If you asked Bill Curry where he stood on some issue, you would hear a five-minute ramble with an answer in there somewhere," Professor McLean said. "He wasn't quotable in ways that would lead Democratic voters to get excited about his campaign." 
Recent polls showed that Governor Rowland had built a consistent 15 to 18 point lead over Mr. Curry in the weeks after the anniversary of 9/11. In early September, Mr. Curry had pulled within 9 percentage points of Mr. Rowland, polls showed, but that was when Mr. Curry's few television commercials were still running, and before the Rowland campaign had spent the majority of its money on October television ads.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
THEOBALD, STEVEN B.

 BODY:
 THEOBALD-Steven B., age 57. An investment banker who was an innovator in the financing of housing and financial institutions, died on Monday, November 4 in Chicago. The cause was cardiac arrest, which occurred while he was jogging. Mr. Theobald was born in Rock Island, IL on June 15, 1945, the son of Walter M. Theobald, a Methodist Minister and his wife Helen. He attended the University of Illinois and after graduation served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Thailand. He returned to the United States in 1972 and joined the staff of the Illinois Housing Development Authority, rising to the position of Director of Finance. After obtaining an MBA from the University of Chicago in 1978 he moved to New York to enter public finance investment banking at Loeb Rhoades. In 1979 he joined Merrill Lynch to become a Sr. investment banker in tax-exempt housing finance. While at Merrill Lynch he quickly rose to the position of Managing Director and played an instrumental role as Merrill rose to become the leading firm in housing finance in the 1980's. He was well known in the industry and served as the Sr. Banker for the California Housing Finance Agency, the Illinois Housing Development Authority and the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development Agency, among others. In 1986 he moved to Merrill Lynch's Mortgage - Backed Securities Division, where he became head of the CMO Trading Desk. In 1997 he joined Lehman Brothers and soon thereafter, moved to Singapore, where he worked as advisor to the Thailand Reconstruction Finance Authority and the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency. 
In 2000, Mr. Theobald returned to Merrill Lynch as head of financial institutions investment banking for East and South Asia, a position he held until last fall. Mr. Theobald is survived by his wife, Nancy Rapoport and their two daughters Rachael and Sarah Theobald, of New York; his mother, Helen Theobald of Clinton, IL; and two sisters, Nancy Beadles of Clinton, IL and LouAnne Shuyler of Salem, OR. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, November 7 at 4PM at "Riverside Memorial Chapel", 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Steven B. Theobald Scholarship Fund at the University of Chicago Business School.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS; 
Guns and Butter and a World of Worries at Ballot Boxes Across the U.S.

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SALINA, Colo., Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Election Day in this gold-rush town in the Rocky Mountains seemed like a journey to another era. The polling place was a one-room schoolhouse built in the 19th century. Voters greeted one another with hugs, passed around a tin of ginger cookies and did a lot of catching up around a potbellied stove. Outside, the season's first snowfall sparkled beneath the ponderosa pines.
 But when people got talking about politics, the quaint setting was lost to cold calculation and a litany of worries about what was to come. They expressed fears about an attack against Iraq, an economy that seemed stuck in neutral and a federal government that was so deeply divided on critical issues that there might not be a right choice at the ballot box. 
 "If you don't have a strong home, you have no business messing with your neighbor," said Bret Gibson, chief of the volunteer fire department, who worried that the country was too conflicted on domestic matters to take on Iraq. 
"It is easier being the fire chief here because my wife is very supportive," Mr. Gibson said, "but if she weren't, I would have to work on that before going to fight fires far from here."
Colorado was one of those states with a tight Senate race that might help tip the balance of power in Washington. People here, like voters in a half-dozen or so other states with tight matchups, said that significance weighed heavily upon them as they made ballot choices today. 
Mr. Gibson voted for Senator Wayne Allard, a Republican, because he did not like the Democrat, Tom Strickland. But he said he had seriously considered Mr. Strickland because of the possible impact of the race on the Senate. Though a Republican, Mr. Gibson said he wanted to see the Senate remain in Democratic hands in the hope it would prevent President Bush from attacking Iraq. He finally convinced himself that control of the Senate would not come down to the outcome of the Colorado contest.
It was that sort of Election Day across the country. Voters weighed issues, but also played the odds. Some remained true to their partisan leanings; others sacrificed ideology to some larger good or strategy. Still others, worn weary by the back-and-forth on the national stage, narrowed their focus to strictly local matters. As they have in the past, people almost everywhere complained about negative advertisements and the absence of substance in the political debate.
"I'm not sure anyone, Republican or Democrat, has an answer," said Joel Wexelman, who cast his ballot early this morning in a suburb of St. Louis. "The problem is the lack of overall focus on addressing problems. Not the party line."
The Senate race in Missouri was one of the most watched in the country, as Senator Jean Carnahan, the Democrat, faced a fierce challenge from Jim Talent, a former congressman who had the strong backing of Mr. Bush. Despite predictions that cold rain would keep voters away, polling stations reported a high turnout most of the day.
Susan Newman, who voted at Wydown Middle School in Clayton, a suburb bordering St. Louis, said she was drawn to the polls by Mrs. Carnahan. The senator was appointed two years ago after her husband, Gov. Mel Carnahan, died a few weeks before the election but still finished first. Ms. Newman said she wanted to preserve Mrs. Carnahan's "centrist voice" in the Senate and also keep the Carnahan imprint on Missouri politics.
"I'm here because I'm concerned that people have a general anxiety about what's happening in our country today, the economy, 401(k)'s, the possibility of war," Ms. Newman said. "People are anxious but not angry yet. Anxiety paralyzes you. You sit back and let it happen. It's too easy to let the status quo sweep over you."
At the same polling place, Tom Currier described himself as a regular voter who had planned to cast a ballot today no matter what the national significance of the Carnahan-Talent contest. But Mr. Currier expressed fatigue with politics and what he characterized as "secrecy in Washington." He was especially upset that Vice President Dick Cheney's dealings with Enron, the troubled energy company, had not been fully disclosed.
But like many voters, Mr. Currier was not immobilized by his worries. He said he was passionate about some local ballot measures that would affect taxes on cigarettes, home rule in St. Louis and policies related to the construction of power plants. 
"The hot-button issues to me are the environment and the economy," he said.
In many states there were competitive statewide races, but not the neck-and-neck Senate contests found in Colorado and Missouri. That gave voters more leeway to consider other priorities when marking their ballots.
In Burlington, Iowa, the coffee shop in the Hy-Vee grocery store was a popular stop for voters. The discussions over biscuits, gravy and cheese omelets were not about power brokering in Washington. Instead voters moaned about plant closings, job layoffs, the high cost of medical care, illegal immigration and a general sense of insecurity since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.
"I voted for a lot of nonincumbents, just because I am sick of the ones that are in there," said Randy Augustine, a construction worker. "I don't care who they are, either party. I think we need to get some new faces in there. Get rid of these guys."
Bill Cook, clerk at a furniture rental store, was among a group of retirees and near-retirees that talk politics at the coffee shop every morning at 9. It being Election Day, the chatter was especially intense. They pulled several small square tables together to make the conversation easier.
Mr. Cook said he almost always voted a split ticket. "I try to find the merits of each candidate and go from there," he said.
In this election, Mr. Cook and his friends were influenced mostly by state and local issues, especially the problems with the slumping economy in Iowa. "Me being a working man, they pushed me toward the Democrats," Mr. Cook said. "Since big business seems to be abandoning our area, I support the Democrats."
Across the country in New Hampshire, the race to succeed Senator Robert C. Smith was one of those considered too close to predict. Political calculation was certainly at work for some voters, but so was the memory of the presidential election in 2000. Gregory Burks, a waiter in downtown Concord, said that that election had convinced him to vote after he had sat out many elections.
"Before, it was just voter apathy, but Florida cured that," Mr. Burks said. "Now it's part of my civic duty."
Mr. Burks listed three priorities in the election: abortion rights, state taxes and school reform. Based on those issues, he voted for Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, the Democrat for Senate, and for Craig Benson, the Republican for governor.
But like many other voters who were interviewed today, Mr. Burks said he worried that the issues most important to him would be overshadowed by the possibility of war with Iraq. He suggested that politicians in Washington were using Saddam Hussein as a convenient distraction.
"The reason we will attack Iraq is to keep domestic issues at bay," he said. "If they can focus your attention somewhere else, you will forget what is really going on."
That sentiment was echoed in the one-room schoolhouse here in Colorado. Gretchen Acharya, an art teacher, said she was voting against "government by diversion." Ms. Acharya's mind was mostly on her 20-year-old son, a student at a nearby community college. "I am not willing to send him off to die," she said.
Bill Jones, a Republican poll worker at the schoolhouse, had a much more menacing view of Saddam Hussein, likening him to Hitler and suggesting he needed to be stopped. Mr. Jones said he voted along party lines, mainly because he is a member of the National Rifle Association, and the organization backed the Republicans. Even so, he said he was also suspicious of the war talk in Washington, and he hoped the election would be close.
"A one-vote majority either way would not be bad," he said. "I guess I am a cynic, but I don't trust any of them."
Vanessa Reich-Henbest, who turned 18 on Sept. 11 and was voting for the first time today, described the election process as exciting if flawed. She had not thought much about Iraq but said the hardest part was getting straightforward information about the candidates. Money played too big a role, she said, and advertisements were nasty and deceptive.
In the end, those drawbacks were not enough to keep Ms. Reich-Henbest from voting. Elsewhere, though, the negative campaigns were believed to have soured voters and even lowered turnout.
In Apopka, Fla., Sandra Green, who is retired, said she voted for Gov. Jeb Bush and favored a Republican majority in the House and Senate. But Ms. Green said she was disappointed that none of the candidates seemed to speak to her concerns, including prescription drugs.
"The candidates should stick with the issues and not run everybody down," she said. "It hurts when they do that."
In North Carolina, where Elizabeth Dole, the Republican, and Erskine B. Bowles, the Democrat, slugged it out for the Senate, Rhonda Harmon said she would have nothing to do with it.
She sat out Election Day.
"All of it was negative, it was just, 'He did this,' 'She did this,' " Ms. Harmon, a collections agent for Bell South, said while eating lunch with friends in Greensboro. "I still don't know what they stand for."

GRAPHIC: Photos: BRET GIBSON, Salina, Colo. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times); RANDY AUGUSTINE, Burlington, Iowa (Melissa Jansson for The New York Times) Map: "THE POLLING PLACES -- How It Looked Inside the Booth" shows the percentages of votes counted by punch cards, lever machines, paper ballots, optical scans, electronics, and mixed. (William McNulty and Hugh K. Truslow/The New York Times)

Correction Appended 
 Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1310 words

HEADLINE: S.E.C.'s Embattled Chief Resigns In Wake of Latest Political Storm 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Harvey L. Pitt resigned tonight as the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission after a political firestorm over his selection of the head of a new board overseeing the accounting profession.
 Mr. Pitt announced his resignation just before 9 o'clock as polls were closing nationwide. For days, he had insisted he would continue to serve as long as he had the confidence of the president. At the same time, White House officials strained to try to keep the growing crisis at the agency from becoming a political issue that would remind voters of Washington's response to corporate scandals. The officials publicly voiced support for him but privately expressed deep anger about his stewardship. 
 Administration officials said tonight that Mr. Bush had not requested Mr. Pitt's resignation but that White House officials welcomed it, particularly because Mr. Pitt had created a new round of political difficulties for Republicans in the days leading up to the election. 
Mr. Pitt's leadership of the agency had grown increasingly tenuous in recent months with a series of political missteps, including a widely ridiculed effort over the summer to insert a provision in the corporate antifraud legislation that would raise his pay and elevate his status to that of cabinet level. 
His hold over the agency cracked last Thursday with the disclosure that he had failed to tell either the White House or the four other commissioners at the S.E.C. that he had known that William H. Webster, the new accounting board chairman, had headed the audit committee of a company accused of fraud. Mr. Webster, who was recruited for the post by the White House, was approved by the commission 10 days ago in a bitterly divided vote in which two of the five commissioners said he was unqualified for the job.
The disclosure that Mr. Pitt withheld information about Mr. Webster's ties to the ailing company, U.S. Technologies, led to the immediate start of three investigations into Mr. Pitt's handling of the selection of the new board, including a Congressional inquiry that was preparing for three days of Senate hearings this month. A fourth inquiry, by the S.E.C., is examining Mr. Webster's work for U.S. Technologies, which is virtually insolvent and the subject of a criminal investigation. 
"Unfortunately, the turmoil surrounding my chairmanship and the agency makes it very difficult for the commissioners and dedicated S.E.C. staffers to perform their critical assignments," Mr. Pitt said in a letter to President Bush. "Rather than be a burden to you or the agency, I feel it is in everyone's best interest if I step aside now, to allow the agency to continue the important efforts we have started.
A woman who answered the phone at Mr. Pitt's residence this evening said, "I'm sorry, we're not taking any calls right now."
A White House spokeswoman, Claire Buchan, said "this was his decision," speaking of Mr. Pitt's decision to step down. She added that no interim successor had been selected. 
In his letter, Mr. Pitt said he would leave "as soon as I can help your staff ensure a smooth transition of leadership."
Among the people being considered to succeed him are Richard C. Breeden, a former S.E.C. chairman under the first President Bush; Michael Chertoff, the assistant attorney general in charge of the criminal division at the Justice Department; James Doty, a securities lawyer who was S.E.C. general counsel under Mr. Breeden and represented George W. Bush before he became governor of Texas; Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor; Joseph A. Grundfest, a former S.E.C. commissioner who now teaches at Stanford Law School; Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma; and Frank Zarb, the former chairman of Nasdaq. 
Mr. Pitt is only the second chairman of the S.E.C. to resign abruptly because of political turmoil. In 1973, G. Bradford Cook resigned 74 days after taking office during part of the Watergate-related scandals. He had been accused of deleting references from an S.E.C. injunction to a secret $200,000 cash contribution made by the financier Robert L. Vesco to the Committee to Re-elect the President.
Mr. Pitt's announcement tonight was an embarrassing ending for his government career. He was the 26th chairman in the agency's history, was unanimously confirmed by the Senate last year and was widely praised as one of the most experienced securities lawyers in the nation.
"It's a terrible personal tragedy but the appropriate thing for an agency that he and so many people love," said Joel Seligman, the dean of the law school at Washington University in St. Louis and author of a history of the commission. "It's important for the economy that the agency not be a target of ridicule but that it get back to work and restore investor confidence in the markets."
Mr. Pitt had served the agency in the 1970's with distinction, rising as a protege to Stanley Sporkin, one of the legendary prosecutors at the agency, to become the youngest general counsel in the commission's history. He left in 1978 to lead one of the most lucrative private practices on Wall Street as a partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.
But his close ties to the accounting profession that he once represented, his slow response to the growing crisis in the markets and a series of political gaffes eroded his support and ultimately caused the White House to lose confidence in him.
Neither the first or even second choice of Mr. Bush, Mr. Pitt assumed office in August 2001, a few weeks before the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center prompted a crisis by forcing the major markets to shut down. He was widely praised for moving swiftly to help coordinate the reopening of the markets.
But a few weeks later, he outlined a conciliatory approach to the American Association of Certified Public Accountants, and his words came back to haunt him when a series of accounting frauds led to the collapse of some of the nation's largest companies, including Enron and WorldCom.
After Enron's collapse put auditors in the spotlight, Mr. Pitt called for the commission to create a new accounting oversight panel to replace an ineffective one already in place. But Mr. Pitt failed to tell that board's members about his plan before discussing it with leaders of the accounting industry. The angry board resigned in January, and some members accused Mr. Pitt of being too protective of the accounting industry.
The missteps continued.
Last April, Mr. Pitt met privately with the chief executive of the accounting firm KPMG while it was being investigated by the S.E.C. for the work it did for Xerox.
In July, he privately urged lawmakers to elevate his office to cabinet rank, on a par with the secretary of state and attorney general. The plan, which was ridiculed by Democrats, was quickly disavowed by the White House, which apparently had been unaware that he had planned to propose it.
The latest furor began early last month, when Mr. Pitt backed away from naming John H. Biggs, a widely respected chief executive of the investment plan TIAA-CREF and vocal advocate for stricter accounting rules, to head the new accounting panel. Mr. Biggs has said Mr. Pitt vowed in September to support him. But he said Mr. Pitt backed down after members of the accounting profession complained that he was too aggressive.
When senior Congressional Democrats reacted angrily to reports about Mr. Biggs's treatment, Mr. Pitt breached political protocol by attacking them with uncharacteristic bluntness.
"Their facts are wrong," he told reporters in Brussels. "They don't know what they're talking about." 
Ignoring his critics and making no effort to find a consensus candidate, Mr. Pitt selected Mr. Webster to fill the top post on the audit panel. But officials said he then failed to tell the commission, and the White House, about Mr. Webster's experience at U.S. Technologies.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 22, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Nov. 6 about the resignation of Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, omitted attribution for quotations critical of Democratic lawmakers that Mr. Pitt made during an October trip to Brussels. They were from The Wall Street Journal.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST; 
NEBRASKA

BYLINE:  Nichole M. Christian, John H. Cushman Jr., Sherri Day, Sam Dillon, Neil A. Lewis, Robert Pear, Terry Pristin, Philip Shenon, Jacques Steinberg and Leslie Wayne contributed to this report.

 BODY:
 Senator Chuck Hagel, a Republican completing his first term, defeated his Democratic opponent, Charlie Matulka, a construction worker who lacked money and name recognition. Mr. 
Hagel has established himself as an expert on foreign policy, a conservative who speaks his mind, as he did when he said President Bush appeared "hellbent" on war with Iraq and needed to focus on economic problems. 
 Gov. Mike Johanns, a Republican, won re-election, defeating Stormy Dean, the Democratic candidate. In a low-key style, Mr. Johanns guided the state through fiscal difficulties. He opposed casino gambling in the state, while Mr. Dean pushed for expanded gambling, saying it would reduce property taxes.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: TRENDS; 
Democratic Party Gains in an Increasingly Wealthy and Suburban State

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
New Jersey has more money than most states, more corporate headquarters, and more M.B.A.'s and S.U.V.'s, status symbols long associated with a Republican world view. But this year they have symbolized the rise of New Jersey's Democrats. 
 In defiance of patterns that were once political gospel, New Jersey has become more Democratic as it has become wealthier, more suburban and more educated. 
 Today, the state gave Frank R. Lautenberg a resounding victory as his Republican opponent, Douglas R. Forrester, lost nearly all the advantage he had built when he was running against Senator Robert G. Torricelli just a few months ago. 
That was no surprise in a race between a well-known former senator and a political newcomer chosen by a state Republican Party in such disarray that it could not persuade its most popular leaders to run. Mr. Lautenberg had the mantle of incumbency, even though he had been retired for two years, and limited scrutiny in his 35-day campaign.
But his victory also reflected bigger changes in what John B. Judis and Ruy Teixeira, the authors of "The Emerging Democratic Majority," have called "the nation's pre-eminent suburban, post-industrial state." 
New Jersey is, they say, one of many increasingly suburban states where the Republican franchise is weakening, a trend in the Northeast, the West Coast and parts of the Midwest, including Illinois, largely because of Chicago's ever-expanding suburbs.
But New Jersey is "exhibit No. 1" in the changing politics of the Northeast, said Mr. Teixeira, a senior fellow at the Century Foundation, a liberal research group. "A lot of these places are on the knife's edge, but New Jersey is not," he said. "It's pretty far gone." 
That much was clear a year ago, when the Democrats took over the governor's office and the General Assembly and won half of the State Senate seats. Trenton had been dominated for eight years by Republicans, led by Gov. Christie Whitman, but at the same time the party was struggling in national and Congressional elections.
After voting for Republicans in six straight presidential elections, New Jersey gave Bill Clinton a slim margin in 1992 and 54 percent of the vote in 1996. In 2000, Al Gore won 56 percent of the vote, to 40.6 percent for George W. Bush. The state continued to elect Democrats to the Senate, as it had done since 1972. 
Many of those Democratic votes have come, as always, from Newark, Jersey City, Camden and the other urban areas where the party was perfecting its already formidable get-out-the-vote machinery. They are largely responsible for the Democrats' registration advantage, 25 percent to 19.6 percent for the Republicans, across the state. 
But many other Democratic votes have come from relatively new arrivals in formerly Republican strongholds, said James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "As a consequence of sprawl and of new populations moving into the counties that were once rural and Republican," Mr. Hughes said, "there's been a gradual transition to a more diverse political base." 
Mr. Hughes, who writes extensively on New Jersey's demographic trends, sees the most pronounced changes in the fast-growing central counties that he calls "the wealth belt." The boom there, led by growth in the pharmaceutical industry, has helped give New Jersey the nation's highest median household income.
It has not made these formerly Republican counties more Republican, however. Rather, Mr. Hughes notes, they have drawn affluent, well-educated voters very likely to be among the 56 percent of New Jerseyans who are politically unaffiliated. 
"It's not that they're in love with Democratic candidates," he said. "But the Democrats have put the specter out there: if you give Republicans full control of the federal government, those are policies far to the right of most New Jerseyans." 
Those suburban voters, it turned out, were especially concerned about the issues that Mr. Lautenberg, and Senator Torricelli before him, advertised like a three-part cheer: abortion rights, gun control and environmental protection.
Mr. Teixeira said that with the state's economic boom, "all of North and Central Jersey were becoming one big ideopolis" -- a term that he and Mr. Judis coined to identify an urbanizing area with a common political culture. 
"Professionals were playing a much bigger role in politics and the economy," Mr. Teixeira said, and were joined in their Democratic voting tendencies by "a coalition of women, minorities and more progressive blue-collar workers." 
Cliff Zukin, the director of the Star-Ledger/Rutgers Eagleton Poll, has an additional explanation: Younger people joining the electorate are increasingly Democratic in their allegiances. "We call it generational replacement," he said, and it has gradually expanded the party's base. 
Of course, these shifts have not routed the state Republican Party, however discombobulated it is right now. State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the state party chairman, pointed out tonight that the party still has "half of the State Senate seats, nearly half of the Congressional delegation, half of the county boards of chosen freeholders."
Senator Jon S. Corzine, who ran far behind Mr. Gore in 2000 even while outspending his Republican opponent by more than 10 to 1, pointed that out as he celebrated tonight.
"I don't think Republicans in New Jersey stand with Trent Lott," he said. "When the Republicans put up a moderate candidate in New Jersey, I think we have very competitive races."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank R. Lautenberg rejoiced at his victory last night in New Brunswick, N.J., with Senator Jon S. Corzine, left, and Gov. James E. McGreevey. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News Analysis

PERSON: FRANK LAUTENBERG (89%); BILL CLINTON (78%); JON CORZINE (59%); AL GORE (57%); GEORGE W BUSH (51%)

GEOGRAPHIC: TRENTON, NJ, USA (92%); CHICAGO, IL, USA (79%); NEWARK, NJ, USA (79%) NEW JERSEY, USA (97%); ILLINOIS, USA (79%); MIDWEST USA (79%) UNITED STATES (97%)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE FLORIDA VOTE; 
Bush Wins 2nd Term With Surge

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Gov. Jeb Bush today became the first Republican governor in Florida history to win re-election, after a campaign that seemed to have as much to do with his brother, the president, as it did with his own first term in office. 
 With 97 percent of the vote counted, the governor was leading his opponent, Bill McBride, 56 percent to 43 percent. 
 Mr. McBride called Governor Bush to concede, and President Bush called to congratulate his brother. 
In declaring victory, Governor Bush said: "Fifteen minutes ago, Bill McBride called me and graciously conceded the election, and I told him that he ran a hard race and that I look forward to working with him to build a better Florida. Now is the time to unite us as a state, and I appreciate Mr. McBride's contribution to the political process.
"I want to thank my mother and dad for being my inspiration in life. And I want to thank our great president of the United States for coming down and lending a hand to his little brother."
The governor pledged to diversify the state's economy, improve child support for working mothers, reduce domestic violence and protect the developmentally disabled in his next term.
"I will not let you down," he said. "I will work as hard as I can."
Mr. McBride said he had wished Mr. Bush well and added: "What I talked about all during this campaign is consensus building and family and treating Florida like a family. This was an election about choosing the head of the Florida family for the next four years. And I want all of you to consider that and consider your support and your help because the new head of the Florida family, this governor, needs support."
Despite fears that electoral problems seen in 2000 and in the Democratic primary this year would be repeated, voting went smoothly.
Frequent campaign visits by top Republicans and Democrats, including President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore, revived memories of the election debacle in 2000 and pointed to the state's importance in 2004. But voters today said they were looking beyond the hanging-chad chaos of the 2000 election and were instead focused on education, the economy and terrorism. 
Florida voters handed the governor a huge challenge by approving an initiative to limit class sizes in the state's public schools. The initiative passed, 53 percent to 47 percent. 
The measure, Amendment 9, would change the Florida Constitution to require the state to give schools enough money to reduce substantially the number of students in classes over eight years. Mr. Bush opposed the measure, contending that it had a price of more than $27 billion and that Florida could not afford it. Mr. McBride supported the measure, but provided few details about how he would pay for it beyond a 50-cents-a-pack cigarette tax that would have only generated about $1 billion a year.
In an unguarded moment in the campaign, Mr. Bush said he had a "devious plan" for dealing with the class-size issue if the measure was approved. He later apologized for the remark. 
Anita McCann, a saleswoman from West Palm Beach, said she voted for Mr. Bush because of the education issue. "I realized during the last debate in Orlando McBride doesn't know where he's going to get his money." Ms. McCann said. "That made me turn."
Mr. Bush will also have to contend with a potential shortfall in the state budget, pressure from older-citizens groups for more aid to pay for the rising costs of prescription drugs and a host of environmental issues affecting the Everglades and the state's coastline.
The campaign had been viewed by the national Democratic and Republican Parties as somewhat of a preview of the 2004 presidential race 
"It's the beginning point for 2004, on everything from voter turnout to issues," said Susan MacManus, a political scientist at the University of South Florida. "Neither party feels they can win the presidential election without Florida's electoral votes."
In Governor Bush's hotel suite, Mr. Bush and his parents, former President George Bush and his wife, Barbara, monitored the election results and played a bit of political family trivia.
Jim Towey, a friend of Jeb Bush and director of the White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, was looking at county-by-county numbers for the 2000 presidential election and he and the governor were comparing how George W. Bush did in 2000 compared with the governor's performance this year.
"Does it mean that you're better than George," Barbara Bush asked.
"No, it means we're using him as a benchmark," the governor replied. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2138 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR; 
Pataki Coasts to a 3rd Term; McCall Is a Distant Second

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki, a pragmatic Republican who ran a campaign intended to appeal as much to liberals as to conservatives, was elected to a third term yesterday with a solid majority, ending the quest of the Democratic challenger, H. Carl McCall, to become the state's first black governor.
 In other New York races, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer obliterated his Republican opponent, Dora Irizarry, to win a second term, firmly establishing himself as one of the brightest young stars in the state Democratic Party and a possible candidate for governor. 
 The closest statewide race in New York was for comptroller. Alan G. Hevesi, the Democratic nominee and a former city comptroller, squeaked by John J. Faso, the former Republican leader in the State Assembly, winning with 50 percent of the vote to Mr. Faso's 47 percent. 
In New Jersey, Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat, was elected to the Senate by a comfortable margin, and in Connecticut, the Republican governor, John G. Rowland, was returned to office easily. Pages B1 and B16. 
Mr. Pataki declared victory at 11:15 p.m. and profusely thanked all 18 million New Yorkers for their confidence in his policies.
"There are no stronger, better people than New Yorkers," Mr. Pataki said, as supporters cheered. "And when we are united, when we stand together, we can accomplish miracles. And it's been my goal as governor not to be the governor of some, but to be the governor of all."
His victory makes him only the third Republican to win more than two terms in New York, putting him in a class with Thomas E. Dewey and Nelson A. Rockefeller. 
Mr. McCall went down in defeat after running a campaign that failed to raise enough money to mount a viable challenge to Mr. Pataki and could not hold onto the traditional Democratic base. Mr. McCall also made several pivotal mistakes in the final weeks of campaigning that kept him from cutting Mr. Pataki's lead, political strategists said.
Although Mr. McCall wanted to make history as the first black governor, he came dangerously close last night to making history in another way, as the Democratic candidate who received the smallest percentage of total votes in modern history for a statewide race. That record was held by Peter F. Vallone, who got 33 percent of the vote four years ago in the governor's race. The only major party candidate to do worse in modern times was Pierre Rinfret, the Republican candidate in 1990, who got 21 percent of the vote.
With 98 percent of election districts reporting, Mr. Pataki had 50 percent of the vote, Mr. McCall 33 percent and Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, 14 percent, with minor party candidates picking up another 3 percent. The Liberal Party failed to get the 50,000 votes it needed to automatically remain on the ballot for future elections.
The race was the most expensive in the state's history, with the major candidates expending more than $131 million. 
Mr. McCall, 67, conceding defeat last night, said that while he wished the governor well, the schools and flagging economy still needed attention. "If we could just put the same effort and the same level of passion and energy and funding into governing as we put into campaigning," he said, "things would be a lot better."
Mr. Golisano, 60, a Rochester billionaire who has run three times for governor, spent more than $65 million of his own fortune and came in third. He said before the polls closed that he felt he had won a moral victory by attacking what he considers inertia, waste and fraud in state government.
He conceded shortly after 11 p.m., but did not congratulate the governor in his speech. "If we achieved anything," he said, "it's for the next several years, the two-party system in this state has got to keep their eye out on us, because we're going to be watching them."
Mr. Pataki, who is 57, coasted to a third victory by taking credit for cutting income taxes, winnowing the welfare rolls and reducing crime. He talked up several liberal programs that expanded under his watch, among them health insurance for poor children and their parents.
Yet the governor did not offer an agenda for his next term as governor, an office with an annual salary of $179,000. Nor did he present concrete plans for confronting the deep financial crisis the state faces next year, including a yawning $5 billion budget gap. He stressed his experience instead, saying he had handled a similar crisis in 1995 and could be trusted to do so again.
It remained unclear whether Mr. Pataki had achieved the kind of crushing victory that could transform him into a contender for national office. He won with 54 percent of the votes in 1998 against Mr. Vallone, but he faced a much more formidable campaign this year by Mr. Golisano.
The election was a defining moment in the career of an adaptable politician who has evolved over his first two terms. He first ran in 1995 as a conservative who promised to slash income taxes, revamp welfare and restore the death penalty. But he has taken on more and more liberal causes over the years, championing tight gun-control laws, an equal-rights bill for homosexuals and expansion of Medicaid benefits to cover indigent children, to name a few.
He won this year in part because of his aggressive pursuit of traditionally Democratic voters, especially Latinos and union members. At the Hilton New York Hotel in Midtown last night, several hundred happy Republican campaign workers and Pataki supporters stood around the ballroom, eagerly awaiting the governor's anticipated victory speech. Some danced to loud rock music or shrieked with pleasure as the returns rolled in. "The bottom line is people know him, they like him, they trust him," Michael McKeon, the governor's chief spokesman, said.
The mood was more subdued at Mr. McCall's headquarters in a union hall downtown, where prominent Democrats were taking some solace in the thought that their candidate had run a good campaign with the resources he had.
"I think it's very important to recognize that no campaign is perfect, no winning campaign is perfect," said former Mayor David N. Dinkins, a longtime friend of Mr. McCall. "We should not be so quick to condemn this campaign."
Yet other McCall supporters also talked of betrayal by the National Democratic Party for not pumping more money into the New York race, and were already second-guessing campaign strategies, even as they praised their candidate.
The race failed to inspire many voters, as turnout across the state was light to moderate. In New York City, some Democrats expressed disappointment with Mr. McCall's candidacy even as they voted for him.
Lacking a big campaign treasury, Mr. McCall had turned to his Democratic allies for help and support, especially Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, who has been Mr. McCall's mentor for decades. 
Bill Clinton and his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, both campaigned hard for Mr. McCall in the closing days. Senator Charles E. Schumer endorsed Mr. McCall early on and appeared in an advertisement, warmly recommending him to voters. So did Mr. Clinton. 
In a sense, Mr. McCall ran an old-fashioned partisan campaign, laboring to persuade moderate Democrats who support Mr. Pataki to come back home. 
But the governor presented himself as a nonpartisan liberal, despite having run as a tax-slashing conservative in 1994. He rarely mentioned his party on the hustings, but repeated a mantra about unity and wanting to be "the governor of all the people." He attracted a significant number of prominent Democratic supporters to his camp. 
Mr. Pataki also benefited from history. The governor's popularity soared after Sept. 11, as New Yorkers, and Americans across the country, rallied around their leaders. What had seemed a winnable race for the Democrats became much tougher overnight, strategists said.
Mr. Pataki seldom spoke of his high profile role after the attacks, but other Republicans praised his leadership frequently at campaign rallies, and he often appeared in front of a giant American flag. 
Toward the end of the campaign, Mr. Pataki adopted a frontrunner's strategy, issuing no position papers and refusing to debate unless the full slate of candidates for governor were included. 
Mr. McCall, meanwhile, tried to run on two main themes: that the governor had failed to improve the state's schools and had not had any success lifting the upstate economy from the doldrums.
Last night, Mrs. Clinton praised Mr. McCall, saying he had set a wonderful example. "This is a man," she said, "that you should tell your children and grandchildren about."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: WEST; 
IDAHO

BYLINE:  Nichole M. Christian, John H. Cushman Jr., Sherri Day, Sam Dillon, Neil A. Lewis, Robert Pear, Terry Pristin, Philip Shenon, Jacques Steinberg and Leslie Wayne contributed to this report.

 BODY:
In a state long dominated by Republicans, the incumbent senator, Larry E. Craig, defeated his Democratic challenger, Alan Blinken, ambassador to Belgium in the Clinton administration. This will be Mr. 
Craig's third Senate term. 
 One of the more conservative members of the Senate, Mr. Craig stumbled briefly during the campaign when he said he believed that terrorists of Al Qaeda were in Idaho. Still, he went into the election with polls showing him with a 30 percentage point lead. 
 Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, the Republican incumbent was also re-elected by a comfortable margin, overcoming a feisty challenge from Jerry Brady, an Idaho Falls newspaper publisher.
Governor Kempthorne ran advertisements showing himself shoulder-to-shoulder with President Bush, while Mr. Brady, who inched up in the polls in the final days, blamed the governor for Idaho's economic woes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, faced only light opposition for a third term. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: MASSACHUSETTS; 
Ex-Steward Of Olympics Wins Governor

BYLINE:  By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Mitt Romney, a Republican businessman who was in charge of the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, was elected governor of Massachusetts today, defeating Shannon O'Brien, the Democratic state treasurer.
 With 66 percent of the precincts counted, Mr. Romney had won 52 percent of the votes to 43 percent for Ms. O'Brien, 763,153 votes to 640,423. 
 Mr. Romney, 55, won after the most expensive political race in Massachusetts history in which the two candidates had been in a virtual dead heat in the polls for the last week. 
Mr. Romney emphasized his business experience as the leader of Bain Capital, an investment firm, and his success in the 2002 Winter Olympics, appealing to voters as a political outsider who could fix a huge state budget shortfall and bring jobs to Massachusetts. 
"We took on an entrenched machine and we won," Mr. Romney said in his acceptance speech.
In winning, Mr. Romney overcame two handicaps. He ran as a Republican in a largely Democratic state, and he is a Mormon in a heavily Roman Catholic state.
Mr. Romney's victory was also a personal vindication after he lost a race for the United States Senate in 1994 to Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Mr. Romney's father, George Romney, was governor of Michigan who made an unsuccessful bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 1968.
Some Democrats initially expressed skepticism that Mr. Romney would serve out his term as governor of Massachusetts and was simply using the election as a steppingstone to become Republican candidate for vice president or even president. But these doubts did not seem to influence voters, and Mr. Romney carried even such urban Democratic strongholds as Brockton and Quincy.
Mr. Romney will replace Jane M. Swift, the acting governor, a widely unpopular Republican who inherited the job when Gov. Paul Cellucci resigned after President Bush nominated him to be United State ambassador to Canada. Ms. Swift, who had been lieutenant governor, had been expected to run as the Republican candidate for governor this fall until Mr. Romney, sensing her weakness, returned from Utah after the Olympics and drove her out of the race.
Mr. Romney will face a severe state budget crisis, with tax revenue taking the biggest plunge in 50 years, said Michael J. Widmer, president of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, a nonpartisan research group backed by businesses.
After a decade of rapid economic growth, Massachusetts legislators had embarked on ambitious programs combining tax cuts with increased spending for education and health care. But with capital gains and income tax revenue in free fall, the new governor's main task will be to slash state spending and try to balance the budget.
In television advertisements, Mr. Romney said his business experience would help him balance the budget and cut state taxes while attracting new businesses and jobs. Ignoring the fact that Republicans have been governor of Massachusetts for the last 12 years, Mr. Romney also promised to "clean up Beacon Hill," the location of the statehouse.
Ms. O'Brien, the daughter of a political family from western Massachusetts, has been a state legislator as well as state treasurer and has close relations with the Democrats who control the Legislature. In her campaign, Ms. O'Brien was strongly supported by traditional Democratic groups, including labor unions and public school teachers.
But she was hurt by Mr. Romney's attacks on her husband, who is a lobbyist, and she lost votes to the Green Party candidate, Jill Stein.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shannon O'Brien, right, was hugged by her running mate, Chris Gabrieli, after losing the race for Massachusetts governor. (Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LENGTH: 750 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: NEW HAMPSHIRE; 
Senate Seat Stays Republican As Sununu Defeats Governor

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 5 

 BODY:
The Republicans won the battle for the Senate in New Hampshire tonight as Representative John E. Sununu defeated Gov. Jeanne Shaheen in what had been one of the tightest races in the country.
 Polls showed the two New Hampshire political heavyweights neck and neck until Election Day. But in the end, Mr. Sununu appeared to pull out a decisive victory. With 96 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Sununu had 51 percent of the vote while Ms. Shaheen had 47 percent. At 10:30 p.m., Ms. Shaheen conceded the election. 
 "I called John Sununu and congratulated him on his win," she said. "It is now important to all of us that we succeed by working together."
She added, "This election is over, but important battles remain, to get our economy working again, to assure seniors a secure retirement and our children a clean environment."
In his victory speech, Mr. Sununu said: "We were outspent in this election but we weren't outworked. This was a tremendous grass-roots effort."
He added: "At the end of the day, I want the people of New Hampshire to know I will stand up for the issues important to them. I won't be afraid of ideas. I won't be afraid of leadership."
Mr. Sununu, a three-term congressman and son of John H. Sununu, the former governor of the state and chief of staff to the first President Bush, had outrun the incumbent senator, Robert C. Smith, in the Republican primary.
Ms. Shaheen, a three-term governor and longtime state senator, is a moderate Democrat whose past electoral success was attributed to her siding with Republicans on issues like taxes and capital punishment, views that appeal to New Hampshire's growing number of independent voters, who tend to lean Republican.
Those voters were crucial in today's election, and the candidates promoted themselves by citing the instances in which they had differed with their parties.
"The underlying political landscape in New Hampshire is pro-Republican, and any Republican running for statewide office has a natural advantage," said Andrew Smith, director of the University of New Hampshire Survey Center, which conducted polls showing that the race was too close to call. "To counteract that, what a Democrat has to do is run as a moderate Democrat, have an excellent statewide campaign, and then it still may not be enough."
Mr. Smith's latest poll indicated that even a tiny percentage of Smith supporters who planned to write in his name or sit out the election could sway the outcome to Ms. Shaheen. Figures on the write-in voting were not expected to be available until late tonight.
During the campaign, the candidates squared off on issues like taxes, abortion, Social Security and the economy. Ms. Shaheen accused Mr. Sununu of supporting big business and privatization of Social Security to the detriment of small businesses and the elderly. Mr. Sununu fired back that Ms. Shaheen would be a tax-and-spender and accused her of failing to solve the state's education funding problem.
Ultimately, said Constantine Spiliotes, a government professor at Dartmouth College, many voters felt so overwhelmed that they just made "a gut-level decision of who's going to be a better leader for the state."
He said: "Shaheen, being a chief executive, was open to charges that she's had weak leadership. Sununu, as one out of 435 congressmen, is open to charges that he's just concerned about his party caucus."
The contest, along with a governor's race here, propelled a record number of voters to the polls, said William M. Gardner, New Hampshire's secretary of state.
"It will be the most number of votes cast in this state in a midterm election," said Mr. Gardner, who has predicted that the numbers will reach 385,000, about 60,000 more than the previous midterm election record. In Ward 1 in Manchester, election officials watching the voting at the Webster School said that by 9 a.m., one-third of the precinct's 5,460 voters had already turned out.
Voters interviewed outside the polling place appeared equally divided between Shaheen supporters and Sununu supporters. A number of independent voters, however, said that they had difficulty making up their minds.
"It was a tough choice; it really was," said Melissa Fortin, 39, a freelance architectural designer. "I saved all the campaign literature from both sides, and at the last minute I ruffled through it."
She said she finally decided to support Ms. Shaheen because of her opposition to big corporate tax breaks and her policies on education, and because "she's a good person."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John E. Sununu, right, the Senate winner in New Hampshire, and its other Republican senator, Judd Gregg. (Associated Press) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Greenspan on Liberal Arts

BYLINE:  By Karen W. Arenson

 BODY:
 When ALAN GREENSPAN, chairman of the Federal Reserve, was in New York last week, he talked not about interest rates but about the value of a college education. "An economist can scarcely fail to notice the advantages that we have accrued in this country by having the marketplace work efficiently to guide our educational system, defined in its widest sense, toward the broader needs of our economy," said Mr. 
Greenspan, who was at a dinner to receive the Stephen P. Duggan Award for International Understanding from the Institute of International Education. Mr. Greenspan also spoke of the value of the liberal arts, and warned that in the face of increasing scientific knowledge, "our universities are going to have to struggle to prevent the liberal arts curricula from being swamped by technology and science." Karen W. Arenson

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LENGTH: 1089 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
President's Risks Are Rewarded at Polls

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, said it early in the evening, "I see a Republican breeze blowing," and a few hours later he was proved right.
 If it cannot yet be declared a cyclone, it was still powerful enough to give President Bush, who had risked much of his political capital, a highly satisfying night. 
 Early this morning, the Republicans took control of the Senate and assured themselves of keeping the upper hand in the House of Representatives. 
It appeared more than possible that the Republicans would gain seats in the House -- something achieved by the party holding the White House only twice since the Civil War, and never by the Republicans. 
President Bush did his utmost to personalize the campaign, appealing for allies to help him push through his program, especially his domestic security bill, and raising a record amount of money. Campaigning widely, if less so than Mr. Bush, former President Bill Clinton and former Vice President Al Gore also sought to nationalize the race, with much less success. 
Two years ago, Mr. Bush exhibited no coattails at all. In the intervening months, he clearly developed some.
Mr. Bush's impact was especially notable in the South, where he helped Representative Saxby Chambliss oust Senator Max Cleland, a war hero who lost both legs and an arm in Vietnam. Mr. Cleland apparently paid the price for voting against the President on domestic security. Mr. Bush also rode to the rescue of his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida and helped elect several new Southern governors, in states like Georgia and South Carolina.
His handpicked nominee in the Missouri Senate race, former Representative Jim Talent, defeated Senate Jean Carnahan to put the Republicans over the top.
Elsewhere, the campaign remained more a mosaic of many minicampaigns than a unified overall picture, with no overarching themes to unite the pieces. Taxes dominated some races, education others and health care still others.
Against the general trend, the Democrats succeeded in ousting Senator Tim Hutchinson, a Republican, in Arkansas, and Representative Constance A. Morella of Maryland, one of the last liberal Republicans, on Capitol Hill. A famous political name helped Mark Pryor, the victor in Arkansas, and her age (70), her independence and a redrawn district worked against Ms. Morella.
For the president, three races mattered most: the Senate contest in South Dakota, where Senator Tim Johnson, a Democrat, was seen as a surrogate for his colleague, Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, and Representative John Thune, a Republican recruited by the White House, was seen as a surrogate for Mr. Bush; the governorship contest in Florida, where Mr. Bush's brother Jeb, is seeking re-election as governor, and the governorship contest in Texas, where Rick Perry, a Republican who served under Mr. Bush in Austin as lieutenant governor, this year sought election as governor in his own right.
The President got his way in the two governors' races, but the outcomein South Dakota remained in doubt. In Florida, Mr. Bush helped raise $13 million - and that apparently helped Jeb Bush to victory.
Two years after the most bizarre presidential election in American history was decided by the Supreme Court, 14 months after the unspeakable horror of terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the nation voted in a mood of evident disenchantment and curious disconnection from the political system.
The American public is faced with a series of potentially life-altering issues, including the prospect of war with Iraq, the possibility of further assaults on national security at home, the reality of a prolonged slump in the stock market and the uncertainty of the economic outlook.
With pep rallies devoid of pep and stump speeches that stirred few voters, the campaign that led up to the balloting was nevertheless notably lifeless and cheerless. But the electorate sent a clear enough message.
In an early sign of the tide, Representative Anne M. Northup, a Republican, easily carried her district in the Louisville suburbs, which had been rated by experts as a toss-up. Democrats had hoped to win it.
Perhaps more significant, the Republicans' drive to recapture the Senatewas aided by their success in holding every single one of the five open Republican Senate seats, from New Hampshire in the northeast to Texas in the southwest. One of the sweetest victories for the Republicans came in North Carolina, where Elizabeth Dole, whose campaign had seemed to be slipping in recent days, won by a considerable margin.
An unusual number of Senate races went down to the wire. In sum the country appeared every bit as evenly divided as it was in 2000.
Norman Ornstein, a political scholar at the American EnterpriseInstitute, argued that even if the Republicans made a breakthrough in the Senate, "We're still going to be in single digits, and we're still going to be in age of parity, perhaps unique in American history and likely to be with us for some time to come." If final results bear him out, CapitolHill may well be in for an unproductive couple of years.
"With parties so closely matched," said Anne Wexler, a Democratic lobbyist who worked with Congress during the Carter administration, 'it's hard to make any meaningful policy. It's all but impossible to create coalitions. It's all but impossible to impose any party discipline.Everyone is worrying about his or her own seat and about the next election, so you have 535 different free-lance operations up there."
But in symbolic terms, controlling the White House and both houses of Congress would count for a lot. And even if pushing some major legislation through remains beyond the President's capacity, he will no doubt take yesterday's voting pattern as a mandate to pursue his goal of ousting President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, by force if need be. Control of the Senate would also give Mr. Bush a better shot at winning confirmation for any conservative nominees he may choose in the event of Supreme Court vacancies.
Two years from now, yesterday's contests for governor may seem to have been more important than those for Congress. Excluded for years from the governor's mansions in many of the states with large blocks of electoral votes, the Democrats regained several of them, which should greatly assist their 2004 presidential campaign. Democrats swept back into power in Pennsylvania, Michigan and Illinois, the kind of Mid-Atlantic and Midwest states that have formed the engine-room of American politics for generations. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News Analysis 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
