SECTION: Section B; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1279 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE SENATE; 
Republicans Regain Control of Senate, With a Victory in Missouri

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM and ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
The Republicans' razor-thin reversal of fortune in the Senate removed the Democrats' sole power base in Washington and breathed new life into President Bush's stalled domestic agenda in Congress, from contested judicial nominations to deeper tax cuts and a new Department of Homeland Security that has been blocked by disputes over workers' rights.
 But in a body where 60 votes are required to cut off debate, the Republicans' narrow new working majority also fell far short of the margin needed to avoid Democratic filibusters on a range of contentious major issues from Social Security to health care, all but guaranteeing another two years of contentious partisan wrangling. 
 In a strong showing from New England to the South, the Midwest and the Rocky Mountains, the Republicans held on to all but one of their closely contested seats, and knocked off enough Democratic incumbents to foil the Democrats' attempts to keep control. The Democrats' sole pickup, the victory of Attorney General Mark Pryor of Arkansas over Senator Tim Hutchinson, was not enough to offset Republican gains elsewhere.
Shortly after 2 a.m. Eastern time, Senator Jean Carnahan of Missouri sealed the Democrats' fate, conceding to supporters that she had lost to Representative Jim Talent, thus making it impossible for Democrats to retain control, whatever the outcome of close contests in Minnesota and South Dakota. 
"As always, others will come to lift the fallen torch," said Mrs. Carnhan, who was running to fill the unexpired term of her husband, Mel, who died just before Election Day two years ago but won anyway; she was appointed to fill his seat temporarily. "The fire will not go out."
Mr. Bush campaigned hard all year to regain control of the Senate, which the Republicans lost last year with the defection of Senator James M. Jeffords to independent. He raised money and stumped repeatedly for handpicked candidates in close races, and his efforts paid off.
Leaving his office in the Capitol last night at 10:30, the Republican leader, Senator Lott of Mississippi, said: "The signs are very encouraging. Things are looking good."
By early this morning, Democratic Party officials had all but conceded they could not win all the bitterly close contests they needed -- in Missouri, South Dakota and Minnesota -- to retain control. Moreover, Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, was forced into a December runoff election because she received less than 50 percent of the vote, making her seat a fat target for national Republicans then.
Upset victories went to Representative Saxby Chambliss of Georgia, a Republican who defeated the Democratic incumbent, Senator Max Cleland, and to Mr. Pryor.
But the Republicans staved off two of the Democrats' best prospects, Gov. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Tom Strickland, a former United States Attorney in Colorado. They also easily rebuffed Democratic candidates for open seats in North and South Carolina held for decades by Jesse Helms and Strom Thurmond, who are retiring, and claimed victory in open seats in Tennessee and Texas. Elizabeth Dole, the former cabinet secretary and presidential candidate, won the North Carolina seat.
In New Hampshire, Representative John E. Sununu, the son of the former Republican governor and White House chief of staff, appeared before cheering supporters at 10:40 p.m. to claim victory. He had defeated the incumbent Republican, Bob Smith, in a bitter primary that left the Democrats hopeful that Ms. Shaheen might take the seat.
"This is your victory," Mr. Sununu said. "We were outspent, but we weren't outworked."
The election capped a tumultuous two years in which partisan control of the Senate shifted to the Democrats with Mr. Jeffords' switch. But both parties struggled to find clear advantage on issues from the economy to terrorism.
Until the death of Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota in a plane crash 11 days ago, the Democrats held only a single-vote working margin in the Senate, so any one of a handful of tossup races held the power to shift control of the chamber.
In Georgia, Mr. Chambliss, a Republican who has recently drawn attention as chairman of an antiterrorism subcommittee in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, declared victory over Mr. Cleland, a decorated, disabled Vietnam veteran. Mr. Chambliss, who received major support from President Bush, told cheering supporters, "Something like this never happens without a lot of hard work."
Mrs. Dole, a former secretary of labor and transportation who abandoned her Republican presidential bid more than two years ago, comfortably defeated Erskine B. Bowles, a former chief of staff to President Bill Clinton, to win the North Carolina Senate seat held for 30 years by Mr. Helms. Mr. Bowles, a millionaire businessman, spent heavily on his own behalf and Democrats had hoped a strong black turnout might let him eke out a victory in a state that favors Republicans.
With her victory, Mrs. Dole dispelled some lingering doubt about her electoral viability and positioned herself for a potentially prominent future role in national Republican politics. She and her husband, the former Senate Republican leader Bob Dole, now join former Senators Howard Baker of Tennessee and Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas in a select club of married couples who have served in the Senate from different states.
"I am just as thrilled as you are," Mrs. Dole told her supporters last night. "We'll never forget this night, will we?" She reached out to hold her husband's arm, pronouncing him "the best surrogate" a campaign could have.
In South Carolina, Representative Lindsey Graham, running to fill the Republican seat vacated by Mr. Thurmond, who at 99 is the Senate's senior member, handily defeated his Democratic opponent, Alex Sanders, a former president of the College of Charleston.
Former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, recruited at the last minute to take the place of the Democratic incumbent, Robert G. Torricelli, who dropped out under an ethical cloud, kept that seat for the Democrats.
In Tennessee, former Gov. Lamar Alexander handily won the Republican seat being vacated by Fred Thompson, the former prosecutor and part-time actor who decided not to seek re-election after the death of his daughter and who now has a regular role on the popular television series "Law & Order."
In Texas, John Cornyn, the Republican nominee, claimed victory in incomplete returns over his Democratic opponent, Ron Kirk, to hold the seat being vacated by Phil Gramm.
Both parties made extraordinary efforts to turn out voters in close contests, and by last evening, Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the head of the Democrats' Senate campaign committee, said that turnout was unusually high in some states, comparable to that for a presidential election year.
"We are very confident that at the end of the day, it will be a good day for Senate Democrats," she told reporters.
But in other ways, much was business as usual, with at least 18 Senate incumbents returned to office without serious challenge. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who staged a losing battle against efforts to overhaul campaign finance laws to bar the parties' use of so-called soft money, trounced his Democratic challenger, Lois Combs Weinberg, to become the first Republican in his state to win four full Senate terms.
With 34 of the Senate's 100 seats at stake, Democratic incumbents drove to safe victories in Delaware, Illinois, Massachusetts, Michigan, Montana, Rhode Island and West Virginia, while Republicans held onto their seats in Alabama, Alaska, Idaho, Kansas, Kentucky, Maine, Mississippi, Nebraska, New Mexico, Virginia and Wyoming.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Elizabeth Dole celebrating last night in North Carolina. "I am just as thrilled as you are," she told supporters. (Associated Press); Representative Lindsey Graham, left, after winning the Senate seat being vacated by Strom Thurmond. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE OVERVIEW; 
G.O.P. RETAKES CONTROL OF THE SENATE IN A SHOW OF PRESIDENTIAL INFLUENCE; PATAKI, JEB BUSH AND LAUTENBERG WIN

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Republicans swept to victory in the United States Senate last night, assuring Republican control of the White House and Congress for the next two years, and thrusting President Bush into a commanding position for his legislative agenda.
 The Republican Party also maintained -- and possibly solidified -- its hold on the House, in an election that amounted to a major drubbing for the Democratic Party. 
 The results mean that a single party, the Republicans, will once again control both houses of Congress and the White House. The party lost the Senate in June 2001, when Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont switched from the Republican Party and became an independent, though mostly voting with the Democrats.
Republicans captured high-profile Senate races from North Carolina to New Hampshire, winning contests in governors' races in Democratic states. 
"We made history tonight," said Representative Thomas M. Davis III, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign committee. "It was a great win for the president of the United States."
The outcome of marked a break with historic patterns in which the party that controls the White House almost invariably lost, rather than gained, seats in mid-term Congressional elections.
The result signaled a major change in the way Washington does business, in particularly, removing what Mr. Bush had repeatedly complained in recent days was Democratic opposition that had prevented him from winning confirmation of his judicial nominations and such measures as a permanent tax cut and a homeland security bill.
The result was a huge lift for Mr. Bush, who spent much of the past two weeks campaigning across the nation on behalf of Republican candidates for the House, the Senate and for governor. At the time, Democrats said that Mr. Bush was gambling his prestige on the outcome of the race. That was one bet that the president clearly appeared to have won last night.
Gov. Jeb Bush survived the fallout from his brother's disputed election in 2000 to win a second term in Florida, drawing an early-evening congratulatory call from the White House. In Maryland, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, a Democrat and a daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, lost her bid for governor to Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. -- the first time a Republican was elected governor of that state since Spiro Agnew was elected in 1966. Voters in Massachusetts, another of the most Democratic states, elected a Republican as governor, Mitt Romney.
Democrats were able to claim a handful of victories, like the one by Frank R. Lautenberg, the retired Democratic senator who reappeared on the political stage last month after Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey was forced aside by an ethics investigation. In one of the few dark moments for Republicans yesterday, Mark Pryor, the Democratic attorney general of Arkansas, toppled Senator Tim Hutchinson from office, while Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, won re-election.
The Democrats recaptured the governorships in Illinois, Pennsylvania and Michigan, important states in that could have significant bearing in the 2004 presidential race.
Still, the evening was more than a little discouraging for Democrats. In what would amount to biggest upset in Senate races, Representative Saxby Chambliss unseated Senator Max Cleland, a celebrated war hero and a Democrat from Georgia. Elizabeth Dole, a two-time cabinet secretary and Republican candidate for president in 2000, was elected senator from North Carolina, and Representative John E. Sununu Jr. won the Senate race in New Hampshire. Both Republicans withstood spirited challenges from Democrats, assuring that those two states remained in the Republican column.
The Republicans also sent Representative Lindsey Graham to fill the South Carolina Senate seat that was being vacated by Senator Strom Thurmond, while former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, a two-time presidential candidate, kept that state's Republican Senate seat.
"What a great night -- what a great victory," Mr. Sununu shouted to a crowd ecstatic that he had triumphed over the state's popular governor, Jeanne Shaheen.
In Louisiana, Senator Mary Landrieu, a Democrat, was forced into a runoff because t she drew less than 50 percent of the vote. The runoff, which would not be held until Dec. 7, could conceivably determine control of the Senate.
Democrats tried to put the best light on the outcomes last night, arguing that they had faced a tough task from the beginning because of Mr. Bush's high approval rating and the financial advantage enjoyed by Republicans. It was particularly distressing news for the Democratic leaders of the House and the Senate -- Senator Tom Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt. They are viewed as prospects for president and could be tarnished by the outcome.
"What you've got to look at is the incredible amount of special interest money that was on their side," said Mr. Gephardt, the House minority leader. "There were races where we were outspent 4 to 1, 5 to 1, the pharmaceutical companies probably spent $60 million across the country."
"And you've got a president at 65 percent approval," he said. "I think part of that comes from 9/11. The whole country's rightful reaction to the horrible attack on our country, that whole cluster of issues are still out there."
Republicans were potentially on the verge of a historic achievement. The party that controls the White House almost invariably loses House seats in off-year elections. Democrats broke that trend when Roosevelt was president in 1934, and when Bill Clinton was in the White House in 1998. But the Republicans have never gained seats in the House when a Republican was president.
Similarly, the party that controls the White House generally loses seats in the Senate, with a handful of exceptions, including 1962 under Kennedy and 1970 under Nixon.
The results came on what was, at least by virtue of the number of candidates on ballots in all 50 states, a huge day of voting, with potentially deep significance for how the nation is governed over the next two years as well as the dynamics of the presidential election of 2004. Margin of control in both the Senate and the House had not been this tight going into an election since the first term of the Eisenhower administration.
But it was also an occasion of unaccustomed suspense because of the collapse of the system of surveying voters leaving polls that has made early calls standard for elections for more than three decades.
The Voter News Service, a consortium of news organization that surveys voters to offer running forecasts of the outcomes of races, announced yesterday afternoon that its system had failed.
Governor Bush's defeat of over Bill McBride, a Tampa business executive, was not only welcomed by the White House, but was also a significant personal victory for Mr. Bush, who had returned repeatedly to Florida on behalf of his brother. For much of this campaign, it had seemed that Jeb Bush might pay in defeat for the contested victory of President Bush in Florida in 2000. It loomed as a particularly unwelcome development for the combative chairman of the Democratic Party, Terry McAuliffe, who had singled out Mr. Bush as his No. 1 target of the campaign.
The early results seemed to confirm what had been a Democratic concern in the final days of the campaign: the Democrats had failed to capture the political agenda and make a case against the Republicans on the economy.
For much of the campaign season, members of the House and the Senate were pulled off the campaign trail by the debate in Washington on President Bush's request for authority to remove President Saddam Hussein of Iraq from power. By early this week, Democrats were acknowledging that no matter the final outcome, any hope they had of, in effect, nationalizing the election had not been realized.
The race to succeed Mr. Torricelli was one of a dozen contests that were being closely watched by Democratic and Republican leaders anxious to see if the Democrats would retain what had been, until the death of Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, in a plane crash last month, a one-seat edge in the Senate. There were close races being fought for Mr. Wellstone's seat and in Missouri, Colorado, South Dakota and Arkansas.
The Democrats held periodic news conferences yesterday complaining about episodes of voting irregularities, but there was no indication of the degree of problems that tainted the presidential election in 2000 in Florida, or the Democratic contest for governor there earlier this year.

ORGANIZATION: SENATE (US); HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES (US); CONGRESS (US) 

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (91%); TOM HARKIN (89%); FRANK LAUTENBERG (89%); MITT ROMNEY (79%); MARY LANDRIEU (74%); MARK PRYOR (59%); ELIZABETH DOLE (59%); TOM DAVIS (59%); SAXBY CHAMBLISS (59%); LINDSEY GRAHAM (59%); JOHN SUNUNU (58%) BUSH, GEORGE W (PRES); NAGOURNEY, ADAM; BUSH, JEB (GOV); BUSH, GEORGE (FORMER PRES); TOWNSEND, KATHLEEN KENNEDY (LIEUT GOV); EHRLICH, ROBERT L JR (REPR); ROMNEY, MITT; LAUTENBERG, FRANK R; PRYOR, MARK (ATTY GEN); HUTCHINSON, TIM (SEN); CHAMBLISS, SAXBY (REPR); CLELAND, MAX (SEN); DOLE, ELIZABETH; LANDRIEU, MARY (SEN); GEPHARDT, RICHARD A (REP); HARKIN, TOM (SEN); SUNUNU, JOHN E (REP); THURMOND, STROM (SEN); GRAHAM, LINDSEY (REP)

LENGTH: 1592 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE GOVERNOR RACES; 
G.O.P. May Retain Its Lead in Statehouses

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Republicans scored upset victories last night in governor's races in Maryland, Massachusetts and Georgia, where an obscure former state senator named Sonny Perdue became the first Republican elected governor since Reconstruction.
 On a grim night for Democrats nationally, the party's candidates won the governor's offices in Illinois, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, throwing four populous potential roadblocks in the way of President Bush's drive to re-election in 2004. 
 But they failed to unseat Mr. Bush's brother Jeb as governor of Florida or the president's successor as governor of Texas, Rick Perry.
Republicans fared surprisingly well in the Northeast, easily winning re-election in New York and Connecticut while picking up the New Hampshire seat being vacated by Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat who chose to run for the Senate. 
They also recaptured the governorship of South Carolina, where Jim Hodges, a Democrat, was ousted after one term by former Representative Mark Sanford, who had attacked him over the state's lagging educational performance and economic fortunes.
While Democratic victories in the Midwest and the Southwest appeared likely to translate into a net gain in the number of governors' offices held by the party, Republican upsets in the South and the Northeast nearly offset those advances and may have preserved the Republican edge in control of the nation's statehouses. Heading into the elections yesterday, the Republicans held 27 governorships, the Democrats 21, and independents 2, in Minnesota and Maine.
In perhaps the most shocking upset of the night, Mr. Perdue, a onetime veterinarian who had made the football team as a walk-on at the University of Georgia, stunned Gov. Roy Barnes, a Democrat who had amassed a huge campaign war chest and led in every poll.
In Massachusetts, the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics organizer, defeated State Treasurer Shannon P. O'Brien, a Democrat.
In Maryland, Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a conservative congressman, ran as a moderate and became the first Republican elected governor since Spiro T. Agnew 36 years ago. Mr. Ehrlich defeated Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, who was criticized for a lackluster campaign.
An unusually large turnover of state chief executives, a result of term limits in most cases and retirements in a few, put more governor's offices within reach of the opposition party than at any other time in at least three decades. Democrats were hoping to recapture a majority of governorships for the first time in eight years.
But in Texas, Mr. Perry defeated Tony Sanchez, a petroleum tycoon who was on course to spend $70 million of his own money on his race.
And in Florida, Mr. Bush prevailed over Bill McBride, a lawyer who had beaten former Attorney General Janet Reno for the Democratic nomination. The closely fought and costly Florida campaign had drawn the president back to the state again and again to raise money and rally support for his brother.
"I want to thank our great president of the United States for coming down and lending a hand," Governor Bush said last night after being introduced to supporters by his father, the 41st president.
Republican incumbents also won in Nebraska, where Gov. Mike Johanns defeated a dark-horse Democrat, Stormy Dean, and in Ohio, where Bob Taft handily beat Tim Hagan, a former Cuyahoga County commissioner. In Colorado, Gov. Bill Owens turned back a challenge by Rollie Heath, a Democratic businessman. 
Republicans in Rhode Island retained the governor's office in a race between two business executives: Donald Carcieri, the winner, and Myrth York, the losing Democrat. 
Another Republican, Gov. Kenny Guinn of Nevada, easily won re-election over Joe Neal, a state senator who, with H. Carl McCall in New York, was one of two black candidates for governor nationwide. Republicans were successful in Idaho as well, where Gov. Dirk Kempthorne easily won re-election over Jerry Brady, a newspaper publisher from Idaho Falls. 
In South Dakota, where Gov. William Janklow was term-limited, a fellow Republican, former State Senator Mike Rounds, defeated Jim Abbott, president of the University of South Dakota. And in Arkansas, the Republican incumbent, Mike Huckabee, withstood a late surge by State Treasurer Jimmie Lous Fisher.
In the Vermont race, yet another Republican, State Treasurer Jim Douglas, led a field of 10 candidates. But he was short of 50 percent of the vote, meaning the race will be decided by the General Assembly, the state's legislature.
Much more was at stake in the three dozen contests for governor than the stewardship of state finances in a time of shrinking tax revenue and soaring deficits, issues that dominated all but a handful of campaigns.
Were there to be a wholesale shift in control of the nation's statehouses, it could carry enormous consequences for the 2004 presidential race, as governors oversee vast armies of party workers and priceless party infrastructure. Republican governors allied with Mr. Bush played a critical role both in his effort to capture the 2000 Republican presidential nomination and in the fall campaign against Al Gore.
In addition, governors dominate fund-raising at the state level, which is about to become far more important as a new campaign finance law limits the ability of political parties to raise money through their national committees.
Further, any Democratic gains in gubernatorial elections could give rise to a new crop of presidential contenders, just as the avalanche of new Republican governors in 1994 -- when the party captured a majority of governors' offices for the first time in a quarter-century -- created a farm system of candidates and cabinet officials.
A spate of new Democratic governors would also give the party new laboratories for policy experiments, just as Republican governors in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and elsewhere led the way in reshaping welfare programs and setting spending priorities as states raked in record surpluses throughout the 1990's.
To that end, Democrats did win important electoral territory in the industrial Great Lakes yesterday, including governor's offices in Illinois and Pennsylvania. 
In Illinois, Representative Rod R. Blagojevich defeated State Attorney General Jim Ryan, whose campaign was hampered by association with the Republican incumbent, George Ryan, leaving office under a cloud of scandal involving the trading of contracts and driver's licenses for campaign contributions.
In Pennsylvania, Edward G. Rendell, former mayor of Philadelphia and onetime Democratic national chairman, easily defeated Mike Fisher. The incumbent governor, Mark Schweiker, a Republican who succeeded Tom Ridge last year, did not seek election to a full term.
And in Republican-rich Kansas, the Democratic nominee, State Insurance Commissioner Kathleen Sebelius, defeated State Treasurer Tim Shallenburger, a conservative who had prevailed in the Republican primary over two moderates.
Democrats also made steep inroads in staunch Republican territory in the Southwest, winning governorships in Arizona, New Mexico and Oklahoma, and in the race for the open seat now held by a Republican in Tennessee.
In Arizona, where Gov. Jane Dee Hull was term-limited, State Attorney General Janet Napolitano defeated former Representative Matt Salmon. Bill Richardson, energy secretary in the Clinton administration, was elected governor of New Mexico, defeating John A. Sanchez, a state legislator. 
One of the biggest Democratic upsets of the night was State Senator Brad Henry's victory in Oklahoma over former Representative Steve Largent, a Republican seeking to succeed the term-limited Gov. Frank Keating.
In Tennessee, the Democratic nominee, Phil Bredesen, former mayor of Nashville, defeated the Republican, Representative Van Hilleary, in a close race in which both candidates attacked the Republican incumbent, Don Sundquist, nearly as much as each other.
Democrats also captured the governor's office in Maine, where Gov. Angus King, an independent, was term limited. In that race, Representative John Baldacci defeated Peter Cianchette, a former state legislator.
Of the five Democratic incumbents, Tom Vilsack of Iowa had the only easy re-election battle. He comfortably defeated Doug Gross, a lawyer and lobbyist, after what many had considered an exceedingly competitive race.
In his victory speech in Des Moines, Mr. Vilsack declared that "democracy is best when people work at the grass roots," and said the Democratic effort that helped elect him should be celebrated as a "return to grass-roots organizing."
Though the battle for Congress dominated the political scene throughout the year, the fight for power at the state level was no less pitched. The 36 races for governor produced 21 extremely competitive contests. 
While campaigns for the House and the Senate focused on terrorism, Social Security and health insurance costs, governors' races were shadowed by the nation's stalled economy, as incumbents or their chosen successors were kept on the defensive about budget deficits, squeezed spending for education and health care, and tax increases lurking around the corner. Members of Congress may bear little individual responsibility for the mounting federal deficit, after all, but governors are responsible for managing, and balancing, their budgets. 
Republicans have held a majority of governors' offices since 1994. But their past successes meant the party had more ground to defend this year: 23 of its 27 governors' offices were up for election.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Rod R. Blagojevich, a Democrat, thanked supporters last night in Chicago after he won the Illinois governor's race. Mr. Blagojevich defeated Attorney General Jim Ryan. (Associated Press)(pg. B7)

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Preston Bailey; 
A Single Rose Will Never Do

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

 BODY:
PRESTON BAILEY is quite an arrangement.
 Mr. Bailey, 53, an event designer who specializes in flowers, was wearing Versace (top), Armani (bottom) and Prada (boots) on Monday, sitting in a cream-colored club chair in his living room on lower Lexington Avenue, surrounded by flowering bougainvillea trees that had been tweezed like eyebrows until they were nothing but tropical leis wreathing the air -- ocean breezes with blossoms. 
 Mr. Bailey was giving a party for himself and a thousand guests the following night at the Rainbow Room, on the occasion of the publication of "Preston Bailey's Design for Entertaining" (Bulfinch, $45), his first book. But Mr. Bailey typically gives four or five parties a week for clients, working with event planners, so he didn't appear to be breaking much of a sweat. He was as natural as a pruned bougainvillea as he spoke. 
"I'm one of those people who believe more is better," he said, angled in his armchair as though he were wearing that, too. "If somebody's going to send me Champagne, send me a case. Twelve bottles, not one."
Mr. Bailey let out a high extended melodic tone that sounded like someone calling in a herd of goats, which is how he punctuates surprise or approval or just makes a point. He also likes to slap the arms of his chair, bounce himself a foot into the air and then land on the hip he wasn't using before he launched.
"I think 'over the top' is the most fun thing in the world to do," he said, which is good, because that's what Mr. Bailey does.
Mr. Bailey is the man who recreated czarist Russia (in winter) at the Plaza Hotel in 1998 for Joan Rivers, for the wedding of her daughter, Melissa, to John Endicott, which included a cathedral aisle of 20-foot-tall birch trees painted white with a "snowfall" of 30,000 white flowers hand-tangled into the blue-lighted branches. The bill for Mr. Bailey's decorations was $300,000. The couple separated this year.
Mr. Bailey designed the inauguration party for O, the Oprah Winfrey magazine, in 2000, with 12-foot-tall orchid trees and several thousand red flowers making a big "O." He has done fashion shows for John Galliano, and he did Liza Minnelli's Halloween party last week, with white not black. Mr. Bailey also designed Ms. Minnelli's wedding to David Gest this year. He has married as many people as a Las Vegas judge.
Anyone not from New York could fairly assume that Mr. Bailey lives in the grand ballroom at the Pierre, or in the penthouse at the St. Regis, or in the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- the city's great party spaces. In fact, he rents a two-room apartment, where he lives with Michael Speir, a graphic designer, and two cats, including a deaf 22-year-old calico.
Mr. Bailey, who started his event designing informally in 1980, is self-taught. He had a men's clothing store on Third Avenue, which went out of business in 1977.
"We sold very tight French suits," he said. Two friends, Vicente Wolf and the late Bob Patino, interior designers, put him to work providing flower arrangements for their Park Avenue clients.
"I absolutely did not know what I was doing," Mr. Bailey recalled. "I can't tell you the amount of mistakes." That means a lot of dead songbirds, so to speak, when you are working the exotic in flowers. Mr. Bailey bought flowers from retail florists to cover the attrition when clients walked into party setups, to check on them, just as the arrangements were starting to die. A money-losing venture initially, Preston Bailey Entertainment and Set Design now has an office of 15 employees on West 25th Street and annual billings of $2 million to $3 million.
"With thousands and thousands of flowers, it's a matter of timing it very carefully," Mr. Bailey said. "With experience, you realize that you have to get the flowers, you have to open them and you have to treat them properly." Peonies take two to three days to open, for example, and the temperature of the water you put them in will slow or speed the process. If you're having a dinner party, get started on the flowers at least the day before. If you live in New York, buy in the flower district, in the West 20's, on Tuesdays or Thursdays, when most of the imported flowers arrive.
"Clean the bottom leaves, and cut the stem, with an angled cut," Mr. Bailey said. "Make sure you give a flower clean water. Allow it to drink water -- flowers start becoming themselves when they've drunk a day's water."
Mr. Bailey also had advice on whom -- or what -- to follow home from the flower market.
"Roses," he said. "Romantic. If they like red, you know that they're hot, passionate people, so keep that in mind. If it's quantity, then you're really in -- three dozen at least. I have no use for the one-rose type."
Mr. Bailey was born in Panama. He moved to New York City at 19 to study accounting at Pace University. He has never lived anywhere else.
"This is hooooome," he said. (Goat-herding call, high bounce.) "I just couldn't wait to get out." He was raised in the countryside. "I don't need a country house. I'm very happy being in the city."
New York in 1969, when Mr. Bailey showed up, was "lots of drugs, lots of fun," he said. "I had just escaped from Panama. I didn't speak the language. Oh yes, I've been around."
Mr. Bailey, who is 6-foot-2 and built like an athletic dancer, said he has been sober for 12 years.
"I had a drug problem," he said. "Coke, alcohol, you name it. I went through the entire 'almost lose your home' kind of a thing." His therapist intervened, threatening to drop him as a patient if he didn't clean himself up.
Mr. Bailey said he thought the event design field was largely a New York phenomenon at the over-the-top level.
"Robert Isabell -- he is the grandfather of this entire industry," he said, speaking of the designer based on West 13th Street, who has his own line of perfumes. "Philip Baloun, and Renny. Well, Renny's an institution." Renny is Renny Reynolds of Renny, who got his start decorating Studio 54, the 1970's discotheque, every night, to keep it fresh for habitues like Halston and Liza Minnelli.
Mr. Bailey can tell the history of New York with flowers.
"It was the high-tech single-flower look in the 70's, and then it segued into the Hawaiian look," he said, as though he were reciting the alphabet. "Everything was very hard-stemmed -- birds of paradise, heliconias. Then the French and English abundance kind of a thing, much softer, much richer." This means roses and hydrangeas. Mr. Bailey was asked about irises.
"Seventies," he said. The 80's "went wild -- you couldn't get enough flowers." Then what happened?
"The recession happened!" he said. (Goat call, no bounce.) "We went back to the 'single' look. Simplicity, candlelight. We're still with it."
Mr. Bailey's corporate clients have scaled back their entertainments this year, or canceled them. Budgets in some cases have dropped by half; designs are strictly conservative, if that's possible in a world like Mr. Bailey's. The social side of the operation is still strong.
"People want to party," he said, something that became apparent last December, after the two chilling months succeeding Sept. 11.
On Tuesday night, Mr. Bailey stood on the revolving dance floor of the Rainbow Room, welcoming well-wishers. His evening arrangement: black Jean Paul Gaultier (top), Armani (bottom) and Prada (slippers).
Outside the famous windows, New York City at night looked like something Mr. Bailey might have designed. Inside, there were green baby elephants made of mums, with red rose saddles.
There is a difference between outrageous and fabulous, as Mr. Bailey explained on Monday, a distinction perhaps he and his adopted town understand better than most.
"You can decide to be outrageous," he said. "But you have to be crowned fabulous."
Ms. Minnelli and Mr. Gest walked down the stairs. Mr. Bailey's court was assembling.

(Meg Henson for The New York Times; top, Roger Dong)(pg. F1); EXTREME INDOOR/OUTDOOR -- Preston Bailey designed a Russian winter, above left, for the wedding of Joan Rivers's daughter, Melissa. Far right and above, the Moorish details in his living room, also home to five flowering bougainvillea trees, are from a party at Carnegie Hall. (Photographs by Meg Henson for The New York Times)(pg. F8)

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: Global Accounting Panel to Seek an Options Standard 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The International Accounting Standards Board, along with accounting regulators in Britain, Australia and New Zealand, will propose a rule today that would force companies to record the value of stock options issued to executives and employees as an expense. 
 The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets United States accounting rules, is expected to seek comment on the proposed international rule, with a view toward adopting it. Approval by the American board would produce the same accounting treatment in virtually all leading countries. 
 "We are saying that options are an expense," said Sir David Tweedie, the chairman of the international board. "All around the world, people are moving in the same direction." 
The proposed international standard calls for calculating the value of options in a way that is similar to the method now in use in the United States, which requires companies to make the calculation but gives them the choice of whether to deduct the expense from their income. But in the case of companies that are not yet public, the proposed international rule would call for a significantly higher value for the options -- a step that is sure to provoke opposition in high-technology industries.
The proposed rule is subject to public comment until March 7, 2003, after which the board is likely to hold hearings before adopting a provision. Sir David said the goal was to approve a rule in 2003 that would be effective at the end of that year, but said delays were possible.
American companies, led by high-technology businesses, which are the heaviest issuers of options, have long opposed rules to require the treatment of options as an expense. The American board was poised to do that in 1994, but retreated under heavy political pressure that was applied most directly by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, who argued that lower reported profits would make it harder for such companies to raise capital.
Many companies are gearing up to oppose the international rule as well. A group called the International Employee Stock Options Committee, supported by groups including the Business Software Alliance, Financial Executives International and the Nasdaq stock market, argued this week that "there is no accurate, reliable and meaningful method today to value stock options," and that valuations created by existing models are "inaccurate and misleading."
Sir David said that the board was open to proposals on better ways to value options, but he noted that the board had talked to numerous experts, including Myron S. Scholes, who won a Nobel Prize in economics for his work on options pricing. 
Kimberley Crook, a project manager at the international accounting board, acknowledged that measurements of options values are inexact. But Ms. Crook added, "People use this argument to say we should never put anything in the accounts."
She said "zero is never" going to be right.
One reason critics say that models do not reflect the value of employee options very well is that such options are not publicly traded. But Sir David said that the board's calculations take that into account by basing the calculation on a forecast of how long the option would remain outstanding, not on its maximum life. By reducing the 10-year life of most options to 4 or 5 years, the values will be reduced.
Another major component in options pricing models is volatility, with higher volatility translating into higher values. The proposed international rule would allow companies to assume that volatility will be lower in the future than it has in the past, but they would have to disclose how much lower the estimate was and give reasons for thinking that future volatility would be lower.
While the international board's proposal provides somewhat more leeway in valuing options than the current American rule does, and differs in some details, it is likely to produce similar values.
An exception is options offered by companies whose shares are not publicly traded. The American rule allows companies to effectively assume there is no volatility, and to value the options based only on the value of being able to delay paying for the stock. The international rule would require companies to estimate volatility, perhaps by looking at the trading of shares in similar companies.
That would lead to far higher values -- and to lower reported profits for companies preparing to make initial public offerings of their shares.
As in the American rule, the value of the option would be estimated on the date it was granted. It would be treated as an expense over the period until the option became vested -- that is, until it could be exercised -- but the value shown as an expense would not change even if the option was clearly very valuable, or virtually worthless, by the time vesting occurred.
One small change is that in the American rule the value of options that do not become vested are not charged to earnings, and if need be they are credited to earnings in later years to reverse earlier charges. For example, if a worker was granted options on 300 shares of stock, all to become vested in three years, the income statement would be charged with the value of 100 options in each of the three years. If the employee quit after two years, meaning that the options would not become vested, the value of the options already listed as an expense would be added back to profits.
Under the proposed international standard, the company would estimate the likelihood that the options would not become vested, and reduce their value based on that assumption. But the amount charged to expenses would not be affected by how many options did become vested. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ACCOUNTING (94%); ACCOUNTING STANDARDS (93%); BANKING & FINANCE REGULATION (90%); STOCK OPTIONS (90%); AGENCY RULEMAKING (89%); STANDARDS & MEASUREMENTS (89%); APPROVALS (78%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (78%); COMPANY PROFITS (77%); EMPLOYEE STOCK OWNERSHIP PLANS (77%); BUSINESS SOFTWARE (73%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (72%); NOBEL PRIZES (63%); PROJECT MANAGEMENT (60%); AWARDS & PRIZES (60%); COMPUTER SOFTWARE (50%) EXECUTIVES AND MANAGEMENT; ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS; STOCK OPTIONS AND PURCHASE PLANS 

COMPANY: NASDAQ OMX GROUP INC (52%)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
If the rich are becoming richer, are they also buying relatively more stuff?

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; Virginia Postrel is the author of "The Future and Its Enemies" and is writing a book on the increasing importance of aesthetics in the economy and society. E-mail: vpostrel@dynamist.com

 BODY:
THIS economic downturn seems weird. Business spending has dropped sharply, but consumers keep buying. That baffles a lot of analysts.
 Why don't consumers stop spending? Don't they know the economy is in bad shape? Is America just a nation of free-spending fools? A recent study of an entirely different subject -- income inequality -- suggests a rational explanation. 
 Economists generally agree that since the late 1970's, income inequality has increased in the United States. Top earners account for a larger percentage of total income, and college-educated workers command an increasingly large premium.
Equally striking, there is a broader spread of incomes among people of the same education, occupation, age or sex.
But the usual measures look at current income: what everyone is making at a given moment in time, not what people can expect to make (and spend) over their lifetimes.
"Looking at the distribution of current income is probably not a good enough measure of what you're really interested in, which is the distribution of well-being, the distribution of resources among Americans," says Fabrizio Perri, an economist at the Stern School of Business at New York University.
There are really two different components of income inequality: permanent differences and temporary fluctuations. People tend to base their spending on what they expect their long-term prospects to be.
Poor graduate students spend more than equally poor waitresses, because they can expect higher incomes later. Conversely, professional athletes have to save some of their big bucks to finance a comfortable life after sports.
To see how well-being is distributed, consumption provides a better long-run picture than income. In a paper titled "Does Income Inequality Lead to Consumption Inequality?" Professor Perri and Dirk Krueger, an economist at Stanford, look at the distribution of consumption from 1972 to 1998. The article, now a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper, can be downloaded at http://pages.stern.nyu.edu/fperri/research.htm.
If the rich were becoming richer in the 1980's and 90's, were they also buying relatively more stuff? And if the poor were becoming poorer, were they buying less?
"We wanted to see whether this rise in income inequality had in fact given rise to an increase in consumption inequality," Professor Krueger said. "We were fairly surprised that it hadn't."
The economists expected consumption to fluctuate less than income, since people can save in good times and borrow in bad times. But the results were far more marked than they anticipated: Even as the distribution of income changed significantly, the distribution of consumption barely budged.
A common measure of how spread out the income distribution is (the standard deviation of the log of after-tax labor income) increased 20 percent, while the same measure for consumption rose only 2 percent.
To take a single comparison, the poorest 20 percent of Americans made about 6 percent of all income in 1972-73 but only 4 percent in 1997-98. That substantial drop did not show up in their spending, however. It stayed flat, at about 9.2 percent of total consumption.
Or consider the ratio between the top and bottom. In 1972-73, the top 10 percent of earners made about five times as much as the bottom 10 percent. In 1997-98, they made more than nine times as much -- a sharp increase that, again, barely shows up in spending. The top 10 percent of households spent about three times as much as the bottom 10 percent in 1972-73, a ratio that inched up to 3.35 in 1997-98.
These results are particularly striking because the income figures include only wages and government benefits. Spending, by contrast, can come from all sources of money, including the stock market returns and other investment income enjoyed mostly by the wealthiest Americans. The high investment returns of the 1990's do not seem to have notably widened the spending gap between rich and poor.
It is hard to see the effects of increasing income inequality in how people actually live. In a theoretical model that fits the trends of the last two decades, the economists propose an explanation: Permanent income differences have increased just a little, while short-term fluctuations have increased a lot. What looks like increasing income inequality turns out to be mostly increasing income instability.
As incomes have become more unstable, consumers have benefited from more efficient ways to borrow and save. Better credit markets have kept consumption from becoming as lopsided as current income.
"The permanent inequality tends to push up consumption inequality," Professor Perri explained, "but the income instability would tend to push it down."
"People react by saving more and by borrowing more," he said, "so there's this development of credit markets."
In particular, it is much easier for consumers to borrow with credit cards or home equity loans than it was 20 years ago. Middle-class earners also have access to many more ways to save and invest.
When credit markets are well developed, people having a good year can save, providing money to be lent to people having a bad year. And the penalty for default -- being turned down for future credit -- is more serious, deterring careless borrowing.
How consumers react to economic news depends largely on whether they think it portends a permanent change in their incomes. That may explain, then, why consumers have kept spending despite the sluggish economy. They may be making less money, but they do not expect that situation to last forever -- and they have their credit cards to tide them over.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 6, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Nov. 7, about trends in consumer spending, referred incorrectly to ratios between top and bottom income groups from 1972-73 to 1997-98. The ratios, which rose sharply for income but only slightly for spending, measured the difference between people at the 90th percentile of income and those at the 10th percentile, not all those in the top 10 percent and the bottom 10 percent.

GRAPHIC: Photos: People tend to base their spending on what they expect their long-term prospects to be. A waitress might see her prospects differently than a young adult. (Herb Swanson, left; Barbara Alper) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ECONOMIC DECLINE (90%); INCOME DISTRIBUTION (90%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (90%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (89%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (78%); MARKET RESEARCH (78%); UPPER INCOME PERSONS (78%); CONSUMER BEHAVIOR (78%); BUSINESS EDUCATION (78%); WAGES & SALARIES (76%); COLLEGE STUDENTS (75%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (70%); STATISTICAL METHOD (70%); GRADUATE & PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS (70%) UNITED STATES ECONOMY; SALES; CONSUMER BEHAVIOR; WAGES AND SALARIES; INCOME

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: Label Mania Lends Dazzle to Humble CD's 

BYLINE:  By ROB FIXMER 

 BODY:
MARK SMITH, the owner of a small record store in Philadelphia, produces and distributes his own dance music on compact discs.
 In her home office in Bath, Ohio, Ann DeVilbiss creates customized demos of her video productions on CD's for potential clients. 
 Bill Isaacson, the Dallas-based regional manager for a large manufacturing concern, hands out CD-ROM's with full-color copies of his company's catalog in Microsoft Word format.
 And in Manhattan, Alex Dranovsky, a 22-year-old student at the School of Visual Arts, spends many hours creating compilation CD's of trance music to share with friends. 
 All four of these people represent typical users of computer CD burners, and each will tell you that what gives a home-brew CD a visceral appeal in business and social circles is less the disc or its contents than the label affixed to it.
 "A good label says it's a serious professional product," said Mr. Smith, who recently won a label design contest.
 The look is so important, in fact, that Mr. Isaacson, the Southwest regional manager for the Armorcast Products Company, a maker of equipment enclosures, said he "would never consider sending a customer a CD of my catalog if the label was even slightly off center."
 No longer just a paper ID with adhesive backing, the CD label has morphed into a cultural artifact, a medium for aesthetic expression ranging from simple colored backgrounds for directories of songs, photos or files to ambitious graphical designs, a sort of digital folk art for the new millennium.
 In fact, software developers say that designing or copying CD labels and inserts is now by far the most common use of desktop publishing by amateurs. Small businesses account for much of that volume for simple economic reasons: professional CD duplication services are costly and often require a run of several hundred or even 1,000 discs.
 But the most numerous users of CD labels today are consumers like Mr. Dranovsky, whose designs are motivated by a love of music rather than by business needs. Among this group's members the label has become an icon of legitimacy.
 "It's all about fun," he said of his label designs for the compilation CD's he shares with friends. But he also asserted that a label design says as much about a compilation as the musical selections and maybe even more about the person who compiles it.
 "When somebody gives me a CD, if it doesn't have a label, chances are I'll put it on the back burner and look into it three or four months later," he said. "But if they give it to me with a nice label, it definitely piques my interest. It says, 'Hey, I made this and I'm proud of it, and I want to do a little extra to give it a little pizazz.' If you give somebody a label with just a scribble on it with a Magic Marker, it shows you don't really care that much."
 Participants in a recent MSN chat about swapping MP3 files said they too took pride in the label designs of the CD's they made. "It's not cool to write on a disc," a participant declared. "If you're serious, you design your label from scratch, and it has to say something about the music."
 Several other participants in the chat room, an anonymous gathering place for college-age and high-school-age users of MP3 file-swapping services, were more divided about the correct labeling protocol for copying a commercial music CD. Some insisted that the label had to have a unique design; others preferred to scan in the original label and often the jewel box inserts as well.
 People without scanners often acquire exact copies of commercial CD labels by visiting Web sites like CDCovers.cc (www.cdcovers.cc), which bills itself as "the world's largest cover archive." The site offers free downloads of labels and jewel case inserts for nearly 120,000 audio CD's and thousands more labels for DVD's, videocassettes and game media. 
 Most of the labels and inserts have been scanned from originals by users of the site. Another site, the Mega-Search service (www.mega-search.net), says that its database directs users to 450 online sources for prescanned labels with a combined inventory of more than 500,000 CD covers. (Matt Oppenheim, who represents the Recording Industry Association of America in legal matters, warned that uploading or downloading such images is illegal because cover designs are included when record companies register the copyrights for CD's.)
 For do-it-yourselfers, there is also a wide and growing choice of CD labeling products. All of the market leaders offer startup kits with a few sample sheets of labels; design software that ranges from simple but limited to powerful but complex; and an applicator, typically a plastic spindle on a spring for aligning the label to the disc.
 Label choices have evolved into an expansive product family that includes glossy high-resolution photo-quality stock, solid colors, transparent film and metal foil. A few companies offer confetti and glitter backgrounds, which are marketed as "holographic" labels because they produce a three-dimensional illusion if you squint.
 "As a designer, I think it's awesome," said Ms. DeVilbiss, who designs motion graphics for television commercials. She distributes demos of her creations in Quicktime format on 8-millimeter "pocket" CD-ROM's. "I'm 42, but I see young kids out there doing MP3 CD's and they're making these wonderful labels," she said. "It's just great."
 Label manufacturers encourage the trend by sponsoring design contests.
 "This wasn't even a business a few years ago," said David Kennough, vice president for sales for the Neato division of Fellowes, which sponsored the competition won by Mr. Smith. This year, Mr. Kennough anticipates that he and his major competitors -- Avery/Stomper, Memorex and SureThing -- will sell more than 500 million CD labels.
 In fact, secondary label markets are already springing up. At least a dozen small developers offer software for designing and printing CD covers and other labels. An entrepreneur who goes by the online name 70's Dude now offers a small selection of generic "indie labels" at cut-rate prices at www.labels-cdrs.com.
 Beyond aesthetics, there are practical reasons to label a CD. First, contrary to popular belief, it is the top of the disc, not the bottom, that is most vulnerable to scratches and other damage that make a CD unreadable. A label helps protect the surface.
 And in an age when drivers are continually changing home-brew CD's in car stereos, a label can make disc changing easier.
 "It's harder to read writing than it is to recognize an image," Mr. Dranovsky said. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: PERFECTIONISM -- Mark Smith, shown at his store in Philadelphia, designed the insert at bottom center for a dance music CD. Top left, bottom left and far right, trance music labels and inserts by Alex Dranovsky; middle left, a demo label by Ann De Vilbiss. (Above and bottom center, Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ferrer Agrees To Take Over Banana Kelly Housing Unit 

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
The state attorney general's office announced yesterday that Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, would assume control of the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a Bronx neighborhood redevelopment group that has struggled in recent years amid questions about its finances and management practices.
 Under an out-of-court settlement negotiated with the attorney general's office, Banana Kelly's chairwoman and chief executive, Yolanda Rivera, as well the agency's board of directors, will step aside for Mr. Ferrer and others, including Harold DeRienzo, Banana Kelly's founder. Mr. Ferrer, Mr. DeRienzo and three new board members have agreed to serve until at least April 30. 
 Banana Kelly, a nonprofit organization that once owned or managed dozens of buildings in the South Bronx, has been under investigation by the attorney general for nearly two years.
The group became a much-studied model for neighborhood redevelopment after it was formed more than two decades ago by some South Bronx residents but has in recent years been more a model of disarray. Its buildings and finances became poorly maintained, and questions were raised about its oversight and management practices.
"In the past few years, this historic organization has fallen on hard times," said Mr. Ferrer, who is president of the Drum Major Institute for Public Policy. "Banana Kelly's residents and the community deserve better."
Under the settlement, the state investigators will discontinue their investigation into Ms. Rivera, who assumed control of Banana Kelly's day-to-day operations in 1991, and the current board. The attorney general's office, however, will continue to investigate Banana Kelly. The charities bureau of the office will work with the new board to conduct an internal review of Banana Kelly's finances and programs.
Last year, the group sold the management contracts to the last 25 buildings it controlled, although it has kept the title to the buildings and remains a provider of social services like rental assistance and mental health programs.
Some board members and former employees have raised questions about how government money has been used and about how Ms. Rivera is compensated. She failed to respond to several messages left at her office yesterday.
Federal prosecutors in Manhattan will continue to investigate Ms. Rivera, the attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, said.

HEADLINE: North Sea Cod Crisis Brings Call for Nations to Act 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: GILLELEJE, Denmark, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
The cod are disappearing from the deep gray waters that stretch to the horizon from this gull-festooned town, a stark reminder that there is a finite number of fish in the sea and that man's growing appetite for seafood, if left unchecked, could eventually drive many species to extinction.
 Scientists warned last month that unless almost all commercial fishing in the North Sea was banned, the cod stocks might soon collapse, meaning that the number of cod necessary to repopulate the overfished region could fall so low that the popular food fish might never recover. 
 "The cod are now so depleted we're not really sure of their population dynamics," said Henrik Sparholt, a fisheries assessment scientist at the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, which has advised closing the North Sea to most fishing indefinitely.
Mr. Sparholt said the number of North Sea cod was at its lowest level ever and was half of what was considered the minimum for assured propagation. 
The cod crisis is one of many facing the international community as countries compete for thinning stocks in the world's once fish-thick seas. Fish are the last food source hunted on a large scale in the wild, and the United Nations warns that the world's 17 main fisheries are fished at or above sustainable levels.
None of the endangered species of fish affects so many countries and so many people or has such historic significance as cod. Once known as "beef of the sea," it is the world's most popular food fish and was a driving force in the development of the global economy.
Thanks to their lethargic swimming style, cod are easy to catch and have the whitest flesh of all white-fleshed fish. The meat is low in fat, high in protein and easily filleted.
The low fat content makes it easy to cure and made it the perfect fish for marine provisions and international trade before the invention of refrigeration. The Massachusetts Bay Colony was established, in part, to make money by selling cod to England.
Cod stocks have collapsed before. The fish was once so abundant off the northeastern coast of North America that the Italian explorer John Cabot reported catching them with a bucket in 1497.
But after 500 years of increasingly intensive fishing and repeated warnings that the cod were endangered, they suddenly all but disappeared more than a decade ago. Despite a fishing ban, they have yet to come back in significant numbers.
Thinning cod stocks in the North Sea have worried scientists for years now, and though the European Union has fiddled with quotas and the sizes of net holes -- larger holes let younger fish survive until they can spawn -- it has been slow to offer the fish adequate protection. 
Part of the problem is that harsher measures would devastate the economies of towns like Gilleleje, where cod fishing is the biggest industry.
"I'm 57, and I have to work another 10 years because I have no pension," said Peter Andersen, winding a heavy green net onto the winch of his 56-foot blue and white trawler docked at the town's nearly empty harbor. "I wouldn't earn a living if I couldn't fish cod."
Hunching against a bitter wind, Mr. Andersen says increasingly restrictive quotas on cod catches have already shortened his annual fishing season from 10 months to 5. He supplements his income by catching lobster but says too many fishing boats are doing the same for the lobster to last if the cod industry is shut down.
Demand for cod rose sharply in the early 1900's after Clarence Birdseye developed his method for freezing food and the fish industry began filleting fish by machine. Then, in 1962, the owner of a McDonald's franchise in Cincinnati invented the Filet-O-Fish sandwich for Catholics who did not eat meat on Friday. Demand for cod surged again.
Today it is eaten in almost every country in the world. To meet demand, competing Danish and Scottish fishing fleets use nets that drag across the seabed and can sweep a mile or more of water free of fish in a matter of hours.
There are some areas where cod remain plentiful -- around Iceland and in the Barents Sea -- but the rest of the world's major stocks, relatively distinct populations of the fish that live in a particular region, are thinning rapidly or are already depleted. In the early 20th century it was not unheard of for fishermen to catch man-sized, 200-pound cod, but such old fish are rare these days.
Last year the European Commission put forward a plan devised to help North Sea cod stocks recover, but the fishery ministers of European Union members countries have bickered over the plan because it uses limits on the length of time that fishermen can spend fishing cod instead of quotas on the quantity they can catch.
The switch, intended to combat the chronic underreporting of catches, is unpopular because it could leave some countries with less fish than others if their fishermen were unlucky.
While the ministers argue, the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea says the situation has grown increasingly dire. The council, which makes policy recommendations to its 19 member countries, advised last month that until the cod recover, fishing should be banned altogether for most fish in the North Sea, the Irish Sea and the waters west of Scotland.
Because many cod are caught as a "bycatch" by crews fishing for other species in the region, the council's scientists want the ban extended beyond cod.
Franz Fischler, the European commissioner responsible for agriculture, rural development and fisheries, has blasted the European Union's fishery ministers for letting the situation go so far.
"It is galling after repeatedly warning of the dire consequences of inaction," he said in a speech delivered after the council made its advice public, "to see our worst fears realized."
Mr. Fischler said that if the European Commission's own scientific committee backs the council's advice when it delivers its report on cod stocks next Monday, he will propose a ban on cod, haddock and whiting fishing in the area, and substantial reductions in the quotas for other fish, until the ministers can agree on a longer-term solution.
But many marine biologists worry that politicians lack the will to sacrifice jobs for cod. With stocks so low, Mr. Sparholt says, anything less than a total, indefinite ban may leave the cod population vulnerable to nature's periodic environmental shocks, like changes in water temperature or a sudden drop in the food supply.
Such environmental variations are blamed in part for the failure of cod to rebuild their numbers off the North American coast. Scientists suspect that dwindling schools of capelin, a tiny fish eaten by cod, have hurt the cods' fertility there when its numbers were already reduced.
"You have to manage the stock so that it can cope with what nature has given before and will give in the future," Mr. Sparholt said over a plate of pickled herring in one of Copenhagen's canalside restaurants.
But even if the North Sea cod are saved, the pressure will likely move to other fisheries to meet the voracious appetite for fish sticks, fish and chips and fried fish sandwiches -- or it will go to other species. The more plentiful pollock, for example, is increasingly being used as a substitute for cod.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Andersen, on his fishing boat off Gilleleje, Denmark, with part of his catch. He says quotas on cod catches have already shortened his fishing season and fears that a ban would deprive him of his livelihood. (Henrik Saxgren for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fed's Statement on Cutting Interest Rates 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Open Market Committee, reduced its benchmark rate by half a percentage point:
The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points to 11/4 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50 basis point reduction in the discount rate to 3/4 percent. 
 The committee continues to believe that an accommodative stance of monetary policy, coupled with still-robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing important ongoing support to economic activity. However, incoming economic data have tended to confirm that greater uncertainty, in part attributable to heightened geopolitical risks, is currently inhibiting spending, production and employment. Inflation and inflation expectations remain well contained. 
 In these circumstances, the committee believes that today's additional monetary easing should prove helpful as the economy works its way through this current soft spot. With this action, the committee believes that, against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are balanced with respect to the prospects for both goals in the foreseeable future. 
Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were Alan Greenspan, chairman; William J. McDonough, vice chairman; Ben S. Bernanke; Susan S. Bies; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Jerry L. Jordan; Donald L. Kohn; Robert D. McTeer Jr.; Mark W. Olson; Anthony M. Santomero and Gary H. Stern. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Dallas and New York.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST; 
WISCONSIN

BYLINE:  Nichole M. Christian, John H. Cushman Jr., Sherri Day, Sam Dillon, Neil A. Lewis, Robert Pear, Terry Pristin, Philip Shenon, Jacques Steinberg and Leslie Wayne contributed to this report.

 BODY:
Among the Democrats to take a governorship from the Republicans was Jim Doyle, the state attorney general, who will assume office on a platform of balancing the state's budget and putting an end to the political corruption that led to charges against leaders of both parties in the State Legislature in the last year.
 Mr. 
Doyle ousted the incumbent, Scott McCallum, who was filling the two-year vacancy created when Tommy G. Thompson, the popular and influential former governor, was brought into President Bush's cabinet as secretary of health and human services. Mr. McCallum had held state office since 1976, when he was just 26. But his brief tenure as governor came at a tough time, and he seemed to take the blame for high unemployment and a big budget deficit. 
 The two candidates and their supporters spent an estimated $20 million on the race, a record for the state, and much of the money went into negative advertising. The technique did little for Mr. McCallum, who never got much traction in the polls. His effort late in the campaign to link Mr. Doyle to the state scandals, calling him "crooked," appeared to backfire. Perhaps because voters were unhappy with the nasty tone of the race, Mr. Thompson's brother, Ed Thompson, running on a Libertarian ticket, made a strong showing as a third-party candidate.
The state's entire House delegation was re-elected, returning three Republicans and four Democrats to Washington for two more years. None of the races were close.

GOVERNOR
100% reporting

Doyle: 800,971 (45%)
McCallum: 732,796 (41%)
Thompson: 185,085 (10%)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: NORTHEAST; 
MARYLAND

BYLINE:  Nichole M. Christian, John H. Cushman Jr., Sherri Day, Sam Dillon, Neil A. Lewis, Robert Pear, Terry Pristin, Philip Shenon, Jacques Steinberg and Leslie Wayne contributed to this report.

 BODY:
Neither Kathleen Kennedy Townsend's middle name nor her support for gun control, an issue whose importance grew quickly during the recent sniper attacks, could help her beat her Republican challenger, Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. He was elected the state's first Republican governor in three decades. 
 From the very start of his campaign, Mr. Ehrlich said Ms. Townsend, the state's lieutenant governor, was as much to blame for its economic problems as the departing governor, Parris N. Glendening. Mr. Ehrlich painted himself as a fiscally conservative antidote to Maryland's problems. 
 Paul Herrnson, director of the Center for American Politics and Citizenship at the University of Maryland, said one of the smartest things Mr. Erlich did as a Republican in a heavily Democratic state was to link Ms. Townsend to Governor Glendening. "He was a very unpopular governor who became like an anchor around Townsend's neck," Mr. Herrnson said.
An eight-term incumbent, Representative Constance A. Morrella, a Republican, lost her race to Christopher Van Hollen Jr., a 43-year-old state senator.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: MIDWEST; 
MISSOURI

BYLINE:  Nichole M. Christian, John H. Cushman Jr., Sherri Day, Sam Dillon, Neil A. Lewis, Robert Pear, Terry Pristin, Philip Shenon, Jacques Steinberg and Leslie Wayne contributed to this report.

 BODY:
After Senator Jean Carnahan, the Democratic incumbent, conceded that she had lost to Jim Talent, a conservative Republican from the suburbs of St. Louis, Republicans nailed down control of the Senate. 
 Mrs. Carnahan, who was appointed to the Senate two years ago after her husband's death in a plane crash, did well in St. Louis and Kansas City, but that was not enough to overcome Mr. Talent's strength elsewhere. 
 The two candidates raised a total of more than $18 million. President Bush visited the state five times to assist Mr. Talent, while prominent Democrats, including Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, showed up for Mrs. Carnahan.
Republicans suggested that Mrs. Carnahan, who had never held elected office, was not up to the Senate job. Mr. Talent, a former four-term congressman who served eight years in the State House of Representatives and ran unsuccessfully for governor in 2000, said he had more experience. Mrs. Carnahan said she could handle the responsibility, as another Missourian, Harry S. Truman, did when he became president after the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Mr. Talent promised tax cuts to stimulate the economy and create jobs. Mrs. Carnahan, who portrayed herself as a centrist, won support from labor unions and women's groups. She promised to resist cuts in Social Security while providing prescription drug benefits under Medicare.
A staunch supporter of his party after Republicans took control of the House in 1994, Mr. Talent softened the sharp edges of his political persona in this year's campaign.

SENATE
100% reporting

Talent: 931,423 (50%)
Carnahan: 907,892 (49%)

LENGTH: 696 words

HEADLINE: Tiptoeing to Defeat 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The Democratic Party is like an army that dutifully goes off to battle but leaves its ammunition and its principles behind. It's bad enough to lack the firepower that you need to win. It's worse to not even know what you're fighting for.
 Despite the economic burdens that the middle and working classes are shouldering, despite the two million jobs lost and the scandalous concentration of wealth and income in the precincts of the very rich, the Democrats have yet to offer a compelling alternative to the reverse Robin Hood policies of the G.O.P. 
 Throughout this year's campaign, the Democrats let the president bang the cynical war drums on Iraq whenever and however he wished. Other important issues -- the economy, employment, the administration's appalling environmental record, the threat to abortion rights and civil rights posed by the president's federal court nominees -- were largely pushed aside, to the delight of Republicans nationwide. 
Republicans didn't win control of the Senate on Tuesday. The clueless Democrats lost it.
There was a time when Democrats had some fire. "I never give them hell," said Harry Truman. "I just tell the truth and they think it's hell." That was then. Now the Democrats proceed on tiptoe, always afraid they might say the wrong thing, vote the wrong way, get burned. The party of Roosevelt, Truman and the Kennedys has morphed into the party of timidity.
Consider the fiasco in Minnesota. Many of the Democrats who loudly lamented the loss of Senator Paul Wellstone in a plane crash had for years considered his fierce commitment to principle to be, at best, a little weird. He had an agenda and there was room in it for working people and the poor. Democrats have come to think of that as dangerous terrain. 
But when Senator Wellstone died, the national Democrats, panicked at the prospect of losing their one-vote hold on the Senate, were quick to exploit the sympathy factor in an effort to save his seat. And that backfired.
When a televised memorial for the senator turned into a now-notorious campaign rally (at which Democrats were cheered wildly and some Republicans were booed), voters were turned off in large numbers. It was a fiasco that extended beyond Minnesota. Not only did the Democrats lack a message, they seemed also to lack class. 
The bottom line: Paul Wellstone was actually ahead in the polls at the time of his death. Walter Mondale, who was dusted off and sent out to run in his stead, was defeated.
In New York, which should be Democratic heaven given the party's lopsided registration advantage, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Carl McCall, lost to the Republican incumbent, George Pataki, by 16 points. Mr. McCall, a decent, affable man, did little more in the campaign than wave his resume. He rallied no one and he lost big time.
The leadership void among Democrats is dangerous for both the party and the nation. The courts are being shaped by right-wing Republicans for decades to come. And there is a particular need for elected officials willing to fight for the interests of ordinary families and individuals who are struggling to keep up with such fundamental expenses as mortgages and tuition.
Affordable housing is a huge national issue, and alarms that are increasingly loud are summoning our attention to the problems of hunger and homelessness. These are issues that get incredibly short shrift in a plutocracy. They are Democratic issues. Or at least they were when the Democrats had some fire.
A fresh start is needed. New voices and new strategies must be heard. It's time for Democrats everywhere to look in the mirror and determine who they really are, and what they really stand for. Those who favor what the Republicans favor are not really Democrats.
Lyndon Johnson is not held in very high esteem at the moment, which is too bad. He never ran away from the poor and working people. He brought us Medicare and Medicaid and student loans and Head Start and Upward Bound and consumer protections and housing assistance -- just a whole litany of those sorts of things.
But that was another era, when Democrats had energy and ideas and values they believed in and the courage to lead. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (90%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (90%); RESUMES & CURRICULA VITAE (89%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (89%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (89%); VOTERS & VOTING (88%); POLITICS (78%); ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (75%); CIVIL RIGHTS (74%); GOVERNORS (72%); ABORTION (53%); AIRCRAFT ACCIDENTS (50%) UNITED STATES POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS 

ORGANIZATION: SENATE (US) 

PERSON: HERBERT, BOB 

GEOGRAPHIC: MINNESOTA, USA (92%); NEW YORK, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (92%); IRAQ (79%)
