PUB-DATE: November 7, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section A; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 814 words

PERSON: Lynden B. Miller 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
An Address on Fifth, but She's No Hothouse Flower

BYLINE:  By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
"MY friend Elizabeth -- a very nice lady -- once told me, 'We have to work harder than anyone else to be taken seriously,' " Lynden B. Miller, designer of public gardens, is saying while heading down Fifth Avenue after a garden tour. The tiniest pause. "Because of the way we look."
 This is an ambiguous phrase, and there is a possibility that she is referring to the "lady gardener" look. The miniature watering can hanging from a string around her neck; the two "New Yorkers for Parks" pins; the holsterlike leather belt that holds her clippers. In short, a wacky tree hugger, an assumption, if you hear Ms. Miller describing the Conservatory Garden as her third child or referring to the "gloooo-rious" chrysanthemums, you might make. 
 But, one senses, this is not the look to which Ms. Miller, with the Social Register listing, is referring. 
You're talking about an "address on Fifth Avenue" sort of bias, Ms. Miller?
She gives a closed-mouth reply and a sidelong glance of the sort one gives when confirming something one would prefer not to discuss: "Mmmmmmmm." 
That, Ms. Miller quickly adds, was 20 years ago and she has worked very hard to be taken seriously, which, of course, she now is. Credited with rescuing the Conservatory Garden, at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, in the 1980's, Ms. Miller, 63, runs a design firm from her home and is paid for her work. She has designed the gardens of some of New York's loveliest parks: Bryant in Midtown and Wagner in Lower Manhattan. 
She was a painter for many years and talks of parks as a collage, but spending a few hours with her is also reminiscent of being with a politician on a stump. Ms. Miller grew up in Washington, and returned there after graduating from Smith and to work for a senator. Her husband, Leigh M. Miller, was the deputy assistant administrator in the Agency for International Development in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations. Her son Gifford Miller is City Council speaker.
Ms. Miller has a platform, and she hammers it home: Parks make everyone feel better. They bring down crime. They're good for the economy. The finest have been paid for with private funds; the city should step up to the plate, for in poorer neighborhoods, private money is wanting.
It was Ms. Miller who conceived of last year's Daffodil Project, in which a million bulbs were planted around the city in commemoration of Sept. 11. 
NEXT week, as co-chairwoman of New Yorkers for Parks, an advocacy group, she will be inaugurating the Daffodil Project as an annual event. Her organization will also be honoring Hans van Waardenburg of B & K Bulbs, the Dutch businessman who contributed the bulbs, and Adrian Benepe, the city's parks and recreation commissioner. But, truth be told, it was Ms. Miller who masterminded the gift and the style of a practiced hostess, and back in the Fifth Avenue apartment, where rooms with richly colored walls melt into rooms with richly colored walls, and a once feral Conservancy Garden cat lolls on chintz, she tells the tale.
The Dutch benefactor? "Ah, the divine Hans, the bulb guy," Ms. Miller sings out. 
Then, "Sept. 11, I was mourning Wagner Park," Ms. Miller says. "I was sure Wagner Park was dead. I didn't know anyone who died, but I grieved for Wagner Park." 
When a fax arrived from Mr. van Waardenburg, Ms. Miller answered it with a handwritten fax of her own, in big, loopy writing, which, while it may be sexist to call women's college script, is hard to imagine coming from a fellow:
"Isn't it awful?! I think Wagner Park is probably destroyed, though I don't know that. I have an idea that we could plant bulbs all over the city in memory of this in all the parks -- (1,700 parks). Do you think that the Dutch bulb growers would donate any? I could also try to raise $ --."
Pretty smooth, she is told.
"I was being very subtle. I didn't want to ask him directly, because I knew how generous he was."
It sure sounds like she asked him directly.
"I did, but I was subtle; this is me being subtle," Ms. Miller says. "What I didn't want to do was put him on the spot."
Whom she doesn't mind putting on the spot: politicians. As a board member of the Parks Council, which has since become part of New Yorkers for Parks, she worked toward making increased funds for parks an issue in the 2001 mayoral campaign. She speaks proudly of a rally in Union Square, which had representatives of 1,000 city parks, she says. The organization also convinced five out of six candidates to sign a pledge to "work to restore the funding of the parks to 1 percent of the city budget." It was not a firm commitment, and many thought it too ambiguous, but Ms. Miller considered it a victory.
Then came Sept. 11, Ms. Miller says, and there went that. No matter, her organization will continue to work. You doubt her ability?
"I helped get a son no one had heard of elected," she says. "I've worked in campaigns."

GRAPHIC: Photo: LYNDEN B. MILLER (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Biography

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE ELECTORATE; 
Familiar Results Belie Voting Bloc Breakdown

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
In three successful runs for governor, George E. Pataki's share of the total vote has barely changed -- 49 percent in 1994, 54 percent in 1998 and 49 percent on Tuesday.
 That looks like a static electorate, but those numbers disguise dramatic changes in where the Republicans' and Democrats' votes are coming from. Tuesday's election added a new chapter to what may be the most significant long-term story in New York politics: the breakdown of geographic and ethnic voting blocs whose party allegiances were once bred in the bone. 
 "Every part of the state is more competitive than it used to be, and every group of voters is more up for grabs," said Michael McKeon, the governor's communications director. "Neither party can take anyone for granted any more." 
The traditional patterns are still there, but weaker, and they show themselves in legislative races and statewide contests that draw little attention. Tuesday's election for state comptroller was a perfect example: the Democrat, Alan G. Hevesi, won overwhelmingly in the city; the Republican, John J. Faso, won easily upstate; and they were competitive in the suburbs.
But in high-profile contests, that template is less true each year.
In three elections, the share of the New York City vote won by Mr. Pataki, a Republican, rose from 28 percent to 33 percent to 39 percent -- the latter being the best showing by a Republican candidate for governor in the last half-century.
The trend for Mr. Pataki in upstate New York, the longtime Republican stronghold, has been in the opposite direction, from 62 percent to 57 percent to 51 percent.
Mr. Pataki benefited from New York City voters' growing willingness to go with Republicans, a trend that has produced three successive Republican mayoral victories for the first time in the city's history. But he also shrewdly nurtured that trend, courting labor unions and Hispanics, normally Democratic pillars.
With legislative deals worth billions of dollars to raise worker salaries, the governor cemented his relationships with the two most politically powerful labor groups, 1199/S.E.I.U., the health care workers union, and the United Federation of Teachers. He won the endorsements of those and other unions, giving him access to thousands of foot soldiers in the city who ordinarily would be in the Democratic camp.
The health workers union sent more than a million pieces of mail to its members urging a vote for Mr. Pataki, and on Election Day it had 4,000 volunteers on its get-out-the-vote effort and 80 people calling voters from dawn to dusk.
Mr. McCall, who won 53 percent of the vote in the city, also had union backing, but not as potent as the governor's. Democrats traditionally rely on the unions for much of their get-out-the-vote effort, and union leaders on both sides said that the effort for Mr. McCall was anemic.
The split among unions kept the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., the umbrella group for all of them, from taking sides, an important factor in marshalling Election Day resources. "A Democratic candidate is traditionally at 70 percent or higher in New York City, but when the unions are split, and some are neutral, you can't do that," said Denis M. Hughes, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O.
The governor's political advisers have said that the key to the Republican Party's survival in an increasingly Democratic and nonwhite state is to win over the Hispanic population. Mr. Pataki methodically chased that vote for the last two years, learning some Spanish and using it frequently, building alliances with Hispanic officials, becoming a vocal opponent of naval bombardment on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques, and visiting Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republican.
No exit polls are available yet from Tuesday, but John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University Graduate Center, analyzed votes by election district and estimated that Mr. Pataki won 38 percent of the Hispanic vote, to 56 percent for Mr. McCall. That is a marked change from 1998, when Mr. Pataki won 25 percent.
Mr. Mollenkopf said his analysis showed that Mr. Pataki fared better than ever among Jewish voters, but that black voters kept to their traditional support of Democrats, with well over 90 percent voting for Mr. McCall, who is black.
Mr. Pataki's biggest improvement by county was in the Bronx, the state's most Hispanic county, where he won 31 percent of the vote, up 8 percentage points from 1998. In the heavily South American communities in central Queens, he won an outright majority.
Mr. Pataki's declining vote upstate is partly a product of the growing appeal of Tom Golisano, the Rochester billionaire running on the Independence Party line, who won 22 percent of the upstate vote. But the Republicans' grip on upstate has clearly slipped in recent elections, and Mr. Golisano's success there can be read as a protest vote against the governor in a region where people are suffering from economic stagnation.
Mr. McCall took 24 percent of the upstate vote, a showing that is stronger than it appears. He was badly outspent in a three-way race, and split the anti-incumbent vote with Mr. Golisano. His counterpart four years ago, Peter F. Vallone, won just 17 percent upstate, and Mario M. Cuomo, in 1994, took only 33 percent and nearly won the election.
Traditionally, the downstate suburbs have been a political battleground, with a Republican leaning. A long string of elections for county offices, legislative seats and other posts shows the suburbs becoming more fertile terrain for Democrats.
But Mr. Pataki has established an absolute stranglehold on the region, meaning that a huge number of voters now regularly split their ballots. He won 49 percent of the suburban vote in 1994, 62 percent in 1998, and 59 percent on Tuesday.
"It really does look as if a lot of the demographic voting patterns are breaking down," Mr. Mollenkopf said, "and I'd guess that will continue."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday on his way to the first news conference after his resounding election victory. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times) ; Chart/Map:Gov. George E. Pataki's Support in New York City Increased Between 1994 and 2002 . . . Map of New York City highlights the areas of the winner's vote percentage in 1994 and 2002 . . . With Growing Popularity Among White and Hispanic Voters Map of New York City highlights the different races and ethnicities and where they live. (William McNulty, Andrew Phillips and Josh Barbanel/The New York Times/The New York Times)(Sources: Election data from Associated Press and Prof. John Mollenkopf, City University of New York; Race and ethnicity data from 2000 Census)

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: FED CUTS KEY RATE BY ONE-HALF POINT IN AGGRESSIVE MOVE 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut its main interest rate today by half a percentage point, an aggressive move to ward off renewed economic weakness at a time when threats of terrorism and an impending confrontation with Iraq are weighing down business and consumer confidence.
 As the political parties in Washington digested the economic policy implications of Tuesday's Republican victory in the midterm election, the Fed put aside internal differences over the need for further rate cuts and voted unanimously for the half-point reduction. The step was intended to stimulate business investment and consumer spending by lowering borrowing costs. 
 But the Fed also hinted that it does not plan to cut rates again when it next meets in five weeks, reflecting a view at the central bank that rates are now low enough and that it is in any case running out of room to reduce them much further. 
Economists said the United States would now have to rely increasingly on stimulative fiscal policy -- some combination of tax cuts and increased government spending -- to give the economy a boost if it does not bounce back soon.
With Republicans now in control of the Senate as well as the House and the presidency, analysts said Congress is likely to take up a package of new tax cuts early next year.
The Fed's action today generated a mixed response on Wall Street, where stock prices first rose right after the announcement, then fell sharply before gaining ground again as investors sought to sort out the economy's prospects and the altered political landscape. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 8,771.01, up 92.74. The Nasdaq composite index rose 17.82, to close at 1,418.99.
The central bank cut its federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks to 1.25 percent, its lowest level since July 1961, from 1.75 percent, where it had been for 11 months.
It also cut its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system by half a percentage point, to 0.75 percent from 1.25 percent.
The reductions will put downward pressure on interest rates for some types of business and consumer loans, especially those tied to the prime lending rate, which fell at many banks today in lock step with the Fed's move. The effect is likely to be less pronounced on mortgage rates, which depend largely on movements in longer-term bond prices.
It is not clear how much of a boost the economy will get from the rate cut. While lower interest rates have supported automobile sales and helped homeowners by encouraging waves of mortgage refinancing, they have had little effect on what is perhaps the biggest problem afflicting the economy: the reluctance of businesses to invest in new plants and equipment at a time when they are laden with overcapacity and face uncertain demand for their products.
After having cut the federal funds rate by 5.25 percentage points in less than two years, the Fed also now faces the question of whether to conserve the limited monetary ammunition it has left as its main rate effectively approaches the zero point, a consideration that has troubled the Japanese for years.
The Fed's decision came after several weeks in which economic indicators were weak or declining, leading some forecasters to predict that growth would slow to a crawl in the fourth quarter. 
But it also came after a weeks-long recovery in stock prices that seemed to reflect a judgment by investors that the worst for the economy might be past or soon would be. 
In the end, the Fed's decision seemed to be as much about addressing unsettled investor, consumer and business psychology as about reacting to hard numbers, reflecting the belief of Alan Greenspan, its chairman, that human nature is as often as not the main variable in times of economic stress.
It amounted to a a sharp turnaround from the Fed's last meeting, in September, when it held rates steady despite calls from at least 2 of its 12 voting members for an immediate rate cut.
"This was a 'feel-good' policy action," said Kenneth T. Mayland of ClearView Economics, a consulting firm. He noted that sectors of the economy sensitive to interest rates, like housing and automobiles, are already vigorous and that the Fed's rate cuts ripple through the economy with long lags rather than providing a quick boost.
Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist for High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm, said the Fed's real intention was "to calm the nerves of the market" until the economic indicators begin to improve.
In a statement explaining its action, the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee was careful to avoid suggesting that the economy had any deep-rooted problems that might lead it to stall again a year after emerging halfheartedly from the first recession in a decade. It emphasized that interest rates are already low enough to support an economic rebound, and that in the long run the economy is benefiting for an upturn in productivity, or business efficiency.
Instead, the Fed characterized the economy as being held back by a lack of confidence, linked in part to the possibility of a war and further terrorist attacks. Suggesting that it will not rush into further rate cuts, the Fed shifted its outlook for coming months to neutral from its previous assessment that the economy was at risk of a slowdown.
The statement said today's rate cut "should prove helpful as the economy works its way through this current soft spot."
In moving to a neutral outlook, the Fed said the risks to the economy were now balanced between a return of inflation and further economic weakness, a formulation that seemed to minimize any concern that the economy was on the brink of deflation, or a generalized decline in prices. 
Still, by cutting rates half a percentage point today, a bigger step than many analysts had expected, the Fed was following the playbook it has developed for dealing with a situation in which deflation is a risk and interest rates do not have much further to fall.
In an internal staff paper written earlier this year, the Fed concluded, based on a study of Japan's failure to deal effectively with a similar situation, that central banks should cut rates early and aggressively when confronted with deflation, even if official short-term rates are already approaching zero.
Acting aggressively now, however, gives the Fed that much less flexibility to cut rates next year, should the economy suffer a big shock like a spike in oil prices related to a war with Iraq.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "The Last Rate Cut?"The Federal Reserve yesterday cut its target rate one-half point to 1.25 percent. But it shifted its view about the balance of risks from a worry over economic weakness to a neutral stance, suggesting that the Fed may not cut further unless the economy suffers another setback. Graph shows the Fed funds target rate with the balance of risks (inflation (higher rates), weakness (lower rates), neutral) since 1999. (Source: Federal Reserve)(pg. C12)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Trying to Spur Recovery, Fed Cuts Interest Rate
The Federal Reserve cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point, an aggressive move to ward off renewed economic weakness at a time when the terrorist threat and the confrontation with Iraq are weighing down business and consumer confidence.
 But the Fed hinted that it does not plan to cut rates again when it meets in five weeks, reflecting a view within the central bank that rates are low enough. Page A1. 

Cisco Says Revenue Is Flat
Cisco Systems, which became a technology bellwether in the 1990's, said that it had earned $618 million in its first quarter, compared with a net loss of $268 million a year ago. The company said revenues were nearly flat with the previous quarter and predicted little improvement in the current quarter as purchasers of its equipment remained cautious. C5.

Global Panel Seeks Accounting Rule
The International Accounting Standards Board, along with regulators in Australia, Britain and New Zealand, will propose a rule requiring companies to record stock options issued to executives and employees as an expense. The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets rules in America, is expected to seek comment, with a view toward adopting the rule. World Business, Section W.

American Plans New Round of Cuts
American Airlines said that it was planning additional cost cuts. But the airline does not plan to seek pay cuts from its unions as it seeks to save up to $4 billion a year. C9.

Tenet Faces Review of Medicare Fees
Federal regulators are planning a comprehensive review of Medicare reimbursements to Tenet Healthcare, the company said. C18.

Justices Hear Asbestos Case
Supreme Court justices, hearing arguments in an asbestos liability case, were asked to decide whether workers who suffer asbestos-related illness can sue for additional damages. C18.

Swiss Insurer Ousts Its Chief
Swiss Life dismissed its chief executive, Roland Chaplowski, whose short term has been marred by two embarrassing accounting errors and by the use of an investment vehicle that profited its top executives. Rolf Dorig, left, 45, will succeed Mr. Chaplowski. He is Swiss Life's third chief executive this year. World Business, Section W.

Adelphia Sues Its Former Auditor
Adelphia Communications sued its former accountants, Deloitte & Touche, accusing the firm of either knowing of wrongdoings and failing to disclose them or not knowing about them and being negligent. Deloitte said it, and the public, had been deceived by Adelphia. C17.

Trying to Add Sass to Hot Sauce Ads
Frank's Red Hot Cayenne Pepper Sauce, one of the oldest entrants in the competitive market for hot sauces, is receiving a makeover from its new agency. Frank's hopes the campaign will inject some sass and sauciness in what until now has been a staid brand. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.

2 Components of Income Inequality
Economists generally agree that since the 1970's, income inequality has only increased. But income inequality has two different components: permanent differences and temporary fluctuations. And people tend to base spending on their long-term prospects. Economic Scene: Virginia Postrel. C2.

HEADLINE: National Urban League's Chief Is Stepping Down After 8 Years 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Hugh B. Price, who has been among the nation's most outspoken civil rights advocates in his eight years as president of the National Urban League, said yesterday that he would step down by mid-April.
 Mr. Price, 60, a lawyer, told its board in a memo: "I believe very strongly that leaders of national organizations like the League should not cling to their positions interminably." 
 In an interview, he said he was seeking a new professional challenge and wanted to "recalibrate the balance between my professional and personal lives" after a grueling regimen of travel for the league, which kept him away from his Westchester County home during 38 weeks and 19 weekends in the last year.
Michael J. Critelli, the chief executive of Pitney Bowes Inc. and chairman of the league's board, said in a news release that he would name a committee to seek a new president. He praised Mr. Price's "legacy of strong leadership."
The league, based in Manhattan, was founded in 1910 and has affiliates in more than 100 cities. When Mr. Price was appointed president in July 1994, it was under financial pressure and was forced, like other civil rights organizations, to re-examine its focus in light of the changing economic and political status of African-Americans.
Mr. Price graduated from Yale Law School in 1966 and from 1978 through 1982 was a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, where he wrote about issues like public education, welfare and telecommunications.
He was a vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation when he became the league's chief executive, making organizational changes and working to improve its finances. He helped to recruit several senior executives at large corporations to serve on the league's board. And according to his memo, the league has operated with budget surpluses for six years.
He has also maintained cordial relations with the Clinton and Bush administrations, while criticizing their policies on education, capital punishment, support for the United Nations and other issues. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE; 
Hevesi Elected Comptroller, His Opponent Concedes

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
Eighteen hours after the polls closed in the tightest statewide election in New York, John J. Faso, a Republican assemblyman, conceded yesterday that he had lost the campaign for state comptroller to his Democratic opponent, Alan G. Hevesi.
 Although early unofficial results showed that Mr. Hevesi, the former New York City comptroller, was more than 110,000 votes ahead, Mr. Faso did not concede the race on election night, with aides saying it was too close to call. 
 Yesterday morning his aides still spoke of waiting for the official vote tally, which is to be tabulated next week. 
But by midafternoon Mr. Faso announced that he had called Mr. Hevesi to congratulate him on his victory. Mr. Faso said in a statement that a review of the election results made it clear that in all likelihood, "Neither the ballots remaining to be counted nor the recanvass could alter the results as they now appear to be."
The concession capped a political comeback for Mr. Hevesi, 62, who spent 22 years as an assemblyman representing Queens and 8 years as city comptroller before he was soundly defeated last year in his bid to become mayor of New York.
Behind the scenes, the race revived the intense political rivalry between Mr. Hevesi and Rudolph W. Giuliani, who helped derail Mr. Hevesi's mayoral ambitions last year by questioning his ethics. Mr. Giuliani was Mr. Faso's campaign chairman.
The race was much closer than many political analysts had expected. Public opinion polls just before the election showed Mr. Hevesi with comfortable double-digit leads.
The latest unofficial results compiled by The Associated Press indicated that he won by just 3 percent, with 50 percent of the vote to Mr. Faso's 47 percent.
A preliminary breakdown of the vote shows that Mr. Hevesi carried New York City by a commanding 3-to-1 margin, but lost in the suburbs and upstate. 
Mr. Hevesi's aides said that he would move ahead with preparations to assume his new office.
"The transition is going to be very informal and very low key," said Hank Morris, his campaign consultant, saying that Mr. Hevesi was intimately familiar with the job.
"This is going to be a transition from one comptroller to another comptroller."
Early yesterday morning, as he gave a victory speech to a group of bleary-eyed supporters at a Midtown hotel after a long and edgy night of watching the returns trickle in, Mr. Hevesi said he would use his new position to invest and spur investment in the state and New York City, both of which are facing large budget deficits.
"The state and city are in deep trouble," Mr. Hevesi said.
"We are going to be heavily involved in economic development, both as an adviser, marketing the state, putting business together with capital, creating new technologies and, prudently and carefully, doing what we did in New York City: leveraging pension funds to create jobs and build housing and provide for the improvement of our communities."

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 751 words

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: FLORIDA; 
Bush Looks to 2nd Term As Analysts Point to 2004

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
The morning after a big night for the Bush brothers, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida looked ahead today to a second term that will be as much about the 2004 presidential race as about his own goals for leading the state in the next four years.
 Upbeat but sleep deprived after a historic night of family victories, Governor Bush emerged from a Miami hotel suite to present his goals for a second term, one he said would be defined by improved reading scores, a more diverse economy and a renewal of the spirit of community. 
 "I want to continue to improve access to government for the average Floridian, especially through technology," said Mr. Bush, whose 13-percentage-point victory over the Democrat Bill McBride made him the first Republican governor in Florida history to win re-election. "And education will continue to be our highest priority." 
But political analysts said his second term would also be measured by his ability to hold the state's 25 electoral votes for his brother George. 
"Everything he does will be viewed in terms of the 2004 presidential election," said Lance de Haven-Smith, a political science professor at Florida State University. "The road to the White House runs right through the middle of Florida."
Still, Mr. Bush will have to focus on education as never before. The voters handed him a huge, unwelcome challenge by approving a measure to reduce class sizes in the state's public schools over the next eight years. Mr. Bush opposed the measure, saying it would cost the state at least $27 billion and require tax increases.
Instead, he said, he wants to focus on improving reading skills, diversifying Florida's tourism-driven economy and and helping families in crisis through programs related to domestic violence, child support and the developmentally disabled. Mr. Bush said he would assemble a transition team to seek advice on policy, coordinate staffing and conduct a review of state government "from an outside perspective."
Jim Kane, director of the Florida Voter Poll, a political news and polling service, said the transition planning might lead to a more bipartisan administration, and added, "By reaching out to Democrats and independents, he prevents the other side from becoming organized and successfully opposing his brother in the next election."
For now, voters in Florida have given Mr. Bush an enormous vote of confidence. On Tuesday, he won 56.3 percent of the vote to Mr. McBride's 42.9 percent.
Voter turnout in Florida was remarkably high for a midterm election: 42.9 percent, up from 36.5 percent in 1998 and 41.5 percent in 1994, according to the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a research group based in Washington.
"Turnout was higher among Republicans and much lower among Democrats," Mr. Kane said. "You would think Democrats, because it was Jeb, would have voted no matter what. But you have to give credit to the Bush campaign. They managed to create enough doubt in voters as to whether McBride would be a good governor that many decided that staying home was better."
Republican leaders were more blunt. "For four years, the Democrats, liberal special interests and union bosses have thrown everything but the kitchen sink at Governor Bush and our Republican Legislature, and recently the national Democrat Party elite labeled our governor as their top target," said Al Cardenas, Florida's Republican chairman. "But on Election Day, Florida voters proved they know how to vote -- physically and philosophically."
Democrats said Mr. Bush should take care not to overstep his mandate. "If they want to take the state to the far right, then they do that at their own peril," said Ryan Banfill, a party spokesman. "Florida, no matter what the results say, is philosophically a divided state." 
Mr. McBride, a wealthy Tampa lawyer, had won the Democratic nomination by upsetting the early favorite, former Attorney General Janet Reno. He put up a good fight but was outgunned from the start, Mr. Banfill said, adding: "You had the president of the United States flying into Florida a dozen times. He effectively turned Air Force One into Jeb Force One."
Mac Stipanovich, a Republican strategist in Tallahassee, said that while Governor Bush was doubtless thinking about returning the family favor in 2004, his primary motivation was improving Floridians' lives. "He definitely feels more pressure than the governor of Idaho," Mr. Stipanovich said. "But I think this governor believes in what he does and does what he thinks is right."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, responding to questions yesterday about his next steps in office, checked the time since his re-election on Tuesday. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

ORGANIZATION: FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY (55%)

GEOGRAPHIC: MIAMI, FL, USA (90%) FLORIDA, USA (99%) UNITED STATES (99%)

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section A; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-18

Final U.S. Draft at U.N. Gives Iraq a Last Chance
The United States presented the Security Council with its final proposal for a resolution to give Iraq a last chance to disarm through rigorous weapons inspections or face American-led war. A1

Ukraine Reportedly Aided Iraq
A new report by American and British investigators reinforced suspicions that Ukraine secretly sold advanced air-defense equipment to Iraq more than two years ago. President Leonid D. Kuchma of Ukraine called for a new United Nations inquiry. A13

Cubans Accused as Spies
The Bush administration has ordered the expulsion of two Cuban diplomats from Washington and has moved to expel two others at the United Nations for what was described as serious espionage activities against the United States. A7

Journalist's Hunger Strike
A leading journalist and critic of Kazakhstan's authoritarian president is in deteriorating health after the sixth day of a hunger strike to protest what he called a government effort to frame him on child-rape charges. A11

British Tories in Dispute
Iain Duncan Smith's leadership of the Conservative Party has been cast in fresh doubt. He accused rivals of plotting to depose him after some Tory members of Parliament refused to vote against plans to allow unmarried couples, including gay and lesbian partners, to adopt children. A5

Corruption in Eastern Europe
A study by the Open Society Institute reports that corruption is rampant in the Central and Eastern European countries that expect to join the wealthy European Union, and is likely to persist after the union expands unless anticorruption measures are significantly strengthened. A14

Delicate Peace in Korea
A senior North Korean official is reported to have said the 1994 Geneva framework agreement under which the North promised to stop developing nuclear weapons was "hanging by a thread." The language is actually a step back from the earlier stance that the agreement had been "nullified." A22

Israel's New Foreign Minister
Benjamin Netanyahu was sworn in as foreign minister, and promised to work with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon even while campaigning to unseat him. A party primary is to be held in the next few weeks. A18

Plane Spotters Cleared
Three Greek judges overturned the conviction of 12 British and 2 Dutch aviation enthusiasts after they raised suspicions of terrorism nearly a year ago by logging planes, a hobby of planespotting. The outcome dismisses accusations of international espionage that had caused friction in Greece's relationship with Britain and the Netherlands. A16

NATIONAL A24, 26

Election News B1-20

Sniper Charges Are Filed By Virginia Prosecutors
Prosecutors in Fairfax, Va., filed murder charges against the two suspects in the sniper shootings. The move by the Virginia authorities comes just before Attorney General John Ashcroft is expected to make a decision on which jurisdiction will be allowed to conduct the first trial. A24

Actress Guilty of Shoplifting
Winona Ryder, the actress whose six-day shoplifting trial drew national attention and stirred tabloid frenzy, was found guilty of grand theft and vandalism for walking off with more than $5,500 worth of designer goods from a Beverly Hills department store. She was found not guilty of commercial burglary. A24

Stay of Execution in Texas
The Supreme Court granted a last-minute reprieve to James Blake Colburn, a death-row inmate who suffers from severe mental illness, halting his execution as prison officials were preparing to lead him to the gurney to be injected with lethal fluids. A20

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Drug Lessens Paralysis in Mice
Researchers at the University of California in San Francisco reported that experiments in mice suggest that statins, drugs normally used to lower cholesterol, may also prevent or lessen paralysis in people with some forms of multiple sclerosis. A24

Fishing Threatens Cod Supply
Scientists in Denmark warned that unless almost all commercial fishing in the North Sea was banned, the cod stocks might soon collapse. A3

ARTS E1-10

Pocket-Sized Editions Return
The Armed Services Editions of pocket-sized books, popular among World War II soldiers, will return, with 100,000 copies of new versions of four books to be distributed to American troops abroad. E1

NEW YORK/REGION A27-29

Survivor of Massacre At Wendy's Testifies
Two and half years after he survived a massacre at a Wendy's restaurant in Queens, fainting and then playing dead as five co-workers were brutally executed around him, Patrick Castro took the stand and gave the first inside look at a night of crushing violence. A27

Restaurant Employee Killed
A man who had struggled to overcome a criminal past and homelessness was stabbed and killed outside a fast food restaurant where he worked in downtown Brooklyn after he volunteered to remove a man who was drinking beer in the restaurant, the police said. A27

Man Has Bubonic Plague
A 53-year-old New Mexico man was in critical condition at Beth Israel Medical Center with bubonic plague, the rare and deadly disease that once decimated Europe, health officials said. A27

EDUCATION

Union Criticizes Pace of Talks
Leaders of the New York City principals' union accused Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein of stalling their contract negotiations and worsening a shortage of principals while he mulled possible work-rule changes. A27

Early Admission Rejected
Yale and Stanford said they would no longer require students who are accepted through early admission to attend their colleges, eliminating a process used by most selective colleges but which has drawn much criticism. The change will take effect next year. A24

BUSINESS DAY C1-18

An Agressive Rate Cut
The Federal Reserve cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point, an aggressive move to ward off economic weakness as the terrorist threat and the confrontation with Iraq are weighing down business and consumer confidence. A1

Resignation Sets Back S.E.C.; New Chief Is Eagerly Awaited
Experts say the resignation of Harvey L. Pitt as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission will set back by months the efforts of the agency to clean up Wall Street and provide vigorous oversight of the accounting profession. C1

What Wall Street leaders say they need most from the triumphant Republicans in Congress and the White House is a thoroughly nonpolitical choice to replace Harvey L. Pitt at the Securities and Exchange Commission as soon as possible. C1

American Plans Cost Cuts
American Airlines said it would cut flights, conserve jet fuel and eliminate some perks offered to corporate customers in a drive to cut costs. C9

 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section D; Column 3; Sports Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1402 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Yankees' Tier a Bargain Basement

BYLINE:  By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
You can buy a grande caffe mocha and an oatmeal cookie at Starbucks or a fitness magazine that promises amazing abs, or drive across the George Washington Bridge (with E-ZPass), all for about $5. Or you can buy a ticket to a smattering of Yankees games next season for the same price. Five bucks to see the Yankees? That sounds as believable as the Yankees' adopting the rally monkey, but it's true.
 The Yankees raised ticket prices by 7 percent for next season and cited the new collective bargaining agreement that will end up costing them about $55 million in luxury taxes and revenue sharing. It was no surprise that the Yankees increased their prices after setting a franchise attendance record, 3.465 million, last season. The fans keep flocking to Yankee Stadium, and they will be asked to help support George Steinbrenner's burgeoning payroll and the escalating costs of owning the Yankees. 
 But the Yankees have also showed creativity by introducing several discount plans for next season that are designed to make the games more affordable for the fan not inclined to pay $72 for a box seat with waiter service. The most intriguing of these plans -- which received an ad-libbed, and unpublicized, test run in 2002 -- involves eight games in which the great majority of seats in the massive upper deck will be sold for $5, instead of $10 to $35, a concept as foreign as the two-and-a-half-hour game.
"It's a sign of the times," said Dan Migala, the executive editor of Team Marketing Report, a sports marketing publication. "It's not a minor league idea. It's creative. It's out of the box. It fills a need. It's a nice, subtle way to get a few people back in the ballpark."
The Yankees are not the first or the only team to offer truly affordable tickets in a bid to lure fans to the park. The Arizona Diamondbacks have always sold 300 game-day tickets for $1 and also offer 7,500 more seats for $6. The Los Angeles Dodgers sell 10,500 seats for $6. The Kansas City Royals have 6,343 seats in a $5 section. The Cincinnati Reds are opening the Great American Ballpark in 2003, and it will include about 1,700 $5 seats. The Chicago White Sox discount more than one-third of their tickets. All of these teams and others offer the low-priced tickets all season. The Yankees are offering the $5 tickets for one-tenth of their schedule.
But what makes the Yankees' adoption of the $5 ticket noteworthy, even for eight games, is their recent history. The Yankees have drawn 13.25 million fans across the last four years, a major league best, and have also won four World Series championships since 1996. If there is one team with a product attractive enough not to mark it down, it is the Yankees. Instead, they increased the prices for the expensive seats, figuring that those fans can better handle it, and might have half the Stadium filled with $5 ticket-holders on a handful of nights.
"I kind of applaud them for it," said Scott Brubaker, senior vice president of marketing and sales for the Diamondbacks. "It's not a Yankee-type move. I'm going to be interested to see how it works out. They may be on to something."
Another wrinkle that baseball executives expect to become more and more prominent is variable ticket pricing. The Colorado Rockies have been one of the teams at the forefront of this policy: charging more for tickets to certain games against elite opponents, or on important dates. Several teams are adding or considering variable pricing. The Cleveland Indians, who have seen their attendance plummet by more than 800,000 since 2000, have reduced prices on four ticket types. But the Indians also added 10 "showcase" games for which they will charge $5 extra per ticket.
Back in the Bronx, one five-spot gets you at least nine innings of baseball. In those eight games, the Yankees are offering 24,706 of their 57,468 seats for $5. But do not get greedy and expect to see the Red Sox or the Mets for $5 and do not be silly and think that you will see the sweat on Derek Jeter's neck because your seats will be close to the on-deck circle. Be realistic about what $5, even in a sweet deal, gets you.
The one weekday and seven weeknight affairs the Yankees have singled out run from April to August and include games with the Minnesota Twins, who advanced further than the Yankees this postseason; the Royals; the Tampa Bay Devil Rays; the Baltimore Orioles; and the Toronto Blue Jays, who will be the opponents for a cheap date in the Bronx on four occasions. The $5 seats include 3,745 in the tier box seats along the right- and left-field lines, which usually sell for $35; the entire tier reserved section of 15,562 seats, which go for $20; and all 5,309 bleacher seats, which usually cost $10.
The Yankees actually offered a similar total of $5 tickets for eight games last season, but did so in impromptu fashion, not as a policy, and a number of those games came at the tail end of the season. Although the Yankees were second in the major leagues in attendance in 2002, they still wound up having over a million empty seats. So, in the games that are known as "dog games" in the industry because a club knows it will have difficulty attracting many fans, the Yankees are trying to fill those seats, generate more revenue and paint themselves as being fan-friendly.
"We have extra inventory," Lonn Trost, the Yankees' chief operating officer, said.
"We don't really sell out," he added, referring to the Yankees 43,323 average attendance last season. "We still have inventory. We thought it would be a great idea to make them available and affordable."
It is an interesting approach by the Yankees to remain affordable, in some capacity, to most fans, while also putting more people in the park. More fans means more concession and souvenir sales. No business wants to charge $5 for something on Monday that it sells for $35 on the other six days of the week, but Trost does not feel the $5 tickets devalue the product. Others agree.
"It's the equivalent of seeing a matinee or a big Broadway show at night," Migala said. "It's still the production of a Broadway show and all the amenities, but it's not the pizazz you'd see on a Saturday night."
Rick Cerrone, a spokesman for the Yankees, added: "A family of four can come to the game for $20, and they can bring their own food if they keep it in a bag. Why not give people a chance to go to a game at affordable prices?" 
After the Yankees lost to the Anaheim Angels in the division series in October, Trost said the Yankees studied their operating costs and the new and uncertain world in which the team will share a lot and be taxed a lot. General Manager Brian Cashman has stressed the need to cut a $135 million payroll. One way to make money is turning an empty $20 seat into a filled seat, even for a lower amount.
The Yankees are also offering $20 tier reserved seats for $14 on Tuesdays, except when they oppose Boston on May 27. They are also offering the same discount on selected games Monday through Thursday. All tickets for children 14 years old and under will be half-price if the child is with an adult. For seven games, 4,000 senior citizen tickets will be sold for $5. The team is also offering discounts for tickets purchased in advance. Tickets go on sale Dec. 13.
The Mets will announce their ticket policies in a few weeks. But Dave Howard, their senior vice president for business and legal affairs, said any price increase would be modest.
"Fans are clamoring for cheaper tickets," John O'Brien, the director of ticket operations for the Reds, said. "Even though N.B.A. seats are $120, everyone wants a cheaper baseball ticket. You have to find a happy medium between what to charge and being able to put a good product on the field." 
Brubaker, the Diamondbacks executive, called the $5 tickets part of "a very astute marketing plan" by the Yankees. He said he doubted that offering about 200,000 such tickets during the season would diminish their product. Brubaker laughed and said, "It's hard to take 26 world championships and say, 'Hey, that's not worth anything.' "
But, in this ever-fluctuating economic environment, even the Yankees realize they must do more than point to their 26 flags to entice fans. 
"Now it's a drive to get the average fan back," Migala said. "These are the people who are going to come to see the Blue Jays in freezing weather in April. I think you're definitely going to see more of it."

GRAPHIC: Photos: For eight games next year, most upper-deck seats and all the bleachers in Yankee Stadium will cost $5. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)(pg. D1); Yankee Stadium's 5,309 bleacher seats usually sell for $10. They will be half-price for select games next season under the Yankees' new plan. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)(pg. D6)
